HEADLINE: Refuge Inside Arctic Circle Is Also in the Middle of U.S. Energy Debate

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: KAKTOVIK, Alaska, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Roughly 250 miles north of the Arctic Circle, hard by the icy Beaufort Sea, this tiny Eskimo village is unlikely to be a stop on the presidential campaign trail.
Getting here entails a bumpy flight across the Brooks Range, and arrival is marked by a cheerful greeting from Kaktovik's mayor, Lon Sonsalla, who gestures across the gravel airstrip to the magnificent but fearsome animals lumbering nearby on the tundra: "Watch out for the polar bears." 
 Yet as the candidates spar over what to do about rising fuel prices, the people who live here in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge find the future of their homeland to be a major campaign issue, one that popped up in the first presidential debate. For while they are living in one of the great untouched wilderness areas of the world, they are also atop what may be the largest untapped oil reserve in the United States.
The dispute over this refuge could not be more clear. Drill it, says Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Leave it alone, says Vice President Al Gore.
The same line divides the oil industry and environmental advocates. And it divides two native groups who have lived here for centuries, generating perhaps the most bitter tensions of all, since the stakes involve their very way of life.
The Inupiat Eskimos of Kaktovik generally favor plans to drill along the 1.5 million acres of coastal plain for oil, which they think will bring them enormous economic benefits, including improvements in schools and health care. So they endorse the arguments of drilling proponents, including Alaska's top politicians, who say it is lunacy not to explore the tundra for the billions of barrels of oil that may lie beneath.
"Moola," Fenton Rexford, president of the Kaktovik Inupiat Corporation, the business arm of the Eskimos, said with a hearty smile.
But the Gwich'in Indians, citing fears that rigs, roads and pipes will mar the land and devastate the caribou herd on which they rely for food, are viscerally opposed. They are allied with environmental groups, who say drilling is a short-term energy fix that will permanently scar this austere but beautiful landscape. It lies frozen for much of the year but bursts to life in the Arctic spring with such a display of birds and wild animals, including tens of thousands of migrating caribou, that some call it an American Serengeti.
"There's no technology in the world that will make it safe for mothers and their calves," said Sarah James, an elder in Arctic Village, a Gwich'in community of about 120 people.
The two groups live on opposite sides of the 9,000-foot-high Brooks Range and have become so alienated on the issue that they barely speak to each other.
And members of both groups say they have been paying much more attention than they otherwise might to this presidential campaign. They have satellite dishes and a string of cable television lines set up in Kaktovik, a complex of small wooden and corrugated-steel homes and other buildings that hugs the shore of an ice floe-laden sea.
"Oh, boy, another month of this," said 78-year-old Isaac Akootchook, a whaling captain and village elder, rolling his eyes when yet another news clip showing Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush popped up on the screen. Yet they are keenly aware of what the candidates are saying, at least about the Arctic refuge.
Governor Bush, echoing a plan that his father, then President George Bush, unsuccessfully sought in Congress, strongly favors opening the refuge to exploration and drilling.
While no one knows for sure how much oil is below the permafrost, Mr. Bush, citing oil experts, says that the fields could produce a million barrels a day -- roughly the same amount, as he put it in the debate, as the country imports daily from Saddam Hussein, with whom his father went to war over protecting Middle East oil supplies.
Mr. Bush was speaking in rough terms, since the average this year for oil imported from Iraq is 585,000 barrels a day, says the Energy Department.
Mr. Gore is just as staunchly opposed to opening what he calls "this environmental treasure" to drilling, arguing the country needs to focus on conservation and other ways of decreasing demand.
"It would only give us a few months worth of oil, and the oil wouldn't start flowing for many years into the future," he said in the debate. "That's the wrong choice. I know the oil companies have been itching to do that. But it is not the right thing for the future."
The government's geological estimate of likely reserves ranges from about 3 billion to 16 billion barrels, and each side dramatizes what the figures mean in very different ways.
Opponents like Mr. Gore, using the lower figure, often say it contains "only 6 months" of the nation's demand for oil; supporters, citing the higher figure, say it could be enough to represent 30 years' worth of what the country imports from Middle Eastern countries like Iraq.
Here in Alaska, the issue is huge, for obvious reasons: oil, mostly from the Prudhoe Bay fields 100 miles or so to the west, is Alaska's economic engine. It not only pays for roughly three-quarters of the state budget and keeps residents here from paying state income taxes, it is also responsible for the annual "dividend" that every man, woman and child in the state receives simply for living here.
The money -- $1,963.86, in checks that are being mailed this month -- comes from the state's so-called Permanent Fund. But despite that optimistic name, oil is coursing down the Trans-Alaska Pipeline at half the peak rate in the late 1980's of two million barrels a day, says the State Division of Oil and Gas. For many Alaskans, extending drilling to the Arctic refuge may be a way to extend their oil-fueled financial bonanza another decade or two.
There is general support in the state for opening the refuge -- the Legislature once voted 59 to 1 in favor of a resolution urging that course.
For the Inupiat Eskimos who live in Kaktovik, population 260, and who own more of the land where the drilling would take place, the benefits are clear.
"Energy, warmer houses, better transportation, better schools, more opportunities for the young people," said Mr. Rexford of the Inupiat business group. Many Eskimos say the Gwich'in are jealous, because they would get less in the way of oil revenues. And they resent outsiders debating what to do with their land.
"Who is Al Gore to say what to do here?" said Carla Sims Kayotuk, an Eskimo who runs the local store here. "He wants to keep this a rich man's playground."
But the Gwich'in, members of an Athabascan tribe who are the northernmost Indians in the United States, say money is not an issue. They want to preserve a sacred place, and the 129,000-strong Porcupine caribou herd.
And Gwich'in say the Eskimos, who depend on whaling for much of their protein, are inconsistent because they remain deeply opposed to proposals for offshore drilling for oil. Inupiat whaling crews here recently took three 30-ton bowhead whales from the Arctic Ocean, providing enough meat for everyone in the village for the coming year.
Drilling proponents pointed out that despite dire predictions, a smaller caribou herd nearer the Prudhoe Bay complex has actually grown since oil production started there.
"You fly into Deadhorse, and there are caribou all over the place," said Ken Boyd, director of the State Division of Oil and Gas, speaking of the oil town at Prudhoe Bay. "They're on the runway. These animals can adapt. This idea that they'll drop dead because they see oil production going on, it's just nuts."
And Roger Herrera, a geologist and consultant to Arctic Power, a lobbying group that favored opening the refuge, said the oil industry had "bent over backwards" to prevent harm to the caribou at Prudhoe Bay, and would do so here.
David R. Klein, professor emeritus at the University of Alaska's Institute of Arctic Biology, who has been studying Alaskan caribou for nearly 40 years, said any comparisons between what happened at Prudhoe Bay and what might happen here are treacherous, as this herd is larger and may share a smaller calving and foraging space with oil facilities.
"There will be impacts, that's obvious," he said. "The magnitudes of that impact are simply very difficult to project."
Mr. Sonsalla said he thought drilling would happen eventually.
"Change is inevitable," he said. "Hopefully we can control our own destiny."

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN IN YUGOSLAVIA: THE SANCTIONS;
Easing of Some Restrictions By West Could Happen Soon

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Disastrous civil wars, onerous sanctions and corrupt misrule turned Yugoslavia from the most open and developed nation in the old Communist orbit into the sick man of Central Europe, with a collapsed economy, plummeting living standards and a wretched inventory of bombed bridges, severed electrical lines and outdated factories.
But President Clinton and European leaders, who promised an immediate easing of sanctions once they feel certain that Slobodan Milosevic is gone from power, seem likely to remove most sanctions on trade and investment with Yugoslavia in the coming week. This will include lifting remaining restrictions of the sale of oil, which have in any case eroded badly. And it seems likely they will eliminate the ban on air travel, currently suspended, to and from Serbia. 
 The United States and 15 nations of the European Union are also preparing to restore the nation's rights at the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Some of the toughest sanctions will remain in force, at least for now, including a ban on transferring assets out of Yugoslavia and some penalties aimed at Mr. Milosevic and his close associates. State Department officials said that it was important to guard against the Milosevic-linked elite fleeing the country with looted wealth.
Western nations are also preparing to expand a multibillion dollar reconstruction plan for several Balkan countries to include Serbia, creating what some European officials have referred to as a mini-Marshall Plan for the war-torn region.
Oil, telecommunications, consumer products and infrastructure companies, some of which operated in Yugoslavia before sanctions began making investments difficult in the early 1990's, also seem likely to explore business opportunities there if the new democratic government proves stable.
But while General Electric, Foster Wheeler and Procter & Gamble among other companies had significant operations in the old Yugoslavia, several analysts and company officials said that it would take time to attract significant private investment to the largely state-controlled economy. It has fallen more than a decade behind many of its former Communist neighbors, which began economic overhauls after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
"The problem was Milosevic, Milosevic, Milosevic, now it's economy, economy, economy," said Milan Panic, a Serbian-American who runs California-based ICN Pharmaceuticals, which once owned one of the largest private companies in Serbia. "This will be a major test for the United States and Europe."
Mr. Panic's pharmaceutical plant in Belgrade was confiscated by the Milosevic government in a bitter political battle after Mr. Panic contested -- and lost -- a race for president against Mr. Milosevic in 1992. He now plans to return to Serbia. But he says reconstruction will be slow.
"It is still a socialist country and you will have to change the culture," he said in an interview. "It will need aid money -- seed money -- before you will see much private investment."
Clinton administration officials said that NATO-led intervention in Kosovo and the campaign to oust Mr. Milosevic will ultimately remain incomplete unless they help reverse the free fall of Yugoslavia's economy, which contracted by 20 percent last year, with 50 percent inflation and 30 percent unemployment.
"Now is not the time for the United States or our allies to retreat from the Balkans in complacency," Mr. Clinton said Friday. "Now is the time to stay the course and stick with people who have won their freedom; the time to build the economic and civil institutions that will allow democracy to endure."
A senior State Department official said Western powers are aiming to channel money and expertise into repairing roads, bridges, schools and hospitals, and to deliver aid quickly.
"We want to fund projects that will have an immediate impact on people's lives," the official said.
After NATO forced Mr. Milosevic to retreat from Kosovo last year, the United States and the European Union began a joint effort known as the Stability Pact to support democracy and spark economic growth in the Balkans. The European Commission and the World Bank administer the pact. But the United States plays a significant role and sees it as the main vehicle for extending a helping hand to Serbia, the senior State Department official said.
Participants in the pact, especially the World Bank and European nations, have already made pledges of hundreds of millions of dollars to finance projects like a wastewater treatment plant in Croatia, a new airport terminal in Albania and road improvements in Kosovo.
The Clinton administration recently introduced a bill in Congress that would grant zero-tariff trade status to democratic Balkan nations. And the United States Overseas Private Investment Corporation has set aside $150 million to back companies willing to invest in the Balkans.
Serbia could use the help. A group of private Yugoslav economists recently estimated that NATO allies inflicted about $4 billion dollars of damage on Serbia during the Kosovo war, while they put the cumulative financial impact of sanctions at $30 billion.
But several Clinton administration officials said that Europe and the private sector would have to take the lead, citing the reluctance of Congress to fund major international aid programs.
Theoretically, Serbia should be an attractive market. It has 11 million consumers, slightly more than neighboring Hungary. The Danube, one of Europe's major rivers, runs through it. It is the overland bridge between Western Europe and Greece and Turkey.
Early investors could include Ericsson, the Swedish telecom company, which has ambitions to resume work on a $210 million mobile phone network. The engineering company, Foster Wheeler, of Clinton, N.J., built oil facilities in Yugoslavia before the Kosovo war and has expressed interest in helping rebuild the nation's largest oil refinery, damaged by NATO bombs.
But Gary Litman, managing director for Europe and Eurasia at the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington, said that while many multinationals had expressed interest in Balkan investments, the market could prove unattractive in the short term.
"There's been almost 10 years with no development there," he said. "There's a big question mark about whether this curiosity will translate into real investments."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Lazio Portrayed as an Ostrich

 BODY:

Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign will begin broadcasting this 30-second commercial in upstate New York tomorrow.
 
TITLE -- "Ostrich" 

PRODUCER -- Team Hillary
 
ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial opens with a shot of an ostrich, meant to represent Representative Rick A. Lazio, standing alone in a desert. With what sounds like a children's song playing, the camera remains on the bird as the narrator speaks about the struggling upstate New York economy. Finally, the ostrich sticks its head into a hole in the sand. Before the close, Mrs. Clinton is shown in two quick scenes, walking with people and then moving down a line, shaking hands.

THE SCRIPT -- "Over the last five years, upstate New York has ranked near the bottom of the nation in job growth. And since 1992, 170,000 young people have left. But Rick Lazio doesn't think the area needs targeted economic help. Guess it's hard to find a solution when you can't see the problem. Hillary Clinton. A strong voice for New York families with a detailed plan to create new jobs in upstate New York."
 
ACCURACY -- The economy in upstate New York grew much more slowly than in the rest of the nation from 1995 to 1998, but it has improved in the last two years, although growth remains slower than in the New York City area. Mrs. Clinton has advocated tax credits for small businesses that locate in communities with low job growth or high poverty, among other initiatives. Mr. Lazio has said he will help the upstate economy by pushing for its "fair share" of federal aid and a broad-based tax cut.

SCORECARD -- Mrs. Clinton pokes fun at her opponent in an area where he is clearly vulnerable. During their first debate, Mr. Lazio said he believed that Mrs. Clinton was trying to portray upstate New York as a "vast economic wasteland" when in fact the economy there "has turned the corner." The Buffalo News, in an editorial, has mocked Mr. Lazio's remarks and criticized him for not advocating targeted economic help for the region. The advertisement, which injects a touch of humor in what otherwise has been a largely humorless campaign, could help Mrs. Clinton win votes upstate, a region where Republicans traditionally do well but where polls suggest that Mr. Lazio is lagging.

HEADLINE: OCTOBER 1-7;
Europe to America: Ante Up

BYLINE: By Barbara Crossette

 BODY:
The Europeans brought their pie-charts (the French call them camemberts) to the United Nations to demonstrate how much the European Union gave to the organization's various budgets compared with the richer United States, and why Washington did not deserve the cut in dues demanded by Congress. European and American shares of the world's total gross national product, on which basic national dues are assessed, are about the same: 29 percent.
But the Europeans pay 36.7 percent of the United Nations' regular budget of $1 billion a year, compared with the Americans' 25 percent (when Washington pays at all). Congress wants that lowered to 22 percent, or it will withhold even more payments. In peacekeeping, the gap is wider: 39 percent for Europe, 25 percent for the United States. 
 Europe pays half the costs of special programs and agencies, more than twice what the United States contributes.

HEADLINE: 2000 PLAYOFFS: NOTEBOOK;
Do Athletics Know The Way to San Jose?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
A Bay Area World Series between the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics would be a tame preliminary to a turf battle between the owners of the two teams. That battle may never develop, but it simmers close to the surface.
The object of the potential scrap: San Jose. The Giants have it; the Athletics want it. 
 "Obviously there has been a three-decade debate on the relationship of the Giants and the A's in the Bay Area, and baseball frankly has attempted to solve it in many different ways over the years," Commissioner Bud Selig said. "It's something I'm monitoring extremely closely and I continue to talk to both clubs."
The Giants' wildly successful new home, Pacific Bell Park, has only exacerbated the tension between the teams, making the team 12 miles away on the other side of the water feel even more like the Bay Area's stepchild.
The Oakland owners, Stephen Schott and Ken Hofmann, are said by some people in baseball to want either to move the team to San Jose or neighboring Santa Clara, or, perhaps preferably, receive permission to sell to someone who would move the team to San Jose or Santa Clara.
Calls to the owners seeking clarification of their position were not returned; Jim Young, a club spokesman, said the owners "don't make themselves available to the press."
Michael Crowley, the club president, said he wasn't sure "what the owners have done at this point."
But he added, "There's no question that the economic engine of the Bay Area, if not the world, is the Silicon Valley."
Peter Magowan, the Giants' managing partner, left no doubt about his position. San Jose and Santa Clara are in Santa Clara County, he noted and explained that Santa Clara County is an integral part of the established Giants territory.
"When Schott and Hofmann bought the A's franchise, they knew what territorial rights the A's had and what territorial rights the Giants had," Magowan said. "Santa Clara County is in the Giants' territorial rights so they can't really go there if we object. If they want to violate our territory, there will be a battle."
The Major League Constitution delineates each team's operating territory. In the case of other two-team areas -- New York, Chicago and Los Angeles/Anaheim -- the territories listed for each team are the same, with the provision that they "shall be shared" with the other team.
However, the same formula does not apply with the Giants and the Athletics. The Athletics have Alameda and Contra Costa counties, both on their side of the bay. The Giants have San Francisco, Santa Clara, San Mateo, Santa Cruz, Monterey and Marin, a string of counties that occupy the coast line north and south of San Francisco. "We have been assured by Bud Selig that he will be supportive of every franchise's territorial rights," Magowan said.
Any change in the existing understanding would require a three-quarters vote among the 30 major league clubs.
"If the Athletics want to go right across the street from Yankee Stadium, they could do it if they could persuade three-quarters of the clubs to go along with that," Magowan said. "But I think all the clubs know if they vote to violate this guy's territorial rights, then the precedent has been set for the violation of their territorial rights so I don't expect that to be a very successful initiative."
The Athletics' owners bought the team five years ago and tried to sell it last year, but the league owners tabled the proposed $122 million deal, effectively killing the sale. The general feeling among the owners of other teams was that the prospective purchasing group did not have pockets deep enough to operate the team and would most likely be looking to sell it themselves in a few years.
Schott and Hofmann have not attempted to sell the team since, but they have been reported to have spoken with officials and others in the potentially lucrative San Jose/Santa Clara area. In fact, one official said Selig told club officials to cease and desist after newspaper articles began appearing about their talks.
Santa Clara County, 40 miles south of San Francisco, is in the heart of Silicon Valley, where a team would most likely prosper far more than some existing teams.
"This is a privately built ballpark," Magowan said of the Giants' pride and joy. "We paid for this ourselves. The people who helped build this are our fans and the heart of our fan base is in San Mateo County and Santa Clara County, so all of the people who bought charter seats and bought sponsorships and bought suites, their loyalty to the Giants would be adrift if there were a competing stadium in San Jose."
Just last week city officials in Oakland came up with a site for a new ballpark in their town that they speculate could be as beneficial financially to the Athletics as Pacific Bell Park is to the Giants. But given the experience across the bay, the team's owners would certainly be expected to finance a significant portion of the construction, and they have shown no inclination to take that economic step.
The Giants drew 3,315,330 fans this season, the Athletics 1,728,888.
"From the team's perspective, what's happening with our attendance right now is certainly a concern," Crowley said. "We've said from the start we're going to make an attempt to make it work in Oakland."
How long will they make the attempt? "That remains to be seen," the executive said.
While the Athletics struggle, the Giants have increased their revenue to about $145 million from $68 million last year. They will show a profit of about $7 million. They made their $20 million mortgage payment for this year in one line item on the business ledger: Last season they sold $3 million in stadium sponsorships, this year $23 million.
While Giants officials express confidence that baseball will maintain the status quo in the Bay Area, they will exhale only when Selig issues a final decision on the matter. He is not expected to do that for some time.
"I don't think Bud Selig wants to do anything that would help a relocated franchise be successful if their success comes at the expense of making an already successful franchise into a nonsuccessful one," Magowan said. "That's what he has to really think about.
"I'm not saying San Jose isn't a lot better market than Oakland. I know it is. Anybody would know it is. It's a bigger market. It's faster growing. There's more money down there. There's more corporate support down there. Nobody argues with that. The question is would it hurt the Giants. The answer to that is yes, it would. The conclusion is, therefore, I think, by Bud Selig, it should not be done."
Asked what the Athletics thought the commissioner's position should be, Crowley said: "I think Bud has to act in what he feels is the best interests of baseball. That's his charter."
 
Apathy in Montreal
The franchise most urgently in need of relocation is the Montreal Expos. With an attendance of 926,263, they were the only team that didn't attract one million fans. People in Montreal once cared about the team, but at this point if the Expos left, would anyone miss them?
The question is if Jeffrey Loria, the managing partner, wanted to move the team to northern Virginia, could he do it? Peter Angelos, the Baltimore Orioles' owner, has said he will do whatever was necessary to block a team from moving into the Washington-northern Virginia area, but that area is not part of the Orioles' territory.
Their territory is listed as the city of Baltimore and five counties in Maryland, nothing outside the state.
 
Going Against the Norm
One of the major pieces of statistical evidence presented by the Blue Ribbon Panel on Baseball Economics in dealing with payroll disparity was that from 1995 through 1999, no team with a payroll in the third and fourth quartiles won a playoff game.
Oakland has ruined that perfect record, winning two games of their playoff series against the Yankees. However, the Athletics' victories have been the only ones registered by a team in payroll quartiles III and IV. They have also lost two games to the Yankees , and the Chicago White Sox lost all three of their games with Seattle. Four of the playoff teams are in the first quartile and two are in the second.
 
So Much for Milestones
So Todd Helton did not hit .400, Darin Erstad did not break the record for hits in a season, Jose Lima did not give up the most home runs ever by a pitcher, no batter hit 60 home runs for the first time in three years, the season went without a no-hitter for the first time since 1989 and no team changed managers during the season for the first time since 1942. Of course, a week after the season, five teams have fired their managers.
And for the first time in history, no team finished with a won-lost percentage as high as .600 or as low as .400. One more victory by the Giants or another loss for Philadelphia or the Chicago Cubs would have prevented history from being made.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: GENDER POLITICS;
Among Men, It's Bush the Maserati by a Mile

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7

 BODY:
When Gov. Gray Davis's political advisers want to take Californians' temperatures on the presidential race in voter focus groups, they ask a question that might sound goofy: if Al Gore and George W. Bush were cars, what would they be?
"Among men, Gore is viewed as a Ford Taurus, a Chevy station wagon, a Volvo, safe and kind of boxy," said Garry South, the chief political aide for Mr. Davis, a Democrat. "With Bush, you get things like Maserati and Mustang convertible, and by no means all of the men who say that are doing it pejoratively. They're saying: 'Wait a minute; that guy's like who I'd like to be.' " 
 Mr. Gore is running comfortably ahead in the polls in California, in part because it is one of the few places where he is holding his own or slightly ahead among men, who tend here to be more liberal than their counterparts in the South and Midwest. But even here, Mr. Gore runs behind Mr. Bush among white men and married men, and the car quiz sums up what may be one of his biggest challenges as the presidential race moves into its final month: how to get guys who may not be like him to like him all the same.
Since at least 1980, when polls first showed men and women sharply diverging in their presidential preferences, with women leaning Democratic and men Republican, politicians have sought to exploit the gender gap, typically by making special efforts to court the votes of women, who are the greatest share of the electorate and tend to look to government as a supportive partner in challenges from child care to health care and the environment.
So this year, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush have gone out of their way to demonstrate their sensitive New Age guyness by gushing with Oprah Winfrey and praising their wives' uplifting influences. In their debate on Tuesday, Mr. Bush, who like most Republicans does worse with women than his Democratic opponent, went so far as to brag about crying with Texas flood victims. "That's what governors do," he said.
Bill Carrick, a Democratic consultant here, said, "Neither one of these guys is trying to project himself as John Wayne."
But men, especially white men, remain a potent political force, perhaps even more complicated to court. And among this group, Mr. Gore is struggling, trailing Mr. Bush among men over all by 22 points in one recent Los Angeles Times national poll and by smaller but still significant margins in most other surveys. At the same time, Mr. Gore has not been doing well enough among women, especially married women, to be certain he will be able to offset his deficit among men.
Part of the problem is axiomatic and beyond Mr. Gore's control: men are more likely to be what the Republican pollster Kellyanne Fitzpatrick calls "congenital Republicans."
"If the way to a man's heart is through his stomach, the way to a man's vote is still through his wallet, and men do still see the Republican Party as being more protective of their assets," Ms. Fitzpatrick said. "Even in 1996, with what was sometimes a very inarticulate and uninspired defense of his own tax plan, Bob Dole was still able to secure an advantage among men. It's their default position."
Mr. Gore has made his share of efforts to appeal to men. He promotes himself as the repository of fiscal responsibility and deficit reduction. His biographical advertisements are careful to note his Army service in Vietnam. Even his celebrated kiss of his wife, Tipper, at the Democratic convention, pollsters say, could be seen as much as a gesture of solidarity with his fellow family men as an appeal to women.
But political professionals in both parties say Mr. Gore also faces particular problems growing out of his earnest, wonkish personality, and his tendency to lecture. "One of the things that I think is happening is that Bush has been able to convey and project a personality type that I think appeals to men," Mr. South said, "a kind of free-wheeling, macho guy, more compatible with where the typical white, middle-aged male voter would be than Gore has."
Mr. Bush may be helped in this regard by his running mate, Dick Cheney, a former high school football captain who made appearances at two athletic events this weekend. On Friday night Mr. Cheney went to a high school football game in Waterloo, Iowa. This afternoon he went to a tailgate party at the Iowa State-Nebraska football game in Ames, Iowa, shaking hands with chilly football fans huddled around beer kegs.
Oddly, Ms. Fitzpatrick suggested, Mr. Gore may suffer by comparison not with Republicans but with Mr. Clinton, who as a candidate and president appeared often in pop culture forums that helped transform many voters' relationship with the president and presidency from a paternal one to more of a peer-to-peer regard.
"Before it was always, 'Can he stare down the Soviet Union?' " Ms. Fitzpatrick said. "Now it's, 'Is he like me and do I like him?' And with Al Gore the answer to both is no. Clinton is always looked at as having an outstretched hand, and Gore as having a pointing finger."
Joel Cook, 32, a milk truck driver in Los Banos, Calif., a swing area in the Central Valley, said it did not matter to him that Mr. Gore was a veteran like himself. He said he thought Mr. Bush would do a better job of building up the military.
"I don't like the way Gore talks," said Mr. Cook, who usually votes Republican. "I feel like he's trying to put one over on me, and tell me something just for a vote."
Robert DeSouza, 60, a disabled former appliance repairman in Sacramento, still calls himself a Democrat but says he has voted Republican since Richard M. Nixon's election in 1968. He is not a big fan of Mr. Bush but says Mr. Gore could not persuade him to vote Democratic.
"All the big promises he's making, he knows he can't do it," Mr. DeSouza said. "The Democrats had their chance to do all this stuff the first two years of Bill Clinton's administration when they controlled Congress, and they still couldn't do it."
In fact, according to the most recent New York Times/CBS News poll, taken late last month, Mr. Gore is doing about the same among men as Mr. Clinton did in 1992 and 1996, drawing the support of about 4 in 10 male voters, though other polls have shown him faring worse.
But Mr. Gore is so far not doing as well among women as Mr. Clinton did, drawing the support of just 47 percent of likely female voters in the most recent Times/CBS News poll. When Mr. Clinton was elected in 1996, he won the support of 54 percent of women, surveys of voters leaving the polls found.
Moreover, before Mr. Clinton's affair with a White House intern and his subsequent impeachment took its toll, the president had managed to make strong inroads of support among the kinds of blue-collar families that the Democrats had been ceding for years. These are among the voters Mr. Gore is trying to reclaim with his oratorical emphasis on "working families."
But here, too, Mr. Gore faces problems caused in part by Mr. Clinton's alienation of these voters, and in part by Mr. Gore's having spent much of the winter running to the left to stave off a primary challenge from Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey. At the same time, he may suffer in stylistic comparisons with Mr. Clinton, who is a past master at creating connections with his audience, whatever it happens to be.
"If he was asked about gay marriage, for example, the typical Clinton response lays out right away, 'I do not favor gay marriage,' " said one Democratic strategist here who has complained to Mr. Gore about this point. "And then he segues into a sympathetic-sounding response about how we have to uphold everybody's differences and dreams. Gore's tendency is to give the long, sympathetic answer, and then, as an afterthought, add, 'Having said that, I do not favor gay marriage.' "
This strategist added that there are few people "as masterful as Bill Clinton at defining himself in a way that keeps those white male voters in the pen without alienating those female voters that really give you your edge as a Democrat."
Mark DiCamillo, director of the statewide nonpartisan Field Poll in San Francisco, said that younger men, in particular, should be a natural demographic target for Mr. Gore, but that Mr. Bush had shown strong appeal among this group.
"The issues that Bush is raising have a certain appeal for young men, like Social Security, where he says I'll give you the right to invest some of your own funds," Mr. DiCamillo said. "When you poll the attitudes of the young, they basically have much less trust in government to be there when they need it, and the farther you are away from retirement age, the more likely you are to be skeptical about whether the government will deliver. I also think the entrepreneurial spirit, the kind that drives the booming California economy right now, that spirit is more reflected by Bush in his economic proposals. The key question to me nationally is, will these young people go out and vote?"

SECTION: Section 1; Page 44; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1137 words

HEADLINE: Fairness of New York Condemnation Procedures at Issue in Property Owners' Lawsuit

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 6

 BODY:
Bill Brody says he would have challenged this village's condemnation of the four downtown buildings that he owned and had just renovated into office and retail space, and that Port Chester officials plan to turn over to a developer for a Stop & Shop supermarket.
But he never got to fight that fight. 
 For all the steps Mr. Brody took in his effort to follow every turn in Port Chester's 27-acre downtown renewal plan, he missed a classified legal notice in a local newspaper last year saying the property was eligible for condemnation. He did not learn about the notice until 10 months later, too late to contest the decision.
Mr. Brody is one of three property owners in the New York area who are challenging the constitutionality of the state's eminent-domain procedures in a lawsuit filed Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The other two plaintiffs are the owner of a cabinetmaking business in Harlem and a church in North Hempstead, on Long Island.
A ruling in the plaintiffs' favor could change the way the state and local governments acquire millions of dollars' worth of property every year for a range of projects, including new sidewalks and sports stadiums. The process has come under increasing scrutiny as more government agencies are acting as conduits for the transfer of property from one private owner to another.
Shortly after the lawsuit was filed, Judge Harold Baer Jr. issued a temporary order barring the condemnations until he could hear the owners' motion for a preliminary injunction.
The New York law does require a public hearing, but only in the early stages of the lengthy process that can lead to the condemnation of a property. At that hearing, government officials must explain the potential cost and the public benefit of a proposed project, and members of the public may speak briefly. But the officials do not have to answer questions, or permit the property owner to call witnesses or present more than brief objections.
Nor does the law require a government agency or official to directly notify an owner when, sometime after the hearing, a property is identified as subject to condemnation in a legal notice. Such identification may come months or years before the government begins court proceedings to actually seize the property.
Once the notice appears, an owner has 30 days to appeal. The notice is not required to mention this time limit, or the right to appeal.
As a result, land-use lawyers say, owners often learn months or years after the 30-day period has expired that they are being displaced.
"New York's is the weirdest statute I've ever seen," said Dana Berliner, a lawyer for the Institute for Justice, a public-interest law firm in Washington, which filed the complaint by Mr. Brody and the others.
Ms. Berliner said that in many states, the government's court petition for condemnation might be the first notice to a property owner. But almost all other states notify the owner of his right to appeal.
The cabinetmaking shop, on East 117th Street, is on the site of a retail center planned by the State Urban Development Corporation. The center would include a Home Depot and a Costco discount warehouse store.
Like Mr. Brody, the owners of the cabinetmaking shop, William J. Minnich and his nephew Bill Minnich, went to a public hearing, but were given only three minutes to speak.
According to the suit, no one explained that the hearing would result in a final decision. When the decision was announced in September 1999, the Minniches were notified by mail and told that they could appeal. But the suit says the notice made no reference to a time limit.
When the Minniches went to State Supreme Court in Manhattan to challenge the condemnation, their suit was dismissed because the time limit had expired.
A spokeswoman for the development agency, Maura Gallucci, said the agency could not comment on this week's lawsuit, but was "taking the proper steps in this process."
Ms. Gallucci said the agency's plans for the center had been widely known. "This project started out with a very public announcement by the governor and the mayor," she said.
Three years ago, the third plaintiff, St. Luke's Pentecostal Church of Westbury, a village in the town of North Hempstead, bought a building that had been scheduled for condemnation as part of an urban renewal plan. The church maintains that this fact was not publicly recorded and did not turn up in the title search.
"How were they supposed to know?" Ms. Berliner asked. "They went to the building department before they purchased their property and got a full go-ahead."
After spending $130,000 for the building and hundreds of thousands more on renovation and repairs, the suit says, the church was notified last November that it would receive $80,000 for its property from the North Hempstead Community Development Agency. The congregation, which now rents space in the basement of another building, is allowed by law to contest the amount, but not the condemnation.
A lawyer for the town, Martin N. Kroll, said the church had been advised that the building was in an urban renewal area.
In any event, he said, the church could not have successfully challenged the condemnation because the property was designated for subsidized housing, clearly recognized as a "public use." Under the law, a condemnation must serve a public purpose, and the owner must receive fair compensation.
Most courts have found that promoting development and creating jobs are public purposes, even if they require seizing property from one owner and turning it over to another.
But as local governments have grown bolder, some have lost. Last year, three property owners in Atlantic City won a ruling barring the New Jersey Casino Reinvestment Development Authority's plan to buy them out so the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino could expand.
The New York suit argues that property owners have no opportunity to raise such claims.
"These procedural questions are not petty," said Norman Marcus, a Manhattan land-use lawyer and former general counsel to the New York City Planning Commission. In the case of the three New York owners, he said, "the procedures killed them."
Lawyers for Port Chester could not be reached by telephone for comment this afternoon.
Mr. Brody said he wanted to contest Port Chester's finding, made years ago, that the downtown area was "blighted," and to argue that a supermarket and parking lot would serve the public no better than the 10 businesses that are his tenants.
He also said he had many discussions with the planning and zoning department as he proceeded with renovations.
"If you're doing work in an urban development zone and somebody else wants to come in and they like that use better, that's it," he said. "Nobody told me that."

HEADLINE: Footnotes

BYLINE: By Sandra Ballentine

 BODY:

1. The sight of a large piece of furniture being hoisted through the window of a New York City apartment is no big deal. The sight of an oil tank being airlifted by crane into a loft, however, might raise a few eyebrows. This was definitely the case when the 7,200-gallon tank from an oil truck arrived at Josh Morton's building just over a year ago (a, b). Can't live without a tank of your own? Morton acquired the rehabilitated tank for a mere $3,500 from Garafano Tank Service in Paterson, N.J. That's about $50,000 less than the cost of a new truck. And there's no need to worry about fumes or trace petroleum: each three-ton tank is meticulously steam-cleaned by Peter Garafano and his crew.
 
2. If you think a tank is hard to move, imagine what it would be like to transport LOT/EK's next project: the fuselage of a 747 jumbo jet, which the firm intends to turn into a new student lounge for the University of Washington. It's understandable why the architects made the connection between the university and airplane parts: the Boeing Company was the cornerstone of Seattle's pre-Microsoft economy. Boeing worked with university engineers in the mid-1930's to create the Kirsten Wind Tunnel, shown here. The tunnel, part of the University of Washington Aeronautical Laboratory, simulates high-speed winds and played a crucial role in the development of commercial aircraft. 

3. Besides tractor-trailers, shipping containers, oil tanks, detergent bottles, refrigerators and municipal water tanks, LOT/EK's building materials include large quantities of industrial metal sinks. The firm recently installed two pivoting walls in the Chelsea offices of Edizioni Press, an Italian publisher, each consisting of some 20 sinks coated with a thick shell of car paint. Not only are the sinks visually arresting, but they function as storage cubbies, too.
 
4. Champions of enclosed personal spaces, the architects mounted an installation at Manhattan's Deitch Projects two years ago that consisted of tanks morphed into cozy, individual TV-viewing chambers. The group has developed its TV-tank concept for this year's Neiman Marcus Christmas Book. For $70,000, technophiles can treat themselves to the "Mixer," shown here, which is an actual cement mixer retrofitted with 12 monitors, a PlayStation 2-and-DVD player, Orgazmotron-caliber surround sound, surveillance cameras and a cushy electric-blue, rubberized-foam interior. Two people can comfortably close the hatches against the physical world in the seven-foot isolation capsule. For a copy of the Christmas Book, which costs $15, call (800) 634-6267.
 
5. The architects at LOT/EK were afraid that the resin they wanted to pour into the catwalk grating that surrounds Morton's sleeping area -- rendering it more "stiletto friendly" for female guests -- would break the project's $180,000 budget. No problem: Morton's father had connections, and he garnered cost-effective materials and labor to realize both the walkway and a LOT/EK-designed dining table. Poured and cast resin has also been well utilized by other artists and designers. They include the painters L.C. Armstrong and Fred Tomaselli and the sculptor Rachel Whiteread, whose luminous resin works (a) influenced the English furniture designer Simon Dance to make the table shown here (b). Inquiries can be sent to mail@simondance.com.
 
6. The loft's industrial-looking color palette was achieved using baked-on car paint (for the yellow interior tank sections) and poured epoxy (for the blue floor). LOT/EK suggests Benjamin Moore's Industrial Maintenance Coatings, which come in such colors as "Safety Yellow" and "Safety Blue," to approximate the look. A gallon costs $35.79 at Janovic/Plaza, 161 Sixth Avenue.
 
7. Morton's dog, Ski, may not venture onto the apartment's catwalk, but he is content to lounge downstairs and play with his superswanky toys. He prefers to get his rubber bones from the Blue Ribbon Dog Company, the ultrachic canine outfitter. They cost around $20 at Ad Hoc Softwares, 136 Wooster Street, Paul Smith, 108 Fifth Avenue, and the Terence Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street.
 
8. Dog bones excepted, the loft is fairly devoid of ornamentation. The few artworks Morton does display are three sculptures by his mother, Judith Morton. She works in metal and in stone, and also in marble, as in "Contentment," pictured here. Her most recent show was at the Prudential Center in Boston. -- Sandra Ballentine

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 106; Column 3; Home Design Magazine

LENGTH: 1549 words

HEADLINE: The Thing Dynasty

BYLINE: By Stephen Mihm

 BODY:

Jeffrey Bernett Studio B, New York
Jeffrey Bernett, opposite, 36, likes to get his hands dirty. "I used to race motorcycles as a kid," he says, "so I knew my way around a machine shop. That started my appreciation for design." And it has resulted in products as diverse as the luxurious Tulip chair for B&B Italia and the mass-market Daisy doormat for Authentics. Before becoming a designer, Bernett, who started Studio B in 1995, toyed with the idea of a career in finance. But after the Wall Street crash of 1987, he drifted west to Colorado to ski. Another crash -- Bernett broke his back on the slopes -- provoked another career crisis. He enrolled in a design workshop in Aspen, where one of his teachers was the director of Parnham College, a crafts-based furniture school in England. Bernett signed up at Parnham shortly after, but found his Modernist sympathies at odds with the school's traditional ethos. He left after a year, but not before designing an umbrella stand -- part of a collection that won the editors' award for decorative accessories at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in 1996 -- that is now made by the Italian manufacturer Cappellini. Other European clients followed, including Ligne Roset, who makes the magazine rack shown in the foreground opposite. In a nod to his sporting roots, Bernett now wants to design athletic equipment. "I have a lot of knowledge of skiing in particular," he quips. 
 
Suzanne Tick Knoll Textiles, New York
"Most people in textiles don't know how to make a yarn," Suzanne Tick, right, says incredulously. A weaver by training, she's fascinated by fiber, thread and "the technical side of things."
Tick, 41, got her start while studying for her fine-arts degree at the University of Iowa. "Weaving was in the home-economics department," she says. "Eventually the art department let me have a loom."
Before joining Knoll Textiles, for which she is the creative director, Tick worked for the fabric manufacturer Boris Kroll, developed a collection of fabrics for the Groundworks division of Lee Jofa and formed her own carpet company, Tuva Looms. A 1998 show at the Museum of Modern Art showcased her experiments with Japanese steel yarn, which Tick had fashioned into shimmering curtains.
In June, Knoll Textiles introduced Imago, a line of translucent panels made from woven fibers encapsulated in clear resin. Developed by Tick and Ray Goodson, an entrepreneur and aerospace engineer, this material can be used for everything from screens and panels to wall coverings, table tops, shelving and even marker boards. As a divider, it admits light while also affording privacy.
Tick is currently playing with light in other ways. "I'm interested right now in objects like surfboards and scooters and how the light reflects off them," she says. Coming soon: a silk carpet for Tufenkian that she describes as "totally luminous, unlike anything you've ever seen."
"My philosophy," she says, "is that the world doesn't need another fabric or carpet unless there's something unique about it."
 
Jonathan Ive Apple, Cupertino, Calif.
Jonathan Ive, left, 33, loves simplicity. "I'm not talking about simplicity as style," he says. "I'm talking about a simpler product to assemble and use. That's what informed the Cube."
He's talking about the Power Mac G4 Cube, of course, the latest in a series of technological marvels from Apple, for which he is the vice president of industrial design. "There's too much visual clutter in our lives," he says. "We went in the opposite direction, utterly serene and utterly quiet."
That sums up Ive, who speaks in measured tones and is modest to the point of self-deprecation. The son of a British silversmith ("I never grew my craft skills to the level of my father's," he laments), he studied design at Newcastle Polytechnic. After graduating, he designed ceramic washtubs and basins for Ideal Standard and soon began consulting for Apple.
The challenge of designing a computer, he says, is that you can't fall back on centuries of examples for inspiration. "When you look at a wash basin, you know what it is," he observes. "But when you look at a circuit board, you don't understand it, and maybe even are frightened of it."
Intrigued by that challenge, Ive joined Apple in 1992, only to see the company lose its way in the wake of Steve Jobs's departure. "We kept doing provocative studies that gathered dust," he recalls. Then Jobs returned, and Ive found himself in charge of the iMac, the symbol of the company's resurgence.
"There is not a detail of the iMac that doesn't have a reason to be there," he says fondly. "It's all about removing the unnecessary."
 
Matali Crasset Paris
Matali Crasset, right, 35, is a master of reinvention, transforming the detritus of modern life into iconic objects. Born in a tiny village in Champagne, France, she attended Les Ateliers E.N.S.C.I. in Paris. While a student there, she cut her hair into her signature bob.
After graduation she landed a job with Philippe Starck, designing for Thomson Multimedia, a European manufacturer of consumer electronics. Her whimsical, curvaceous radios and televisions did away with what Crasset derisively terms the "black box" paradigm.
Two years ago, she struck out on her own. "Many designers make things for the world," she observes. "Instead, I started making things for my friends." Her guest bed, for example, is named "When Jim Goes to Paris."
It is Crasset's humblest design, however, that has garnered the most attention. Digestions, her new product line for the Italian furniture maker Edra, transforms the plaid plastic shopping bags found in immigrant neighborhoods in Paris into foam-filled sofas, chairs and tables.
A sense of playfulness pervades her work. "I don't like to make oppressive decorations," she says. "I designed the foam-filled bags to allow people to create their own space."
As Crasset sees it, she's less a designer than a collaborator. This fall she'll use that philosophy in helping wooden clog makers in rural France find new designs for their age-old skills. "I don't want to impose anything on them," Crasset says. "Designers need to work more on evolution and less on revolution."
 
Ayse Birsel Olive 1:1, New York
When Ayse (pronounced EYE-sha) Birsel, opposite, was a teenager, a great-uncle in her native Turkey told her, "Even though your husband and family will be there for you, you have to know how to take care of yourself."
Birsel, 36, took him at his word. She set up her own company in 1997, and, with her Resolve collection for Herman Miller, she is one of the rare women to have designed a line of office furniture for a major manufacturer. And it's a far cry from the sterile cubicles that fill most offices: everything about it echoes the natural world, from the petal-like canopies to the honeycomb-shaped work spaces. "That's the structure nature uses," Birsel explains.
It was her feminine perspective that catapulted Birsel to prominence five years ago with her design for the Zo Washlet, a combination toilet-bidet for the Japanese bathroom-fixture giant Toto. The Zo features a deodorizing fan and a heated, snap-on seat. "I wanted it to be easy to clean," she says. At first, Toto's all-male design and engineering staff dismissed the detachable-seat idea. Realizing that none of them had ever cleaned a toilet, Birsel made it their homework assignment. They returned chastened, and Birsel got her way.
Birsel has a host of new products in the works, including a version of Resolve for the dot-com set and a plastic sink inspired by the geometries of the Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer.
She is fond of saying that "design is kind of like bringing a child to life." At this rate, she'll have a bigger family than most.
 
Bodo Sperlein London
Bodo Sperlein, left, isn't pleased -- about the status of ceramics in the design world. "People don't give it the respect it deserves," he says. "It has a brown-rice, hippie reputation." Sperlein, 34, who prefers Burberry to Birkenstock, hopes to change all that.
Sperlein came late to design. Born in Germany, he spent most of his 20's working as a translator in London. When it came time to furnish his own flat, he couldn't afford high-quality dishes and so decided to make them himself, enrolling in a local pottery class. "I was the youngest one there," he recalls. "It was full of grannies."
Hooked, Sperlein went back for more, eventually getting his degree at London's Camberwell College of Arts. He soon landed a contract with Nymphenburg, one of Germany's oldest and most established porcelain houses. Sperlein's minimalist pieces are a radical departure from Nymphenburg's famously ornate china and figurines. Indeed, some of his designs are subtle to the point of ambiguity. A tapas plate doubles as an ashtray; a sake beaker works as a bud vase; an espresso cup becomes a toothbrush holder.
"Multifunctionality is very important to me," Sperlein notes.
Much of his recent work incorporates a composite of bone china and synthetic resin that enables Sperlein to create thin, translucent ceramic sheets like the ones found in his ethereal lighting fixtures. "I love it when materials are pushed to their limits," he says.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Highland Park, N.J.;
Small in Size but Large in Diversity

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
THE tiny 1.8-square-mile borough of Highland Park in Middlesex County, N.J., has been taking on a cosmopolitan flavor in recent years. Eating establishments such as Jerusalem Pizza and Kosher Chinese, which reflect the Jewish character of Raritan Avenue, the main business street, have been joined by Pad Thai, the Seven Hills of Istanbul and a Chinese bakery. Although less than a mile long, Raritan Avenue has about two dozen places to eat.
Like its diverse restaurant offerings, Highland Park is made up of distinct communities and interest groups. It is about 30 percent Jewish and supports four Orthodox synagogues and the Highland Park Conservative Temple. The borough is surrounded by a symbolic fence, using utility and other wires, that is called an eruv and that permits Orthodox Jews to carry objects or wheel baby carriages within its confines on the Sabbath. There are seven churches representing various Christian denominations. 
 Forty-nine percent of the borough's adults have at least four years of college, and there is a thriving community of students and lecturers associated with Rutgers University, just across the Raritan River in neighboring New Brunswick. In the early morning and evening they can be seen walking across the Raritan River Bridge, along with many commuters to New York City headed to or from the New Jersey Transit train station in New Brunswick. There are also significant black, Hispanic, Asian-American, artistic, literary and gay communities.
"Our diversity is ethnic, social, religious and economic," said Mayor Meryl Frank, a political scientist and Democrat who last year unseated an entrenched Democratic Party machine by pledging to bring the politics of inclusion to the borough. "My son has one friend who is a millionaire and another who is homeless and they all sit together at school. Students know that some families can have two same-sex parents and that's O.K. People here are accepting of differences."
Mayor Frank said her administration would be judged by the success of her efforts to revitalize downtown, which has a few empty stores and a dowdy appearance because of cracked and yellowed sidewalks and an abundance of aging storefronts. She said she was assembling a team made up primarily of local volunteers to determine how Highland Park can best be promoted.
"We need more parking, but I'm not sure that our downtown revitalization should include the normal brick pavers and old-style street lamps," she said. "We must capitalize on Highland Park's strengths. For instance, we could have local artists paint murals on large buildings and put sculptures in public places so people driving through will know we are an artsy town."
Despite its diminutive size, Highland Park has a large range of housing. The unifying factors are an abundance of maple trees and the age of the houses -- most of them more than a half century old. Last year, 125 single-family houses were sold through real estate agents. Prices ranged from $77,000 for a two-bedroom, one-bath ranch on Raritan Avenue to $1,210,000 for the largest house in the borough, the three-story, six-bedroom Greek Revival Livingston Manor House, on two acres that include a pair of barns and a greenhouse.
Situated at 81 Harrison Street in the northern section, the house was first built in the early 1800's and has had several additions since. It is named for an early owner, the Rev. John H. Livingston, 1830's head of Queen's College, now Rutgers University.
The house is the focal point of the proposed 12-block Livingston Manor historic district with its 1920's colonials, many with slate roofs and sweeping verandas, that sell for $250,000 to $500,000. The Highland Park Historical Society is preparing applications to have the district included on both the National and New Jersey Registers of Historic Places.
THE few newer homes in Highland Park are mainly on the northern side of town. Four-bedroom colonials that are about 10 years old on Parkview Terrace sell for from $400,000 to $450,000, said Pamela Zdanowicz, a sales associate with Century 21 J. J. Laufer Realty. The average Highland Park house is a three-bedroom prewar colonial on a 36-by-100-foot lot selling for from $200,000 to $250,000.
Some of the most affordable homes are in the Triangle section, named for a fork that splits Raritan Avenue into Woodbridge Avenue and New Jersey Route 27, two busy roads in Middlesex County. Several small homes needing work on Columbia Street, Ninth Avenue and Alcazar Avenue in the Triangle went for under $100,000 last year.
Among newer residents are Micky and Linda Landis, who bought a 90-year-old five-bedroom center-hall colonial on Harrison Street in the Livingston Manor section for $400,000. Seeking a walking town with a sense of community for their three children, ages 4, 2 and 3 months, they moved from nearby East Brunswick, a sprawling township with no main street.
"I grew up in Highland Park and loved the diversity of the schools and wanted that for my children," said Mr. Landis, who works for a real estate investment trust in Princeton, a 45-minute drive away. "I like the fact that when I am outside, people stop and say hello. And we walk everywhere in town. We also walk to the theater and the restaurants in New Brunswick."
At the end of September, 26 single-family houses were on the market. Prices ranged from $109,000 for a small three-bedroom, one-bath colonial on Parker Road in the Triangle to $495,000 for a larger three-bedroom, two-bath colonial on Lawrence Avenue in Livingston Manor. There were also 11 two- to four-family homes on the market, ranging from $159,000 to $295,000.
Highland Park has about 200 condominium units, most of which are in two high-rise buildings -- the Highlander and River Ridge Terrace -- on South Adelaide Avenue near the New Brunswick line. Recently, two one-bedroom units in the Highlander sold for $55,000 each. No two-bedroom units -- the largest in the building -- were sold in the last year. However, Ms. Zdanowicz estimates that such units would sell for about $120,000. In River Ridge Terrace, sales over the last year ranged from $143,000 for a one-bedroom to $349,000 for three bedrooms.
According to Ms. Zdanowicz, last spring Highland Park's real estate market was the hottest it has ever been. "Homes were selling the day they were listed, many with multiple bids," she said. "Now we get few multiple offers, but houses that are priced right still go in a week or less."
Mayor Frank said that renters make up 60 percent of the population. There are approximately 3,000 rental units in a dozen large garden apartment complexes around the perimeter of the borough. Ms. Zdanowicz said that rentals range from $750 to $950 a month for two bedrooms.
Nowhere is diversity felt more than in the 1,650-student Highland Park Public Schools district. It consists of the K-2 Irving School, the Bartle School, for third through sixth grade (and where prekindergarten classes are also held), and the 650-student Highland Park High School for grades 7-12. Class sizes average 20 students in Irving and the high school and 22 in Bartle; the state average is 21.6. Computers are introduced in prekindergarten with mathematics and science play programs. All district classrooms are wired for the Internet.
The superintendent of schools, Dr. Marylu Simon, said that 70 languages and dialects are spoken in pupils' homes. Although the town population is more than three-quarters white, the school system is 49 percent minority, in part because 300 Jewish students -- 23 percent of the borough's school-age population -- attend religious schools in Edison and East Brunswick.
As part of its diversity education, the district satisfies its state-mandated foreign language requirement by teaching Mandarin Chinese to all students in grades 1 to 4. "It is the most widely spoken language in the world," Dr. Simon said. The program is not offered in the higher grades.
THE district offers 14 advanced placement courses in English, foreign languages, history, the sciences, music and calculus. It also allows seniors who have completed their course requirements to take classes for college credit at Rutgers University. Last year, the district hired a Rutgers professor to teach 14 students a second-year college course in calculus.
Of the 75-student graduating class of 1999, the last class for which official state figures are available, 82 percent went to college. On the College Boards, the graduates had a combined verbal and mathematics average of 1,092, 83 points above the state average.
Besides its many restaurants, Raritan Avenue has three book shops, a dozen beauty salons, three camera stores, a dozen specialty food shops and one supermarket with extensive kosher and other ethnic food departments. On Friday afternoons, an open-air farmers market draws crowds to Raritan Avenue. For major shopping, residents can go to the Brunswick Square Mall in East Brunswick or the Menlo Park Mall in Edison, both less than 10 miles away.
Raritan Avenue was originally part of the Leni Lenape Indian Assunpink Trail, a path that connected the Hudson and Delaware River Valleys. By 1681, the area was home to a dissident Baptist community led by the Rev. Francis Drake, a descendant of the explorer of the same name.
During the Revolutionary War, Hessian soldiers stationed on the Highland Park side of the river exchanged fire with Col. Alexander Hamilton's artillery in New Brunswick. The first railroad bridge across the Raritan was built by the Camden and Amboy Railroad in 1838, facilitating travel from New York City to New Brunswick. In 1905, Highland Park split from Raritan Township -- now Edison Township -- in a dispute over schools and taxes.
Today, much of Highland Park remains county parkland. It is sandwiched between the 90-acre Donaldson Park off South Second Avenue on the borough's southern tip, And the 473-acre Johnson Park, on River Road. Both parks have ball fields, picnic grounds, tennis courts and ponds. Johnson Park also has a petting zoo.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
In Some Foreign Funds, a Way To Overcome the Strong Dollar

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
AMONG the world's major currencies, the dollar has reigned supreme this year, climbing 14 percent against the euro and 5 percent against the yen. While that has meant bargain travel for American tourists, it has generally meant miserable returns for Americans holding foreign mutual funds.
According to Morningstar Inc., foreign funds lost 10.69 percent of their value through the third quarter, compared with a small loss of 1.54 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. 
 Those few foreign funds that have done well this year generally concentrated on picking stocks, not on hedging their currency risks. Still, debates over to what extent investors should venture back into foreign funds often turn into debates over currencies, especially the euro.
For the first three quarters, Morningstar found 29 individual funds in positive territory, with 15 having returns above 5 percent.
The Ivy International Small Companies fund, one of the top performers, returned better than 21 percent for the nine months. Miranda Richards of Henderson Investors in London, the fund's manager, attributed the results entirely to stock-picking, with no currency hedges to bolster the results.
"There are very good small-cap companies that are global leaders in niche businesses," and her job is to find them, Ms. Richards said. Because the companies are small, she is often able to meet with the company's top management, not just the investor relations staff. As a result, she said, she has a better opportunity to know a company well than do managers of funds that invest in large-cap companies.
One of her core holdings is Rational, a German company that has 41 percent of the world market for some specialized ovens used by professional cooks. She bought shares in the initial public offering earlier this year and expects 40 percent annual growth in the stock price. Another favorite is CSL, an Australian company that is a leader in blood plasma products.
If investors have the appropriate horizon of five years or more, she said, they will have less reason to worry about exchange rates. "On this fund, we have no hedges at all at the moment," she said. "We do not do very much hedging, because over the long term, currency fluctuations are less important."
Sheridan Reilly said that the Ivy Funds, where he is international equities chief, are now unhedged but would consider currency hedges when they would be likely to enhance returns or preserve capital. If a portfolio were "overhedged," he said, "it could limit the upside."
THE costs of hedging can vary widely, he said, from "negligible" in Japan, where interest rates are extremely low, to punishingly expensive in politically or economically less stable countries like Indonesia and Malaysia, where short-term interest rates have been more than 25 percent in recent years. "That means you're agreeing to give up 25 percent if you hedge," he said, because hedges are a function of interest rates. In such conditions, he added, "we exit the market."
Mr. Reilly said Ivy's approach was twofold -- stock-picking based on a thorough five-year review of individual companies and on disciplined portfolio construction. He cited Siemens of Germany as a favorite. "Over the past five years, it has slowly transformed itself from quasi-state-owned to a vibrant entrepreneurial company," he said. He also likes Nokia of Finland, despite its recent tumble on an earnings warning.
In constructing a portfolio, Mr. Reilly said, Ivy looks for companies with price-to-earnings ratios below the market's, earnings growth rates and return on equity above the market's, and price-to-book ratios near the market's.
"American investors should have up to 30 percent of their holdings in foreign equities," he said. "There are tremendous opportunities." But they should go in only for the long term -- three to five years -- he added.
An independent investment adviser, Michael Stolper, had similar views. His San Diego firm, Stolper & Company, works with institutions and wealthy individuals, often by investing directly in domestic stocks and using mutual funds for international holdings. Among the funds he likes are Acorn International, Oakmark International, Tweedy Brown Global Value, Harbor International Growth and the various Templeton funds.
"We still have about a 20 to 25 percent weighting overseas," Mr. Stolper said, a proportion with which he was happy. Asked if he looked for funds that hedged for currency fluctuations, Mr. Stolper said: "I'd probably be more nervous if they told me they were fully hedged than if they weren't. The cost of hedging can be awesome.
"The longer I'm alive, the less conviction I have that anyone can predict currencies with accuracy," Mr. Stolper said. "I'm surprised at the strength of the dollar and the weakness of the euro. It's a rotational pattern."
Does that mean that today's depressed euro offers a buying opportunity for American investors? "There could be a tactical advantage," Mr. Stolper said, if new money or tax-sheltered retirement-account money is to be deployed. But he said he would not advise selling holdings with a big taxable capital gain to go into a European fund now. Attempts to time the market are usually "exercises in vanity over economics," Mr. Stolper said.
Peter Harrison, head of the global portfolios group at Chase Fleming Asset Management in London, which markets funds in 44 countries including the United States, said the long-term results of an investing strategy were clearer when portfolios were left unhedged. "We don't, as a rule, hedge any of our portfolios," he said. "First and foremost, we are great believers that stocks matter. History and academic evidence show that performance is driven much more by companies than by where they are listed."
Many American investors, enjoying strong domestic markets and the strong dollar, have not felt a need to diversify overseas, Mr. Harrison said. But he thinks Europe will follow the United States in the growth cycle, and he said he was optimistic about the euro for the long term. "We feel it is being dragged down by sentiment," he said, "and by European companies buying U.S. assets -- $150 billion this year."
But Richard Gluck, senior vice president and head of the fixed-income team at the Ivy Funds, said the euro "is not likely to be strong any time soon." He gave several reasons: "Europeans are investing heavily in the United States. Japanese are liquidating European positions, putting pressure on the euro. The United States has an extraordinarily strong economy with high productivity levels. The oil-price rise hits Europe twice because oil is priced in dollars, and the E.C.'s central bank has been pursuing an anti-inflation policy."
Germans have been buying United States Treasury bonds, he noted, and given the dollar's strength against the euro, "they are up 26 percent this year."
Still, "things do change over time," Mr. Gluck said. "The euro will find its base level," he added. "So be diversified; don't catch the wave after it has moved 20 percent."
