SECTION: Section 7; Page 37; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1109 words

HEADLINE: I'm O.K., You're O.K.

BYLINE: By Matthew Miller; Matthew Miller, a syndicated columnist, is a senior fellow at the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania.

 BODY:

 The Fourth Great Awakening & the Future
 Of Egalitarianism
 By Robert William Fogel.
 383 pp. Chicago:
 The University of Chicago Press. $25. 
If poor people today grow nearly as tall, live almost as long and surf roughly as many cable channels as rich people, shouldn't liberals stop whining? If the spiritual benefits of education are so indispensable that funds for lifelong learning (especially for needy kids and depressed older people) need to rise by a stunning $400 billion each year, shouldn't conservatives pay up? It gives you some feel for how ideologically refreshing the latest book by Robert Fogel, the 1993 Nobel laureate in economic science, is that his answer to both these questions is a matter-of-fact yes. "The Fourth Great Awakening & the Future of Egalitarianism" is an ambitious effort to account for the cycles of reform in American history. While its religious-historical framework is a bit overwrought, Fogel's book is remarkable for weaving insights from history, religion, biology, nutrition, demography, economics and even a field called "technophysio evolution" into an integrated perspective that suggests how the priorities of today's left and right might meld into a powerful new egalitarian agenda to complete the nation's unfinished business.
Shunning the prejudices of current political debate, in which the label "egalitarian" is even more fatal than "liberal," Fogel argues that "the egalitarian creed . . . is at the core of American political culture." Much of political history, he argues, involves the swing between rival interpretations of this creed, one emphasizing "equality of opportunity," the other "equality of condition." The ebb and flow of these reform paradigms, Fogel says, has turned on whether the prevailing religious ethic viewed poverty and disadvantage as the wages of sin, or as the by-product of broader flaws in society.
Fogel traces this battle through America's previous religious awakenings. The first, in the mid-1700's, saw revivalist leaders assail the corrupt church hierarchy, helping fuel the related war on British rule in the American Revolution. The second great awakening, starting in the early 1800's and peaking at midcentury, preached the struggle against sin as the path to grace, and gave rise to the temperance and abolitionist movements. The third great awakening, stretching from 1890 to 1930 and beyond, was born in the flood of displaced farm workers and new immigrants to the cities and led to the reforms associated with the Progressives, the New Deal and, eventually, the Great Society. Fogel's fourth great awakening began in the 1960's and shapes politics today. Nearly a third of the electorate now claims membership in "enthusiastic religion," powering the anti-abortion, antitax and welfare reform movements. Partly in response to the exhaustion of the third awakening's redistributive agenda, Fogel argues, the religious pendulum has swung back toward an emphasis on individual responsibility.
Fogel concedes that his analysis ends up "tying political history far more closely to religion than some historians consider warranted." Most readers will, I think, agree. It may be true, as Fogel contends, that "the evangelical churches represent the leading edge" of reform in our society. But it's hard not to view the Depression as the truer inspiration of the New Deal agenda, to cite just one example. And when Fogel recasts familiar battles (like the clash between labor and business at the turn of the century) as showdowns between the end of one awakening and the rise of another, the results feel forced.
Luckily, these aspects of Fogel's framework are easy to skip over, allowing one to feast on the surprising and illuminating data he has culled from various disciplines. Consider: Life expectancy in New York and Philadelphia in the 1830's averaged 24 years, six years less than that of Southern slaves. Nutrition was so poor in the early 1900's that one-third of American men were deemed too weak to serve in World War I. Our species has so mastered our environment that we've increased our body size by 50 percent and life spans by more than 100 percent in just 300 years. The saturation of consumer goods is so complete that American homes now boast more than one radio per ear.
These facts and hundreds like them help Fogel to make his case that life is vastly better today, even for the worst-off Americans. Which raises a provocative question: what is the proper angle of vision for reformers -- the long historical view, or a look down today's mean streets? If your standards for outrage are set by the ages, little on the current American scene seems a cause for alarm. But the long view can be so olympian as to counsel a weirdly informed indifference to the fate of millions with scant hope.
It is a measure of Fogel's subtlety that he is able to encompass both perspectives. Even as he catalogs the country's enormous progress, he's filled with ideas about what should come next. Fogel is aware that government played a big role in increasing incomes and life spans for the poor over the last century, largely through subsidies for education, pensions and public health. Indeed, he sees the "egalitarian revolution" of the 20th century as a huge success save for one thing: the "glaring failure to promote moral behavior" in a society more prone today than a century ago to teenage pregnancy, single motherhood, drug addiction and crime. In Fogel's view, "immaterial" goods -- a sense of purpose, a commitment to family and a work ethic -- are now more important than mere cash in lifting up the poor. These spiritual gaps aren't easy to fill, since they're transferred through intimate relationships, not government handouts. Fogel thus calls for a revolutionary expansion in mentoring and similar forms of extended education, aimed at disadvantaged kids, single mothers and the elderly. With material comfort freeing ordinary Americans to seek self-realization, and productivity increases likely to make retirement at age 55 routine before long, Fogel predicts a surge in volunteerism that could go far to address the virtue gap.
While this emphasis sounds conservative, Fogel insists that the next generation of reform needn't be either/or -- that Great Society liberals and tough-love conservatives should find common ground promoting education, pensions and health care, as well as curbing drugs and media violence. If his history is any guide, Fogel's dream may not come true, but it's worth hoping our politics can grope its way toward approaches as catholic and inclusive as his own vision plainly is. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Trust in Government

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An Oct. 5 letter posed a question -- "are government bureaucrats more capable of running my life than I am?" -- similar to what George W. Bush has asked in the debate and his stump speeches. To many of us, however, that is not the key question. 
 Voters should be asking themselves if an increasingly unregulated and oligopolistic market economy should continue to prevent many Americans from access to basic necessities, like affordable health care. I would also like to know why government is such an anathema to so many in a representative democracy.
 
ROGER DOBRICK
Milwaukee, Oct. 5, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 677 words

HEADLINE: It's Not Oil vs. Beauty in the Arctic

BYLINE: By Frank H. Murkowski; Frank H. Murkowski, a Republican senator from Alaska, is chairman of the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Clinging to a position that would prevent America from developing some of the most promising of its domestic energy resources, Al Gore and Joseph Lieberman have repeatedly stated their opposition to oil exploration in a tiny sliver of the Arctic Coastal Plain. They say it would yield only a six-month supply of oil, and only at the cost of the destruction of a pristine wilderness. In suggesting that we must choose between Arctic oil and environmental protection, they are presenting a false choice.
What is at stake here, according to the latest estimates of the United States Geological Survey, is 16 billion barrels of oil -- an amount sufficient to replace all of our imports from Saudi Arabia for the next 30 years. And it can be extracted and moved to consumers in the "lower 48" states without harming the wildlife that inhabits the coastal plain at various times of the year. More than 25 years of experience at nearby Prudhoe Bay, a region that has supplied America with roughly 25 percent of its domestic oil production since the late 1970's, have shown that energy production and environmental protection can coexist. 
 At the time Prudhoe Bay was discovered, some claimed that oil development would devastate the central Arctic caribou herd. Today that herd is more than triple the size it was then. Nesting populations of migratory birds in the area are also on the rise. It is clear that we now have the technology that can both develop the oil and protect the environment.
The 19 million-acre Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is roughly the size of South Carolina. In 1980, Congress declared 8 million acres of the refuge as strictly protected wilderness and an additional 9.5 million as refuge lands off limits to energy exploration. Mindful of the fact that the remaining 1.5 million acres of coastal plain was North America's best and last hope of a giant oil discovery, Congress designated the coastal plain as a special study area that could be opened to oil and gas leasing.
In the intervening years, a federal environmental impact study has shown that exploration of the coastal plain could occur during the winter, when animals are not present and no habitat would be disturbed, to determine if any recoverable oil is even present. If a large oil field were found, the oil could be developed using directional drilling technology, which requires very little use of land at the surface. It would disturb only 2,000 acres or less of the flat, treeless tundra that makes up the coastal plain.
In other words, we can determine if the oil is there with no environmental impact at all, and if a very large field were found, we could develop it with minimal environmental impact. The sad fact is, at present, we aren't even allowed to look.
America will remain dependent on oil for the foreseeable future, and increasingly, our dependency is on foreign oil. During the Clinton-Gore years, our oil imports have soared 17 percent while domestic production has decreased 14 percent. We now rely on foreign suppliers for 58 percent of our crude oil, and that reliance carries several risks.
As we import more oil on foreign tankers, which lack the safety features required of American ships, the risk of oil spills increases. Pushing production out of America to nations without our environmental standards increases global environmental risks. Moreover, our growing dependence on foreign oil, including oil from Iraq, is inconsistent with our foreign policy objectives. And we endanger our economy as we rely increasingly on a cartel for an essential resource.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Lieberman heralded the recent release of oil from our existing Strategic Petroleum Reserve as instrumental in easing prices and building inventories of heating oil. But they oppose looking for the oil field that many geologists think may be under Alaska's coastal plain -- a huge field that could have a meaningful and sustained effect on consumer prices. We are flirting with danger by refusing even to see what may lie under the coastal plain. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
Back to Death Row With a Convict and a Crusading Nun

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
America is a young country with stories to tell. So rapid is our history that we like our stories simple, our characters unequivocal and our conflicts vivid, and this is why we turn so many of them into operas. This kind of narrative balladry has taken on an American style of its own: a lyrical storytelling in which music is an amiable, often meek appendage, happy to echo pastoral themes and bend to the dynamism of words and action.
An old working model and a new prototype for American opera occupied the San Francisco Opera this weekend. Friday night it was "The Ballad of Baby Doe," Douglas Moore's minor epic of boom, bust and romance in the Colorado silver industry 125 years ago. Last night brought a far more bitter and less romantic kind of art, a new opera taken from Sister Helen Prejean's book about a Louisiana execution, with music by Jake Heggie and a libretto from Terrence McNally. The book also inspired a devasting film by Tim Robbins starring Sean Penn and Susan Sarandon. 
 "Dead Man Walking" is drama so loaded with moral questions, politics and the sheer horrors of suffering and death that the romance of American ballad opera quickly curdles. We are asked to weigh the violent deaths of murder victims against the institutional murder of the man responsible, also to reconcile Christian obligations to love with the near-justifiable instinct for revenge. More important, "Dead Man Walking" does not debate these issues; it shows them. We follow Joe de Rocher through the corridors and anterooms of Angola Prison as failed legal appeals and the machinery of execution take him gradually to his death.
The San Francisco production by Joe Mantello and Michael Yeargan does this very well. Scene changes are liquid; the images are simple. Institutional gray and seediness set this stage as it should be set. Patrick Summers has prepared his orchestra and singers handsomely. Mr. McNally does his part. The economical libretto avoids verbiage and condenses scenes; indeed, "Dead Man Walking" does not keep us waiting.
So with such strong forces at work in this new opera, it is sad to report that its music fails to show up. Mr. Heggie's career, or what I know of it, has taken a distinctive path to success. Whereas most composers appeal to the public for approval, he has gone to performers. Principally a writer of songs, Mr. Heggie is a proficient flatterer of the human voice, with a real knack for hitting its G spots. As a result, a series of important singers, charmed by the easy, unthreatening flow of his music, not to mention his considerable personal appeal, have carried the Heggie name to the public in their concerts. The San Francisco Opera, where Mr. Heggie worked in the public relations department, seems to have been the most charmed of all, having commissioned him to write "Dead Man Walking" and provided a first-rate production.
Yet nice as Mr. Heggie's musical gifts may be, they are no match for the explosive issues and episodes entrusted to him. Singers are accommodated, schmoozed and made comfortable; and when high drama is required, Mr. Heggie gives us a drumroll, a few timpani whacks and a brass crescendo. The massed crowd choruses thrive on loudness and congestion. When these big ensembles do take on a certain power in the last scenes, credit more the raw, visceral drama surrounding the music, less the music itself. There is nothing musically offensive about "Dead Man Walking," but to paraphrase Gertrude Stein, there's not much there there. The aesthetics of ingratiation take an artist only so far, and this is subject matter with far greater needs.
Mr. Heggie works hard to enliven his orchestra with conflicting inner motion and rhythm, but so ineffective is the instrumental sound that potentially interesting detail is lost in the general pallor. Mr. Heggie would have done well to turn his orchestration over to a professional.
The singing principals are first-rate. Susan Graham sings touchingly as Sister Helen. John Packard is deeply and vividly affecting as the condemned man. Frederica von Stade works hard as his stricken mother. Also good are the quartet of bereaved parents: Nicolle Foland, Catherine Cook, Gary Rideout and especially Robert Orth in an extended part. Theresa Hamm-Smith, John Ames and Jay Hunter Morris do well. Sam Fleming's costumes capture the wash-and-wear culture of the Southern poor. So much of "Dead Man Walking" is worth our while, and so much of it is missing.

HEADLINE: Semiconductor Growth Predicted

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 8

 BODY:
Worldwide sales of semiconductors will show double-digit growth in the next three years as manufacturers find places for them in a variety of devices other than the personal computer, a new report says.
Sales of semiconductors are growing at a rate of at least 25 percent as electronics manufacturers put them into cellular phones, game consoles, cameras, set-top boxes, handheld electronic organizers and other devices, Dataquest, a research unit of the Gartner Group, says in a report. 
 Total worldwide revenue in 2000 alone is expected to increase 37 percent compared with figures in 1999, to $231.6 billion, before moderating somewhat in 2001-02 and turning downward slightly in 2003, according to the Dataquest forecast.
A separate report from the research firm International Data Group predicts European semiconductor sales will grow 13 percent this year.
A spokesman for Intel, the leading maker of semiconductors, said the company could not comment on the reports because it had entered a mandatory quiet period ahead of reporting its earnings.
Intel, Advanced Micro Devices and other chip makers have been scrambling to increase manufacturing in the face of continuing shortages of high-end processors and memory chips. Cellular phone makers such as Nokia and Ericsson and makers of electronic handheld devices such as Palm and Sony are moving to make "smart" devices capable of accessing the Internet, but the equipment requires greater processing power with low heat consumption.
Flash memory, which retains information even when a device is turned off, has been in particularly short supply as nearly all manufacturers of mobile electronic devices compete for it. Analysts predict prices will remain high through 2001 until new factories begin production. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Patents;
An early move in Congress to limit the protection of business methods to what is truly original.

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
PATENTS for methods of doing business have existed in small numbers at least since the early 1980's, but only in the mid-90's did they suddenly begin to loom large in the economy. It was then that electronic commerce created a new arena for traditional business practices and several patents were granted that appeared to give exclusivity for such practices to some Web-only companies. As people sat up and took notice of the trend, some did not like what they saw.
One of the most recent to express displeasure was Representative Howard L. Berman, a Democrat representing a Los Angeles district. Last week, Mr. Berman, along with Representative Rick Boucher, Democrat of Virginia, announced legislation to "provide that where an invention is new only in that it uses a computer to implement the business practice," the Patent and Trademark Office "will presume the invention to be obvious, and thus, not patentable." 
 The bill would also require the Patent and Trademark Office to publish all business-method patents 18 months after they are filed, even if they have not yet been granted. It calls, as well, for giving opponents of an awarded patent a means for challenging it without having to resort to a lawsuit.
The two Congressmen said they were concerned that business-method patents were being issued without enough evidence whether an idea was already in the public domain.
"This is particularly difficult with Internet and high-tech practices," a press release by Mr. Berman said, "since very little published information exists." He cited a patent that covers the choosing of a car color when buying a vehicle over the Internet, and asked: "Given that auto salesmen have never patented their approach on the salesroom floor, is there a published record of activity of auto salesmen? And was this record considered in the drafting or examining of the patent?"
The bill could raise questions on what the use of a computer means, since business-method patents might involve software, hardware and Web sites including Internet portals. And in the past, any hint of publishing patents before they are issued has set off vigorous opposition in this country, where there is a long tradition of protecting an inventor's secrecy until the patent is awarded.
For now, the bill amounts to little more than a gesture, as it was introduced two days before the end of the regular Congressional session, and it is impossible to know whether it will get attention next year. Both men sit on the House Judiciary subcommittee on courts and intellectual property. As the ranking minority member, Mr. Berman could become the chairman if the Democrats regain control of the House in next month's elections. Of course, he could also be defeated for re-election, though political analysts say that is unlikely.
In any case, Mr. Berman said he did not offer the legislation for immediate action. "I am not taking a position one way or another as to whether business methods should be patentable," he said in the statement. "I tend to think they should be, but I could be persuaded otherwise. My intent with this legislation is to stimulate the dialogue."
Neither Mr. Berman nor Mr. Boucher represents a district with a large number of high-technology companies. But according to the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan group that tracks political contributions, Mr. Berman's re-election campaign received nearly $150,000 last year and this from political action committees and individuals connected with the entertainment industry, and Mr. Boucher accepted just over $80,000 from PAC's in the entertainment, publishing, telecommunications and computer industries.
These industries are weighted toward traditional companies that own the information and entertainment "content" increasingly being sold over the Internet, and that are developing the hardware and software for the future of e-commerce. Such companies are not enamored of the idea that young high-technology companies like Amazon.com might patent and own a method of conducting digital business like the "one-click" online purchase.
Across the Capitol, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee did not vote last month on the long-pending international trademark agreement known as the Madrid protocol, despite intense lobbying by the International Trademark Association. Both the White House and Congress have supported the accord, which would allow one-stop international trademark processing -- meaning that people could apply for or renew a trademark in nearly 50 countries simply by filing the paperwork and paying the fee at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Leaders of the trademark holders group had not expected last-minute opposition over a section of the agreement from one industry -- liquor distillers. Their outrage originated with the French company Pernod Ricard, which has been locked in a trademark battle with Bacardi Ltd. over a Cuban rum brand name, Havana Club.
The contested section of the protocol is based on a 1999 law that has roots in the economic embargo against Cuba and the industries that were seized there after Fidel Castro came to power four decades earlier. The law prevents anyone other than the original owner of a Cuban trademark from paying to register or renew it with the Patent and Trademark Office. It says that "designated nationals" -- like the Cuban government or any Cuban national -- do not qualify. Thus, the law effectively strips the Cuban company that controls the rum name Havana Club from enforcing or defending a trademark in this country.
Bacardi, which leads the $3.5 billion-a-year rum market, began selling a rum of its own called Havana Club in the United States in 1995. A Cuban holding company sold a rum with that name elsewhere in the world. The Cuban company went to United States courts to stop Bacardi from using the name in this country, and also licensed the Havana Club trademark to Pernod Ricard.
Bacardi had been a supporter of the 1999 law. But now the European Union has challenged the law, saying it violates World Trade Organization agreements.
Last month a W.T.O. panel began looking into the distillers dispute. And last week, the Supreme Court turned aside an appeal from the Cuban company to stop Bacardi from using the trademark.
But by then, what the International Trademark Association had expected to be a smooth adoption of the Madrid protocol had already become tangled in the distillers fight.
In the days before the Senate's scheduled vote, Pernod Ricard began a public campaign against the 1999 law, and Congress, which has been considering the Madrid protocol since 1989, put off its vote once again.

HEADLINE: Signs of Market Saturation in PC World

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The personal computer industry, whose double-digit growth helped propel technology stocks for years, finally faces stiff competition -- from personal computers.
Lately, it has become increasingly hard to sell consumers and corporations new computers because so many consumers and businesses already own them. Some analysts see signs of market saturation that could portend the end of the glory days for PC makers and their suppliers. 
 In recent weeks Intel, Apple and Dell have seen their stocks tumble after warning that demand for computers is lighter than anticipated. The tepid forecasts have dampened investor expectations for the coming quarterly financial reports from those companies and others in the PC food chain.
When Apple issued its warning, its chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, described it as "a speed bump." But some industry analysts say the warnings, taken together and coupled with other evidence, suggest something more fundamental is behind the slower demand. They say the personal computer market, especially the corporate market, is so saturated the industry can no longer assume sales will grow at annual rates of 15 or 20 percent or more to which it has grown accustomed.
"We've run out of room for growth," said Martin Reynolds, research fellow at Gartner Dataquest, a market research firm in San Jose, Calif. "Look at the saturation in the market. We're there. We're filled up."
Mr. Reynolds even predicts the PC market, rather than simply seeing slower growth, could actually contract by the year 2002.
The financial and product analysts who see market saturation say the shift does not yet mark the dreaded dawn of the so-called post-PC era, in which the use of personal computers would be usurped by other handheld computers and other gadgets. Rather, they see the beginning of the replacement-PC era.
"The corporate market has become a replacement market," said Anne Bui, a senior analyst with the International Data Corporation, or IDC, a research house. "There's no reason to buy anything now. They've bought everything they need."
The figures for saturation levels of the home market vary. Estimates from various market research firms indicate that from 53 to 60 percent of the nation's households now have computers, and some analysts expect greater penetration levels to be reached only gradually.
Since 1994, annual sales of computers in the United States have increased at a torrid pace. As recently as 1999, sales soared 23.8 percent, to 45 million computers, up from 36 million in 1998, according to IDC.
But for the current year, IDC is projecting a growth rate of only 12.2 percent in the United States market. That would be the lowest annual percentage rise since 1994, the earliest year for which IDC provides statistics.
Mr. Reynolds and Ms. Bui said that the computer market might begin taking on the cyclical and seasonal traits typical of other industries. Computer sales, for example, could ebb and flow with standard replacement cycles, or be pegged more directly to new software releases.
To be sure, not all analysts see systemic changes at work. Some say it is simply too soon to read anything into the recent warnings or even IDC's slow-growth projections for 2000.
And they point out that PC sales have had their ebbs and flows over the last five years. For instance, worldwide sales slipped to 12.8 percent in 1998, according to IDC, but rebounded dramatically, by 23.6 percent, the very next year.
"There's no question that in our industry's history we've seen times when supply has caught up to demand," said Seymour Merrin, president of Merrin Information Services Inc., a consulting firm in Santa Fe, N.M.
Mr. Merrin said he believed that oil prices, among other factors, are slowing the economy and that the drag on computer sales is "a 9- to 18-month situation."
Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, said PC makers and their investors should take heart that IDC, even while projecting 12.2 percent growth in the United States market this year, projects worldwide sales at 18.9 percent.
Mr. Murphy said that roughly 435 million PC's had been installed worldwide to date, which he estimated as only one-fifth the total that will be installed in the coming years. "Before this whole revolution is over, there will be 2.5 billion computers shipped worldwide," he predicted.
Where Mr. Murphy does agree with Mr. Reynolds and Ms. Bui is in saying that the weakness in the euro is hurting PC sales. Another factor that some analysts say has clouded the figures this year is the slow uptake of Microsoft's Windows 2000 software.
Steve P. Kleynhans, a vice president at the Meta Group, a market research firm in Stamford, Conn., said many corporations were testing Windows 2000 on "hundreds" of new computers before rolling them out on "thousands" of upgraded computers. "I don't see this as a long-term problem," Mr. Kleynhans said. "It's a short-term problem hitting for a couple of quarters."
Mr. Kleynhans said it was misleading to draw an industry conclusion from the combined warnings of Dell, Intel and Apple, which he said were each dealing with different factors.
Intel, he said, which warned analysts on Sept. 21 that its third-quarter revenues would not meet the company's earlier expectations, was facing newfound competition from its chip-making rival, Advanced Micro Devices, and was not executing as well as it could be.
And he said that Dell's sales were a victim of the sluggish acceptance of Windows 2000. Last week, Dell warned that revenue for its fiscal third quarter would be 3 percent below previous forecasts.
Only in the case of Apple does Mr. Kleynhans see "a fairly saturated market," noting that the Macintosh faithful "all have machines." On Sept. 28, Apple said it would earn 30 to 33 cents a share in its fourth quarter, far below analysts' forecast of 45 cents.
Charles R. Wolf, executive director at the investment bank UBS Warburg, who closely follows the PC industry, said all PC makers need to realize that their industry has matured -- that they have successfully saturated the European and American business markets and now must concentrate on becoming a replacement industry.
He said PC makers could still find growth selling to households -- not only because that market is not yet saturated, but because households often purchase more than one computer.
Short term, as investors and analysts await further details from the PC industry as companies report financial results in coming weeks, stocks could be in for further punishment. Mr. Wolf said investors seem to be saying, "PC sales are slowing and there seems to be no bottom."

HEADLINE: Loans Tightening to Young and Deeply Indebted Businesses

BYLINE: By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
As the stock market gyrates and rumors are heard about Wall Street firms' incurring losses on high-yield bonds, investment worries are spreading to new markets.
A quiet credit squeeze is under way for the most heavily indebted corporate borrowers. Banks and other companies are increasingly wary of lending to start-up businesses, companies undertaking leveraged buyouts and other leveraged enterprises. The volume of new loans to such companies, which typically carry bond ratings below investment grade, was 25 percent lower in the first nine months of this year than it was in the corresponding period a year earlier, according to S & P/Portfolio Management Data, an affiliate of Standard & Poor's. 
 "Only the best issuers are able to tap the market right now," said Sam DeRosa-Farag, director of global strategy for leveraged finance at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
A tighter loan market means that many of the small start-up companies that have fed the stock market's rise are finding it hard to obtain the credit they need to grow.
The loan market, although it receives little publicity, is a critical source of financing for corporate borrowers of all stripes. Typically, one or two banks or Wall Street firms take the lead on making a large loan to a company. They then sell pieces of the loan to other firms, a process known as syndication. The riskier the company, the higher the interest rate.
For many years, corporate loans simply stayed on lenders' books until they were repaid. But more recently, lenders have begun trading their holdings, and a relatively active secondary market for corporate loans has developed.
In theory, corporate loans are among the most secure types of investments. The investors in loans have first claim on a company's assets should the company end up in bankruptcy. Next in line among creditors are bondholders, with stockholders having lower priority and assuming more risk.
Start-up companies and deal makers undertaking leveraged buyouts rely on the high-yield-bond and loan markets to satisfy their hunger for hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars in financing. And with high-yield bonds in a slump, these would-be borrowers have increasingly depended on so-called leveraged loans.
But buyers of such loans are increasingly wary of lending to marginal borrowers.
What has many institutional lenders worried right now is the same fear that concerns the high-yield bond market: a rise in corporate defaults. For the 12-month period ending on Aug. 31, 3.87 percent of all high-yield debt was in default, up from 1 percent two years ago, according to Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. With the increase in such defaults, the number of leveraged loans trading at distressed levels now accounts for 16 percent of the market.
Last week, bankers were busy renegotiating loans for two companies, according to investors. A group seeking to acquire Johns Manville, the building materials manufacturer, in a $2.9 billion leveraged buyout was debating whether to invest more cash in the company after weak demand from banks.
Another company, MainStream PCS, postponed efforts to raise more than $1 billion in loans last week, according to bank loan investors, due in part to their wariness about putting money into telecommunications start-ups. MainStream was raising money to finance the purchase of assets from Verizon Communications, Bell Atlantic's corporate successor. A spokesman for Manville declined to comment; a spokesman for MainStream could not be reached for comment.
The week before, a third company, the car battery maker Exide, agreed to give its lenders warrants entitling them to purchase as much as 3 percent of its stock, in order to raise $250 million in bank loans it needed for an acquisition. That marked the first time a large corporate borrower was forced to issue stock to its lenders, according to Christopher Donnelly, a director with Portfolio Management Data.
"This hasn't been the best period for the auto industry," said Bruce Ling, head of syndicated finance at Credit Suisse First Boston, which, together with Citigroup, took the lead on the Exide loan. In addition, Exide is in the midst of a corporate turnaround. "We thought this was a creative way to market the deal to a broader investor base," Mr. Ling said.
But to some investors, Exide's willingness to part with stock smacked of desperation. "A deal that's selling well doesn't need an equity kicker," said David Millison, managing director of Caravelle Advisers, which manages a $2.1 billion investment portfolio that includes senior loans. Indeed, Citigroup and Credit Suisse have yet to sell a majority of the loan, according to investors in the loan market, suggesting some wariness on the part of other lenders. "We are still in the process of selling the deal," Mr. Ling said.
Banks that make leveraged loans are also facing pressure from the government to reduce their exposure to such lending. Last month, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency completed a survey of bank underwriting practices. The report found that the problem loans on banks' books had doubled in the last two years, to $100 billion, or 5.1 percent of the value of all outstanding syndicated loans greater than $20 million.
The good news for borrowers is that banks' role in the leveraged loan market has been shrinking for some time. Commercial banks long dominated the market. But securities firms have expanded their presence, and the wave of banking mergers over the last decade has caused the number of financial institutions participating in this market to dwindle. In the last few weeks alone, J. P. Morgan, Summit Bancorp and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette -- all participants in the leveraged loan market -- have announced plans to be acquired.
As banks reduce their role in the leveraged loan market, private investors have stepped in. Investment funds now account for nearly half the buyers of leveraged loans, according to Portfolio Management Data. That compares with a share of 17 percent in 1994. These investors include mutual funds set up specifically to purchase loans, as well as pools of loans known as collateralized loan obligations that are then sold to insurance companies and the like. (There are also collateralized debt obligations, which invest in a combination of loans, high-yield debt and equities.)
The growth of the mutual funds and collateralized funds helped the market for leveraged loans quadruple in size between 1993 and 1999, rising to $626 billion from $150 billion, according to Donaldson. That worked to the benefit of growing companies eager to borrow money.
But there are signs that this new crop of lenders is even quicker than banks to cut back on lending when markets become wobbly. These nonbank lenders look at new loans with a much more critical eye than was customary in the old, clubby world of banking.
"Banks will often provide credit for relationship reasons," Mr. Donnelly of Portfolio Management Data said. A company seeking a loan might also look to the bank for cash management services, or trading. "What has developed is a large segment of the market that's immune to those kind of issues," Mr. Donnelly said. "They have no bridges to burn."
Mr. Millison of Caravelle is a case in point. As the manager of a collateralized debt obligation fund, he is continuing to buy some new issues, but lately he has been spending more of his cash buying existing loans in the secondary market.
"There is a flight to quality," he said. "The loan market is still fairly robust. But with default rates on the rise, we're being very selective."

HEADLINE: Disarming Leader at Battle on the Hill

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Representative J. Dennis Hastert was elected speaker by his Republican colleagues last year for one reason: He was the opposite of Newt Gingrich.
Where Mr. Gingrich was fiery and combative, blamed for going so far as to shut down the government rather than concede to President Clinton, aides say Mr. Hastert is subdued and devoid of ego, a conciliator who works diligently behind the scenes. 
 Never have the men's opposing styles of leadership been more evident than now, a month before Election Day, when Mr. Hastert must go head-to-head with the president in year-end budget negotiations.
With control of the House at stake, Mr. Hastert is more willing than his predecessor to broker agreements with the president without betraying rank-and-file Republicans, a delicate balancing act. It is an approach that brings out the natural dealmaker in Mr. Clinton, a president who is always eager to split the difference and hash out policy details.
Their dynamic harks back to a political era before Mr. Gingrich, when presidents and speakers from opposing parties -- like President Reagan and Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. -- cajoled and disagreed, all without personal animosity.
"I think we've had a pretty honest, open relationship with each other," Mr. Hastert said in an interview. "I'm not here as a person who tries to play games and set traps. I've always told him I'm not going to try to blow smoke at him, and I'll be a straight shooter."
At a time when profound partisanship still dominates Capitol Hill, their bond -- one built on mutual trust -- has led to several successful legislative partnerships, from fighting drugs in Colombia to combating poverty in America.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert spoke for about 20 minutes one day last week on a range of subjects as different as spending bills and breast cancer research, aides said.
The two men occasionally detour into chitchat about their Labrador retrievers or Mr. Clinton's collection of campaign buttons, but aides say Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert thrive on getting down to business. There is little gamesmanship. There are few existential tangents.
"They can essentially level with each other about what they want or don't want, what they can or can't deliver," said the White House chief of staff, John D. Podesta. "They are not buddy-buddy, but they have a kind of solid relationship of trying to work to get some stuff done."
This solid relationship is often tested by election-year politics. Mr. Clinton must consider the needs of Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic presidential nominee, and Mr. Hastert, who seldom speaks with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican nominee, must nevertheless be sensitive to his standing in the polls. Mr. Bush's success or failure could play a pivotal role in whether Republicans keep control of the House.
In fact, the president and the speaker disagree on many things. When gas prices jumped in the Midwest, Mr. Hastert said the Clinton administration lacked an energy policy. They have also traded sharp words publicly on Republican tax cuts that Mr. Clinton has vetoed.
Despite Mr. Hastert's efforts to find common ground with Mr. Clinton, Congressional Democrats say the process does not work that way on the Hill, where they say Republicans have abandoned bipartisanship on major issues like the importing of prescription drugs.
But Mr. Hastert's collegial relationship with Mr. Clinton is in stark contrast to the open acrimony that prevailed on Capitol Hill under Mr. Gingrich, particularly during the impeachment.
And while House Republicans have not necessarily lost their contempt for Mr. Clinton, they recognize that they must work with him or risk being portrayed as unable to govern. Such a conciliatory approach is made more palatable by Mr. Hastert, who has won over conservatives and moderates by including them in decisions. This tactic has earned the speaker the good will of his colleagues and made it easier for him to govern with a seven-vote majority.
Mr. Hastert first dealt with the White House in 1993 on Mr. Clinton's ill-fated health care plan, when House Republicans were still in the minority. But it was not until Mr. Hastert became speaker in January 1999 that he began working with Mr. Clinton regularly.
From the start, Mr. Hastert took a less combative tack, in part because of his longtime ties to Mr. Podesta, a friend since their paths crossed in college.
The first challenge came within months, when Mr. Hastert backed a Democratic resolution in the House to give symbolic support to Mr. Clinton's air campaign in Kosovo. Even though the measure failed in a tie vote, Mr. Podesta said that the speaker took a "constructive role, a nonpartisan role."
Mr. Hastert recalled telling Mr. Clinton: "We'll work with you on the Kosovo thing. We do have a responsibility in Congress to pay for these things. We don't want to be surprised. We'll work with you, but don't take us for granted."
By fall, the president and the speaker were working closely on a bipartisan plan to encourage investment in cities and rural towns with high unemployment rates. In an unusual display of comity, the two met on the south side of Chicago, a short drive from Mr. Hastert's district, to promote the plan.
At the same time, the annual fall showdown over the budget approached. House conservatives were clamoring for Mr. Hastert not to yield on protecting the Social Security surplus. And he stood firm, telling the president that was one line he could not cross. "I'm just telling you the facts," Mr. Hastert said he told Mr. Clinton.
This impressed conservatives, including Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, who had felt betrayed by Mr. Gingrich's penchant for cutting deals with Mr. Clinton without consulting them, Republicans say. The one bit of advice they have given Mr. Hastert is "trust but verify," said Representative John Shadegg, an Arizona Republican who is a leading House conservative.
In June, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert championed a bill to send $1.3 billion to help train and equip Colombian Army and police forces to fight drug traffickers. The two flew to Colombia to deliver the aid.
Mr. Hastert's opening move in this year's contentious year-end budget battle was so conciliatory it unsettled even some of his strongest allies, including Mr. DeLay. Mr. Hastert offered to compromise on a deal to increase the minimum hourly wage by $1 to $6.15 in exchange for tax breaks for small businesses. Both sides are optimistic they can reach a deal. In the end, Mr. DeLay resigned himself to the trade-off.
What has made for this more cooperative relationship is Mr. Hastert's plain, uncomplicated style. He is impervious to flattery, aides say, and his patience is legendary. Earlier this year he presided over a meeting on a health care bill from 5 p.m. to 2 a.m.
At the White House, currying favor with Mr. Gingrich was easy, officials and Republican aides said; one time, Mr. Gingrich arrived there to find a copy of Time magazine with his picture on the cover lying on a coffee table. "If you want to get to Denny, you have to throw out Bass Master magazine," said one House Republican leadership aide.
Bill Paxon, a former Republican congressman from New York who is now a lobbyist, said with a chuckle: "I've been around the world with Denny, and I've seen him meet with potentates and princes. He is not a guy who is easily impressed. He's more impressed being out at an old car auction with someone who understands engines."
With Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Clinton in the same room, conversations would often veer off into esoteric tangents and there was always an undercurrent of one-upmanship. The fine details of legislation seemed too mundane, aides said.
"Newt was much more a kind of theoretician," Mr. Podesta said in an interview. "At the end of the day, even on stuff he knows he's going to have to give up, he will spend 20 minutes telling you why you are wrong asking for it. Hastert will say, 'I understand you need this, let's move on.' "
Although Mr. Hastert is often dismissive of House Democratic leaders, he takes a much more hands-on approach in negotiations with the White House and is more pragmatic than Mr. Gingrich was, Republican aides said. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert meet privately about four times a year and speak on the telephone about the same number of times.
Election-year forces may yet conspire to derail this collegiality. While there is some hope for a bill to overhaul managed care, aides say Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert are far apart on legislation to provide prescription drug coverage to the elderly and to make attacks on gays a federal hate crime.
On top of that, Mr. Hastert speaks only for House Republicans. Senate Republicans, led by Trent Lott of Mississippi, feel less vulnerable this campaign season and less inclined to compromise. "What Hastert wants and what he can deliver are two different things," Mr. Podesta said.
Mr. Hastert recognizes that the president faces his own pressures. Mr. Clinton tries to be a straight shooter "as much as he can," the speaker said. "He's pretty much laid things out on the table."
But, Mr. Hastert added, "he has a party he must go back to in the Congress."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CALIFORNIA;
House Race Important to Control of Congress Draws Outside Interest and Money

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif., Oct. 3

 BODY:
Except for a few placards and a scattering of advertisements on cable television, there is almost no readily visible evidence that an election is being held this fall in California's 36th Congressional District, the sunny ocean-side strip of Beach Boys country, from just south of Santa Monica to just north of Long Beach.
Still, a hot political battle is being waged in the 36th, one that is expected to go down to the wire and play an important role in deciding which party ends up controlling the House. The two candidates -- Steven T. Kuykendall, the Republican incumbent, and Jane Harman, his Democratic challenger -- are having at each other daily, trying to gain traction, even if little attention is being paid. 
 Available polls indicate that of the 52 House races in California this year, this one might be the closest and might be decided by many of the same tax, health care, education and Social Security issues that are at play in the presidential race.
The district is roughly 40 percent Republican, 40 percent Democrat and 20 percent independent and has a history of swinging from one side to the other in elections. It tends to be moderate on social, cultural and environmental issues, and conservative on fiscal issues. For decades it was heavily dependent on the defense and aerospace industries, and on sun-and-surf tourism, but in recent years it has added a balancing and economically stabilizing mix of entertainment and communications industries, along with numerous ventures related to trade around the Pacific Rim.
Mr. Kuykendall, more moderate than many California Republicans because of the moderate tilt of the 36th, won the seat two years ago by just two percentage points, all but guaranteeing he would face a strong challenge this year. Ms. Harman, also a moderate, held the seat for three terms from 1992 to 1998, giving it up in 1998 to run for governor, unsuccessfully.
National Democratic leaders pressed hard to get her to jump back into the fray this year. She says she agreed because, in her view, Mr. Kuykendall has been little more than a status-quo legislator and is too wedded to Republican plans for huge tax cuts and privatization of some of the investment aspects of Social Security and some of the prescription drug provisions in Medicare.
"The role of a member of Congress is to be a leader," she declared a few days ago in the campaign's first debate. "Steve Kuykendall and I stand in very different places."
Mr. Kuykendall readily agreed with the latter point, asserting that little happened on Capitol Hill to help the residents of the 36th "in the six years that Jane Harman was in Congress."
He contends she is too liberal for the district and out of touch with its residents.
"She's a big-government person and she's out of touch because she's never really bothered to get down on the ground and work the district," he said the other day. "The people of this district have needs, and they want answers to them, reasonable answers like good health care and good jobs and fair taxes. But they are not big-government people."
Each candidate has raised well over $1 million in campaign money. Both say they easily could spend more than $2 million each, about double what House candidates usually spend in California. Certainly spending $2 million would be no great challenge for Ms. Harman, since there is great wealth in her family and she did not hesitate to dip deeply into it in her losing run for governor -- a run in which she failed to carry the 36th District, Mr. Kuykendall likes to point out.
Considerable outside money also is being spent on the race by special interest groups and by campaign committees of the national political parties, and national party figures have been visiting to help the candidates raise even more money. If the contest stays close, along with the overall race for control of the House, still more outside money and visitors almost certainly will flow in.
The Los Angeles-area television market is one of the country's most costly, so neither Mr. Kuykendall nor Ms. Harman has started to run television advertisements, preferring to husband money for blitzes in the final weeks. But the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Natural Resources Defense Council and the state and national Democratic and Republican parties have been running commercials.
One of the hardest hitting is a labor federation advertisement contending that Mr. Kuykendall "voted against guaranteeing seniors prescription medicine under Medicare and backed a private insurance plan that will leave millions without coverage." Mr. Kuykendall says that the advertisement is "completely off-base" and that he has a solid history of supporting comprehensive medical care programs for older people.
Neither Vice President Al Gore nor Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has campaigned recently in the district, but Mr. Gore's running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, caused a splash when he showed up to help Ms. Harman, as did Senator John McCain of Arizona when he came in to help Mr. Kuykendall. In fact, Mr. McCain is due for a return visit in the final days of the campaign.
"What happens here will have great bearing on whether the Republicans maintain control of the majority in the House," he said in his first visit. "A lot is at stake here."
In March, when Mr. Kuykendall and Ms. Harman ran in the state's open primary, he got 42 percent of the vote and she got 41 percent. No independent polls have since been conducted in the district, but each candidate is polling and each says the race remains too close to call.
Mr. Kuykendall says that the polls he has conducted have all shown him and Ms. Harman "running about even, sometimes with me up a couple of points, sometime with her up by a couple." Ms. Harman says her polls have all shown the race "essentially a tie when you factor the possible sampling error."
Nonpartisan political analysts consider the contest a tossup, too.
"The slightest political breeze over the next month could nudge either candidate to victory," said Amy Walter, who follows House contests for the Cook Political Report. "Both sides will be pouring in the television and the mass mailings and working the streets, such as you can work streets in California. If Bush eventually pulls out of the presidential competition in the state to concentrate his efforts elsewhere, that just might give Harman the edge she needs. But then again, suppose Bush hangs in?"

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1565 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ECONOMY;
Roots of Prosperity Reach Past Clinton Years

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Any claim that President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have to credit for the country's long run of prosperity dates to the evening of Aug. 6, 1993. That was when Mr. Gore cast the tie-breaking vote in the Senate on the administration's plan to reduce the budget deficit by raising taxes and restraining spending, a move fraught with political as well as economic risks.
Republicans, not one of whom voted for it, predicted that the legislation would choke what had been a fragile recovery from the 1990-91 recession. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore asserted that it would unlock the economy's potential by easing the pressure on interest rates, and they say history has proved them correct. 
 "Twenty-two million new jobs and the greatest prosperity ever," Mr. Gore said in touting the outcome in his debate with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on Tuesday night.
Even critics of the administration acknowledge that the 1993 budget plan did not have the dire effects Republicans had warned of, and there is a widespread consensus that it helped support the wave of business investment that has characterized the economy in recent years.
But many economists say it is a considerable stretch to suggest, as Mr. Gore often does, that the powerful expansion of the 1990's was born with the passage of that plan.
For one thing, they say, other policy decisions played a role in straightening out the government's finances. Among them were a deficit-reduction bill signed by President George Bush in 1990 and a deal between Mr. Clinton and the Republican Congress in 1997 that cut capital gains taxes while further restricting spending.
Moreover, economists and business executives say, much of what happened to the economy in the 1990's had little to do with Washington and was part of a process that began before Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore took office.
At the same time that the administration was setting out to address the fiscal mess, the Federal Reserve Board's decision to hold interest rates at rock-bottom levels throughout 1992 and 1993 was giving the economy a kick as it emerged haltingly from the recession that ended in March 1991.
In the private sector, companies were starting to see the benefits of painful steps to make themselves more competitive at home and abroad, including plant closings and layoffs of previously secure middle managers.
And perhaps most important, years of technological progress were beginning to click into place in a way that promised tremendous benefits, most notably through a pickup in productivity, the basic measure of efficiency and the best predictor of long-term economic potential.
By acting as a brake on inflation, the surge in productivity allowed the Fed more flexibility in holding down interest rates in the mid- and late-1990's, and helped generate profits and wealth that in turn created huge new tax revenues for the government and turned budget deficits into surpluses.
"Clinton came in at a time when technological innovation was at a sweet spot," said William C. Dudley, chief economist at Goldman Sachs, the investment firm. "He's gotten the benefits of technical innovation that other presidents didn't benefit from. But he didn't do anything to squelch it, and undertook policies to encourage not squelching it."
Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said the economy's recovery in the early years of the administration was mostly driven by the Fed's low interest rates, and that the economic strength in the second half of the 1990's primarily came from investments by business in technology.
"The Clinton administration merits credit for some early deficit reduction and for letting the Federal Reserve have its independence, and that's it," Mr. Jasinowski said. "The amount of credit the administration gets is a bronze medal behind the Federal Reserve and the private sector's expansion of productivity."
When it comes to the economy, the administration often points to its success in opening foreign markets to trade and in helping low-income workers through increases in the minimum wage and an expansion of the tax credit for the working poor. But inside the White House, the 1993 budget plan is seen as the single most crucial turning point.
At the urging of Mr. Gore, as well as advisers like Robert E. Rubin, then chairman of the White House's National Economic Council, and outsiders like Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, Mr. Clinton decided as he took office in 1993 that the economy was being held back largely by the dead weight of the budget deficit, which at that time was projected to grow inexorably.
The administration's 1993 proposal to raise taxes infuriated Republicans, and its plan to restrict spending frustrated Mr. Clinton, who had pledged to increase spending in areas like education. But the administration was betting that there would be an economic payoff in that narrowing the deficit would reduce the government's borrowing needs and would therefore increase the pool of capital available for private investment.
More capital means downward pressure on interest rates. Lower rates would make it more affordable for companies to expand and modernize, and for consumers to buy houses and cars.
There was considerable debate among economists and on Wall Street about whether the strategy would work. In the end, administration officials say, things unfolded just as they had predicted.
As Mr. Gore put it on Tuesday night, the ingenuity of the American people should get credit for the strong economy, but the American people also had plenty of ingenuity eight years ago when the economy was in the doldrums and the deficit was out of control.
"The difference is we've got a new policy," Mr. Gore said in the debate. At times he has been even more explicit about claiming the credit. "I voted and we won and then we've had an economic recovery since then," he said in a speech on the economy late last year.
But while the administration tends to credit the improving fiscal situation with igniting the technology and productivity revolution, many economists and business executives think it was the other way around.
Indeed, there were already powerful forces reshaping the economy before the deficit reduction plan passed.
Five months before Mr. Gore's tie-breaking vote in the Senate that August, engineers at the Intel Corporation in Silicon Valley had introduced their new Pentium chip.
The Pentium was the latest in a string of advances in semiconductor technology and software throughout Silicon Valley that within a few years would help bring the Internet to every desktop while driving computing power up and computer prices down.
And even as the Pentium was being introduced, engineers at Intel, under intense competitive pressure from equally fast and innovative rivals, were halfway through development of a successor that would cram 75 percent more transistors onto a chip and run three times as fast.
"That's when everything really came together," said Albert Yu, a senior vice president at Intel, describing the atmosphere of rapid-fire progress in the technology business in 1993.
Dana G. Mead, who through most of the decade held the No. 1 or No. 2 jobs at Tenneco, a sprawling conglomerate, said that by 1993 his company and others were seeing the combined effects of more aggressive management efforts to cut costs and years of investment in automation and information technology.
"In the early 1990's, after a decade of this investment, we were finally beginning to see real improvement," Mr. Mead said.
So convinced was Mr. Mead that businesses were operating in a fundamentally more efficient way that he took his message directly to Mr. Greenspan at the Fed in 1995. If the Fed could be convinced that corporate America was better at absorbing costs and producing more for less, Mr. Mead said, then perhaps the Fed would not be so quick to raise interest rates when economic growth picked up.
Unbeknownst to Mr. Mead, Mr. Greenspan was already thinking along the same lines. In early 1994, even as the Fed enacted the first in a yearlong series of rate increases, Mr. Greenspan told a closed meeting of the Fed's top policy makers that "something different" was going on.
Long before other analysts noticed anything, Mr. Greenspan raised the possibility of an extraordinary pickup in the growth rate of productivity, which had mysteriously tapered off in the early 1970's and to that point had shown no clear signs of revival, according to transcripts of the meeting made public this year.
Over the next five years, as the Fed chairman became increasingly convinced he was correct, it led him to allow far higher levels of growth in the economy than traditional economic theory held was prudent.
But while Mr. Greenspan had helped convince Mr. Clinton that there would be an economic payoff for deficit reduction, the Fed chairman has always stopped well short of suggesting that there was a direct link between the upturn in productivity and the 1993 budget plan.
Mr. Greenspan takes a much longer view. He often traces today's prosperity to the development of the transistor after World War II, and a whole series of technological advances since then that converged in the 1990's to supercharge the economy in a way that has happened periodically but infrequently throughout history.

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: A Skid Row's Time Drifts Away

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
As if dipped in amber, the old hotels seem frozen in time. Inside, the mostly elderly men seem from another time, as well. Some of them planned to flop down for a few nights and stayed for 50 or 60 years.
Walk up a steep, narrow flight of stairs in one hotel, the Andrew's, at 197 Bowery. Look into its dim lobby. It is like a yellowing photograph. Smoke hangs in the dank air. The cigar-stained walls are a smudgy green. Wooden chairs are lined in neat rows across the patterned-tile floor. Grizzled denizens peer out dirty windows onto the wide street and wonder where the years went. Time seems to operate oddly there. 
 The men inhabit a world in Lower Manhattan that is fading fast, but that has been captured in a new book celebrated at a reading at the Bowery Mission the other night. Their homes are in flophouses with names like the Sunshine, the Providence and the Prince, indistinguishable amid the metamorphosing mile-long stretch of the Bowery that was once the nation's most infamous skid row.
Poetry and dignity can be found in just about every corner if the search is hard enough. The stories of the men in the flophouses are chronicled in a new book, "Flophouse: Life on the Bowery," (Random House), by two documentary producers, David Isay and Stacy Abramson, and a photographer, Harvey Wang.
The authors say that eight flophouses, officially known as lodging houses, that cost from $4.50 to $15 a night remain on the Bowery. Fewer than a thousand people stay in them.
But before World War II, tens of thousands of men slept in the nearly 100 flophouses that lined the Bowery. The cubicles in which they lived were 4 by 6 feet and 7 feet high, smaller than prison cells, with no toilets or kitchens. The walls between the cubicles extended only part way to the ceiling, so each cubicle was topped with chicken wire to thwart residents called lush divers from jumping from one room to another and robbing a possibly passed-out neighbor.
With the end of World War II, the authors wrote, the flophouses began to empty as returning veterans were greeted by the G.I. Bill and other new programs that left fewer of them homeless. A change in the city's housing code in 1955 also outlawed the construction of such cubicles.
Whether the decline of the flophouses is good or bad, or simply just a change, is not a debate taken up by the authors.
"We don't have a social agenda to suggest that they shouldn't exist or should," Mr. Isay said at the reading. " It's more of a document, a record, a social history."
The book began as a radio documentary that was broadcast on National Public Radio in 1998 about one flophouse, the Sunshine Hotel. For the book, the authors interviewed 50 men who stay in four flophouses on the Bowery.
The authors say that each flophouse is like a self-contained society, with its own distinctive character, clientele and internal economy. Most of the residents are permanent, and some of them, for example, pay fellow residents to perform small tasks.
The atmosphere at the Sunshine might be described as carnivalesque. Bruce Davis, 51, can be found in the lobby, seated in the lotus position, airing his views on a multitude of subjects. Mr. Davis runs as many as 35 errands a day for other residents, such as trying to buy hard liquor on a Sunday.
He recalled what led to his move into the Sunshine about 10 years ago. "I didn't want to have nothing to do with nobody," he said in a soft Tennessee accent.
Mr. Davis said of the place, "It wasn't what I wanted, but I had my troubles."
That afternoon, the hotel's manager, Nathan Smith, was preparing to visit a resident, a former heroin user, who was in the hospital waiting to undergo a leg amputation. A sign on a wall in the hotel lobby said that the resident welcomed visitors, "especially those who owe him money."
The hotel and other flophouses are a haven for loners and men who want to drop out of life, the authors said. Mr. Smith said that many residents at the Sunshine had emotional disorders, and that the hotel is used as a dumping ground by psychiatric hospitals.
Not far down the street stands the White House Hotel. According to the authors, the hotel was said to have earned its name because it accepted only whites for most of its history. The flophouses, which opened around the turn of the last century, were at one time almost entirely populated by white men. Now, the White House and the Sunshine are the most diverse in race and age.
A business card from the White House, a four-story hotel that opened in 1917, indicates just how much the skid-row Bowery has changed. The card states that the hotel is geared toward students and backpackers, and on a recent afternoon, a few women, including one with a backpack, were staying there.
The Andrew's Hotel, though, remains the most timeless of all. It is home to old-timers like John Knudsen, 82, who said he moved there in 1941. Mr. Knudsen recalled how he used to wait at the window, and would leap to his feet when he saw the truck picking up day laborers pull up. "People didn't hang around back then," he explained. "Everyone had a job."
He is resigned to spending the rest of his days at the Andrew's, looking out the window."What are you going to do? There's no place to go," Mr. Knudsen said, working a lighted Marlboro between his fingers.
Mike Gatto, the 80-year-old owner and manager of the Andrew's, said he doubted that the hotel would survive after he retired. He said there was no future in the business. In any event, he said, flophouse residents have plenty of places to go -- public housing, hospitals and cemeteries.
