HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN 2000: The New Jersey Senate Debate;
Excerpts From Debate Between Bob Franks and Jon S. Corzine

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate between New Jersey senatorial candidates Jon S. Corzine and Representative Bob Franks, as recorded by The New York Times. Tom Moran of The Star-Ledger was the moderator. More excerpts are available at The New York Times on the Web at www.nytimes.com.

TOM MORAN -- Welcome to the first debate between the major candidates for the U.S. Senate from New Jersey. They are Democrat Jon Corzine, former chairman of the investment firm Goldman Sachs, who is seeking his first public office, and Republican Bob Franks, a member of Congress since his election in 1992 and former chairman of the state Republican Party.
The debate is sponsored by The Star-Ledger. It's being broadcast on News 12 New Jersey, CN8 and C-Span. The candidates are competing for the seat held by Democrat Frank Lautenberg, who is retiring from the Senate after 18 years. . . . 
 We'll skip opening statements and go directly to questions from our three-person panel. They are Ron Marsico of The Star-Ledger, Lynn Doyle of CN8, and Christopher King of News 12 New Jersey. Ron Marsico, let's begin with your question. The first goes to Mr. Corzine.

RON MARSICO -- Mr. Corzine, yesterday the United Nations Security Council condemned Israel in a resolution for excessive force in the Gaza and the West Bank. The United States abstained. Do you agree with the United Nations action?

JON CORZINE -- . . .
I have the view that the United States voted properly by abstaining. I don't think the United Nations needs to be intervening in an internal matter, which I think is very clearly consistent with a history in the United Nations, not recognizing the rights and responsibilities of Israel to protect its own national security.

MORAN -- Mr. Franks?

BOB FRANKS -- I think the vote by the United States was a mistake. I think it's most important that as we conduct our foreign policy that we stand as a reliable friend for our allies. We have no reliable ally in the Middle East more than the State of Israel. . . . We have no choice but to veto that type of anti-Israel resolution.

MORAN -- The prime minister has said if the demonstrations don't settle down by Monday night that he'll allow his army to remove restraint. Is there a point at which you would say that's too much, Israel, we have to break company with you, those tactics go too far?

FRANKS -- The peace process is all about developing a secure and reliable peace for every country in that very dangerous region. The people of Israel have a right to go to work and live in peace. The Palestinians have a right, as well, to occupy portions of that land, and this negotiating is difficult and tenuous. But we can't allow violence to override the peacemaking process. Israel has a right to protect herself, and if Arafat will not stop the terror, then people are going to have to pay the consequences. . . .

LYNN DOYLE -- Good morning, gentlemen. Congressman Franks, my first question to you is on the issue of abortion. Your position on the abortion plank of the Republican Party differs from the traditional Republicans in that you support a woman's right to choose in certain situations. Can you explain to us under what conditions you feel a woman, or perhaps even a girl, could end a pregnancy?

FRANKS -- I strongly support the Roe v. Wade Supreme Court decision. I believe that in that process a woman and her physician and her clergyperson have the right, a woman ultimately, the right to make a decision as to what to do about her pregnancy.
But having said that, I think it's a national disgrace that we have the reliance on abortion that we do. I think we need to work together as a community to reduce the need for abortions, and we need to do that by working together. I have supported certain restrictions, including a ban on partial-birth abortions, which in my judgment, are overwhelmingly medically unnecessary and represents the most horrendous medical procedure that I can think of. I view it as a form of infanticide.
For 20 years I strongly supported parental notification laws. . .

CORZINE -- I'm unequivocally a pro-choice candidate for the United States Senate. I believe strongly in Roe v. Wade. I believe that the primary issue is protecting the life and health of the mother, and I think these decisions are private decisions, ones that should be left to the choice of the woman, her doctor and the people in her family and those that she looks to for spiritual guidance. . . .

CHRISTOPHER KING -- . . . Mr. Corzine, my first question is to you. You've proposed an ambitious plan to provide universal access to health care. At its core is a requirement that businesses provide coverage to their employees and cover most of the cost. Would that hurt small businesses, and is it politically possible?

CORZINE -- Well, I think that it would not hurt small business because I would create a situation where the employee takes up part of the responsibility for paying for the insurance, with support on a means-tested basis for the employee. And I would work to encourage regional pools, which the federal government then would provide subsidies to. . . .

FRANKS -- To me there's only one thing that's more unfortunate than an employee without health care insurance, and that's an employee without a job. If we mandate health coverage on all small businesses, even those that today are existing on the margin, we will cause a rapid increase in unemployment among those who are less skilled and may find it more difficult to get placed in a job elsewhere.
I believe that it's important to give small businesses and those who are self-employed fair treatment under the tax code. . . .

MORAN -- The Kaiser Family Foundation sponsored a study that looked at what impact change in the tax rules would have on expanding health insurance coverage and found that it would be less than a million additional people that would, under your proposal, would receive insurance. There are 45 million without it now. Is there something else you can propose, or is this problem just too big for us to solve? How else do we get to those other 44 million, let's say we do everything you suggest.

FRANKS -- I don't believe that the answer exists in Hillary Clinton's universal health care program, which Jon talked about during the primary campaign. . . . By permitting pooling together, by permitting 100 percent deductibility for the self-employed as well as for those employees in a small business where the employer doesn't cover them, we can move to begin to close that gap.

MORAN -- And Mr. Corzine, if small businesses do have to pay this bill, even with a pool you would set up and with a subsidy, they seem to take it quite seriously -- this is something that they consider a tremendous burden to them. How do you square that with your belief that it would be manageable?

CORZINE -- Well, I think they have to understand that it is going to be a co-pay arrangement with the employees and there will be support for the employees based on means-testing, and that there will be substantial subsidizations to these regional pools that Congressman Franks is talking about, it's the same thing that I'm suggesting. If that's the case, the cost will be less, and frankly, the idea of using tax deductions for low-income workers who may not even be paying taxes, maybe even in an earned-income tax credit basis, is not going to provide the kind of access at health care that's going to make sense for a lot of the folks that work in these low-paying jobs.
And the idea that this is going to cause unemployment I think is about like saying raising the minimum wage in 1996 was going to throw us into a recession. The fact is the economy has continued to grow, grow very effectively. . . .

MORAN -- You supported an increase in the minimum wage, didn't you, Mr. Franks?

FRANKS -- I did, both back in 1996 and again this year to increase it further by a dollar over the course of two years. . . .

MARSICO -- Congressman Franks, in 1995, you were the only member of the New Jersey Congressional delegation to vote for a revision in the Clean Water Act, an action that environmentalists considered so awful they dubbed it the dirty water act. In 1998 the environmentalists, however, endorsed you. This time they've endorsed your opponent Mr. Corzine. Have you had a change of heart on the environment, and if you had it to do all over again, would you vote differently in that 1995 bill?

FRANKS -- I'm proud of my record protecting New Jersey's precious environment. I'm proud particularly of the fact that just two years ago both the Sierra Club and the League of Conservation Voters stepped into a very competitive congressional election involving my candidacy and both of those organizations endorsed me. I'm proud of that record. . . .

CORZINE -- Well, I think the classification of the dirty water bill speaks for itself. It took away 80 percent -- protection, federal protection of 80 percent of the wetlands in New Jersey. It cut back on funding. It made for the E.P.A. and OSHA, took away standards and enforcement standards, and was a serious denigration of our environmental laws. And these kinds of actions have continued with votes that the congressman continues with -- supports dredging of the Delaware River, which environmentalists are very, very much opposed to. . . . Vote after vote on funding for E.P.A. and environmental agencies are missing in Congressman Franks's record. That's why the Environmental Federation, the Sierra Club, I think, have turned to a positive view about my record and what I will stand for. . .

DOYLE -- Mr. Corzine, I'd like to address the so-called 800-pound gorilla that has dominated this campaign, and quite frankly, that's your money -- both your personal fortune and the amount of money's that been spent on this campaign. So far it's a record-breaking $50 million, as compared to the roughly $3 million spent by Congressman Franks. He's accused you of trying to buy the state of New Jersey because you don't have a public record on which to stand. Can you explain to us why you'd need to spend so much money to secure this seat?

CORZINE -- Well, first of all, I'd make the point that elections are about ideas. If people stand for a prescription drug benefit for seniors, if they stand for registration and licensing of all guns, if they stand with protecting and securing Social Security and locking up and making sure that it's not privatized over a period of time, I think those ideas are what voters will ultimately pull the lever when the go into the voting booth about. I think there is an assumption that voters aren't smart enough to determine who it is that will represent their interests best.
We were -- we do not have 23 years of experience in political life. I have a very public record in my private life. I've been very active in my community. I have a foundation which I've revealed almost everything about. People know the kinds of things I've stood for. I've spent 18 months being very clear about the positions that I'll fight. . .

MORAN -- Mr. Franks?

FRANKS -- Jon, you know, the idea that's a center focus here is the idea that you're trying to buy a seat in the United States Senate. That's the lens through which the people of New Jersey are looking at this contest. That's why interest exists across the country. Because you've shattered every all-time spending record to try to buy a seat in the United States Senate. . . .
I admire success you've had on Wall Street. But I wish, in order to tell people where all this money is coming from, that today you'd tell us that you're going to disclose finally your complete and unabridged income tax returns for the last 10 years. . . .

MORAN -- Mr. Franks, can I ask you on that question, which has been a nagging question for the entire campaign -- on your tax returns, Mr. Corzine -- what is it that you're looking for that you can't find in the Senate disclosure forms? Can you tell us the kind of thing that would raise an alarm with you, the type of investment you would consider out of bounds? Are you worried he's invested in child labor or, you know, trades with Iraq? Give us some specifics, and then I'll ask Mr. Corzine, can you reassure us on those specifics?

FRANKS -- Tom, as I understand it, Goldman Sachs owns hundreds if not thousands of companies. And back in the days when it was a partnership, before last year each one of the partners had to detail their involvement in those investments. But now that Goldman's gone public, Mr. Corzine merely declares on his personal financial disclosure form his interest in Goldman Sachs.
What we don't know is all the companies that Goldman owns. What are their past practices? I candidly don't know specifically what I'm looking at or for, but I think the people of New Jersey have a right to look at the totality of the personal finances of someone who's seeking one of the most important positions of public trust anywhere in this country.

MORAN -- If you could name certain things that would bother you, I'll ask Mr. Corzine, do your investments come from that certain thing ----

FRANKS -- No, Tom, this is a threshold issue. Either you're going to come clean with the people of New Jersey and put it all out for us to review -- I'm not going to play the game of is this in it or is that in it. That would be entirely misleading and disingenuous. Let's -- it's a threshold decision. Do you believe in full, unabridged public disclosure, or are you going to try to hide it?

MORAN -- Mr. Corzine, you've said you have an agreement with your partners at Goldman Sachs not to release certain information. Should that agreement take precedence over the understandable concern of a lot of New Jersey voters that you are buying this election?

CORZINE -- Tom, it's a legal, binding agreement. I think that people in New Jersey have the common sense enough to know that I shouldn't start my public career by breaking a legal agreement. It makes no sense for one to sign contracts and commit yourself, just as I am going to commit myself to fulfill the kinds of pledges that I want to make trying to solve the problems of the people New Jersey would like to see dealt with, by breaking a contract.
And we have gone beyond the letter of the law by releasing exactly what my assets are, what the range of income that comes from them. I have put up summaries that have been certified by public accountants of what my 1040's are back to 1996. We have released the tax returns of my foundation, which are not subject to these issues, listed everything that we have given contributions to right up through September. We have pledged that we will put my assets in a blind trust if elected. And I will release my tax returns once I am free of these confidentiality agreements for the years going forward.
And it is very clear, I think, that if anyone wants to review any of this material, it's on my Web site: www.votecorzine.org, and people can make their own assessment of whether I have been fully disclosed about what my financial ----

MORAN -- Do you think it was a mistake to make that agreement, given that you're making a run at public office?

CORZINE -- When you're in a partnership, we have -- I have signed an agreement, starting in 1980, every other year, right up to the end of my career at Goldman Sachs.

MORAN -- Mr. Franks, what about that? Are you asking him to break a legal agreement?

FRANKS -- You know, Tom, this is becoming a bipartisan tradition in New Jersey. When you run for statewide office you release your tax returns. Senator Torricelli, who's here in the audience today, releases his. Governor Whitman releases hers. Jim McGreevey, the last Democratic candidate for governor, released his. For the last 10 years I've released mine. It just seems to me that if we're going to deal with this issue of public cynicism and public mistrust of elected officials in both political parties, we need to go the extra mile to engender their trust and their confidence in the institutions of the government.
I don't think Jon's purposefully trying to cause greater cynicism or disrespect for the government, but unintended consequences are going to flow from this decision. People are going to question this entire political system.

MORAN -- Let's go to the next question. Chris?

KING -- Congressman Franks, in the presidential debate last week, Al Gore criticized the tax cut proposed by George W. Bush, saying it was too large and that more than 40 percent of the dollars would go to the richest 1 percent of the population. Do you share those concerns, and would you vote for the Bush tax cut package?

FRANKS -- I do share some of those concerns, and I would not vote for the Bush tax cut package as it is today. I'm concerned that it would crowd out other compelling priorities. This nation should first meet the obligations that we've already pledged. We need to save Social Security. We need to save Medicare. We need to continue to pay down the national debt. We need to first honor the commitments we've already made.
Now, having said that, I want to attack immediately the marriage penalty tax. That marriage penalty imposes an obligation on some 800,000 New Jersey couples by forcing them to pay $1,400 per year in higher federal taxes. Mr. Corzine says he wants marriage penalty relief, but the bill that he supports wouldn't give essentially any relief here in New Jersey . . . Let's enact the marriage penalty relief bill now, and get rid of one of the most onerous features of our current tax code.

MORAN -- Mr. Corzine?

CORZINE -- Well, this is one of the most important issues for comparison of Congressman Franks and myself. Last -- this month, in New Jersey Business Week -- or Monthly -- he proposed that we eliminate the capital gains tax. He talked about across-the-board tax cuts. He talked about the marriage penalty proposal that he's talked about, which actually is a new way of providing tax cuts for high-income folks, in addition to the folks that do deserve marriage penalty relief, and an elimination of the inheritance tax. If you add all those up and just divide by two what Governor Bush's proposal is with regard to tax cuts on an across-the-board basis, you come up to 1.8 trillion in tax cuts. That will foreclose anyone from having the ability to invest in our education, protect our environment, our health care, shore up Medicare, all of the things that I think people want to see us invest in. . .

MORAN -- Just for the record, are you for eliminating the capital gains tax?

FRANKS -- As a long-term policy objective, we should reduce the tax rate on capital gains. We still have one of the highest rates on taxation on capital gains anywhere in the industrialized world. It will help us create more jobs and economic growth and prosperity if we work to continue to reduce the tax on capital gains.

MORAN -- Do want to address the question of distribution?

CORZINE -- Well first of all, the statement in the magazine written by Bob is eliminate the capital gains tax. The view that I take is that we should have targeted tax cuts including, by the way, with respect to addressing a number of the factors with regard to the marriage penalty. I both want to raise and equalize the standard deduction for married couples and I also want to raise the top of the 15 percent tax bracket will take care of that $40,000 couple that Bob is talking about.
I believe that we need to take careful aim at where we do have targeted tax cuts, working for long-term care, earned income tax credit expansion at the lower end where people are struggling to make ends meet. . . .

KING -- Mr. Corzine, aside from universal access to health care and long-term care, you propose access to universal preschool and higher education. How much will all this cost? Can we afford it? Can you name a significant social program that you might oppose?

CORZINE -- Well, I'll tell you one thing it won't cost is the estimates that I see on Bob Franks's Web site. We're talking about hope scholarships which provide access for middle-income families to higher education. We've used the same assumptions that Georgia used to start out, of the number of high school graduates, the number of people who apply to colleges, the number of people who go to colleges, maintain B averages over a period of time. And we come out with a $2.2 billion program on an annual basis. Congressman Franks is saying that will cost 58 billion. Sometimes I think that's one of the reasons that maybe people are cynical about political debates.
Similarly when I'm talking about preschool I am talking about fully funding out Head Start. Making sure that the 55 percent of the kids who are eligible for Head Start actually have access at it. That'll cost about $5 billion a year and Congressman Franks is talking that this will cost about, if I read his website correctly, $38 billion a year.
Just like all the other assumptions with regard to a lot of my programs that The Star-Ledger has gone through and scrubbed down completely, come out with 110, he's says they're 756 billion, I'd say are $60 billion programs.

MORAN -- Mr. Franks?

FRANKS -- Tom, I was really looking forward to see which Jon Corzine was going to show up for today's debate. Whether it was the Jon Corzine who went before the Democratic primary voters this spring and declared, with $21 million worth of TV spots, universal long-term care, universal higher education. There were no conditions attached. There were no caveats. It would've taken just about a half a second to add the word "access," universal access.
But that's not what Jon chose to do. He went way beyond that and promised universal higher education and universal long-term care. Only now that I guess his handlers have described to him just how extraordinarily expensive that would be, he's regrouped. Now he's got universal access proposals.
In higher education it means you have to now maintain a B average. You have to choose a state school. And most importantly, the state will have to agree to fund fully half the cost.
Jon, I don't know, was it you in the primary or is this you today?

MORAN -- Do -- go ahead and answer that.

CORZINE -- Bob, the programs that I proposed in the primary are the same programs that I am now talking to the voters of New Jersey about. Same Web site discussion. No alterations, no changes. The same discussions we had in the primary with Governor Florio and the debates we had there are the same ones we're talking about today.

MORAN -- Let me take a closer look at one of those. Long-term care, universal long-term care, which Congressman Franks says would cost over $500 billion dollars a year.

CORZINE -- Five hundred and fifty.

MORAN -- O.K. And you have a proposal that would cost two-and-a-half?

CORZINE -- Two-and-a-half billion unless we have a refundable piece for low-income Americans, which if we have the budget room, I would implement. As in all of the programs I've talked about, I would not spend us back into deficit spending, which would be the case if we implemented all these tax cuts their people are talking about. And I want to make sure we execute these in an affordable manner.

MORAN -- I want to follow up on his point though, that when you say I propose universal long-term care -- or health care, other things -- but to look at long-term care, the 2.6 billion would finance a modest tax cut that Clinton has proposed. Correct? That's not exactly universal --

CORZINE -- The refundable piece would make major inroads and to people who have low income. And I've also, if you read further than just going through the tax credit, we've talked about trying to implement programs that would allow for the prepayment of life insurance to purchase long-term care. We've talked about the ability to possibly restructure pension funds to also support that. And tax deductibility with regard to the purchase of it.
So it's not just money. There are a whole series of steps that can lead to effective long-term care.
Right now, we have a universal long-term care program developing. It's people spending themselves down into Medicaid and allowing the most expensive source of funding for long-term care developing through the Medicaid system.

MORAN -- When you say universal preschool, that's different than an expansion of Head Start, isn't it? Because not everybody ----

CORZINE -- Head Start -- if Head Start were made available to everyone, then there would be access at -- for everyone that met the economic means test -- then there would be access at universal preschool.

MORAN -- And your health care plan you would expect, of the 45 million who don't have health insurance now, I understand you expect roughly half of them to get insurance through your plan?

CORZINE -- It is voluntary, so it will not necessarily lead to universal absolute coverage but it will provide universal access, particularly when you put it together with expanding CHIPS -- Children's Health Insurance Program -- not only for the kids that are available, but to the parents, and also, including offering Medicare to people 55 to 65.

MORAN -- O.K. Mr. Franks?

FRANKS -- Tom, this is unbelievable to me. Universal long-term care for $2.5 billion. You know, it's not me, Jon, it's the newspapers in New Jersey and New York who've looked at your program and made the assessment that it represents the largest expansion in the federal government in history. Everybody in America knows you've got the most liberal agenda running anywhere in the country today, and the most expensive. You say you won't backslide into deficits. You will push us back into deficits, and I want to honor the commitments that we've already made to Social Security, to Medicare, to paying down the debt, and yes, to getting rid of the marriage penalty tax. In my judgment, you're going to crowd out those options by these huge new spending programs that only now you're trying to scuttle back to try to see if you can reconfigure and make them sound as if they're affordable. But Jon, they're not. There's only 100 cents in every dollar. I think you would have appreciated that from Wall Street, but I've had to make the tough decisions to finally balance the federal budget.
And what you also have said, in the Democratic primary, was there will be times when we'll have to engage in some modest level of deficit spending. Jon, government doesn't know moderate levels of deficit spending. You break that balanced budget and we're going to go in a very slippery slope steep down.

CORZINE -- Tom, I have pledged over and over on the campaign trail that we will not go into deficit spending, unless we enter into a recession, when the automatic stabilizers in our economy for unemployment insurance and other things kick in to cause that. I will not vote for any bill that will put us into deficit. And furthermore, I won't vote for any tax increase, except possibly with regard to tobacco taxes, in the first six years that I am in the United States Senate. And the whole idea that we're going to have $1.8 trillion in tax cuts -- and if Congressman Franks follows the leader the way he has in the House, we are going to have even more tax cuts that are going to leave us with no ability to pay down the debt, no ability to invest in our educational system, no ability to do the things that I think the voters of New Jersey would like to see us invest in. Investing actually will lead to progress and prosperity as we go forward, and I think it's absolutely essential that we have a sound, prudent fiscal policy. I know what real numbers are. I've been working with them for 25 years in the private sector, putting together budgets, making them work, showing up and making sure that you're held accountable for them. I'm talking about real numbers.

HEADLINE: Immigrants in the Middle;
Some Workers Want a Union; Others Fear the Costs

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 8

 BODY:
The fortresslike bakery was founded nine decades ago by an immigrant from Italy who sold bread from a bake shop in a barn. The founder, John Joseph Cassone, prospered by offering baked goods to fellow immigrants in a town that then, as now, had an earthier, more working-class feel than the rest of Westchester County.
Over the years, the J. J. Cassone Bakery has grown into a modern giant with 250 employees, several 100-foot-long ovens and an elaborate system of conveyors, mixing machines and steam-filled vats. Its 100-yard-long, red-brick walls dominate a neighborhood where two families often squeeze into a single home and immigrants from Latin America have supplanted those from Italy. 
 Now, this sizable industrial enterprise finds itself in an unusually fierce labor battle between management and union. In the sprawling, sweaty room at the heart of the bakery, some workers complain about scorching temperatures, on-the-job injuries and compulsory 72-hour weeks. Some workers -- almost all the workers are immigrants, many of them illegal -- say co-workers sometimes faint from heat and exhaustion.
"I came to the United States because it was the country of my dreams, but at this point it's turned into a nightmare," said Roberto Lostaunau, a 39-year-old from Peru who is a leader in an effort to unionize the bakery's workers. "This is a nightmarish company."
His view is not shared by all. For some workers at the bakery, like Antonio Torres, an immigrant from El Salvador who works from 4:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. placing bread and bagels into the ovens, the long hours provide the paycheck he needs to support his family.
"When you work a lot of hours, you make a lot of money," Mr. Torres said.
The labor battle at Cassone (pronounced kuh-SOHN) has become a national cause for the union movement, and underscores labor's stepped-up efforts to organize more immigrants, including illegal ones. But the Cassone battle pits immigrant against immigrant, with some looking to the union as the savior for their problems in the workplace, while others see it as an unwelcome intruder.
Seemingly out of place in genteel Westchester, the dispute is exceptional for its bitterness. So far, it has involved firings, litigation, unionization votes and divisions among immigrants who come from the same countries, but who have very different sensibilities and desires. The battle reflects the labor movement's hopes -- and problems -- in dealing with a fast-changing labor force in which legal and illegal immigrants account for an ever-larger share of the working population.
Convinced that immigrants are ripe for labor's message, union officials have devoted extensive manpower to try to organize the bakery's workers, who they say are horribly exploited. But to labor's surprise and chagrin, many of the immigrant workers praise Cassone's 72-hour weeks and even its modest wages, viewing them as the key to achieving their American dream of buying a house and a family car.
Several immigrant workers said management used an especially worrisome tactic to keep the union out. They said supervisors threatened to call in the Immigration and Naturalization Service to clean out the place if the workers voted to unionize -- something management has denied. In recent years, unions have had a hard time unionizing workplaces with many illegal immigrants because these workers are often fearful of deportation and reprisals by management.
In some ways, the labor war in working-class Port Chester grows out of tensions roiling just beneath the surface of Westchester's affluence. As in other wealthy suburbs, the county's economy is increasingly relying on immigrant laborers. But for these workers, it is often a daunting challenge to make ends meet in a county where housing, and so much else, is so expensive.
At the heart of the unionization drive is the alluring pitch that a union contract could provide such large pay increases that the bakery's employees would need to work just 40 hours a week, not 72, to support their families and begin their climb to the middle class.
But several workers at Cassone said the union has misunderstood the immigrants' desires and work ethic. Indeed, the main reason that several workers gave for voting against unionization was the fear that a contract would limit them to 40 hours a week. Mr. Torres said that thanks to the 72-hour weeks, he has been able to buy a house, support his wife and three children and take a two-week family vacation to Disney World.
"If you work just 40 hours a week, there's no way you can afford a vacation like that," said Mr. Torres, who has worked at the bakery for 11 years. "Do you think you can work 40 hours a week and still buy a house?"
For most of the bakery's workers, pay runs from $6.50 to $11 an hour, which translates to about $13,500 to $23,000 a year, based on a 40-hour workweek. But for a 72-hour week, with time-and-a-half pay for overtime, those hourly earnings add up to $29,000 to $49,000 a year.
Officials from the Bakery and Confectionary Workers Union, the labor group that is trying to organize Cassone, say that if management paid the $11 to $15 an hour that some unionized bakeries offer, the employees would not need to work 72-hour weeks.
Mr. Lostaunau, the union supporter, has a far grimmer view of the bakery and its long hours than Mr. Torres does. Mr. Lostaunau, who spent 20 years working for a Peruvian oil company before moving to New York, complained about earning $7.10 an hour, about the exhausting hours, and about the withering heat from working alongside an oven. He also complained of injuring his left shoulder when he slipped on a floor slick from water and flour.
He tensed up, his expression turning angry, as he described an episode several months ago in which he was not scheduled to take a break for five hours. After four hours of loading loaves into the oven, he recalled, he left his work station to use the bathroom, not being able to wait any longer. Mr. Lostaunau, who was working the 3 a.m.-to-3 p.m. shift, said his boss told him he was being fired for leaving his oven without permission, even though he said he had found a co-worker to substitute for him.
"My boss was yelling and screaming and cursing at me, and he told me, 'You're fired,' " Mr. Lostaunau said, noting that his boss, after cooling down, reduced the punishment to a three-day suspension.
Marc L. Silverman, the bakery's lawyer, denied that Mr. Lostaunau had been punished for merely going to the bathroom. He said Mr. Lostaunau had been punished for taking 15 minutes to go, and for not having someone substitute for him.
J. J. Cassone's managers said that the bakery was a contented place and that the union had manipulated immigrant workers into maligning their employer.
"If they're trying to make us out to be the bakery equivalent of a sweatshop and a labor law violator, they're dead wrong," Mr. Silverman said. "Many of our employees are happy. They can work substantial hours and can make $35,000 and up a year in what is basically a minimum-wage industry."
Mr. Silverman said the workers did not want a union. He pointed to last December's election, in which 118 workers voted against joining the union and 37 voted in favor of joining.
Union officials said the election had been poisoned by what they insisted was illegal behavior by management. They said management had fired four of the most outspoken union supporters to chop the head off the organizing drive and to scare other workers. They said management threatened to close the bakery if the workers backed a union.
Federal law prohibits companies from firing workers or retaliating in any other way for supporting a union.
Several workers said management's most effective weapon was its threat to have illegal immigrant workers deported if they voted to unionize.
"They would tell us they're going to fire us if the union wins," said a pencil-thin illegal immigrant from Guatemala, who would give only his first name, Antonio. "They'd say they're going to get rid of all the undocumented people. That made a lot of people very afraid."
The union has pointed to such threats in urging the National Labor Relations Board to overturn December's election. Yet some workers back management's version of events.
"Nobody talked about getting rid of the undocumented workers," said Gustavo Cardenas, 37, an immigrant from Mexico who works in shipping and receiving. "That's a lie."
Jose Mario Castro, a 33-year-old from El Salvador, said he concluded that a union was needed soon after he began working at Cassone seven years ago. Most weeks, he put in 67 hours a week cleaning the machinery, often working months at a time without a day off.
"For five and a half years, I worked seven days a week," Mr. Castro said. "I had no days off. We need a union because of the very low wages and for better treatment. Nobody can complain by themselves."
Mr. Castro said management fired him in April after he arrived at work a half-hour late. Workers are rarely punished for minor lateness, he said, asserting that he was dismissed because he had campaigned for the union.
Mr. Silverman said all the fired workers were dismissed for legitimate reasons, like lateness.
Many workers say no union is needed because the bakery provides pensions, sick days and four-week vacations to longtime workers.
"This is the best job around," said Mr. Cardenas, the shipping worker. "The union can't give me anything that I can't get from the company."

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: New Economy;
Finding some middle ground in a world obsessed with the new and impatient with the old.

BYLINE: By John Schwartz 

 BODY:
HERE comes that darned future again, threatening to tear everything up. Take a look, for instance, at the latest issue of Fortune, which puts the star power of Ben Affleck on the cover and declares, "The future of the Internet: Everything is about to change -- again."
The world is obsessed with the new, and impatient with the old. Our futurists have taken the undeniable changes wrought by the computer and the Internet -- changes that justify the overused word "revolutionary" -- and try to take the concept farther, into some kind of technological Reign of Terror. It is not enough to have a revolution, they seem to say: the past must be wiped out as well. 
 The Internet, the seers have boldly asserted, will be the end of the retailer, as brick-and-mortar stores give way to clicks. The end of the university, because online learning will bring the Ivory Tower down. Of the newspaper (say it isn't so!). The end of taxation, because electronic payments will be untraceable. And geography? So yesterday, now that the Net allows you to be anywhere.
But there are other voices, people who say the end is NOT nigh, and they aren't just professional neo-Luddites. John Seely Brown has surfed technology's long wave for decades as the head of Xerox's famed Palo Alto Research Center, the birthplace of such innovations as the mouse-driven computers. And while the company famously fumbled in bringing its scientists' brainchildren to market -- we use Macintoshes and Windows PC's today, not Xeroxes -- no one can deny that Xerox has served as one of the most creative centers for technology the world has ever known.
And from that, Mr. Brown, 60, has learned a measure of humility. He has been at the forefront and recognizes that evolution is more common than revolution -- and that what's really interesting about the new economy might be what's old about it.
The Internet can transmit information, but conveying knowledge is a much bigger job. Knowledge comes from understanding the context of information, seeing it in practice and learning the things that are tacitly understood but rarely stated. And so change is less radical than we might expect.
Mr. Brown has laid out his views in a recent book, "The Social Life of Information," co-written by Paul Duguid, a researcher at the University of California at Berkeley. The book takes on the facile predictions -- especially the strain of prophesy he calls "endism." He recounts ruefully that his own company was part of the group in the mid-1970's that predicted the "paperless office."
"That was a great idea, we thought, 20 years ago, until we grew up," he said in an interview. Paper, he noted, is genuinely useful and dependable. "A piece of paper never runs out of power. You never have to reboot a piece of paper. A piece of paper never turns blue and says 'sorry: unrecoverable error.' " Most of all, he observed, "paper has infinitely better resolution than the world's best displays today."
We don't just read the data in a book. We do, indeed, judge a book by its cover, and from other cues. We feel its weight, espy the cut and texture of its pages, and assess the underlinings and wear it may have gotten from its last reader.
Geography, too, remains important, because the world is not just made up of bits of information. Silicon Valley flourishes because it is a physical community. And Mr. Brown, who projects a slightly old-world look with his beard and maroon suspenders, asks for a face-to-face meeting to hash out his ideas most effectively.
To explain what he means by the "social life" of information, Mr. Brown points to a Xerox project to build a database of information about fixing copying machines. To begin with Xerox did something smart: it hired an anthropologist to study how its copier repair staff really did their jobs.
What Xerox discovered was that they were often most productive over coffee before work started in the morning. They would toss around stories and build a living database. So Xerox tried to augment that kaffeeklatsch by equipping the workers with two-way radios, and then created a database of stories, not just procedures, that were grounded in practice. The process turned out to be so useful that, at a convention of copier repair staff, the one who contributed the most useful tips received a standing ovation.
Since he published the book in February, the world has only served up more and increasingly desperate warnings of endism -- culminating, perhaps, in an essay earlier this year from the technoseer Bill Joy, a founder of Sun Microsystems and one of the world's truly certified Smart Guys. Mr. Joy predicted that the combination of unregulated technologies such as exceedingly miniature nanotechnology could lead to biological disaster and the end of, well, everything.
While Mr. Joy's thesis was widely read and highly regarded, to Mr. Brown it just looked like the same endist pitch but with a bigger ball. He describes it with one of his favorite aphorisms about the futurist class -- that they count "one, two, three, one million." Life is more gradual than that, the graybeard sighs.
Mr. Brown left Xerox in June and has created a new investment company, Twelve Entrepreneuring, with some star entrepreneurs: Halsey Minor, the chairman of Cnet; the former McKinsey & Company e-commerce expert John Hegel, and Eric Greenberg, founder of Scient. They are trying to figure out what makes a company, in Mr. Brown's words, "truly transformative."
Mr. Brown is not saying much about the new company yet, but suggests that the key is making sure that knowledge is shared throughout the enterprise -- that it "leaks" across the boundaries that separate, say, the researchers who dream up new technologies from the engineers who manufacture the company's products, and that the knowledge is "sticky" enough that trade secrets stay within the company.
Mr. Brown says he is looking to new models, but within traditional bricks-and-mortar businesses, because he says the lessons of the new age are not only for callow dot-coms. "How do you use the clicks to deeply augment the bricks?" he asked, saying he hopes "to replace this ridiculous mind-set that the e-world is everything."
It feels good just to hear somebody say that out loud.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 27, 2000, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The New Economy column in Business Day on Oct. 9 about the views of John Seely Brown, former director of the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center and the author of "The Social Life of Information," misstated his role at the investment firm Twelve Entrepreneuring. He joined the firm after it was created by Eric Greenberg, Halsey Minor and Benchmark Capital; he did not create it with them. The article also misspelled the surname of the firm's chief strategy officer. He is John A. Hagel III, not Hegel.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS: A Rift Deepens in Canadian Labor;
Nationalism Fuels Auto Workers' Feud With Other Unions

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Canada has long been a stronghold of organized labor. But now two of its biggest union organizations are slugging it out in a very public power struggle.
The animosity between the two, the Canadian Auto Workers union and the Canadian Labor Congress, has reached such a point that at last month's Labor Day celebration in Toronto the auto workers boycotted the parade attended by other Labor Congress members and held a party in a hotel instead. 
 It was the first time that the 220,000-member Canadian Auto Workers union, the largest private-sector union in Canada, had not turned out in force for the parade.
Many leaders in the Labor Congress, an umbrella group that represents 2.4 million workers, or two-thirds of all unionized employees in Canada, say the rift is a result of a blatant grab for members and power by the auto workers. Members of the auto workers say their union is fighting for workers' democratic rights, including the right to break away from foreign-controlled unions.
Without a resolution soon, organized labor runs the risk of looking decidedly disorganized. And businesses, which see this fight as a barometer of labor militancy in Canada, are watching closely.
At the center of the dispute is an attempt by potentially as many as 30,000 Canadian members of the Service Employees International Union -- about one-third of the union's total membership in Canada -- to leave their Washington-based parent and join the Canadian Auto Workers. The Canadian Labor Congress, to which the service employees union also belongs, found that the auto workers had raided the service employees' locals, and the congress imposed sanctions against the auto workers in early July. The measures prevent auto worker officials from speaking or voting at congress meetings.
Basil E. Hargrove, president of the Canadian Auto Workers, said his union was not guilty of raiding because it did not initiate recruiting. Dissident service employees union leaders approached his union, he said.
Kenneth Georgetti, president of the Canadian Labor Congress, says his group's handling of the issue has been entirely in keeping with its constitution, one that was created with the help of the Canadian Auto Workers. The auto workers union, he said "was found by an independent third party to have violated the C.L.C. constitution" by raiding the service employees locals. "The sanctions being applied are not arbitrary," he added.
Changing affiliations, though rare, is nothing new for Canada's labor movement, and ideology is usually the uniting or dividing factor. But now, said Anil Verma, a professor of industrial relations at the University of Toronto, "there is more self-interest," more of an emphasis on growth.
"Mergers and takeovers are fair game in the business world," he added, "and they are also fair game in the labor world."
Although he and other experts doubt that the quarrel will change Canada's labor movement greatly, the auto workers union's strong stance on labor issues has wide appeal among workers. In time, that could prove important. Unions have a bigger social and economic role in Canada than in the United States. A third of Canadian workers belong to unions, about twice the level in the United States.
The auto workers' discontent with the labor congress has been simmering for years. Canadian nationalism runs strong in the union, which split acrimoniously from the United Automobile Workers in 1985. Among other things, the union wants to end foreign -- that mostly means United States -- control of Canadian union units.
Membership in foreign unions, once dominant in the Canadian Labor Congress, has fallen to about 30 percent, "and I believe that in time they will all change over," Mr. Hargrove said.
He acknowledged that some unions based in the United States provide responsible leadership for Canadians, but he said he did not count the service employees among them. In a letter to Canadian Auto Workers members in mid-August, he said the Washington-based group had "seized local union assets, fired staff, and sued dissident leaders personally for millions of dollars."
According to court filings by the service employees union, five employees who the union said had been secretly working for the Canadian Auto Workers turned over membership lists, destroyed records and put about $1 million of service employee locals' funds into Canadian Auto Workers trust accounts. The money was returned by court order, and the former employees are being sued for destruction of property.
"An aggressive, powerful union is putting the labor movement back many years with this feud," said Sharleen Stewart, Canadian vice president of the service employees union. But fighting the auto workers is not going to be her focus any longer. Members are more concerned about government cuts to health care spending, she said, and the service employees union is close to creating a separate Canadian arm, with Washington's blessing.
Mr. Georgetti of the labor congress has tried to smooth matters by explaining that the auto workers union is only under sanction, a step short of expulsion. But Mr. Hargrove says his union has been exiled. In July, the Canadian Auto Workers board passed a resolution to explore the creation of an alternative umbrella group.
The auto workers union, meanwhile, is adding more service employees locals to its membership rolls. So far, 6,600 workers have voted to switch and only 40 have voted to stay.
Growth has been a primary objective of the Canadian Auto Workers since it broke away from the United Auto Workers. Membership since then has increased 80 percent -- 100,000 people -- and now less than 40 percent of all members are employed in the auto industry.
The Canadian subsidiaries of Detroit's Big Three automakers are assembling more vehicles than ever in Canada, but with fewer workers, and the Canadian Auto Workers has been unable to crack the new Japanese-owned plants. It has also failed to win over workers in factories owned by Canada's largest auto parts supplier, Magna International Inc.
If the Canadian Auto Workers forms a rival coalition, there could be a noticeable increase in labor militancy, Professor Verma said. "The appeal of the C.A.W. is that it can get more than other unions, so those other unions will also have to be more aggressive," he said. "That will show up at the bargaining table, and it will affect all of us."

HEADLINE: In His Arrest, Chinese Editor Sees Success Of His Journal

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
As he was being questioned by the political security department of the Beijing police in August, Huang Beiling suddenly realized that he had achieved literary success.
For six years Mr. Huang, 40, a Boston-based poet and editor who also uses the pen name Bei Ling, had spent several months a year in China hand-delivering Tendency, a quarterly Chinese literary journal he edits. The 2,000 to 3,000 copies were printed in Hong Kong or Taiwan and ferried across the border by Mr. Huang and his friends in bulging suitcases. 
 On Aug. 11, Mr. Huang was arrested outside his apartment in Beijing. A day later he was charged with illegal publishing and put in a crowded city jail. Two weeks later, after protests from the West, the Chinese authorities collected $2,400 of a $24,000 fine and deported him back to the United States, where he has permanent residence status although he is a Chinese citizen.
Mr. Huang, recounting his experience in a recent interview in New York, said he realized during his initial 10-hour interrogation just how successful his efforts had been.
"I understood that the Chinese government was more and more angry that this issue was everywhere in the country, in the cities and outside," he said. "They said they saw it everywhere, even in bookstores, and they didn't like it."
What they didn't like, it seems, was his lack of concern that the Communist Party did not officially approve his journal.
Before his arrest Mr. Huang had a reception in Beijing to welcome the latest edition and was planning a colloquium to discuss its contents, which include an interview, poems and essays by the Irish poet Seamus Heaney and a collection of Chinese underground poetry written during the Cultural Revolution. Mr. Huang even opened a Beijing office, included its address on the journal's last page and decided to have it printed at a small official printer in Beijing who agreed to take the risk (and, Mr. Huang later found out, was interrogated and fined).
Tendency was first published as an underground poetry magazine in 1988, and its fourth issue, which honored two Chinese poets who died in the tumultuous year of 1989, was seized by the police in Shanghai. The journal started up again in 1994 as a more literary, intellectual publication based in Boston. When its editors decided to print one third of the run in Shenzhen, in southern China, the authorities stepped in again and confiscated all 1,000 issues.
This year the authorities went further, although their action against Mr. Huang backfired. His arrest and jailing and the jailing of his brother and partner, Huang Feng, caused a stir. The PEN American Center published an open letter calling for Mr. Huang's release, and it was signed by Arthur Miller, Susan Sontag, Czeslaw Milosz and Nadine Gordimer. The United States government also protested.
Mr. Huang said that the government was showing increased nervousness about China's publishing boom. He said 15 publishing houses had been closed, a handful of them permanently, and he cited a ban on the writing of two Shanghai feminists. Some Western books, including photography books about the Clinton presidency and about high fashion, that were printed in China for Western markets have been confiscated recently on grounds of being politically offensive or overtly sexual.
"What we are seeing is a tightening of the rules," said Michael Roberts, executive director of the PEN American Center. "Before, certain things were allowed for economic reasons, and now there seems to be concern about how to control the printing business."
It is still not clear which invisible wire Mr. Huang tripped with his latest issue of Tendency. It may have been the photograph of Wang Dan, a leader of the student movement that was crushed in Tiananmen Square in June 1989, which he printed with Mr. Wang's pledge to "continue his struggle against the Communist Party regime."
In a last-minute decision, Mr. Huang dropped one of the two Chinese characters that form the word "against" as well as Mr. Wang's family name in hopes of avoiding official anger. The authorities were aware of the sleight of hand and chided Mr. Huang for trying to "play games." Regular readers say it is not the first time Tendency has tiptoed across the line into quasi-political activity.
"The journal is ostensibly literary, but Huang Beiling has published Havel, he has published underground literature, " said Merle Goldman, a professor of Chinese history at Boston University. "He really does push the edge."
When it started in 1988, Tendency wanted to give underground or alternative Chinese writers a place to publish, and to be a forum for authors to "bear witness" to events in China.
To his list of firsthand experiences, Mr. Huang can now add time in a Chinese prison. "In China, the situation in the jails is very bad," he said. "Someday, I have to write about it."
He spent his first night in a cell jammed with men, women and infants, mostly out-of-towners rounded up as illegal migrants. Mr. Huang said that many of his cellmates had been held for more than the authorized 24 hours without food or water and were subject to beatings.
Later he was transferred to a city jail where he shared a room with 16 to 25 men who slept in shifts and were assigned times to use the single toilet and wash basin in the cell. When they were taken out for interrogation, prisoners had to squat on their heels and keep their hands behind their necks, he said.
The only inmate to escape this treatment was the manager of the cell, a convicted prisoner appointed by the authorities as their spy. "He lived like a king," Mr. Huang said. "There were two people assigned to give him a massage in the morning. He had a double space to sleep."
When he tried to warn the guards that they were dealing with the holder of a United States green card, they laughed, he said. "They said, 'Who cares,' " he said. " 'Here you are a small potato.' "
Toward the end of his second week, Mr. Huang was moved to a hostel, and a higher-ranking police official came to question him, pressing him to admit that he had violated regulations by publishing an unregistered journal. Mr. Huang said he refused to use the word criminal but did agree to sign a statement saying that he was not in compliance with regulations.
When he was told that he was to be released and deported, he said he could sense frustration on the part of his jailers. "They just want to stop this magazine," he said. "They don't want to see it anywhere in China. And they know if they release me, this magazine will continue. And it will."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Name-Dropping

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Let's not mince words here: George W. Bush did not come in second last week in the debates. He came in fourth, because anyone watching could see that Al Gore, Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman all had a better command of the issues than Mr. Bush and seemed more like presidential timber than he did.
That voters noted that is unquestionable. But whether they will care on Election Day is another question. Will voters care more about Mr. Gore's intelligence, or his maddening tendency to pander and fib? Will they punish Mr. Gore for his intellectual arrogance, or reward Mr. Bush for his affable ignorance? Whom will voters prefer? A candidate who can't tell the truth, or one who can't pronounce it? A candidate who sometimes will say anything or a candidate who sometimes seems to know nothing? 
 These are all open questions. But there are still two more debates for Mr. Bush to regroup in. The place he must improve most tomorrow is on foreign policy. Mr. Bush's answers to the foreign policy questions were so deeply, deeply shallow that you could only wonder: Is he that unfamiliar with the material and uncomfortable with the issues, or have his foreign policy advisers simply not prepared him because they themselves are unprepared for this world? I think it was a little of both.
Consider the moment when Mr. Bush was asked how he would respond to another sudden global financial crisis. He said: I would call Alan Greenspan and I would gather the facts. Wonderful! So would my mother. But she doesn't think she should be president. This is the essence of Mr. Bush's foreign policy. I would call Colin Powell. I would call Alan Greenspan. But what will he ask those advisers, and what happens if they disagree? For that Mr. Bush actually has to know something himself, and he appears to be a man with little intellectual curiosity. Mr. Bush seems to believe that by simply mentioning the name Colin Powell on foreign policy, he has a foreign policy. Had Mr. Bush listened to Mr. Powell on Kosovo, there would probably never have been a U.S. air war against Slobodan Milosevic and he would still be in power.
Mr. Bush's non-answers were a reflection of the shallow level of thinking about foreign policy generally in the Republican Party today. The fact is, the mainstream of the Republican Party, which for decades had the cold war and anti-Sovietism to guide it abroad, has simply gone brain dead since the cold war ended. It has lived off Clinton gaffes and a kind of drive-by foreign policy, in which Republicans drive by the White House, shout some insult at the Clinton team and drive on. The only original efforts to come to terms with the end of the cold war in the Republican Party have been the hyper-isolationist American nationalism of Pat Buchanan or the hyper-interventionist American nationalism articulated by William Kristol and Robert Kagan. Since Mr. Bush is not interested in either, it is not surprising that when pressed on foreign policy he falls back on name-dropping or on neo-cold-warism, such as his vow to "rebuild military power," which "starts with a billion-dollar pay raise for the men and women who wear the uniform."
That would be fine if we were still fighting the cold war, and what threatened America today was the strength of Russia, China, Pakistan or Indonesia. But the fact is, what really threatens our security and the stability of the world we live in today is the weakness and potential collapse of all these post-cold-war states -- because of their lack of institutions and total corruption. If anything, we should be spending a billion dollars on upgrading our diplomatic tools, such as the international development banks, on restructuring foreign aid and debt relief to help countries build the necessary democratic institutions for governing, and on strengthening the U.N., precisely so it can do the peacekeeping and nation-building that we want to avoid.
The best you can say about Mr. Bush is that he has thought about the world and decided that it's still the 1980's, and therefore he plans to solve the problems of his father's era with his father's old advisers. The worst you can say is that deep into this campaign he still hasn't been able to master his briefing book on foreign policy and has evinced zero interest in thinking about the world afresh.
Since he may be our next president, both alternatives are troubling. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Fleet Bank Sued Over Credit Card

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9

 BODY:
A lawsuit has been filed against the Fleet Bank, accusing the company of misleading consumers and violating a pledge to charge a fixed interest rate on credit card balances transferred to Fleet accounts.
Fleet Credit Card Services advertised a 7.99 percent annual rate, then raised the rate, violating state law, according to the lawsuit, which was filed last week in State Superior Court. Messages left today at Fleet's public relations office were not immediately returned. 
 Peter Wasylyk, a lawyer from Providence, filed the lawsuit on behalf of Tyler Chavers of Eagle River, Alaska, and asked for class-action status so thousands of other cardholders could be included.
Mr. Chavers transferred the balances from three credit cards in April to obtain Fleet's advertised rate. A month later, Fleet told him the rate would be increased to 9.5 or 10.5 percent, depending on when he had joined, the lawsuit said. "Fleet believed it could increase the fixed rate at any time, and in fact, never intended to provide the fixed rate as advertised," Mr. Chavers said in the lawsuit.
Fleet is now known as FleetBoston.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1024 words

HEADLINE: Tap the Oil Reserve, and Entrepreneurship Flows

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Four stories above the streets of central Harlem, Lance Stroud has created a one-man oil company that, after going head to head with the multinationals, may now play a role in the nation's energy agenda.
Lance Stroud Enterprises, a corporate 97-pound weakling, elbowed into the midst of oil giants last week when it was chosen as one of 11 companies that will receive a total of 30 million barrels of oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. With winter and the elections approaching, the White House decided to release the oil to replenish low supplies of heating oil in the Northeast and Midwest. Mr. Stroud, in his oil deal, offered to buy four million barrels worth more than $120 million. 
 "I feel like I'm the front of the boat and the government is the rest of the boat," said the 35-year-old Mr. Stroud, relishing his luck. "I'm parting the waters of this energy crisis with the weight of the government behind me."
Based in a room more college dormitory than executive suite, with a flooring of sweat socks, sneakers, soup cans and literary anthologies, Lance Stroud Enterprises received the second-largest allotment from the government's oil reserve, just behind BP Amoco, one of the world's huge oil companies.
The Energy Department structured the release of the oil as a swap, which means that the companies will take 30 million barrels now and return 31.56 million barrels between August and November 2001. A third of the oil is going to little-known companies, which besides Lance Stroud Enterprises include Burhany Energy Enterprises of Tallahassee, Fla., and Euell Energy of Aurora, Colo. -- a surprising turn of events that has ignited speculation in an oil market driven as much by juicy rumor as dry numbers.
Traders speculated that the small companies were fronts for mysterious entrepreneurs or shams to prop up the auction. "Really and truly what it says is that the government sold 20 million barrels and not 30 because those little guys don't know what they will do with it," a longtime trader said. "My best theory is that those barrels will never move."
But many of those same traders and big companies are now sidling up to Mr. Stroud, as if he were an orphan come into a kingly inheritance, hoping to buy his oil.
"The oil industry is like a close-knit family," Mr. Stroud said. "I don't have any animosity toward them. Besides, they might need some heating oil."
Mr. Stroud's intention is simple: he plans to sell the oil to a larger company in hopes that the commodity price of oil will fall, allowing him to pay less to return his allotment to the government and pocket the difference.
Robert S. Kripowicz, the Energy Department's acting deputy secretary for fossil energy, said that start-up companies had previously received oil from the reserve. This time, "after the small companies got their bids, major traders and oil companies called our contract people at D.O.E. to say they were in serious negotiations with all three of them," he said.
Mr. Stroud thinks that selling the oil should be easy. Sitting in his office overlooking an air shaft, he said he was negotiating with several concerns to buy the oil, including BP Amoco, which confirmed that it was in talks.
The challenge, he said, may be in finding enough oil to repay the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. To speed the flow of crude oil to refineries in time for the winter heating season, the Energy Department did not require financing up front, which it has in the past, thus providing entry to small players like Mr. Stroud. It instead tapped businesses that extended the most favorable swap terms. Mr. Stroud's offer of 12 percent more oil than he will receive, about 4.5 million barrels, placed him at the upper range of bidders, the Energy Department said.
"Why 12 percent?" he said. "Because I don't have bricks-and-mortar or 70,000 employees I need to pay every week. And I don't need to earn enough for 60 generations to live on off this one contract. I just want this to be my coming out."
For Mr. Stroud to make money on the deal, the price of oil would have to fall by at least 12 percent over the next year, which traders said was probable.
To protect against default on the swap, the winning bidders have to secure letters of credit by Thursday, and Mr. Stroud said he was talking to a major European lender about providing the guarantee. If he fails to get the letter, the Energy Department must decide whether it will auction the oil once more.
Little in his life prepared Mr. Stroud, whose two-year-old company is not even listed in the phone book, for such wheeling and dealing. After four years in military intelligence, he said, he worked as a bus driver, a security guard, a computer programmer and recently, to make ends meet as he set up his business, a census taker. He shares an apartment with his mother and keeps a second office in his sister's apartment two flights up, where his computer keyboard sits on an upturned drawer and a lamp with Winnie the Pooh and Eeyore, taken from his son's nursery, illuminates a small corner.
A math buff with a front tooth missing from basketball, Mr. Stroud was attracted to the oil market because, he said, "everything that moves, moves by vehicle, and that needs oil; I wanted my hand in everything that moves."
By following the weekly statistics that traders, economists and oil companies use, he saw that supplies of heating oil were growing tight worldwide, especially in the Northeast. Then he received an e-mail message from the Energy Department soliciting bids for the oil from the reserve. "I was ready to participate in remedying the energy crisis in New York," he said, "and this fell into my lap."
He understands that trading in millions of barrels of oil could "make or break" him. But like the winner of any lottery, he holds on tightly to his ticket out of a life of odd jobs and bleak fourth-floor views.
"If this works out," he said, "I'll have to move. If someone around here makes a lot of money, something could happen. See, when one crab tries to climb out of the box, all the others will pull him back in."

HEADLINE: A Boycott of Procter & Gamble Is Planned

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John Sweeney, plans to ask consumers to boycott three products made by Procter & Gamble to show support for actors who are on strike against the advertising industry.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., which represents 13.1 million workers, will ask consumers to forgo the use of Tide laundry detergent, Crest toothpaste and Ivory soap. The boycott is scheduled to be announced at a Tuesday morning rally in Bryant Park in Manhattan. Celebrities like Julia Roberts, Tim Robbins and Susan Sarandon, are scheduled to attend. 
 "This strike has been going on for some time and I think it deserves even more attention than we've been giving it," Mr. Sweeney said. "The actors aren't alone in fighting for the future as the economy shifts, and employers sometimes value profits over people."
Actors also plan to stage protests at the company's annual shareholder meeting in Cincinnati on Tuesday and at a Procter & Gamble plant in Oxnard, Calif.
Union officials said Procter & Gamble was chosen because it is one of the largest advertisers in the world and it has continued to make commercials during the strike using nonunion actors, said William Daniels, president of the Screen Actors Guild, which is representing the actors along with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
"We can't just target corporate America," said Mr. Daniels, noting that Procter & Gamble is not the only offender. "You have to pick out a target."
The boycott announcement comes as the two sides agreed to resume talks, which are being overseen by a federal mediator, on Oct. 19 in New York. Talks broke off on September 27. The actors have been on strike since May 1.
"It's unfair to target just one company, particularly one with such a strong, long-standing history of partnership in producing commercials like Procter & Gamble," said Tom Millikin, a company spokesman. "The advertising industry has proposed a fair and lucrative contract which is in line with previous contracts the union has ratified." He added that the company would continue to make commercials using nonunion talent, but that Procter & Gamble remained committed to negotiating a settlement.
Griffin Dunne, an actor and director who has spoken in support of strikers, acknowledged that the announcement of a date for resuming talks did leave him with some concerns regarding the boycott. Still, he said, he supported the action.
"We're not going to hold back," Mr. Daniels said. "We simply don't have a deal."
While negotiators resolved one serious sticking point during the most recent talks -- going back to the status quo system of paying residuals for work on networks and a flat fee for cable -- they deadlocked on how much the cable work would pay. The unions supported increases over the three years of the contract that would ultimately pay $2,460 in the final year. The industry set the maximum payment for the third year at $1,850.
Although the unions are not pressing to negotiate fees for commercials made exclusively for the Internet, they do want advertisers to recognize them as the exclusive bargaining unit for actors who perform on the Internet. The industry wants to study the issue over the next three years. The monitoring of how frequently commercials are shown has also been at issue.
Negotiations with advertisers broke down late last month after nearly two consecutive weeks of talks. Mr. Daniels said the actors remained firm in their position.
"The union has never been stronger than in the face of all this adversity, and this strike, that's gone on longer than any we've had, really kind of galvanized our union," Mr. Daniels said.
