HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
BROOKLYN: MAN SHOOTS INTRUDERS
Two would-be robbers were thwarted yesterday when the owner of a Brooklyn card shop drew a pistol and shot them both, the police said. The authorities said the owner, Ming Chen, 43, fired several shots at the men inside Joe's Card Store on Cortelyou Road after one pointed a semiautomatic pistol at him and demanded money. One of the men, James Baylor, was in critical condition at Kings County Hospital Center with four gunshot wounds. The other, Antoine Miles, was struck once in the abdomen and was in stable condition, the authorities said. Both men were charged with attempted robbery and criminal possession of a weapon. Mr. Chen, who the police said used a legally registered pistol, was not injured or charged. C. J. Chivers (NYT) 

GARDEN CITY: CURB OF COUNTY EXECUTIVE URGED
A referendum on whether to restrict the Nassau County executive's ability to award certain contracts without competitive bidding will be placed before voters on Nov. 7. If adopted, the change would make what is now a governmental agreement into a matter of law: the County Legislature's Rules Committee can approve personal service contracts, like those with law or computer firms, which are often worth $25,000 or more. The same arrangement is now in effect as an an agreement between Judith A. Jacobs, the Legislature's presiding officer, and the county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, above, said Darren Bloch, Ms. Jacobs's chief of staff. Al Baker (NYT)
 
ALBANY: 25 MILLION ROTTING TIRES
Legislation signed late last week by Gov. George E. Pataki is the state's latest attempt to solve a decades-old problem: what to do with 25 million tires rotting in illegal dumps. The problem has become more urgent because the dumps are also prime breeding grounds for mosquitoes. West Nile virus, which has sickened at least 17 people in New York City and New Jersey and killed one this year, is carried by mosquitoes. The dumps could become larger as a result of the recent nationwide recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires. The law creates the State Council on Scrap Tire Management, which will give grants to businesses to recycle dumped tires. (AP)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
WILDWOOD: REDEVELOPMENT PLAN
For years preservationists have championed the pink flamingos and plastic palms of the 1950's motels in the struggling beach resort town of Wildwood. Yesterday, the city officially embraced its low-brow culture by presenting a $40 million redevelopment plan that would include a neon gateway arch on Rio Grande Avenue and eliminate a pedestrian mall on Pacific Avenue, the main commercial strip. Officials said the 1987 mall was a misguided attempt to compete with nearby Cape May, a beach resort of Victorian inns. "We are not Cape May," Mayor Duane Sloan said. "We need to embrace our character and not abandon it." Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
TRENTON: SCHOOLS TO GET COMPUTERS
New computers will soon be arriving to start computer centers in places like housing projects, to bridge a gap between students at urban schools and those in the suburbs. The state has granted 26 school districts a total of $4.8 million to establish innovative computer programs to reach disadvantaged children and their parents who have little access to such technology. The program will eventually total $7.4 million in federal aid once another 24 grants are distributed. (AP)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
FAIRFIELD: GREAT PUMPKIN RECOVERED
Four men, age 17 to 21, were charged with larceny after they were found with a 340-pound pumpkin in the front seat of their car. The police said it was stolen over the weekend from the front porch of its grower's house. Lt. Richard Gunter said the police spotted an immense object on Sunday morning protruding from the front seat of a car driven by Jason Razowski, 19, of Derby. The front passenger door could not be closed because of the pumpkin, and when Mr. Razowski was questioned, the police said, he said he and three friends picked up the pumpkin on the side of the road. (AP)
 
LITCHFIELD: TOWN OPPOSES HISTORIC HOUSE
The man seeking to rebuild the childhood home of Harriet Beecher Stowe, at left, the author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," has hit a snag. The man, Chandler Saint, has not been able to find a temporary or permanent site for the house, which was dismantled and is now stored in two trailers on state land. The Litchfield Historic District Commission denied Mr. Saint permission to construct a building to cover the trailers because the building would violate local zoning laws. And in late August, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said that he did not want to override local laws to store the dismantled house. (AP)

HEADLINE: As Homework Load Grows, One District Says 'Enough'

BYLINE: By KATE ZERNIKE 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 6

 BODY:
Her daughter's tears would start the minute Linda Markowitz arrived home from work.
It was homework again: math problems, a science report, worksheets. By the time Mrs. Markowitz had read enough of her daughter's science textbook to figure out how to help, it was 10:15 and they still had to go on the Internet to do research. Then, more tears as they argued over whether her daughter had time to practice her saxophone and get a good night's sleep before getting up at 6:45 to catch the school bus. 
 And that was just fourth grade.
This year, there are no more tears. There is time for dance lessons, Hebrew school, and even the occasional board game.
This year, Piscataway stood up to homework.
The school board in this district of about 7,000 students limited it on weeknights, from 30 minutes in elementary school to two hours in high school, "discouraged" homework on weekends, and prohibited teachers from grading it or using it as punishment.
The school board, which unanimously voted for the policy, said homework was putting too much pressure on students' already over scheduled lives, too often dragging parents into helping finish it -- read, doing it -- and becoming a substitute for good teaching in the classroom.
Some parents and teachers worry that fewer assignments will leave students less prepared for college. Some studies suggest that rigorous homework leads to better scores; other researchers say there is no correlation.
Still, the policy has made the superintendent of schools in this middle-class suburb about 35 miles southwest of Manhattan something of a hero among parents, not only those like Mrs. Markowitz here in Piscataway, but across the state and even the country, who have been phoning him at his office and on call-in radio shows to ask how they can push their schools to do the same.
Homework has come in and out of vogue through the longstanding debate over whether children need more rigor or simply more time to be children.
Experts say it is hard if not impossible to know how many school districts nationwide limit homework. The National PTA and the National Education Association, the nation's largest teachers' union, encourage limits similar to the ones imposed here; on the other hand, in 1998, the rural community of Akron, N.Y., outraged some parents by imposing minimum daily requirements that are about the same as what Piscataway sets as a maximum.
There is no question that officials in Piscataway have tapped into a growing frustration among parents who say homework is consuming not only their children's lives, but their own.
"We're attacking the fabric of an institution," said the superintendent, Ronald E. Bolandi. "I think we've opened up people's eyes. If Piscataway is in the forefront, so be it."
It was really not so long ago, in the 1930's, that cities including New York and Chicago banned or limited homework, and the American Child Health Association classified it as child labor. But after the Soviets launched Sputnik in 1957, raising concerns about the state of American education, and again after the "Nation at Risk" report in 1983, policy-makers and parents came to see homework as a solution for schools that lagged woefully behind their counterparts in other industrialized nations. When the school board in the tiny California town of Half Moon Bay considered banning homework in 1994, it became something of a laughingstock, and the proposal was quickly scuttled.
Yet in recent years, many educators see a growing desire for more limits.
"Today, homework is not so much an issue because of legitimate pedagogical concerns, but because of increasing pressure on parents' time," said John Buell, a former teacher and co-author of "The End of Homework: How Homework Disrupts Families, Overburdens Children, and Limits Learning" (Beacon Press; 2000). "It's not that parents don't want interaction with their kids, it's that when they get home from work, they don't want that interaction determined by another boss, i.e., the school. We don't want to have to again do someone else's chores. There are enough things we have to order our children to do anyway; there is enough stress in that relationship. Why aggravate it?"
Some teachers say they feel constrained by the limits, that the school board seems to be second-guessing their lesson planning. "A.P. parents expect kids to come home with homework," said Michael Modugno, who teaches senior English as well as the Advanced Placement class. "If they don't see books to read, plays to read, essays to write, I get calls asking what's wrong."
And in practice, the homework policy can be hard to monitor. Already, parents say assignments that teachers say will take a half-hour take two. And some high school students said teachers were finding ways around the policy, grading homework as part of class participation or saying homework assigned on a Friday is not "weekend homework." Several said they saw homework as a fact of life, policy or no.
"No one likes it, but if you don't do it, you only have to study more for the tests," said Troy Ogilvie, 15, a 10th grader at Piscataway High School, who was lugging a bulging backpack on a Friday afternoon.
In a town fiercely proud of its schools, where 70 percent of students go on to college, academic preparation is prized.
Teresa Hopkins, a mother of three, said: "You're not going to be competitive in the world by doing the least you have to do. That's the message we're sending. All you have to do is show up to school."
A University of Michigan study last year found homework increasing overall from 1981 to 1997, with the biggest increase falling on students ages 6 to 8, whose homework load tripled.
Mr. Bolandi found the same thing, anecdotally, when he toured the schools here, a former farming community now given to low corporate office parks and tidy new colonials. Parents complained that children were arriving home with four or five hours of homework, and that teachers were sending home assignments without teaching the concepts first, meaning parents had to brush up on their own skills or hire a tutor.
He also said that he was worried about the inequities that homework caused. Piscataway is notable for its economic and racial diversity -- the district is about one-third black, one-third white and one-fourth Asian, with 75 languages spoken in the schools. Some students cannot afford tutors.
Mr. Bolandi cites studies that show no link between homework and high achievement. But others studies are varied. One found higher standardized test scores among Chinese-American students whose parents demanded they spend more time studying. Another suggested that homework improved achievement, especially as students grew older.
Parents complained that assignments cut into family life, and into other activities that helped round out their children.
"For college, they say you have to see the kid as a package," said Linda Bellew, whose son is a high school sophomore. "I'm trying to give him that package, but a lot of homework makes it very difficult."
In middle school, Mrs. Bellew said, her son's homework forced him to cancel appearances at birthday parties and a christening. He sat at the dinner table with an open book many nights, and his assignments provoked countless arguments about whether he had time to go to karate lessons. She doubted whether he was even learning from it.
"If you have six hours of homework, you're not doing it to learn, you're doing it to get it done," she said.
Mrs. Markowitz envisioned more homework headaches when her daughter entered sixth grade this year: not only was she moving to a junior high school, she was going to be taking accelerated math classes.
"The last two years were nightmares," she said. "This was an A student losing her interest in school, losing her desire to learn. I just didn't see why they had to give 40 math problems when 10 would show that they get it."
The change in her daughter this year, she said, is remarkable.
"She is looking forward to doing her homework, because she knows she's not in for three or four hours of hell."

HEADLINE: Alaska's Voters to Decide On Legalizing Marijuana

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 5

 BODY:
"Vote Yes Prop 5," proclaims the large yellow mural painted on the side of a building here, complete with a large cannabis leaf. A poster on the window offers a quote from Ronald Reagan, though he has certainly not endorsed this particular measure: "Government exists to protect us from each other. Where government has gone beyond its limits is in deciding to protect us from ourselves."
And just inside the door here at the headquarters of Free Hemp in Alaska are more than a dozen versions of pamphlets offering reasons for Alaskans to support the broadest marijuana legalization initiative ever to appear on a state ballot. 
 One pamphlet proclaims that marijuana is a far safer drug than alcohol, another says that passage of the measure would "free police resources to fight real crime."
And a third, "Marijuana and the Bible," has a drawing of Jesus Christ and observes: "Nowhere in the Bible does it forbid people to grow, use or smoke cannabis hemp."
Here, in a state that many Alaskans like to describe as the most libertarian in the nation, voters are being asked in the Nov. 7 election to say "yes" to marijuana in a single, sweeping measure that would not only legalize consumption of the drug for anyone age 18 and over but also create automatic amnesty for those convicted of marijuana-related charges and even require the state to consider restitution for such people.
Supporters of Proposition 5 are visible all over Anchorage, holding up roadside banners, handing out the leaflets, displaying stickers on their car bumpers. They gathered signatures from more than 41,000 registered voters to get the measure on the ballot, more than twice the needed number and a figure that represents nearly 10 percent of all voters in the state. And if marijuana users are derided by drug critics as laid-back and apathetic, the frenetic energy that many are bringing to the cause belies that image.
"It's a travesty that we lock people up and make criminals of them for personal use of marijuana," said James Garhart, a 51-year-old messenger who says he has used marijuana on a "semi-daily" basis for years and is now spending almost all of his free time working for the Yes-on-5 campaign.
"I think most people believe it's simply not a sane policy," Mr. Garhart said, "So I think this will pass."
Some opponents of the measure fear that the measure will pass because, they say, supporters are running a campaign that appeals to Alaskans' libertarian, leave-me-alone instincts and that often refrains from using the word "marijuana." The leading organizations for the measure have names like "Free Hemp in Alaska" and "Hemp 2000," championing a cousin of marijuana that has many industrial uses and only a tiny fraction of the drug's psychoactive properties.
"I'm concerned that the word is not getting out about what this measure would do," said Wev Shea, the United States attorney here during the Bush administration and now a lawyer in private practice, who is a leading critic of the measure. "This thing is so overbroad, unless you really take the time to look at it, you don't realize the vast scope of it."
The measure has plenty of prominent critics, including Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat who calls it "foolish and dangerous," and Chief Duane Udland of the Anchorage police, who has warned that the measure could create a "drug culture" that would attract wayward elements from all over the world.
Many state leaders remain confident that there is no way the measure will pass, with many citing the recent Alaska Poll, a periodic statewide survey conducted by David Dittman, a prominent pollster here.
Of 518 residents surveyed in the last 10 days of September, 42 percent said they were "strongly against" the measure and 19 percent "generally against," while 35 percent indicated they were supporting it.
Alaskans voted two years ago to legalize the medicinal use of marijuana, and Mr. Dittman said there might be strong support for decriminalizing the drug in some fashion because the state electorate did indeed have libertarian tendencies.
"There's certainly an element of that in the Alaskan mentality, but it does not extend to amnesty, to restitution, to the idea that marijuana would all of a sudden be legal for teenagers," Mr. Dittman said. "I think that's where they went too far."
Beginning in 1975, under a right-to-privacy ruling by the Alaska State Supreme Court, residents were allowed to possess small amounts of marijuana; in 1990, voters decided to recriminalize the drug. Still, private use of marijuana is rarely prosecuted here and, in interviews on the streets, it is clear that many Alaskans find that situation acceptable.
But that hardly means the measure will pass. For one thing, many voters seemed concerned that it would legalize the drug for people as young as 18. After all, Alaskans must be 19 to buy cigarettes and 21 to buy liquor.
Others said the amnesty was simply too broad or expressed fears, as one man put it, that passage of the measure would "attract a lot of the deadwood to move up to Alaska, get their check and get stoned." (Oil revenues enable the state to send a check from the so-called Permanent Fund to every Alaskan: this year, nearly $2,000.)
At the busy offices of Free Hemp in Alaska, workers answer phones and hand out brochures. People, some curious and some committed, wander in for information. A big sign reads: "Absolutely! No smoking anywhere, anything in the building."
Sil DeChellis, the treasurer of Free Hemp, explained that he and many other workers on the campaign detested cigarette smoke.
Next door, at the Cafe Pax, a coffee shop where painted cannabis leaves are part of the decor, the chairman of Free Hemp, Al Anders, ticked off the ways he thought life in Alaska would improve if Proposition 5 passes.
"We'll save money on law enforcement costs, and the police can fight real crime," he said.
"We'll have a stronger economy, and some increase in tourism," continued Mr. Anders, who said he did not like to smoke marijuana because it aggravated his bronchitis. ("I prefer it in my chili," he said.) And, he added: "There may be more government revenue, because people will figure out how to tax it."

HEADLINE: Timorese Refugees Tell of Terror By Militias After Foreigners Left

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: MALIANA, East Timor, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Across the river from this small border town, beyond the banana palms that glow in the early morning sunlight, lies Indonesia's latest scene of terror, where armed gangs have run wild, holding tens of thousands of refugees hostage in defiance of international condemnation.
There, in the Indonesian territory of West Timor, the defeated East Timorese militias have regrouped, rearmed and reasserted themselves, shaming the Jakarta government and its military and jeopardizing billions of dollars in international aid. 
 Almost every morning, small groups of frightened refugees emerge from behind the banana trees and ford the shallow river to safety, bringing with them accounts of intimidation, abuse and shrinking food supplies in a no man's land where power has been ceded to the lawless.
Since the killings of three United Nations workers a month ago and the subsequent withdrawal of all foreign workers from West Timor, the escapees are the main source of information about the fate of the refugees who fled or were forced from East Timor a year ago after its vote for independence from Indonesia.
"We now have 100,000-plus people in a hostagelike situation, in complete darkness where there is no international presence to monitor what is happening," said Bernard Kerblat, director of operations in East Timor for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
Debriefed at the edge of the river, their feet still wet from their crossing, the escapees say that the militias have been tightening their grip in the absence of a foreign presence.
"They tell us there is a roll call every night," Mr. Kerblat said. "If they go to the market or to trade at the border they have to leave behind relatives in the camps. When they go to the fields there are militia on motorcycles watching them. What they are also telling us is that they are living on the edge of survival since the unplugging of United Nations aid."
The militias appear motivated by what seems to be the unrealistic hope of reversing the independence vote or chopping off a chunk of East Timorese territory. Or, as in their rampage there after the vote when they forced more than a quarter of the population across the border into the west, they may also be acting now out of sheer hatred and revenge.
Despite pleas and pressure from abroad, the Indonesian government has failed to disarm and disband the militias and free the hostage refugees. In response, the United States and others have threatened to postpone a meeting this month in Tokyo at which donors are to agree on the disbursement of $5.6 billion in aid to the struggling Indonesian economy.
Indonesian officials have reacted with a now-familiar mixture of promises, prevarications and angry nationalistic language. Some diplomats say the statements of President Abdurrahman Wahid suggest that he is not being fully informed on the situation.
Humiliated by the militia killings of the United Nations workers on Sept. 6 -- while he was visiting the United Nations in New York -- Mr. Wahid sounded plaintive when he said: "I received a telephone call today saying we are in full control of the area."
For Indonesia, the militias are in some ways an attack dog that has turned against its trainer.
Recruited and armed by the military in a failed attempt to subvert East Timor's independence referendum last year, the militias, now numbering perhaps 2,000 men, have become a rogue force that highlights the government's weakening control of portions of its territory.
Still backed by elements of the military and by antigovernment spoilers, the militias are also a symptom of the fraying of the military chain of command, in which Jakarta's mandate in unstable areas like Aceh, Irian Jaya and the Maluku islands seems only a distant echo.
The issue will come before the United Nations Security Council again on Wednesday, when Foreign Minister Alwi Shihab is scheduled to present Indonesia's case.
"I've enough ammunition to convince the United Nations that what they have been saying about Indonesia being unable to control the situation is incorrect," he told reporters in Jakarta. "If there is someone saying that people are afraid to walk about in the refugee camps, I'll say that's incorrect."
West Timor has become an international issue both because of the attacks on United Nations workers and because the aggressive militias now threaten to destabilize both East Timor and Indonesia.
In East Timor, they appear bent on complicating the fragile birth of a nation that voted for independence from Indonesia on Aug. 30, 1999.
In the last two or three months, they have stepped up armed incursions across the 100-mile-long border, clashing several times with foreign peacekeepers and killing two of them. The peacekeepers report that the militias, operating in small units, are increasingly well armed and trained, with new boots and bullets to spare.
Speaking in New York a week ago, Sergio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations administrator for East Timor, noted that there had yet to be arrests in the Sept. 6 killings although a large crowd -- including passive members of the Indonesian police and military -- had witnessed them.
"There could hardly be a more eloquent demonstration of Indonesia's current inability to deal effectively with the problem," he said. "This is impunity running rampant."
It is an impunity that the militias learned last year in East Timor. Although they failed to stop the population from voting overwhelmingly for freedom, they did succeed in laying waste to much of the territory, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying about 70 percent of its buildings.
And in a breathtaking logistical exercise, they mobilized ferries and convoys of trucks to transport perhaps 250,000 people, out of East Timor's population of 800,000, into West Timor.
Although about half of those people have returned to East Timor, the others remain for a variety of reasons. Some stay voluntarily, others against their will.
Some are members of the militia or East Timorese members of the Indonesian military who, along with their families, do not wish to return home, or are afraid to. Some worked in the Indonesian civil service and would lose their government pensions and benefits if they returned to what is now a foreign country.
But officials estimate that 60 percent of the people in the camps would return if they were not prevented from doing so by force and by disinformation. Escapees say the militias have told them that United Nations peacekeepers have run amok in East Timor and will rape and kill them if they go home.
"The militias abuse us and they abuse the soldiers too," said one escapee, Fernando Noronha. "They walk around with machetes and knives and homemade pistols. They say, 'If you want to go home, please do, but when the peacekeepers leave we will come and kill all of you.' "
The window for escapes may not last long. And if it closes, West Timor may become an even darker and more hidden place.
In the days leading up to the international donors' meeting in Tokyo, the Indonesian police and military have begun a high-profile sweep for weapons in the camps where the militia both control and blend in with the population.
Only a handful of guns have been recovered, which has led foreign officials to call the sweep "pathetic" and "lame in the extreme." In one instance, a group of militia members confronted the police and seized back a number of automatic rifles.
In some areas, though, the sweep appears to have pushed militia leaders into hiding, and their momentary departure has allowed the current trickle of escapes.
But whatever happens next inside the camps, the border itself will soon become impassable. The annual monsoon rains are about to begin, the river will swell and escape will become more difficult than ever.

HEADLINE: COLLECTING;
The Man With 40 Corvettes, and Other Classic Tales

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

 BODY:
IN this, the Internet era, when "instant" is too slow for some people, millions of Americans still want to go fast the old-fashioned way -- with lots of chrome, authentic hubcaps and engines that evoke a mechanical age, not a technological one. Some crave power, some chase status, all seek to be one with their car of yesteryear.
But not just any car. It must be the right car. A car that says, "This is who I really am." 
 Sheathed in metal, literally wearing the thing they love, drivers of vintage and collectible cars exist in a comforting and contemporaneous past, transcending time. If motoring can be romantic, a 1958 Oldsmobile Rocket 88 is Freud on overdrive.
Day to day, of course, we drive minivans to take the children to soccer. We drive aging Corollas to the train station. But some of us also drive ancient MG's or Thunderbirds or Coupe DeVilles to get to places even MapQuest cannot pinpoint.
The conventional wisdom goes like this: Baby boomers, with empty nests and expendable income, are prepared to indulge their automotive fantasies, and you can always tell who owns what. New-economy entrepreneurs demand investment-grade European cars; middle-aged former denizens of high school auto shop covet muscle cars like the Plymouth Barracuda and Dodge Challenger. Losers end up with the A.M.C. Gremlin.
Yes and no. Most car people are tinkerers. Many have been enamored of intake manifolds since adolescence. Some want to make a statement. Some want a link with their childhood. Some just like the car. And some, like Chip Miller, like the car a lot.
At 57, he has been wiping greasy hands on overalls since junior high school. He owns 40 vintage Corvettes. "I have insane amounts of garage space," he said.
"I was in the car culture when it was really happening," added Mr. Miller, who, with his partner, Bill Miller (no relation), owns the Carlisle, Pa., fairgrounds, home to two big car meets, Spring Carlisle and Fall Carlisle.
"I was 13 1/2 years old, and I had a one-mile walk home from school," he said. "I found this tiny car magazine in the gutter, about half the size of a regular magazine. I must have read that thing 10 times. I didn't know anything about cars. My parents hated cars except to drive them. My dad would never check the oil. He'd wait for steam to come out before checking the water level in the radiator."
AT 15, a year before he could get a driver's license, Chip Miller bought his first car, a 1951 Ford coupe. Price: $100. It needed work.
While his classmates at Jenkintown High School, near Philadelphia, were playing baseball, he was scouring junkyards for transmission bolts.
One car led to another, even as life intervened. He graduated from the two-year engineering program at the State University of New York at Farmingdale. He married. He bought another old Ford. Eventually, Fords gave way to Corvettes, and the passion intensified.
In the early 70's, the two Mr. Millers met at a car auction. Chip Miller owned a '54 Corvette at the time. He had planned to take it to the big meet at Hershey, Pa., but exhibitors were limited to models from 1940 and earlier. Feeling left out, the two men started their own show, in Carlisle. The first, Prewar '74, attracted cars from the 40's, 50's and 60's. There were 800 stalls at the first show. Now, on 81 acres, there are 8,200 stalls and a car corral with 1,800 classic cars.
Among them is one of Chip Miller's Corvettes, with the lowest mileage of any car at the show from the first production year.
"They only made 300 in 1953," he said. "I paid $5,000 for it in 1972. It's the centerpiece of my collection. The only one I ever borrowed money for. Today it's worth $250,000, and the odometer reads 8,788. I'm committed never to turning it to five digits."
Chip Miller's story begins to sound familiar once you start talking to other owners of old cars. Some, like Mr. Miller, have made careers out of their passion. Others simply enjoy weekend drives, or going to a car show and preening. They are, or have become, what they drive.
No one who knows the vintage-car field can quantify the obsession. Hemmings Motor News, the car traders' bible, won't even guess, although it lists more than 9,000 car clubs on its Web site. The Antique Automobile Club of America, in Hershey, says it has no idea how many collectors exist or how much they spend on restorations each year.
But Ty Bennett, a spokesman for Kruse International of Auburn, Ind., an auction house that sells cars nationwide, provided a hint. Kruse, the largest auctioneer of its kind, says it has sold 350,000 vintage or collectible cars in the last 30 years for $3.5 billion. The size of the huge secondary market in accessories and auto parts is anybody's guess. If all these buyers voted in a bloc, American politics might be changed forever.
RICHARD BEABOUT bought his first DeSoto in 1986. It was a 1947 sedan that had been in a barn for 20 years. He had never owned a DeSoto, but had driven Chryslers for years. He and his wife, Betty, needed an older car to enter an antiques-auto hill climb -- timed like a drag race -- near their home in Marshall, Ill., a town near the Indiana border about 90 miles west of Indianapolis. So they trucked the car home and went to work.
"Well," said Mr. Beabout (pronounced BEE-bout), 64, a retired machinist for Caterpillar Tractor, "just before we got the '47 ready for the hill climb, a friend of mine in town said he had a '54 DeSoto. And I bought it." He paused. "Then I had two DeSotos."
In the hill climb, Mrs. Beabout drove the '47 and the '54. His wife won the competition.
"She's now known as the racing grandmother in the national DeSoto Club," Mr. Beabout said.
After the DeSotos came a '36 Chrysler Airflow and then more DeSotos. "I have six cars in a two-car garage," he said, laughing. "But we've expanded several times."
If Mr. Beabout is an accidental DeSoto owner ("It could have been a Hudson or a Packard, I guess"), Joel Cooper, a 46-year-old mail carrier in Hartford, is the man with a mission: the 1970 Dodge Dart. No other year will do.
"I've probably stripped 25 of them, to get parts for the ones I'm working on," Mr. Cooper said.
There was a time when he could barely change transmission oil. "I knew nothing," he said.
But the big Dodge engines available in the early 70's, and the lure of street racing, sold him on the Dart, a car that started as a compact family sedan and grew to be part of a Dodge-Plymouth cohort with names like Demon, Duster and Barracuda.
Mr. Beabout is a DeSoto guy. Mr. Cooper is a Dodge guy.
Until recently, it had never occurred to me that I, too, could be a car guy. I drove a 1992 Mercury Topaz, a car I did not wish to be, and a car decidedly not of pedigreed vintage.
My Topaz was too much like the cars I grew up with: anonymous, unreliable, uncool. And certainly not collectible. At the end, it was barely functioning as a station car, with 130,000 miles on the odometer, no air-conditioning (I gave up after it failed for the third time) and a $900 brake job on the horizon. Its book value, if perfect, was less than $500.
Which made it worthy of inclusion in the pantheon of clunkers that my father had owned: a sinister black 1948 Mercury sedan, a used '54 DeSoto convertible with the transmission that caught fire and a '63 Dodge Dart with turquoise, grease-absorbing upholstery.
Only one of Dad's cars ever worked well -- the bilious green 1955 Plymouth Plaza. But like the Topaz, it began to show its age. Same problem with the old Mercury. Brand new in '48, it looked a lot like a '39, the year Ford first brought out the Mercury line.
By the early 50's, once war shortages ended and design studios cranked up, American cars started to look more like bullets than homburgs. Sitting in the driveway, hearselike, five years after my father drove it off the lot, the Mercury was a brooding, humpback thing, compared with the flashy two-tone Pontiacs and Chevys that gleamed outside neighbors' garages. By 1960, I was the only kid on the block whose family car did not have dual headlights and tail fins.
But now I want that '48 Mercury back, or maybe the DeSoto. Or a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, the Doris Day of automobiles.
"It's adolescence," said John Heitmann, a professor of history at the University of Dayton who teaches a course on the automobile and American life. "They are the cars that were around you and wanted. Or maybe the cars you couldn't have."
"My dad had a '48 Chevy," Dr. Heitmann, who is 52, added. "That was the car I grew up with. A couple of weeks ago, I came across a '48 Chevy convertible at a cruise-in in nearby Kettering. I couldn't take my eyes off it. All those knobs on the dashboard, those little nuances of the interior."
Professor Heitmann drives a 1971 Porsche 911.
"Well, I don't think there's one pattern to collecting," he said. "But there are parallel kinds of motives. The overall pattern I see far more is with people who really know how to appreciate a technological past that puts the person in touch with the machine. The man-and-machine relationship emerges. People who drive old cars are like people who choose a Swiss mechanical watch over a quartz movement, or the fountain pen over an inkjet printer. The difference between my Porsche and the newer ones is like night and day. There is a phenomenal feel to an older auto."
Professor Heitmann is on to something. A combination of aesthetics and performance, something an owner-tinkerer can control.
This dovetails nicely with the thesis of John Armstrong, a research fellow in philosophy and the director of the aesthetics program at the School of Advanced Study, University of London.
"When we get really passionate about a particular kind of car," Dr. Armstrong said, "it is often because it taps into a deep longing we have. But for what? In a beautiful car, everything is 'just right.' The shape of the headlamps complements the lines of the radiator grille; the bonnet relates perfectly to the boot. If the chassis were an inch higher off the ground the car would lose its appearance of power; an inch lower and it would seem to drag.
"You can actually possess and drive a car -- you can get within this beauty and be part of it -- the better you handle the car, the more fully its qualities are revealed," said Dr. Armstrong, whose book "An Intimate Philosophy of Art," was published last month. "This enacts an ideal of what life ought to be like but almost never is."
That leaves nostalgia partly unaddressed. In the century that made them not only popular but also indispensable, cars have become part of the family story. You can trace family mishaps, milestones and personalties through them.
MY father's old Mercury let us down on several occasions, including in a snowstorm on the way to my grandmother's house. We sat in the cold for hours, and I got the measles. The used '54 DeSoto, which Dad insisted on taking to Vermont for a vacation one summer, caught fire as we pulled into a gas station on the New York State Thruway. The '63 Dart was totaled by a school bus that my mother did not see. Is that part of the reason those cars appeal to me?
Joseph J. Tecce, a 66-year-old psychology professor at Boston College, has spent years examining the collector in American society. He said people collect things -- cars, for instance -- for the satisfaction of being known and being knowledgeable, or to protect memories of the good old days. What we collect can make us feel good about ourselves, he said. In particular, cars can function as "social midwife or automotive alter ego."
And while Professor Tecce (the name rhymes with fetch) has graduated from the Volkswagens of the 60's and 70's ("I guess I was saying, 'Look at me, I am a humble college professor' ") to the security of a Toyota Camry, he cannot forget his 1948 Plymouth. "Inside it was comfortable and roomy, economical to run," he said.
"You know, wanting an old car like that Plymouth," he went on, "is kind of like wanting to go back and reverse the clock and get away from the Teflon, automatic, fast-paced jet age that we live in. To go back via the car, when there were fewer cars, less road rage, less road stress.
"It's two things," he said. "We can turn back the clock automotively, and we can turn back the clock psychologically. Some will want to do one, and not the other. Some will do both."
So the old Mercury beckons. And the Topaz? The Topaz, a discontinued model, is gone, given to charity for a tax deduction. I do not miss it. But surprisingly, my 14-year-old son was sorry to see it go.
He said he had hoped to fix it up, cover the seats with fake leopard skin and apply flame decals to the front doors.
He had hoped, he said, to get his license in that old car.

HEADLINE: In a Better World, Five 'Halo' Cars That Would Have Been

BYLINE: By THOMAS HINE; Thomas Hine is the author of "Populuxe" and "The Rise and Fall of the American Teenager."

 BODY:
IN 1956, a Newsweek cover depicted a car of the 21st century. It had a fighter plane's plastic bubble-roofed cockpit with a little spire antenna, three tail fins and wheels that were tucked well out of sight, perhaps because the designers were embarrassed that it did not fly. Half a century ago, cars dreamed of being airplanes.
But progress is not what it used to be. While we still expect automobiles to improve, their appearance need not dramatize their prowess. As long as they work well and are safe to drive, cars are free to be vehicles of pure emotion. Thus, the phenomenon of the "halo" car -- the PT Cruiser, the New Beetle, the reinvented Thunderbird -- which creates new audiences for designs that are decades old. 
 Newsweek's car of the future was based on the Nash Metropolitan, a cute, chubby two-seat Anglo-American economy car that, as it turned out, barely made it to 1960, let alone 2000. The hard-bodied futurism predicted for the car seemed at odds with the cuddly, eccentric Toontown character of that vehicle. In the unlikely event that designers decided to reinvent the Metropolitan as a halo car, it would be one in which Betty Boop would feel more at home than George Jetson.
Best, though, to leave it alone. The Metropolitan was perfect, in its perfectly ridiculous way. All the designs of the automotive past -- old favorites, youthful enthusiasms, false starts, dead ends and failed masterpieces -- are up for grabs in this age of automotive design. Here are five candidates I have chosen for reinterpretation.
1954 CADILLAC ELDORADO -- If ever a car marque needed a halo, it is the Cadillac, which has been trying to rediscover its identity for decades. The mid-50's models, with their tail fins and what Harley Earl, the General Motors styling chief, termed "graceful bulk," epitomized American excess. Now that American excess is very much back in style, it may be time to revisit your grandfather's Cadillac.
Compared with, say, a Lincoln Navigator sport utility vehicle, these outrageously luxurious cars of nearly half a century ago seem almost sensible. Sensible, though, is beside the point. These cars represent a high point in vulgarity, the triumph of nouveaux riches. Today, one would drive the car with a touch of irony about its nouveau riche appearance, while secretly reveling in its triumphant vulgarity.
1936-37 CORD -- This is a luxury car that is the opposite of the mid-50's Caddy, a consensus classic of elegant, subtle design. The Museum of Modern Art featured it in a 1951 exhibition, 14 years after it went off the market, terming it "a most solemn expression of streamlining." This pioneering front-wheel-drive car was designed by Gordon Miller Buehrig to be a smaller, more affordable version of the legendary Duesenberg, which he alsodesigned. The company was going broke. Most of the cars produced had mechanical problems. But the Cord remains an iconic car.
The front fenders were monumental, separated from the engine compartment so that you could see the horizontal louvers of the grille reach down the sides, all the way to the front door. This exaggerated the apparent length of the car, which was almost imperceptibly tipped upward toward the rear to give it a look of power barely under control.
1932-34 FORD V-8 B-400 CONVERTIBLE -- With the popularity of the PT Cruiser, which looks as if it ought to be carrying Edward G. Robinson and a bunch of thugs with machine guns, how about a real getaway car? These are the "dandy cars" that Clyde Barrow, of Bonnie and Clyde fame, always stole "when I could get away with one," during his Dust Bowl-era bank-robbing spree, as he noted in a fan letter to Henry Ford himself. "For sustained speed and freedom from trouble, the Ford has got every other car skinned," he wrote. Barrow was ultimately gunned down in one.
As a design, the Ford is admirably direct, a no-frills machine that delivered horsepower at a good price.
1950 STUDEBAKER CHAMPION STARLITE COUPE -- Because of its distinctive wraparound rear windshield, jokers used to say that this car didn't know whether it was coming or going. But its distinctive bullet nose really left no doubt. This was another aspiring airplane.
Like most other post-World War II Studebakers, this was designed under the supervision of Raymond Loewy, whose exploration of unornamented, fast-looking but unstreamlined forms reached something close to perfection in the classic, though commercially unsuccessful, Loewy coupe of 1953. The 1950 model, by contrast, was odd yet quite popular. Perhaps its strangeness could give a designer some clues about how to add excitement to the mainstream family car.
BUCKMINSTER FULLER DYMAXION TRANSPORT -- What the world needs now is a three-wheel lightweight car that holds 11 passengers, goes 120 miles an hour, gets 30 miles a gallon, can do a U-turn in less than its length, and looks as if it came from the Planet Mongo.
Actually, the Dymaxion looked more like an Airstream trailer with nothing pulling it, or like an airplane without wings, which was essentially what it was. Fuller, the visionary-tinkerer best remembered for the geodesic dome, produced several prototype cars over a decade, beginning in 1933. I am particularly taken with a later five-passenger model whose wheels could all turn when you wanted to park in a space exactly the size of the car. (Each wheel had its own small motor, too, though you didn't have to run them all.)
These were strange cars, and obviously required getting used to. The conductor Leopold Stokowski, who was one of the few people to actually own a Dymaxion, apparently found driving it terrifying and kept it only a few months. The day may come when we have to worry once again about the air we pollute and the oil we deplete when we drive. Fuller's characteristically American response to the challenge was not self-denial but invention. He liked to drive, and nobody thought "outside of the box" quite the way Bucky did.

LENGTH: 1005 words

HEADLINE: All Aboard the Foreign Language Express

BYLINE: By TANYA MOHN 

 BODY:
Richard M. Crain had a sound business reason for teaching himself Japanese. "I looked around, and I said to myself, who has money?" said Dr. Crain, a dentist in Larchmont, N.Y. So he hired a Japanese dental assistant and, with her help, began learning basic phrases. He also installed a phone line with an answering message in Japanese, had his dental forms translated into Japanese and posted notices in convenience stores frequented by the growing Japanese community in Westchester County.
The plan worked. So far, he has treated some 500 Japanese patients. 
 There were a few bumps along the way. Once, Dr. Crain meant to say "please spit" but used the word for sushi instead. The patient just stared at him. Today, though, with an arsenal of Japanese words and phrases at his command, and an English-Japanese dictionary nearby, he said, he can "pretty much handle the whole thing."
Eric Ploumis, an orthodontist whose office is a few doors away from Dr. Crain's, has also given his business a linguistic boost. Dr. Ploumis treats many of the children who attend the local French American school, and about a year and a half ago, he hired a tutor to teach him French.
He did so, not to communicate more clearly with his young patients, who are mostly conversant in English. No, Dr. Ploumis also wanted to be able to connect with their mothers. "Whether it's how to write a thank-you note to a mother in French, or how to say, 'Your child needs four teeth removed,' " mastering French "certainly enhances my business," he said.
Dr. Ploumis and Dr. Crain are just the tip of a linguistic iceberg that has barged rather suddenly into the American workplace. As more immigrants pour into the country and as more Americans do deals with foreign companies, learning a foreign language has increasingly become a career plus, and sometimes a career must.
While nobody seems to track the number of Americans who are studying a foreign language, private language school enrollments reflect the trend. Karen Decker, president of the International Center for Language Studies, a school in Washington that teaches over 80 languages, says about 90 percent of the students attend for work purposes. Cheryl Gordon, founder of Language Plus, in El Paso, says the number at her school is closer to 98 percent.
And Helen Hamlyn, an official with Language Testing International in White Plains, an arm of the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages, says the number of language-proficiency exams administered by companies to employees has soared by nearly 1,000 percent in 12 years.
It is not foreign-bound executives who are leading the trend, either, Ms. Hamlyn says. Rather, languages are being spoken more and more by rank-and-file workers at banks, telephone companies and other service providers that have lots of foreign-born customers. Demand is highest for proficiency in Spanish, but is also growing for Mandarin Chinese, Cantonese, Korean, Vietnamese, Russian and Hindi.
Sometimes, the goal is more to familiarize people with a foreign culture than to make them fluent in a foreign tongue. After entering into a business liaison with Nikon of Japan recently, for example, the microelectronics division of I.B.M. in East Fishkill, N.Y., put a group of its employees through a two-day immersion course in Japanese. The idea was to teach them a few common greetings and also a little bit about Japanese customs.
Margaret Cogswell kicked off the course with a briefing on the formality of Japanese culture and the complexities of exchanging meeshi, or business cards, with Japanese executives. "Japan is a society of manners," she said. The group paired off to tackle words like konnichiwa, hajimemashite and dozo yoroshiku ("Hello, How do you do? Pleased to meet you") and to practice the arts of handing out business cards and bowing.
Carl Bohnenkamp, a senior laboratory specialist, said the class made him realize he probably came on too strong in previous dealings with the Japanese. "I'm going to try to be a little bit more open and sensitive to their culture" in the future, he said.
The classes were conducted by the Language Immersion Institute of the State University of New York at New Paltz, which says it is getting more and more requests for such specialized training. The institute has taught Spanish to personnel at a New York area hospital and even given lessons in "party French" to executives of a New York media company who wanted to take Parisian clients out for a night on the town.
English, of course, is the lingua franca of the global economy, so American executives can travel abroad without uttering the native language. But such ignorance can put them at a disadvantage, while just a little effort can pay big dividends, educators say.
"Even though they hold the meetings in English, you miss the asides," said Harriet Barnett, a consultant at the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages in Yonkers. Just making an effort to say a few words in the native tongue can make a good impression, she said, and "it sends a subliminal message that 'we are equal.' "
The movement has spread to some blue-collar workplaces, especially construction sites, where failure to communicate can result in accidents. John Dusch, the 54-year-old safety director of MKB Construction Inc. in Phoenix, said its safety record had improved since English-speaking workers took Spanish lessons this summer so they could converse with Spanish-speaking colleagues. And for the first time, "the entire crew eat lunch together," he said.
The linguistic demands of work can take some surprising turns. Police officers in El Paso once acquired drug-sniffing dogs from Czechoslovakia, and were unable to communicate with them. So they went to Ms. Gordon of Language Plus, who had taught some of them Spanish. Should they learn Czech, they asked, or should they teach the dogs English? Given how hard it is to retrain dogs, and that Ms. Gordon's expertise was with humans, they learned Czech.

HEADLINE: South Korea Points Fingers On Two Recent Failed Deals

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The South Korean government began trying to assign blame today for the recent failures of two large business deals that have raised questions about the country's commitment to economic reform.
Last month, the Ford Motor Company abandoned a $6.9 billion bid to buy Daewoo Motors, and a week ago, a group of investors led by Nabors Capital, a Houston-based firm, walked away from a proposed $480 million purchase of the Hanbo Steel Company. Both Korean companies are insolvent. 
 The Financial Supervisory Service criticized the Korea First Bank and the state-run Korea Asset Management Corporation, major creditors of Hanbo, for failing to shape a contract that would have penalized the Nabors group for pulling out of the deal.
And it faulted the Daewoo Restructuring Committee and its head, Oh Hogen, for failing to prepare for an event like the Firestone tire recall and the impact that might have on Ford's bid for Daewoo Motors. The government has insisted that Ford's decision to walk away was based solely on Ford's own problems and had nothing to do with Daewoo Motors itself.
"Daewoo's creditors failed to arrange a contingency plan for the deal against a possible pull-out in relation to the Firestone tire recall," the Financial Supervisory Service said in a statement. Ford has said its decision to abandon the Daewoo deal had nothing to do with Ford's Bridgestone/Firestone problems.
The government seemed to time its criticism especially to embarrass Mr. Oh, an aggressive advocate of painful corporate change. He was already scheduled to leave his job as head of the Daewoo Restructuring Committee on Wednesday, when his contract expired, but the government forced him to pack up today.
"It's funny, really," he said in a telephone interview this evening. "They had to have someone to pin the responsibility on, and I was that person. That's it."
In an interview on Aug. 10 in Seoul, Mr. Oh said that his last day in charge of Daewoo's restructuring would be Oct. 11, when his contract expired. "I have no intention of extending it," he said at that time, speaking of his contract.
He foreshadowed some of what transpired today in that August interview. "It's been a tough job," he said, speaking not only of his time at Daewoo but also his previous role as head of the Corporate Restructuring Committee, which supervised the overhaul of many Korean conglomerates in the aftermath of the financial crisis in 1997. "When you've done well, you hardly get any thanks for it, and very often, the people who are supposed to be on your side don't recognize the problems and want only quick solutions, not fundamental fixes."
The government is not his only critic. He left behind a string of angry foreign bankers, who were irked when Mr. Oh forced them to accept a deal under which they would receive on average only 40 percent of their loans to Daewoo.
"It's not just the government that wants to blame me," he said today.
He said he did not expect the government's criticism to hurt his prospects for work in the future. "I'll find something to do," he said.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
An Industry on the Brink of Good Cheer?

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
AMERICANS are drinking more good wine than ever before, and regardless of what happens to the economy, they could, by 2015, be drinking a whole lot more.
At least that's the way a respected California consulting firm sees things, and it backs up those rosy predictions with some fascinating figures. Since 1994, according to Motto Kryla & Fisher, wine industry analysts and consultants based in St. Helena, Calif., adult Americans' per capita spending on wine has increased 83 percent, to $64 a year from $35, while their yearly consumption has risen 22 percent, to 8.4 bottles from 6.9. 
 During the same period, premium wine sales among the same group have grown 77 percent, to 4.6 bottles a year from 2.6. "Premium" is a wide category; it includes all wine selling for $3 or more a bottle.
What is more, the consultants say, "if current consumption in key areas is projected to their future populations, total wine sales could increase 80 percent by 2015." Which is another way of saying that if, for example, the good people of Cleveland, a city noted neither for its profligacy nor its abstemiousness, continue to drink wine at their current rate, while their numbers increase at officially projected rates, wine sales in Cleveland will be 80 percent higher than now.
Heady stuff for Clevelanders, especially their wine merchants.
"We've never seen a period like this in the history of the wine industry," Vic Motto said. "The outlook is not only positive, it's euphoric."
In its euphoria, Motto Kryla & Fisher brushes aside the impact that an economic downturn might have on the wine industry. A cooler economy would be unlikely to "significantly reduce overall wine consumption," the firm contends, because it is "driven more by marketing and cultural factors than economic ones."
Maybe so, but is ours really "a wine culture"? There are probably Americans who have adopted wine as an integral part of their lives, but not all that many. Any astute wine merchant will agree that much of his income derives from other people's discretionary income. And as for being part of the culture, why have the French and Italians been drinking less wine every year since the end of World War II? Cheap wine may have been part of their lives for centuries, but they dropped some or all of it when cold beer and soft drinks became widely available.
As for marketing, most of it is concentrated on fighting over market share. Wine sales may be booming, but the domestic market is still unimpressive by world standards, and recent consumption is actually less than it was 15 years ago. Figures from the Wine Institute, a trade group, showed that in 1999 consumption came to about 2.02 gallons per capita, substantially less than the 2.43 gallons in both 1985 and 1986 and well below the 16.2 gallons consumed in the same year by Italians and the 15.8 gallons consumed by the French.
Worth noting, too, is the domestic per capita consumption of soft drinks (54 gallons) and coffee (30 gallons).
And not all the wine industry is getting in on the fun. In the Central Valley of California, where the grapes for most nonpremium wines grow, prices this year are at all-time lows. While cabernet sauvignon in the Napa Valley is selling for $3,000 a ton or more, Central Valley growers with long-term contracts are getting about $500, and growers with no contracts with wineries are being offered $100 a ton. A big grape crop was cited for the lower prices.
The 2000 grape harvest in California is expected to be 10 to 30 percent larger than the 2.6 million tons brought in last year. Wine exports, while still growing, were up only about 2 percent last year, compared with 26 percent in 1998. Analysts cite increasing competition from other wine-producing countries, the Wine Institute said.
While the wine boom is not confined to the high end of the market, overall figures, like those for per capita consumption, are more modest. All wines entering United States distribution channels last year set a record, 551 million gallons, but the increase was just 5 percent. Wine sales in supermarkets were up about 3 percent.
Still, the action in the expensive end of the market was fast and furious. According to the Motto Kryla & Fisher report, the more expensive the wine is, the faster the market grows. In luxury wines, those $25 or more a bottle, the market grew 30 percent last year and is expected to extend even further as baby boomers grow older and more affluent. Farther down the scale, consumers were moving up to better wines, or at least to more expensive wines.
In 1994, when adults drank 6.9 bottles of wine each, 4.3 of those were generic wines, a nice way of saying jug wines, and 2.6 were "premium" wines costing $3 or more. By last year, with adult consumption up to 8.4 bottles, the categories were reversed: 4.6 bottles were premium and 3.8 generic.
Taste was growing more sophisticated in other ways. White wines were still the most popular, accounting for 39 percent of all purchases, but red wines, at 35 percent, were the fastest-growing category. Roses, blush wines and others were off 3 percent, to 26 percent of purchases. Chardonnay was, yet again, the most popular varietal, with 18 percent of sales; white zinfandel was second, with 15 percent; merlot third, with 9 percent; and cabernet sauvignon fourth, with 8 percent. Merlot's performance was impressive -- its sales increased 26 percent to beat cabernet sauvignon for the first time.

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 6; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: There's No Fair Price

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In his Oct. 4 column about price fairness and Amazon.com's charging different customers different amounts for the same products, Paul Krugman raises an interesting issue that is at the heart of all transactions in our new economy. The idea is to charge the maximum price that the individual or the market at large can bear without any regard to the cost of production or "fairness."
The dictum is in evidence from health care (different prices for different patients for the same procedures and drugs, depending on who is paying for it) to automobiles to open bidding for public and private contracts. Further, even if cost was a consideration for pricing, the relevant cost is debatable -- should it be based on full cost, marginal cost or life-cycle cost? 
 Finally, fairness is arbitrary as well: Fair to the buyer, the seller or society?
 
KRISHAN M. GUPTA
Dartmouth, Mass., Oct. 4, 2000
 
The writer is a visiting lecturer in accounting at the University of Massachusetts.

LENGTH: 1009 words

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT;
A Start-Up's Hiring Attracts Unwanted Attention

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
Like a lot of start-ups, Cardima Inc., a maker of medical devices in Fremont, Calif., found it hard to predict how big a permanent staff it would need. So, in 1993, the company hired mostly independent contractors to fill the gap.
Independent contractors work for a specified length of time for specified pay, and the move made good business sense. But it also created a management problem. Because companies do not withhold taxes or make Social Security payments on the earnings of such workers, any decision to rely on large numbers of them usually sounds an alarm bell at the Internal Revenue Service and state employment agencies. And that is exactly what happened. 
 Four years later, the Employment Development Authority of California investigated Cardima, reviewing records, sifting through accounts and interviewing employees, to determine if the company was unwittingly misclassifying its independent contractors on tax forms. Instead of being independent contractors, the agency wondered, perhaps they were doing the job of a traditional employee and should be classified as such? It turns out that some of Cardima's workers were not correctly classified.
"This is a usual thing with companies, especially start-ups," said Ron Bourquin, Cardima's chief financial officer. While he was confident it had not purposely done anything illegal, he says, he ended up hiring PrO Unlimited, a company in Burlingame, Calif., that manages contingent workers for clients, just to be on the safe side. (Contingent workers include independent contractors; freelancers, who do occasional work for companies at a set fee; outside consultants; and temporary, part-time and seasonal employees.)
Hiring PrO Unlimited was probably a smart move, legal specialists say, because the law is so complicated and executives can probably spend their time more fruitfully planning strategy than trying to figure out all the rules.
"It's very important for business entities to be advised of how independent contractors are properly engaged," said Scott Brenner, an employment lawyer with Barton Barton & Plotkin, in Manhattan. "If a company improperly characterizes employees as independent contractors, or consultants, there is risk that the arrangements could be recharacterized by the I.R.S., sometimes having grave unforeseen financial consequences. We advise clients that this is not generally an area to take great risk."
Indeed, the question of how to classify members of a company's work force has become more pressing as the hiring of independent contractors has become more common. The American Management Association said that 93 percent of the companies it surveyed last year employed some kind of outside workers. The study found that twice as many employers reported more use of temps and contract workers in 1999 than they had in 1996. As of February 1999, a total of 8.2 million workers -- or 6.3 percent of the work force -- were independent contractors, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"Management is recalibrating its relationship with labor, and changing it to be more flexible," said Barrie Peterson, associate director of Seton Hall University's Institute on Work in South Orange, N.J. He helped write the American Management Association study.
Terrie Weinand, the chief operating officer of PrO Unlimited, the company hired by Cardima, says it is easy for managers to become confused. After all, they are focused on putting out a product, not interpreting tax law. What they ought to do is to avoid even the appearance of impropriety, Ms. Weinand says.
"We try to tell people that if they know they are doing something looked upon as shady, don't mess with the I.R.S.," she said. "In 90 percent of the companies they investigate, they do find at least some that misclassify workers."
Some specialists estimate that in Silicon Valley alone, employers have paid nearly $50 million in back taxes and fines to the I.R.S. as a result of misclassifying workers. And though many companies have policies on handling contingent workers, "the I.R.S. doesn't care what you wrote down in a policy manual, they want to know what you did," Ms. Weinand said.
"Under the law, independent contractors are not a worker, they are a business," she added. "But when they walk across your lobby and start acting like employees, that's when the trouble starts. If they sit in a cube all day, bill hourly, have no financial investment in the business and do similar work to what your full-time employees do, then they are, technically, an employee."
It is not just the I.R.S. that is becoming involved, either. Because independent contractors receive no company benefits, the Labor Department is quick to step in if it suspects abuses. Two years ago, for example, it sued Time Warner for failure to pay health and retirement benefits to scores of workers. A company spokesman said the matter was in litigation and declined to comment.
And in 1996, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco ordered Microsoft to pay benefits to hundred of workers that the company said were independent contractors but that the courts found otherwise. Since then, Microsoft has begun reclassifying temporary workers as company employees if 12-month assignments have to be extended.
"This is Microsoft's way of saying to managers, 'Don't just make this a temporary assignment because it could be looked at that way. Is it a temporary assignment?' " said Kimberly Kuresman, a Microsoft spokeswoman. "If you need someone longer, let's make it a real position and hire someone full time."
She will not get any argument from Mr. Bourquin, Cardima's chief financial officer. Cardima had to pay about $25,000 in back taxes for independent contractors found to be employees, and he does not want to have to repeat that painful experience.
"The important part is going forward and knowing you are in compliance with the law," he said. "The state then sees that you made an effort and it makes everything you do more credible."

Chart: "Playing It Safe"
Five tips for employers who hire independent contractors.
 
Make sure all new independent contractors classify themselves as businesses for tax purposes.
 
Keep track of how long they stay with your company.
 
Pay them a set fee for specified projects, not an hourly wage.
 
Make sure they return all company badges, keys and passes at the end of each day.
 
Make them sign nondisclosure agreements.

HEADLINE: Why U.S. Giants Are Crying Uncle;
Europe's Top Antitrust Regulator Steps Up Merger Scrutiny

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 10

 BODY:
If American companies have any lingering doubts about Mario Monti's toughness, they are likely to be dispelled on Wednesday.
Mr. Monti, the European Union's chief antitrust regulator, is expected to approve the proposed $165 billion merger between Time Warner Inc. and America Online Inc. -- but not without extracting a heavy price. 
 Already, after weeks of sparring with Mr. Monti and his merger task force, Time Warner reluctantly agreed last Thursday to abandon a separate $20 billion deal to combine the operations of Warner Music with the EMI Group of Britain.
America Online and Time Warner, meanwhile, have promised, among other things, to open their online networks to competing providers of entertainment.
This is the latest but hardly the only case in which European and American corporations have had their mergers thwarted or at least modified by Mr. Monti, a soft-spoken, silver-haired Italian economist.
Since he became the commissioner in charge of competition affairs last year, Mr. Monti has become feared and respected as a man with the power to derail some of the world's biggest mergers if he is convinced they would restrict competition.
Last spring, he blocked WorldCom's planned $115 billion combination with Sprint. Shortly before that, his objections forced Sweden's two big truck manufacturers, Volvo and Scania, to abandon their plans for a $7 billion merger. Also this year, Mr. Monti effectively blocked a $17 billion merger of three of the world's biggest aluminum companies, Alcan Aluminium of Canada, Pechiney of France and the Alusuisse Lonza Group of Switzerland.
This toughness is not entirely new. Mr. Monti's predecessor, Karel Van Miert, almost blocked the merger of Boeing and McDonnell-Douglas in 1997. Boeing salvaged the deal by capitulating to demands that it abandon its exclusive long-term sales contracts with several airlines.
But Mr. Monti has stepped up the pace. With a staff of only 47 investigators on his Merger Task Force, he has picked his shots carefully but plunged ferociously into many of the world's biggest and most complex deals.
"People say he is much tougher," said Christopher Norall, an antitrust lawyer at the firm of Morrison & Foerster here. "But, to be fair, these cases present new issues where each wave of mergers brings successive waves of concentration."
Over the last decade, the European Commission has rejected only 13 mergers outright. Three of those rejections have come in the year since Mr. Monti took office, and two other companies rescinded their plans before they were officially rejected. But the number of mergers has escalated rapidly, and the vast majority are still approved without controversy. This year, commission officials predict that they will review 340 mergers, up from 292 in 1999.
Indeed, American antitrust officials have reached many of the same conclusions as Mr. Monti. Within days of the European Commission's decision to block the WorldCom-Sprint merger, for example, the United States Justice Department went to court to block the deal as well.
American officials did not appear as worried as the Europeans about the deal between Warner Music and EMI. But they may well be much tougher about Time Warner's merger with America Online, because Time Warner can use its vast cable television operations in the United States to provide high-speed online services.
In Europe, by contrast, Time Warner has no cable television systems and America Online is smaller than local online services in every European country.
Mr. Monti, a methodical man who measures his words carefully, often speaks like an academic and was in fact a professor of economics and adviser to the Italian government earlier in his career. Though Mr. Monti professes loyalty to the "social market economy," he has long been a champion of deregulation and free trade.
Before taking his current job, he spent four years as the European Union's commissioner in charge of harmonizing the various countries' conflicting rules. In essence, Mr. Monti led the effort to dismantle the legal barriers among the 15 members of the European Union.
He pushed for years to persuade European governments to adopt common tax practices, a Sisyphean task that remains mostly unfinished.
But he also showed himself ready to disregard relentless pressure from both governments and corporations. His biggest political battle and success was in rescinding the tax-free status of duty-free shops at airports and harbors.
Trivial as it sounded, the issue provoked furious protests and even street demonstrations by workers in various industries, including duty-free retailers, airlines and liquor companies.
Mr. Monti argued that duty-free shops merely allowed affluent travelers to avoid sales taxes because duties between European Union countries had already been eliminated. After a long battle, he finally won.
He replaced Mr. Van Miert as the competition regulator last year, after accusations of corruption led to a complete overhaul of all the top posts. Neither man was among those accused of any impropriety, but both joined all the other commissioners in voluntarily resigning. Mr. Monti was among a handful of people reappointed to a commission post by Romano Prodi, the European Commission's new president.
Mr. Monti differs sharply from Mr. Van Miert in both style and substance. Mr. Van Miert, a former leader of the Flemish Socialist party in Belgium, routinely made off-the-cuff remarks in public well in advance of final decisions. He also liked to bargain with companies, extracting as many concessions as possible without having to wage a full-court battle.
The current antitrust chief keeps his opinions to himself and he has been much more distant in dealing with the companies. Rather than starting with aggressive demands and backing down, Mr. Monti has picked his targets carefully and then has held firm.
Time Warner and EMI may have learned this a bit late. Mr. Monti objected that their deal would severely reduce the number of worldwide rivals in music distribution, and he was not satisfied when EMI offered to spin off some of its smaller European labels.
Under the rules, the companies were supposed to offer any proposed remedies by Sept. 18. But it was only two weeks ago, after the companies realized that Mr. Monti was ready to block the deal, that they offered to sell Virgin records, one of EMI's major record labels.
It remains unclear whether Time Warner and EMI simply miscalculated by waiting so long. But Mark Powell, an antitrust expert in Brussels with the law firm of White & Case, said the commission had been much stricter about deadlines precisely because it wanted to limit last-minute bargaining.
"There is much less room for maneuver," Mr. Powell said. "At the least, companies going into these deals should have thought through all their fallback positions in case the going gets tough."
