HEADLINE: A TALE OF TWO DOWNTOWNS;
After Worst of Times, Building for the Best

BYLINE: By JOHN LELAND 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
THE old warehouse on Auburn Avenue was long an eyesore, and Alton Evans, 40, can remember when it was worse. Just a few years ago, he said, the building sat gutted, a haven for transients and drug dealers. That was the mid-1990's in the central city neighborhood known as the Old Fourth Ward, and anything could happen. In those days, residents say, the area resembled the Wild Wild West.
On a recent afternoon, Mr. Evans stood on the same site, at the center of a different sort of activity. He hunkered in his tidy metalwork studio, putting the final touches on an Adinkra symbol from West Africa. His neighbors, Ursallie Smith and Celeste Alexander, laid out swaths of bold-patterned fabric -- "Ursace," Ms. Alexander calls it, to rhyme with Versace -- in their interior design showroom. Around them, in place of urban decay, a concrete honeycomb of lofts buzzed with painters, sculptors, Internet developers, glass blowers, designers of all disciplines. 
 Mishele Lesser, 27, a graphic artist and painter, left her door unlocked so neighbors could visit her roomy loft. "I always wanted to live in a loft," Ms. Lesser said, looking up from a computer. "Living here has made me be more free, because I can get different people's opinion on my work."
She was talking about Studioplex, Atlanta's $18.3 million, 225,000-square-foot experiment in urban redevelopment. Two years ago, a nonprofit group called the Historic District Development Corporation took over the disused cotton compress warehouse with a bold plan: in a city of epic suburban sprawl, the group envisioned an arena-size loft community to draw artists and Web pioneers to a poor downtown neighborhood. Some would live and work there. Others, like Mr. Evans, would set up shops to lure visitors. Nonartists were welcome as well. "We figure that anybody who wants to live with artists is O.K.," said Mtamanika Youngblood, president of the development group. "I look at them as patrons."
David Green of Brock Green Architects carved a courtyard down the middle of the old brick warehouse, a 500-foot-long grass swath separating two rows of lofts, galleries and retail spaces.
Then last year, artists and others started moving in: racially diverse, often young, often single and collectively not beholden to the time clock. A community was born.
In the evenings, residents gather in the long public courtyard, buoyed by conga drumming from the dance studio upstairs. "I like to go there and talk about art and smell all the different things cooking," said Jim Alexander, 65, whose showroom loft bustles with his photographs of Duke Ellington, Miles Davis, and other musicians. "Been a real long time since you had white people with an Auburn Avenue address," Mr. Alexander said, laughing gently. "It's getting to be a good mix of people around here."
The complex is the ambitious anchor for a larger, block-by-block program to rejuvenate this neighborhood of wooden ranch houses, bungalows and shotgun houses that was once home to the city's affluent black community. Auburn Avenue, once dubbed "the richest Negro street in the world," includes the birth home of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the King National Historic Site, the city's top tourist attractions.
But the area has been in decline since the 1950's, when cheap land and good highways carried Atlantans to the suburbs, leaving behind a population that was poorer, older and politically weaker. In the 1960's, as in many black neighborhoods, construction of an elevated highway cut Auburn Avenue in two, casting a blockwide shadow across what remained of the business strip.
As locals left or holed up indoors, open-air drug markets flowered along the main avenues; moonshine sales and a nickel numbers racket -- literal small change -- endure even today. On a bright morning, Dave MacDonald, 43, who moved to the Old Fourth Ward in 1992, wistfully remembered some of his old neighbors. "One crack addict drag queen used to walk down the center lane of Edgewood Avenue in a drum majorette uniform at rush hour, holding up traffic," said Mr. MacDonald, a social worker and community advocate. "I canceled my cable because nothing was as dramatic as what was happening on the street."
Now, Mr. MacDonald said, suburban sprawl and its clogged highways are starting to attract a new population to the Old Fourth Ward, with resources the neighborhood needs. "There was an underground arts movement here 10 years ago," said Mr. MacDonald, who is also a sculptor. "Studioplex is bringing it aboveground."
The building now offers 112 living lofts, as well as 41 galleries and commercial spaces, many punctuated with floor-to-ceiling windows to draw in sunlight. About 60 percent of the residents are artists; 20 percent of the lofts are set aside for tenants with incomes below $22,700.
Amy Sherald, who lives in one of the subsidized lofts, pays just $600 rent for 1,038 square feet, where she lives and works. Ms. Sherald, 27, has spiky brown braids, and Japanese characters tattooed on both arms, "artist" on one side, "strong and tall" on the other. On a recent afternoon, one of her oversize canvases awaited further work, and a handful of others hung on the loft's spacious walls: naked, shaven-headed figures in cobalt blues and ruddy browns, vistas of strong color vibrant in the natural sunlight.
Before she moved to Studioplex, Ms. Sherald lived in small apartments with no room for her large works, and she gave up painting. "I don't think anybody can create in a space where they don't feel comfortable," she said. "I feel comfortable here. And I've gotten a lot of exposure here."
The complex hopes to follow successful programs, including several begun by the Minneapolis-based Artspace, where developers used artists -- and federal tax credits -- to jump-start renewal in tough neighborhoods. Besides Studioplex, the development group has built 51 new single- and two-family homes, and rehabilitated another 35, sweeping through the neighborhood a block at a time. Though the Old Fourth Ward is the inner city, most of its terrain is low-density, free-standing homes; a handful of solid structures could anchor a block, Ms. Youngblood said. The new houses follow the mixed grid of the neighborhood, a modest shotgun house, which might sell for as little as $89,000, next to a grander, and much more expensive, Victorian. Mr. Evans, the metal sculptor at Studioplex, saw the bright, pastel new homes as the march of history. "I was concerned about coming here," he said, "until I saw them building $300,000 homes across the street."
Dana White, a professor of urban studies at Emory University, has watched nearly three decades of renewal programs fail in the neighborhood. Most fell short, he said, because they were largely cosmetic; even after the improvements, the stabilizing elements in the community continued to sheer off to the suburbs. Between 1960 and 2000, the city population dropped by 11.8 percent, while that of the city and near suburbs combined more than tripled, according to the Fiscal Research Program at Georgia State University. The current initiative, by contrast, aims to bring in a new urban tribe, to draw on a generation tiring of the suburbs. The 1996 Olympic Games provided early help by bringing people and development money downtown. "It seems to be the beginning of the first major change in half a century," Professor White said, taking care to qualify his optimism. Studioplex will be a test for the development program. Unlike past measures, "it's building a new type of downtown," he said, adding, "Whether there's enough there to draw visitors and be fully viable, we'll see."
For Attiya Melton, a sculptor and ceramist, the complex has been an incubator for collaborative creativity. Ms. Melton, 49, lives in a second-floor loft and has a 3,400-square-foot studio and showroom below. She likes to fire the kiln in the middle of the night, go back up to bed, then come down later to work through dawn. Sometimes, she said, she has to remember to leave the building.
Since she moved to Studioplex last December, Ms. Melton has found an almost small-town bonhomie among the other artists. Web designers helped her document her work digitally; Mr. Evans advised her on indigenous American symbols to use in her work; other artists helped her build walls, lent their equipment and shared tips about the best places to buy supplies. It is a place, she said, of "informal mentoring, just being in the same place, gathering and talking."
It is also a place, potentially, for artists to do some business. Louis Delsarte, 56, a painter from Crown Heights, Brooklyn, is raising his 6-year-old daughter in the complex. "I miss New York," Mr. Delsarte said. "That's why I'm here. This, so far, is the closest I've felt to being in New York, because of the communication and the energy."
Though he does not show his work at any of the Studioplex galleries, Mr. Delsarte has made valuable contacts among the people visiting the center. In the six months since he moved in, he said, he has sold "four or five" paintings, at prices of up to $6,000. Because he sold the paintings himself, he did not have to share money with an agent.
Nor is the development done. Next March, the development group plans to open a restaurant and coffeehouse in the scrubland behind Studioplex, with a commercial strip to follow. Plans are in the works to build a performing arts theater and to reopen the neighborhood's only school, which closed in the mid-1990's.
David Patton, 34, who moved to the neighborhood in 1994, left his job as assistant dean of students at the Emory University School of Law to start the restaurant. After living through the area's rough years, said Mr. Patton, who is president of the development group's board, "we want to rebuild something that resembles the community when Dr. King lived here, with mixed incomes, and the elderly taken care of."
As a retail location, Studioplex has not lived up to what many of the artists hoped. The galleries and shops have had little success drawing tourists from the King sites just down Auburn Avenue. Though a recent National Black Arts Festival drew thousands to the complex, on most days, foot traffic is little more than a trickle. "If I had to rely on the people who come through here, I couldn't survive," said Ms. Smith, 37, the interior designer.
Michael Syphoe, who oversees commercial development for the development group, argued that the artists underestimate the marketing required to make their businesses work. He named a handful of Studioplex tenants that he expected to fail in the next year. "This is a business," he said. "I've got some folks who are not go-getters."
For all the improvements, the Old Fourth Ward is still rough around the edges. Drug dealers, moved off some corners or buildings, resurface elsewhere. Last Friday, Ernie Geyer, a co-owner of one of the neighborhood's bright spots, a new luncheonette called Thumb's Up, was shot in the leg while taking the day's deposit to the bank. Mr. Geyer was not hurt seriously and has returned to work.
Even so, the neighborhood is already threatening to become the victim of its own success. Though the development group has taken care not to uproot its poor neighbors, private developers are not always as fussy.
Dave MacDonald said that the darker signs of gentrification, what he calls "the predators," are creeping in among the pretty renovations. Lately, he said, signs have appeared on telephone poles, saying, "Christian man seeks to buy your house." The offers, he said, are aimed at the neighborhood's poor and elderly residents. "The predators see a chance to make a buck, and offer people $20,000 for their houses." Mr. MacDonald said he rips the signs down, a meager gesture against an unpleasant tide.
Meanwhile, shiny new houses jostle with decaying shells, competing visions of the neighborhood's future. Studioplex has a waiting list of 150 names. For Amy Sherald, the painter, the area's future is already visible, and both wondrous and frightening. With all the new housing going up, she said, "I'm scared of how traffic is going to be." In this town, there is no greater sign of success.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
MYANMAR: U.N. ENVOY MEETS ACTIVIST
The United Nations special envoy to Myanmar met the pro-democracy activist Daw Aung San Suu Kyi at her home in Yangon, the capital, ending more than two weeks of isolation for the Nobel Peace Prize laureate, who is under house arrest. The envoy, Razali Ismail of Malaysia, spent two hours at her residence, accompanied by local United Nations officials. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi has been confined to her home with her telephone cut since Sept. 22. (Reuters) 

PHILIPPINES: CARDINAL URGES PRESIDENT TO QUIT
Cardinal Jaime Sin and a council of 75 Catholic priests urged President Joseph Estrada to resign, saying a payoff scandal had destroyed public trust in his leadership. The presidential palace rejected the call, saying the embattled former movie actor, accused of receiving $8.7 million from gambling lords, would not step down. Demonstrators rallied outside the Senate depicting Mr. Estrada as "The Godfather," above. In 1986 the cardinal helped lead a revolt that toppled Ferdinand E. Marcos. (Reuters)
 
PAKISTAN: RIGHTS SITUATION ASSAILED
Human rights conditions in Pakistan have deteriorated since the military took power a year ago, the New York-based Human Rights Watch said. Its report said political activities have been suppressed, and that opponents of the military regime have been subjected to prolonged detention without being charged. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
BANGLADESH: FLOODS RECEDE
Floods that have killed more than 130 people and left another two million homeless have begun to recede, allowing many people to return to their homes, officials announced. The rains, which started on Sept. 26, have swept away more than 675 miles of road and done major damage to rice crops. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
EAST TIMOR: REQUEST FOR MILITIA CHIEF DENIED
East Timor asked Indonesia to hand over the pro-Jakarta militia leader Eurico Guterres for questioning about massacres in the territory last year. But Indonesia quickly rejected the request, saying Mr. Guterres, 27, would remain under arrest in Jakarta in connection with separate investigations. A spokesman for the United Nations, which administers East Timor, said warrants had been issued for Mr. Guterres's arrest in the slaying of scores of civilians in two attacks before the territory's independence vote in August 1999. (Reuters)
 
JAPAN: 6 HELD IN NUCLEAR ACCIDENT
Six former top officials of a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant were arrested for an accident last year that killed two people and exposed hundreds to radiation. The suspects face charges of negligence resulting in death in the Sept. 30, 1999, accident at the plant 70 miles northeast of Tokyo. The six men could each get up to five years in prison or be fined $4,630, a police official said. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: MORE SUPPLIES FLOWN IN
Turkish and Syrian planes landed in Baghdad with aid and medical supplies to offset the effects of United Nations sanctions. It was the second time this week that both a Turkish and Syrian plane had landed at the recently reopened Saddam International Airport, airport officials said. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
NIGERIA: ISLAMIC CODE SHELVED
The northern state of Kaduna, torn by sectarian riots this year, said it had shelved plans to adopt the strict Islamic Shariah penal code. Gov. Muhammad Ahmed Makarfi cited the cosmopolitan nature of the state as a reason for the move. His announcement is expected to defuse the anxiety of non-Muslims, but could also anger Shariah's ardent backers. Hundreds of people died in Christian-Muslim fighting in Kaduna city last February and May over reported plans to introduce the law. (Reuters)
 
SOMALIA: PARLIAMENT MEMBERS ATTACKED
About 100 members of the new Parliament came under heavy fire from militiamen as they flew into Mogadishu in a step toward restoring central government after almost a decade of anarchy. One gunman was killed and nine people were wounded when the legislators' convoy was attacked outside a hotel. The legislators, none of whom were hurt, arrived from Djibouti, where the 245-member Parliament was set up in August as part of a peace conference bringing together representatives from Somalia's rival clans. (Reuters)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
PERU: FUJIMORI AGREES TO REFORMS
President Alberto Fujimori and the opposition have agreed to key judicial reforms, ending a deadlock in talks over re-establishing democratic institutions in preparation for new presidential and congressional elections next year. The accord does away with a system under which the president appoints provisional judges whom he can hire and fire any time, allowing for manipulation from the executive branch. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
ARGENTINA: 4 QUIT GOVERNING COALITION
Four members of the lower house of Congress said they would leave the government coalition because of their disagreement with President Fernando de la Rua's economic policies, making it tougher for the government to enact its legislative program. The Alianza has been splintering since the resignation last week of Vice President Carlos Alvarez, leader of the social democratic Frepaso party, which is joined in the government with the centrist Radical Party.Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
TURKEY: GREEK ARMY RETURNS
More than 75 years after they left Turkey as a defeated army, Greek troops returned, joining NATO exercises on Turkish territory for the first time. About 30 Greek soldiers jumped off Spanish and Italian helicopters ferrying them from ships in the Bay of Doganbey. The landing site is only 25 miles southwest of the Aegean port city of Izmir, which Greek troops occupied in 1919 as part of a disastrous campaign to seize Asia Minor from the Ottoman Empire. (AP)
 
ITALY: ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS STRANDED
About 500 illegal immigrants, mostly Kurds fleeing Iraq, were left stranded on a ship off Italy when the crew abandoned their passengers to avoid arrest. The coast guard guided the vessel, which left Izmir, Turkey, a week ago, to safety in the southern town of Otranto. The interior minister, Enzo Bianco, said Europe should organize a joint police force to safeguard its borders. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: SOLDIERS SLAIN
Officials said Chechen rebels had killed four Russian soldiers and wounded eight others in attacks on Tuesday in the regional capital, Grozny, and in two other areas. Three died in Grozny when guerrillas attacked an armored personnel carrier with grenades. But a rebel commander told The Associated Press that 20 Russians had died in an ambush of a three-vehicle convoy in southeast Chechnya. Both sides have regularly exaggerated the other's losses, and it was not possible to determine which, if either, was correct. Michael Wines (NYT)

HEADLINE: Study Finds Poverty Deepening in Former Communist Countries

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
At least 50 million children in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union live in poverty and are exposed to tuberculosis levels usually associated with the third world, says a report released today.
The report, by the European Children's Trust, a group active in 10 Eastern European countries, urged the West to help by easing debt burdens. The report, "The Silent Crisis," found that poverty in the region had increased more than tenfold over the decade since the fall of Communism because of reduced spending on health, education and other social programs. 
 "Since the breakup of the Communist system," the study says, "conditions have become much worse -- in some cases catastrophically so.
"For all its many faults, the old system provided most people with a reasonable standard of living and a certain security."
At least 50 million children were found to live in "genuine poverty," with 40 million of them in the former Soviet Union. Over all, more than 160 million people, 40 percent of the population, are thought to live in poverty.
The report measured infant mortality, the proportion of the population not expected to live to 60 and the number of tuberculosis cases. It said infant mortality, at 26 per 1,000 births in 1998, approached rates in Latin America and the Caribbean, where it is 32 per 1,000. In the United States, infant mortality is 7.2 deaths per 1,000 live births.
Tuberculosis rates have risen in Eastern Europe, with an average 67.6 cases per 1,000 people in 1997. That compared with 49.6 percent in Arab states, 47.6 percent in Latin America and 35.1 percent in eastern Asia.
Tuberculosis rates ranged from 20 per 1,000 in the Czech Republic to 80 per 1,000 in Lithuania, Turkmenistan, Latvia and Russia, and 150 per 1,000 in Georgia.
In Kyrgyzstan, 88 percent of people live below the poverty line, the report found.
"Time is running out," the trust said. "That there has not been a total collapse of social structures in these countries so far is a testament to the resilience of the people there. But they cannot continue living this way indefinitely."

HEADLINE: A Safe Rescue for Social Security

BYLINE: By Donald B. Marron; Donald B. Marron is chairman of Paine Webber Group.

 BODY:
Perhaps no proposal has raised more eyebrows and hackles this election year than the notion that America should invest part of Social Security proceeds in the financial markets. Yet there is ample precedent for this kind of investment: the Thrift Savings Plan, a government-run retirement income program for federal workers, including members of Congress and federal judges.
Created by Congress in 1986, the plan had assets of $95 billion at the end of 1999. It offers a choice of stock or bond funds or Treasury securities to workers who contribute through payroll deductions. The stock fund's return of 13.19 percent for the year that ended Sept. 30 could make Uncle Sam blush over the 3 percent the Social Security trust fund earned in the same period. 
 The Thrift Savings Plan is not set up to cover all Americans. But it is a powerful example of the federal government's running a successful retirement plan that permits investment in stock and bond markets.
Social Security will plunge into the red early in the century if something is not done to change it. And something must be done. Most Americans today rely on Social Security for the majority of their retirement income. And Americans show little appetite for saving on their own: in July the country reported a negative savings rate for the first time.
In 1998 and 1999, I served with members of Congress and other appointees from the private sector on the bipartisan National Commission on Retirement Policy, a panel sponsored by the Center for Strategic and International Studies. We made several suggestions for improving America's present retirement system without changing its basic structure or raising taxes: setting a minimum guaranteed Social Security retirement payment; making it easier to carry private pension benefits from job to job; expanding individual retirement accounts; continuing to raise the age of eligibility for collecting full Social Security payments (now increasing on a fixed schedule for people who today are 62 and younger) until it reaches age 70 for those now 33 and younger; and giving economic incentives to workers who wish to stay in the work force beyond the retirement age. Our plan would not reduce the benefits already promised to those over 50 or the poor.
But we also recommended something wholly new: returning two percentage points of the 12.4 percent Social Security payroll tax to Americans for individual investment. Workers could put those dollars into stock index funds, bond funds, Treasury securities or a mix of those, making individual investment choices as they would in 401(k) plans. The government's role would include reporting total dollars flowing to the private markets, monitoring fund performance and making sure fund operation is consistent with all laws and regulations.
The risks of the kind of individual retirement savings accounts we propose are often overstated. Critics assume everyone would invest his or her newly liberated Social Security dollars in stocks, perhaps sinking the lot into the latest high-flier. That's wrong. Choosing a single stock is not an investment option for these dollars. Our plan called for a choice among stock index funds, lower-risk bond funds or Treasury securities. Even those who chose stock funds alone would not be taking an unacceptable risk over the long haul, if history is any guide. The American stock market has appreciated in every 20-year period in its history.
Contrary to another common assumption, Wall Street would not be getting a windfall under a plan like ours. The new investments would be about $60 billion a year, a minute fraction of the $25 trillion now invested in financial markets.
If Social Security as it is structured now is intended to be a savings plan, it is a bad one, for even savings accounts pay higher returns. If it is meant as a payment program funded by a tax, the tax we are using is regressive. The low-income earners hardest hit by this tax are especially in need of a chance to make some true headway into retirement security.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Aspen Journal;
Ski Resorts Struggle to Lure Workers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ASPEN, Colo., Oct. 10

 BODY:
Here in the crown jewel of Colorado's ski resorts, no one really asks who wants to be a millionaire. Many residents and visitors already are. Far more important questions around town include: Who wants to be a housekeeper? Who wants to be a waiter? And who wants to be a retail clerk?
Few places in the country reflect an unintended dark side of the nation's prosperity more than Colorado resort areas like Aspen, where labor shortages are sending employers as far as Europe, Africa and Australia to recruit workers essential to the viability of the area. Here, for example, a vacationer is just as likely to be greeted at a restaurant with "G'day, mate" as "Good morning, sir." 
 "Given the robust nature of the economy, there is a general shortage of people in the resort counties, here as well as nationwide," said Jim Westkott, Colorado's state demographer, who attributes the labor problems to a rapid growth in tourism, the increasing number of second and third homes built in ski resort areas and the soaring real estate market. In many of Colorado's ski towns, a modest single-family house with three or four bedrooms sells for $1 million or more.
As a result, working people who earn hourly wages selling clothes, waiting on tables and operating ski lifts can no longer afford to live near their jobs. In the last few years, many of them have been forced to find more affordable housing 30 to 60 miles away, creating monstrous rush-hour traffic jams, polluting the air and undermining the quality of life of workers, especially those who long to spend more time with their children.
But now, state and resort-area officials say, workers fed up with long commutes and traffic are beginning to abandon their resort jobs to find work closer to home, leaving huge vacuums at the resorts, some of which are seeking to hire hundreds of new workers this season.
It has become an especially burdensome task, even as some resort towns, like Aspen, are now requiring developers to build affordable housing for workers as a condition of building expensive single-family houses.
While the nation's unemployment rate fell to 3.9 percent in August, matching a 30-year record, the rate fell even lower in some of Colorado's prime ski counties: to 1.9 percent in Summit, where Copper Mountain is; 1.5 percent in Pitkin, where Aspen is; and 1.4 percent in Eagle, where Vail is. (August is the last month for which statistics have been compiled.)
It is no longer enough to post "Now Hiring" signs in storefronts or to list job offerings in the local newspapers, as many employers still do. More and more of them, including those at Crested Butte, Copper Mountain and Vail, have sent representatives to job fairs in other states and in foreign countries, offering recruits subsidized housing, hourly wages well above the minimum wage, comprehensive health care packages and free season passes to the slopes.
David Barry, chief operating officer for Copper Mountain, said his resort had worked with employment agencies that had brought in new workers from the Ivory Coast, Jamaica, Australia and New Zealand. Among their benefits is a program for subsidized meals that cost $3 each.
Les Marsh, director of human resources for Vail Resorts, which owns the Vail, Keystone, Breckenridge and Beaver Creek ski areas, said his company had used offers of subsidized housing at recent job fairs in Massachusetts, Virginia, Texas, Oregon and Washington. The company has also dropped its program of drug-testing for all new employees.
Employers at Winter Park get an end-of-season bonus, $1 for every hour they worked.
For many of the new workers, the chance to work in a glittery ski resort is more than a dream job; many say it also enhances their resumes for a future higher-paying job at home or in the United States.
"It's more expensive to live here, but the pay and benefits are twice as good as for the same job back home," said Jac O'Sullivan, a 32-year-old native of Manchester, England, who has worked in the banquet department of the Little Nell Hotel in Aspen for 16 months. She is one of about 30 of the hotel employees who are from other countries.
Sam Reid, 26, who moved to Aspen from London last year, is training in the hotel's food and beverage department. "If it wasn't Aspen, it could be another state," she said. "The working conditions here are really good. You are treated better, and they do look after you better."
For ski towns in Colorado as well as in other Rocky Mountain states, providing a full range of quality service has taken on a new urgency after unusually warm autumns have contributed to a two-year decline in skiing and snowboarding.
"Colorado is anxious to regain some growth and momentum after the past two years," said David Perry, president and chief executive of Colorado Ski Country, a trade organization that represents 25 resorts. "But with the strong economy, it has become very difficult to find people for service and entry-level type jobs, and everybody is competing for those people. We'd like to get more of them and get them faster." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: 2 Americans Win the Nobel For Economics

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Two Americans won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for work that has helped to explain complex behavior, like why some working mothers make more than those with fewer children and why one route is favored for a new highway over another.
The award of 9 million Swedish kronor -- $910,000 -- will be split by James J. Heckman, 56, at the University of Chicago, and Daniel L. McFadden, 63, at the University of California at Berkeley. Nine professors from the University of Chicago have won the prize, more than any other university, since 1969, when the Royal Swedish Academy in Stockholm first gave a prize in economics, adding it to the Nobel Prizes that have been awarded for outstanding work in other fields. 
 Mr. Heckman, whose techniques are now standard practice in studies of the links between, say, job training and wages or a woman's wages and her family situation, had often been mentioned as a potential Nobel winner. Mr. McFadden, whose contribution has been less publicized, was on no one's list, although like Mr. Heckman he had won a prestigious Clarke Medal, which is awarded each year to an outstanding economist younger than 40.
Before yesterday's announcement, the favorites for the Nobel this year included Joseph E. Stiglitz at Stanford and George A. Akerlof at Berkeley, known for their path-breaking economic theory. But the Royal Academy swings between contributions to theory and methodology, and this turned out to be a year for methodology.
"Each of the laureates," the academy said of Mr. Heckman and Mr. McFadden, had developed methods "that are widely used in the statistical analysis of individual and household behavior." The formal award is the Bank of Sweden Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel.
Mr. Heckman was in Rio de Janeiro to speak at a conference when his wife, Lynne, received the call in Chicago at 4 a.m. yesterday. "It was a Swedish voice, but he would not say why he was calling; he asked for Jim's phone number," she said. Soon after, Mr. Heckman called home with the news.
"I feel relieved to get a Nobel," Mr. Heckman said, speaking by telephone to reporters gathered for a news conference in Chicago. "I remember some reporter called me and asked, 'How does it feel to be at Chicago without a Nobel Prize?' After a while it starts to hurt."
Mr. McFadden in Berkeley got the call from Sweden even earlier. "I was dead asleep," he said. "My wife grasped what was happening before I did, and she was jumping up and down while I was still trying to figure out what was going on." Later, he told a television interviewer that he thought his chances of winning were "one in a million."
Mr. Heckman, in effect, has forced the economics profession to doubt findings once taken for granted. A survey, for instance, might find that two people from the same neighborhood, with the same high school education and similar backgrounds were offered job training. One took it and one did not, and the one who took the training then went on to earn a higher wage. The survey concluded that job training lifted wages.
Not necessarily so, said Mr. Heckman, who began to raise this sort of challenge soon after he joined the Chicago faculty in 1972, a year after earning a doctorate at Princeton. Motivation must also be factored in, he said. The one who went through job training and earned more might have been more ambitious and for that reason would have earned more without the job training.
Similarly, among women in the work force, a mother of three or four earned more than mothers with fewer children, studies found. That was puzzling. "Common sense said that employers did not care how many children an employee had," said Frank Levy, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Mr. Heckman, however, added nonworking women to the database and found that women with three or four children insisted on good pay before they would take a job.
The statistical equations that Mr. Heckman developed to meld the workers and nonworkers -- thus correcting for "selection bias" and more accurately calculating the probability of going to work -- won him the Nobel. His findings are sometimes challenged, but not his insistence on all the variables that can arise. "He gets infinite credit," said Lawrence Katz, a Harvard University labor economist, "for pointing out how many inferences used by economists were flawed."
Mr. Heckman and Mr. McFadden are longtime friends who often exchange ideas but have never done joint research, although their findings and techniques are roughly related. "We are both in the business of inventing statistical tools that are appropriate to economic applications," Mr. McFadden said.
He was trained at the University of Minnesota in the 1950's and early 1960's, first in physics and then in economics, mainly because his interest in psychology drew him to professors in the economics department who emphasized psychology. In 1964, a year after arriving at Berkeley, a graduate student asked him for help in analyzing how the California Department of Transportation decided on routes for new highways.
"I worked out a model for her to use," he said. And that became a prototype of the statistical models that eventually won him the Nobel. The model quantified how public opinion polls and political pressure, for example, affected the choice of one route over other possible routes.
The model soon turned out to have other uses. Using the model, he has estimated, for example, what would prompt people to shift to cars powered by electric batteries rather than gasoline. "We found that substantial subsidies would be required," he said. "Nongasoline vehicles are fairly inconvenient and rather expensive, and that is rather discouraging for people."

HEADLINE: Fast Times at Global Crossing;
Enjoying the Spotlight While Building An Upstart in Telecommunications

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 11

 BODY:
"Please forgive me," Gary Winnick said, ushering a guest into his office last Thursday afternoon. "I'm a little distracted today."
Distracted indeed. Asia Global Crossing, a subsidiary of the telecommunications concern Global Crossing Holdings that Mr. Winnick co-founded more than three years ago, was expected to sell stock to the public that day. But that morning, as investors continued to bail out of technology stocks, several money managers had balked at the $9 to $11 a share that was being asked for Asia Global. 
 "I don't want to hear any whining from the bankers," Mr. Winnick snapped at a colleague who popped in to give him an update. Both Salomon Smith Barney and the Goldman Sachs Group had been asked to buy as many as 14 million shares of Asia Global to support the deal, an extraordinary request they could have refused, but did not. Mr. Winnick watched as the deal was done, although he had to settle for $7 a share.
Just four years ago, this relative newcomer to the billionaires' club -- his stake in Global Crossing is now worth about $2.5 billion, down from a peak of more than $6 billion -- could never have demanded such support from two of Wall Street's most respected firms. "But when you make several billion dollars the world's perception of you changes," said Nelson Peltz, a New York financier who has known Mr. Winnick since the early 1980's, when he was a young salesman at Drexel Burnham Lambert, the infamous investment firm, now defunct, that specialized in junk bonds. "You go from being an ordinary bloke to a guy who is infallible." Of course, Mr. Peltz added, neither image is true.
Mr. Winnick, 52, is a former furniture business manager from Roslyn, N.Y., who remade himself not once, but twice in his career. First he turned himself into a successful Wall Street sales executive at Drexel under the tutelage of Michael R. Milken before Mr. Milken's empire collapsed. Now he is known as the telecommunications financier behind Global Crossing, an undersea cable operator that is building a worldwide network to transmit information via the Internet.
And as far as Global Crossing investors are concerned, Mr. Winnick may need to remake himself all over again. Global Crossing's stock price -- down 65 percent from a high of $61.81 -- has taken a beating along with other telecommunications stocks as investors worry whether companies in the industry can deliver on the growth prospects they have promised. It closed today at $21.44, down $2.44.
One problem Global Crossing had early on, analysts said, was that it had plenty of deal makers, but not enough executives with real operating experience. The departure of Leo Hindery Jr. as chief executive after only seven months in the job -- the third to leave in Global Crossing's short history -- suggests that the company is still having difficulty putting together its operating team.
Mr. Winnick said that the company had pulled together the talent to address the problem and that Global Crossing had met every objective it had set for itself so far.
But he is all too aware that if Global Crossing slips up, he, too, may drop out of the spotlight. "I know I can go back to anonymity in a quick minute," he said. "It doesn't take much to fall off a rock."
And Mr. Winnick, for all his protestations, clearly enjoys the spotlight.
A fixture now on the Forbes 400 list of the richest Americans, Mr. Winnick relishes the attention his wealth has brought him, dropping names of famous people he has met, including the Queen Mother of Britain, whose 100th-birthday party he attended. And he has taken on a more public persona as a philanthropist, most recently pledging $40 million to the Simon Wiesenthal Foundation to help build a Museum of Tolerance in Jerusalem.
Not that he has forgotten where he came from. Mr. Winnick, for example, was married at the Swan Club, a catering hall near Roslyn, on Christmas Eve 1972, in part, he recalled, because he knew it would be decked out in tinsel and Christmas trees. Never mind that he is Jewish. "I saved money on the decorations," he said, a sly grin crossing his face. "That way I could serve the guests lobster or steak."
Today, what makes Mr. Winnick stand out, even in a city where success is often measured by how conspicuously you spend, is how quickly and fabulously wealthy he has become with Global Crossing. "Gary is extremely respected," said Alex Yemenidjian, chairman and chief executive of MGM Inc. "One, because he's rich. Two, because he got rich faster than others here."
Mr. Winnick moved to Los Angeles in 1978 to sell high-yield bonds for Drexel, after spending six years on Wall Street. At Drexel, he has told friends, he made as much as $2 million a month, but left the firm in 1985 to start his own investment fund. In 1991, he formed a merchant bank, Pacific Capital Group. For years he made a very comfortable but unglamorous living investing in real estate, industrial companies and entertainment.
Then along came the Internet. In December 1996, David Lee, an executive Mr. Winnick had hired in 1989, pitched an outlandish idea: build a fiber optic cable along the ocean floor to handle the burgeoning traffic over the Internet. It was not hard for Mr. Winnick to pull together the financing, including $15 million of his own money, throwing in an extra $5 million for his partners.
"Gary was never more than two degrees of separation from anyone we wanted to get to know," said Barry Porter, a co-founder of Global Crossing, who, along with Mr. Lee, recently left the company to set up a venture capital firm.
Indeed, Mr. Winnick is a master networker, amassing a Rolodex so fat he can call on just about anyone for help -- politicians, business executives, even socialites. To make sure Global's interests are on every legislators' agenda, for instance, Mr. Winnick and his associates are generous political donors -- well into the hundreds of thousands of dollars -- something they do not apologize for.
"As long as it's legal we're going to be a player," said Lodwrick Cook, who runs legislative affairs for Global Crossing.
But working for Mr. Winnick can be, in a word, tense. He is at times gruff, barking orders from his third-floor office with all the gusto of the Wall Street salesman he used to be. He holds late-night meetings while he works out on a treadmill. And he is not afraid to clash with employees if he believes it is necessary to force better decision making.
"It's always a complex relationship with Gary," said Abbott Brown, a friend since 1994 who recently left Global Crossing. "Love-hate? Maybe. Every transaction has some dark days." He recalled a meeting in 1997 when Mr. Winnick was pitching an idea Mr. Brown thought held little promise. "I made a comment to him like, 'That's a dumb idea,' " he said. Mr. Winnick shot back angrily. "I've listened to a lot of your dumb ideas," Mr. Brown said Mr. Winnick told him. "Now you have to listen to mine."
Mr. Winnick winced when reminded of the incident. "To understand that you had to grow up in my house," he said. Mr. Winnick, who was born in 1947, grew up the youngest of three children. His father, Arnold, struggled as the owner of a restaurant supply business, he said, before the business went bankrupt in the 1960's. His mother, Blanche, was a homemaker and interior decorator. He and his siblings worked out their differences both loudly and openly, he said, but always with respect.
Casey Cogut, a prominent Manhattan lawyer who was a childhood classmate, said Mr. Winnick "had this cute freckled face and you knew he could get away with murder." The two smoked cigarettes at Mr. Cogut's bar mitzvah, captured in a photograph that Mr. Winnick still keeps. And in Roslyn High School's 1965 yearbook, he was dubbed "1/4 Hawaii" because he and his three closest friends used to spend hours listening to the Beach Boys.
His father died when Mr. Winnick was 18 years old. "1966. March 3. 9:30 p.m.," Mr. Winnick said. "Two hours after dinner he had a heart attack. He went to his Thursday night card game. I got the call." Mr. Winnick then held up his right hand to show a diamond-and-ruby wedding band. "My mother handed me his ring that night and I've worn it ever since."
With it came a sense of responsibility for his mother and his future family. Instead of going away to college, he commuted to nearby C. W. Post, graduating in 1969 with a degree in economics. When his mother got ovarian cancer in 1987, he said he moved her to Los Angeles for treatment.
There are few things Mr. Winnick will not discuss. One of them is his experience at Drexel. He was long gone before Drexel filed for bankruptcy in 1990 and Mr. Milken, who masterminded the junk-bond unit, pleaded guilty to violating securities laws and served time in prison. But tensions were running high in the Los Angeles office then. And of particular concern to those there, said several people who worked at Drexel then, were whether or not exiles like Mr. Winnick were cooperating to regulators.
"People were circling the wagons," one former Drexel employee said. "It was us against them."
For his part, Mr. Winnick would not comment, except to say, "I think we come through those experiences, and we all have our scars."
Besides, he said, no one experience defines a lifetime. "I think it is too early to write the script," he said. "In terms of my legacy, I just hope I'm not judged to be a jerk."

HEADLINE: Agency Plans to Study Drug Makers' Records to See Whether Deals Delay Generics

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The Federal Trade Commission announced plans today to subpoena records from 90 pharmaceutical companies to see whether drug industry strategies were keeping lower-cost generic drugs from patients or harming consumers.
The commission has already filed complaints against two brand companies and two generic companies, accusing them of making deals that effectively stopped or delayed the generic version of two brand-name drugs. Several other such agreements are under investigation. 
 "There are more of these agreements than we know about," one commission official said, "so our desire is to get our arms around the scope of the issue."
The economic stakes in the brand-generic drug wars are huge. In the next five years, drugs with $20 billion in annual sales in the United States will have come off patent, said Robert Pitofsky, the commission chairman. Without patent protection, drug manufacturers can lose significant profits. At the same time, the availability of generic competition can mean considerable savings for consumers.
Mr. Pitofsky said the study was meant to "ensure that the process of bringing new low-cost generic alternatives to the marketplace -- and into the hands of consumers -- is not impeded in ways that are anticompetitive."
Jackie Cottrell, a spokeswoman for the brand drug makers' trade group, the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, said that any comment was premature.
"But," Ms. Cottrell said, "we are confident that any balanced study by the F.T.C. will find the brand-name industry's practices are beneficial to patients."
The trade commission's proposed study must undergo a period of public comment and then be approved by White House budget officials. This will delay any investigation until early next year, after the next president takes office.
Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic nominee for president, is a critic of the pharmaceutical industry and has said brand-generic agreements unfairly deny consumers the benefits of competition. His Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, has not addressed this specific issue, but the pharmaceutical industry has been generally supportive of his candidacy.
The trade commission's concerns trace to a 1984 law, now known as Hatch-Waxman, which was designed to ease greater competition between generic and brand-name drugs. But one of its co-authors, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, said some incentives in the law had been used to delay competition, rather than foster it, costing consumers money and denying patients access to life-saving drugs.
Whatever the law's shortcomings, however, it has benefited consumers. A study last year, done for a generic company by Paul MacAvoy, a Yale University economist who advised Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, found that from 1985 to 1997, consumers saved $112.5 billion by buying generic drugs.
Despite the lost sales, the study also found, the brand-name drug companies actually increased their research and development outlays, to $18 billion from $4 billion.
Mr. Waxman wrote Mr. Pitofsky on Aug. 30 asking the commission to produce a study on the issue of deals between brands and generics. Last month, Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona , and Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, introduced legislation to address the potential for manipulation in the 1984 law.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Share Prices Gyrate Before Ending With Steep Losses

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices gyrated in heavy trading yesterday but finished with sizable losses, deepening the slide that has prevailed with only brief interruption since early September.
The Nasdaq composite index, dominated by technology, fell at one stage beneath its low point of the year set May 23, then rallied to show gains for the day before sagging again to wind up with its 13th loss in the last 15 sessions. It closed at 3,168.49, down 72.05 points, or 2.22 percent. 
 Other major gauges also lost ground as Wall Street digested the latest round of warnings about third-quarter profit shortfalls and tried to assess the toll that the economic slowdown being engineered by the Federal Reserve will take on corporate performance next year.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 110.61 points, or 1.05 percent, to close at 10,413.79, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 22.43 points, or 1.62 percent, to 1,364.99.
"You've gone from total complacency to pretty high anxiety levels here," said Hersh Cohen, a portfolio manager at Salomon Smith Barney. "And when people see these big declines, they just sell more."
One depressant, analysts said, has been the seasonal sales of losers for tax purposes, typically to offset gains taken previously.
Brokerage stocks, at least, got a lift in midafternoon when Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the industry leader by market capitalization, disclosed losses of about $89.7 million from dealings in high-yield bonds, many of them telecommunications issues it had underwritten. This was far below the $500 million that had been rumored and that had contributed to a skid in the company's stock, which hit a high of $109.38 on Sept. 11. Shares of Morgan Stanley rose $3.25 yesterday, to $77.75.
And while the shares of Yahoo, Lucent and Motorola continued to be pounded after their late-Tuesday profit warnings, Fannie Mae announced a 13 percent rise in earnings and its shares advanced $3.13, to $71.13. General Electric, whose shares have the highest total value of any company, announced record profits, but its stock fell $1.44, to $56.63.
Yesterday was the 10th anniversary of the Dow's bull market; the average has not suffered any 20 percent declines since a rise that began Oct. 11, 1990.
Some analysts are finding grounds for optimism amid the recent gloom.
"We've had a pretty rough pre-announcement season but the carnage over the past couple of months has been so extraordinary and the sentiment has become so negative that I suspect we're near a bottom," said John Kattar, director of United States equities at Boston Company Asset Management.

Treasury Prices Mixed
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices were mixed yesterday as crumbling stock prices produced some buying of relatively low-risk government debt.
"The stock market is going down, and that's all guys are trading right now," said John Roberts, head of government trading at Barclays Capital.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 1/32, to a price of 99 27/32. The note's yield was unchanged at 5.77 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 4/32, to 106. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.82 percent from 5.81 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Chief Upset at Some of His Allies

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 11

 BODY:
President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia said today that he was having "almost as much trouble from my friends as from my enemies" in the transition from the rule of Slobodan Milosevic and that he was concerned that his own authority was being compromised.
But Mr. Kostunica expressed confidence that Mr. Milosevic's allies could not stage a comeback, even though they appear to be trying, and that difficulties in negotiating a transitional government for Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia, would be resolved. 
 He said that he looked forward to his first meeting, on Thursday, with President Clinton's Balkan adviser, James C. O'Brien, and other senior American officials and that he was eager to begin a new, more balanced relationship with Washington, including a rapid re-establishment of diplomatic relations broken with the NATO bombing war last year.
"The United States has done too much meddling in our internal affairs," Mr. Kostunica said in an interview. "Now it's meddling less than usual, so this will have a positive influence." If re-establishing diplomatic relations is in his competence as federal president, he said, he will do it quickly.
Mr. Kostunica spoke in the offices of the federal president in the Palace of Federations as a small number of aides rushed in and out amid a cacophony of telephones, both land lines and cell phones.
In the interview, Mr. Kostunica said that some members of the 18-party coalition that supported his presidential candidacy were making policy statements that had not been cleared with him and were using extra-legal procedures to take control of certain ministries and companies that have been run by those close to Mr. Milosevic.
"I cannot justify all that's going on," he said. "On the surface there is a peaceful, democratic transition, but below the surface is a kind of volcano, not so controlled."
Mr. Kostunica spoke as a leading member of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party, Branislav Ivkovic, said that the current Serbian government would not resign and that the current prime minister had also taken the job of interior minister, which controls the police.
But Mr. Kostunica said he was confident that early elections for a new Serbian Parliament would take place, as agreed, on Dec. 17. While some parties in the Parliament "are fighting for seats" in a temporary government until those elections, "others are fighting to overturn the outcome" of the popular will, he said. But they would not succeed.
Another Kostunica ally with ties to the old regime, Dusan Mihajlovic, warned that Mr. Milosevic had begun to organize his allies to create difficulties and even chaos, including lifting some price controls, that could be blamed on Mr. Kostunica and his team. "We have information that Milosevic is pulling the strings," Mr. Mihajlovic said.
Mr. Kostunica has said that he does not recognize the legitimacy of the International War Crimes Tribunal at The Hague and would be against handing Mr. Milosevic over.
Some of Mr. Kostunica's allies, worried that Mr. Milosevic is creating difficulties for the new order, are speaking openly of putting him on trial in Serbia. In Washington, administration officials repeated today that the United States would not press for Mr. Milosevic's extradition right now. Some administration officials believe a trial within Serbia would be the next best thing.
Mr. Kostunica's allies are talking about a domestic trial of Mr. Milosevic, perhaps on charges of election fraud, to get him out of political life.
Mr. Kostunica expressed concern that some of his own allies in the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, or DOS as the coalition is known, were providing ammunition for the complaints of chaos and illegality made by the Socialists and Serbian Radicals. "Some members of DOS are not so much eating away at my authority -- that they cannot do," Mr. Kostunica said. "The problem is that they are compromising that authority."
In particular, he and his aides said, the Democratic Party leader, Zoran Djindjic, who leads the strongest party by far in the coalition, is trying to consolidate the popular revolt against Mr. Milosevic, but in a way that has sometimes caused anger.
The best-known example was Mr. Djindjic's effort to put an ally, a well-known businessman, in charge of the Customs office after ousting the old minister. The appointment of Mr. Djindjic's ally caused an uproar among other political leaders and it was rescinded in a day.
In companies, banks, institutes and universities, Milosevic managers are being ousted, usually by workers tired of political bosses.
"Some of this is spontaneous, some of it is not," Mr. Kostunica said. "Some of it is comes from within, and some from the outside. And some of these actions are from people who are in connection with or appear on behalf of DOS or even myself, which is not true. But all together, it's something that worries me."
He said that the image of crime and chaos, part of any transition, was harmful. "But we'll settle all this among ourselves," he said. "But if it's an excuse for any foreign intervention, that would be the problem."
Mr. Djindjic has also made announcements that Mr. Kostunica has not approved. For example, Mr. Djindjic said that the Yugoslav Army chief of staff, Gen. Nebojsa Pavkovic, would be fired. Mr. Kostunica, who met with the army command today, said he had no intention of firing General Pavkovic -- at least for now. The general became a popular hero for his efforts to defend Kosovo. Mr. Kostunica also has no interest now in stirring up a quiescent army while he and his allies try to ensure they control the Serbian police.
Mr. Kostunica and his allies obtained the resignation of the Serbian interior minister, Vlajko Stojiljkovic, who ordered the police to attack protesters. But they have not succeeded yet in winning the job for themselves. Mr. Djindjic thinks it is crucial to protect the revolution, and tonight he offered joint control over four key ministries: Interior, Justice, Finance and Information.
But if the other parties do not agree to a new transitional government by the end of the week, Mr. Djindjic warned, the opposition will call thousands of people into the streets. Again, Mr. Kostunica seems less than enthusiastic over revolutionary tactics.
Mr. Ivkovic's statement to Radio B-92 was a form of challenge. "The Serbian government will go on ruling the republic since it was elected on a four-year mandate and it is the only body that can make legal decisions," he said. Another Serbian government statement, read on YU-Info, a television station close to Mr. Milosevic, accused the opposition of "fomenting violence and lawlessness" and taking over companies and ministries illegally. It urged the police to act and said control of television should be returned to its owners in the state and city.
But the police did not respond. And Mr. Djindjic said: "That government can declare itself not only legal but omnipotent but it's a fact of life they have no control over 80 percent of the processes in the country. We are tired of haggling and manipulations."
Mr. Kostunica and his staff also bridled at another Djindjic announcement that usurped federal presidential powers.
Mr. Djindjic said that Miroljub Labus, an economist, would become provisional prime minister of Yugoslavia. But Mr. Kostunica said today that he would choose a prime minister from Montenegro, as the Constitution required, who would be a member of the Socialist People's Party. The party won nearly all the seats in Montenegro because of an election boycott by the republic's president, Milo Djukanovic.
Mr. Kostunica will travel to Montenegro on Friday to meet the local party leaders and Mr. Djukanovic. They will discuss a new federal government and begin to talk about a new, more equal relationship between Serbia and tiny Montenegro within Yugoslavia.
Mr. Kostunica said today that he was not wedded to the name Yugoslavia, especially after all the wars of secession, and once favored "The Union of Serbia and Montenegro."
"The question is not the name but what sort of state we want," he said. "If the ties are too loose, we lose the sense of unity."

HEADLINE: G.E. Meets Forecast With 20% Rise in Net

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The General Electric Company, apparently immune to the weak euro and the softening economy, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 20 percent, meeting analysts' estimates.
For the quarter ended Sept. 30, net income rose to $3.18 billion, or 32 cents a share, compared with $2.65 billion, or 27 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier when adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split. Revenue increased 18 percent, to $32 billion from $27.2 billion. 
 "To the extent there were surprises, they were good ones," said Martin A. Sankey, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs who follows G.E.
Investors, accustomed to G.E. meeting or beating expectations, reacted unenthusiastically. Shares of G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., slipped $1.63, to $56.63. But analysts reiterated their faith in the stock. "It would be hard not to have a 'buy' on a company with numbers like this," said Jeffrey Sprague, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney.
The news was not all good: locomotive sales were down at GE Transportation; two small GE Capital businesses took a total of $240 million in charges for reorganization; NBCi, the interactive TV company in which NBC owns a 40 percent stake, is losing money; and growth was sluggish in service revenue for several sectors.
Still, G.E. showed stellar results in industries that are riding a bumpy road. All chemical companies are suffering from price increases for petroleum products, but profits at GE Plastics rose 25 percent. Whirlpool and Maytag have issued earnings warnings, yet operating profits for GE Appliances rose 15 percent on a sales increase of 3 percent.
Even the Olympics, which drew fewer viewers than expected, were a miniboon for NBC, the G.E. broadcasting arm. NBC gave advertisers extra air time to make up for the shortfall in viewers, but it did so by cutting promotional spots and squeezing more commercials into breaks. Thus, it did not need to repay money or offer free commercials in the future.
"The Olympics may have been a ratings flop, but NBC probably performed better than it would have predicted," Mr. Sankey said.
Also, more cable networks have agreed to carry MSNBC and CNBC, NBC's cable channels.
Over all, G.E.'s success had several roots. Strong Japanese sales partly offset the euro's weakness. And sales of many of G.E.'s largest businesses, like Power Systems, are booked in dollars and are thus immune to currency fluctuations.
G.E.'s continued emphasis on Six Sigma, a quality control program, and on pushing sales, purchasing and order processing onto the Internet, all helped productivity. Gary Sheffer, a G.E. spokesman, said savings from Six Sigma alone would hit $3 billion this year.
G.E. has been helping its chief customers add Six Sigma and electronic-commerce programs. Analysts say that this cements customer loyalty and may soon be a service that G.E. will sell.
"They are branding themselves as the best provider of information and productivity enhancement services," said Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
GE Appliances already has Web-based systems that let retailers ship items directly from G.E. factories to their customers. The setup has persuaded large retailers like Home Depot and, most recently, Wal-Mart Stores to offer G.E. refrigerators and the like.
"All retailers want to run with minimal inventory, and G.E. is facilitating that," Mr. Sprague said.
The quarter is unlikely to affect the race to succeed John F. Welch Jr., the G.E. chairman, who will retire next year. The contenders remain Robert L. Nardelli, head of GE Power Systems; Jeffrey R. Immelt, head of GE Medical Systems; and W. James McNerney Jr., head of GE Aircraft Engines.
Power Systems and Medical Systems had robust sales and earnings. Aircraft Engines posted a 15 percent rise in operating profits despite a 3 percent decline in sales, and was named exclusive provider of engines for newer versions of the Boeing 777 and for several regional aircraft.
Analysts have generally said that Mr. Immelt has the edge, and nothing about the quarter seems to have changed their minds. "Jeff was the guy, and he's still the guy," one said.

HEADLINE: Supporters of Transportation Bond Act Finally Have the Mayor On Board

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
After several weeks of indecision, the Giuliani administration offered a tepid endorsement yesterday of an Election Day ballot item that would authorize $3.8 billion in new borrowing to finance state highway, rail and other transportation projects.
The administration, while urging city voters to support the measure, echoed skepticism already expressed by several local officials who have questioned how much of what would be the largest bond act in state history would actually end up being spent in New York City. 
 "As the city's strong economy continues to attract new businesses, residents and visitors, our existing transportation infrastructure must be expanded to keep pace," said Robert Grotell, director of the mayor's Office of Transportation, during testimony before the City Council Transportation Committee yesterday. "Yet we are all too familiar with the difficulties of allocating a finite amount of funding across seemingly infinite project opportunities."
As planned, $1.8 billion of the total would be invested in highways and bridge projects statewide, while an additional $1.6 billion would go to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for upgrading the region's subway, rail and bus system. The remaining $400 million would be split among other state public transit systems, ports, airports and canals.
State officials say that over the next five years, the money would help buy 1,100 new subway cars, 1,200 new buses and renovate 64 subway stations and complete the design work for a Second Avenue subway line. The money would also pay for dozens of local highway projects, including the reconstruction of parts of the Grand Central Parkway and Henry Hudson Parkway.
But Giuliani administration officials said yesterday that they were concerned that the new bonds might just replace other sources of state financing already committed for city transportation projects. The skepticism, they noted, is justified given the state's failure to deliver the city money that was promised from previous bond acts, such as 1972 and 1996 measures supporting recycling and other environmental projects.
New York City's support for the measure is considered critical, not only because of its obviously large voting block, but the tendency, in some recent bond acts, for voters elsewhere in the state to oppose new debt spending. The most recent bond measure put before state voters -- a $2.4 billion school construction act in 1997 -- failed, as did two of the six bond acts related to transportation voted on since 1971.
As recently as yesterday morning, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was the target of criticism by some of the many local elected officials, business and labor leaders who had lined up to endorse the $3.8 billion transportation bond act.
"His voice is an important one to be heard," said C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, minutes before Mr. Grotell testified to put the administration on record in favor of the measure.
But even some of the City Council members who support the measure said yesterday that they remained uncertain whether it would pass. There has been no organized statewide campaign to urge voter support, something considered critical in past successful bond act efforts.
"This helps a little bit, but not greatly," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, a Democrat from Queens who is a member of the Transportation Committee. "They should have defined better for voters what this means. That is the fault of Albany."
Joseph Conway, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, said yesterday that the governor welcomed the mayor's support. "We are confident the bond act will deliver substantial benefits for all regions of the state including New York City," Mr. Conway said.

HEADLINE: Changing Course, Giuliani Proposes Rent Subsidies for Homeless Families

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
In a striking departure from its previous policies, the Giuliani administration is proposing rent subsidies for homeless families in an effort to resolve bottlenecks in the city's emergency shelter system.
The proposed subsidies, which are part of a pilot project for more than 500 homeless families, were offered to comply with a court order. But they are also a sign that in a booming economy with sharply rising rents, the city is taking a fresh look at the problem of homeless families. And it acknowledges that the people crowding the city's shelters increasingly include the working poor. 
 Some rental supplements have been provided by the state since 1990, but those are limited to certain welfare households facing eviction. The new proposal, which would require state approval and is part of remedial plan the city submitted in court last week, would be aimed at homeless people who have jobs or are trying to move from welfare to work.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has opposed and even vetoed similar rental assistance programs in the past, contending that they encourage dependency on government and would make the city's emergency shelter system a magnet for families seeking subsidized apartments. Earlier this year, the mayor lost a bid to overturn the right to shelter established in the city through class-action lawsuits two decades ago.
But Mr. Giuliani has been trying to burnish and perhaps soften his mayoral legacy since he withdrew from the Senate race in May. And the administration was confronted with a crisis this summer when more than 500 families were left to sleep on the floors and benches of the Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx, the city's sole portal to shelters for families with children. That practice, which violates a longstanding court order, had been common until a year ago, when the City Council banned it and the Department of Homeless Services made new efforts to comply.
"When the people started sleeping on the floor, we went and tried to get additional relief," said Leonard Koerner, the city's chief assistant corporation counsel, who is handling the case. "This will make more permanent housing available."
At the same time, Mr. Koerner noted: "There is a fear that this is going to create an additional problem, because there are more families than housing. You have all these families out there doubled up."
He added, "I have no idea what the long-term solution is."
Debra Sproles, the spokeswoman for the city's Human Resources Administration, said she did not expect the program to have a magnet effect, but added that because the program would begin as a six-month pilot project, "we have time to see what's going to happen."
Ms. Sproles stressed that the Human Resources Administration considered the program consistent with, not a departure from, its efforts to move people from welfare to self-sufficiency. Though details are still being worked out, she added, the pilot would include about 550 families now in the shelter system. Each family could get up to $600 a month in rental assistance in a combination of state, city and possibly federal money. The average subsidy, she said, is expected to be $300 to $400 and would last for two years.
Apart from the administration's new proposal, four nonprofit groups are also to begin offering rental assistance programs next month for about 200 households. Those programs would draw from $3 million in city money that was budgeted by the City Council. In previous years, the administration either vetoed or left unspent money appropriated by the Council for that purpose.
City officials have said that they do not track how many parents applying for shelter have jobs. But Barbara Cutler, the court-appointed special master who oversees the city's operation of the family shelter system under a longstanding court decree, said they were common. She added that the court was now focusing on problems in the application process that make it hard for working parents to keep their jobs and keep children in school.
"There are people that are real, live, hard-working citizens who still operate every day from the E.A.U.," Ms. Cutler said, referring to the Emergency Assistance Unit. "We have as a society to look at this again. We have to look at what the elements of being homeless really are."
Families who have waited night after night recently for temporary shelter in the Bronx unit office have included a nurse's aide employed for seven years on the midnight shift at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn, and her two children; and a public schoolteacher who said she moved back here from Seattle with her 16-year-old son in response to the city's teacher shortage.
On a weeknight last month, the teacher called a reporter at 11:32 p.m. from the Bronx office and left a telephone message, describing her situation after 11 days of bouncing between overnight or short-lived shelter placements and the intake center, sometimes not getting a bed until after 3 a.m.
"I'm just letting you know how discouraged I am that at 5:30 I have to get up, and at 8:21 I have to be fresh for 61 New York City public schoolchildren," the teacher said. "It doesn't seem as though they anticipated the time when working people would be homeless."
Mr. Koerner told Justice Helen E. Freedman of New York State Supreme Court last month that the city planned an "aggressive program," including rent subsidies, to help move families more swiftly from temporary shelters to permanent housing.
Advocates for the homeless called the Giuliani administration's proposal a step in the right direction. They and the mayor's opponents on the City Council have long championed modest rent subsidies, combined with social services, as a more cost-effective way to help homeless people than the expansion of temporary shelter beds, which they say cost $3,000 a month for a family.
"I have been preaching the gospel of rental assistance for nearly 12 years now," said Mary Brosnahan, director of the Coalition for the Homeless, which pioneered a similar rental subsidy program with money from law firms and churches in the late 1980's. "It's a huge victory, practical and moral."
Steven Banks, counsel to the coalition and to the Homeless Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society, whose contempt motions last month prompted the remedial plan, was more cautious.
"After seven years of resisting the notion that additional housing provided by the city is part of the solution to homelessness, it's a welcome first step," Mr. Banks said. "But it's not enough to make the current crisis, which has built up over years, go away."
In its legal papers, the city in part blamed unexpected demand for the recurrence of the old problem of families left in the Bronx office overnight, saying that the number of families seeking shelter was 9 percent higher between April 1 and Sept. 30 than during the same period last year.
But lawyers for the homeless dispute those figures, contending that the problem is not more demand, but an increase in "churning" -- multiple applications required of families who are wrongly found ineligible, shuttled between one-night placements and forced to reapply.
"The families that are caught up in these desperate circumstances now are including increasing numbers of working families and families fleeing from domestic violence," Mr. Banks said.
Both sides agree that since the court began examining the problem last month, crowding has eased, but Ms. Cutler said churning remained a concern.
In the last fiscal year, through June 30, there were 20,841 applications and reapplications made by families seeking shelter, according to the mayor's management report. The shelter system now houses 5,337 families, including 9,563 children.
