HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

European Panel Approves AOL Deal for Time Warner
The European Commission approved Time Warner's $165 billion merger with America Online, but the companies face bigger objections from antitrust regulators in Washington.
The commission focused its demands almost entirely on preventing the merged company from dominating online music distribution. But regulators played down some of the biggest concerns raised in the United States, like the combined company's potential to dominate online distribution of movies, services like instant messaging and access to high-speed broadband networks. Page C4. 

F.C.C. May Revamp Building Rules
The Federal Communications Commission is considering issuing new rules that would take a step toward forcing commercial landlords to open their buildings to almost any communications carrier that wants access to their tenants. Landlords of apartment buildings and office towers have had an almost inviolable right to determine which companies may set up shop in their buildings. A1.
 
G.E. Profit Meets Expectations
General Electric, apparently immune to the weak euro and the softening economy, said that its third-quarter earnings rose 20 percent, meeting analysts' estimates. Investors, accustomed to G.E. meeting or beating expectations, reacted unenthusiastically. Shares of G.E. slipped $1.44, to $56.63. But analysts reiterated their faith in the stock. C4.
 
More Genetic Corn Said to Be Found
The unapproved genetically engineered corn connected with a nationwide recall of taco shells has been found in a house brand sold by Safeway, a coalition of biotechnology food critics said. Safeway said it would remove the product from its shelves. C2.
 
Bill Passed on Auto and Tire Defects
Both houses of Congress overwhelmingly approved a bill that would stiffen civil and criminal penalties for failing to report defects in cars and tires. The move is an unusually swift reaction to the failure of industry and regulators to recognize a problem with Firestone tires on Ford Explorers. C21.
 
Schedule Set in Microsoft Case
The United States Court of Appeals announced a schedule for Microsoft's antitrust appeal that will bring the two sides back into the courtroom at the end of February. The court ordered Microsoft to file its first written brief by Nov. 27, with the government's reply expected Jan. 12. Final briefs are due on Feb. 9, and arguments are set for Feb. 26 and 27. C6.
 
U.S. Agents Raid Tax-Cut Company
Federal agents with search warrants raided the headquarters of the Tax People, which has been selling aggressive tax-avoidance techniques to middle-class Americans. C4.
 
Gemstar Plans Push Into E-Books
The chairman of Gemstar-TV Guide International will outline today the details of his bid to make his company's technology the dominant format for electronic publishing by becoming the central distributor, bookstore and bookshelf for anyone who reads electronic books. But the scale of his ambitions has already stirred some anxieties about its potential power in the fledgling market. C12.

HEADLINE: On Park Avenue, Another Trophy Changes Hands

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A pair of German developers has won the bidding war for the Seagram Building, the latest in a series of trophy properties changing hands in a frenzied Manhattan real estate marketplace.
The iconic bronze and topaz glass skyscraper on Park Avenue joins such other prime properties as Rockefeller Center, the Chrysler Building, the World Trade Center and CBS's Black Rock on what has become a crowded auction block. Some real estate brokers say that the rash of offerings is an indication that some landlords and investors are cashing out at what they believe is the peak of a four-year-old real estate boom. 
 The Seagram Building, a 38-story landmark at 52nd Street and Park Avenue, is being sold to Aby Rosen and Michael Fuchs. The two agreed yesterday to buy the building from the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association for more than $375 million, according to executives involved in the deal.
The new owners, the executives say, can make lots of money, but they are unlikely to reap the windfall profits of those who bought property cheap during the recession in the early and mid-1990's and then saw rents nearly double in recent years as the economy surged.
That did not prevent Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs from topping a rival bidder, Jerry I. Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties, by more than $12 million, according to real estate executives.
"Many people think the market is either at the top or slightly past the top," said John D. Lyons, chief executive of Granite Partners, a real estate investment bank. "So owners are asking for and obtaining premium prices."
Philip R. DiGennaro, managing director of T.I.A.A., said he was optimistic he would close the deal for the Seagram Building very soon, but he declined to name the buyer. The broker that handled the auction, Insignia/ESG, did not return calls requesting comment.
If the deal closes, Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs, who head RFR Holding, would own the two great postwar glass skyscrapers on Park Avenue. Only 14 months ago, RFR Holding bought the landmark Lever House, the 21-story skyscraper that sits across the street from the Seagram Building at 390 Park Avenue. The building was the first glass-walled office tower built in Manhattan.
Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs moved to New York in the late 1980's from Frankfurt and began buying real estate in 1991, as the market collapsed. In a relatively short time, they have accumulated a portfolio of 16 office buildings and a dozen apartment houses worth nearly $2 billion.
Built in 1958 at a cost of $41 million, the Seagram Building is the only skyscraper in New York designed by Mies van der Rohe, the prince of International Style architecture, and Philip Johnson, who was then his acolyte. The architect was given an unlimited budget for the project at the urging of Phyllis Lambert, the daughter of Samuel Bronfman, Seagram's chairman.
The Seagram Building was the most expensive office tower of its day. And it is still an expensive gem. The bronze exterior of the building is oiled once a year by hand and the terrazzo floors in the elevator lobbies are polished once a month.
But the Seagram Building is not the only trophy on the block. After Rockefeller Center was put up for sale earlier this year, a half-dozen other major office towers suddenly followed suit, each owner hoping to make a huge profit.
"There may be an unusual number of big buildings up for sale," said Darcy Stacom, a broker at Cushman & Wakefield, "but there are an awful lot of interested buyers."
Equitable Life Assurance Society and Nippon Life Insurance of Japan hired Cushman & Wakefield to sell the 42-story PaineWebber Building at the Avenue of the Americas and 52nd Street, and CBS is seeking offers for its 38-story black granite skyscraper at 51 West 52nd Street.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is examining seven bids ranging up to $3 billion for a 99-year lease of the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.
Last month, Goldman Sachs & Company's Whitehall fund, the principal owner of Rockefeller Center, winnowed the list of bidders for the historic 12-building complex to the Fisher real estate family; Mortimer B. Zuckerman, chairman of Boston Properties; Steven Roth, chairman of Vornado Realty Trust; and Sam Zell, chairman of Equity Office Properties. Goldman and its partners, which include Mr. Speyer, bought the seven million-square-foot complex for $1.2 billion and are hoping to sell it for more than $2 billion, although some analysts say the price may be too high.
Mr. Speyer and Travelers Group are also selling, or refinancing, the landmark Chrysler Building on 42nd Street. The partners bought the mortgage for the 1.9 million-square-foot Art Deco complex almost three years ago for $220 million, then spent $100 million on renovations. They now put the value of the property as high as $800 million.
According to Granite Partners, the average sale price for Midtown office buildings has risen to almost $300 a square foot, from about $150 a square foot in 1997. Buyers are willing to pay even more for landmark buildings whose cachet often translates into higher rents. At the Lever House, for instance, rents are close to $100 a square foot, $35 higher than the average asking rent in Midtown. And very little vacant office space is available today in Manhattan.
"The underlying market shows no signs of letting up," said Robert A. Sass, director of real estate investment at GVA Williams.
But with interest rates rising, technology stocks faltering and the economy starting to slow, many analysts expect rents to rise more slowly and profits to be more modest, said Mr. Lyons of Granite Partners.
Still, Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs expect to take advantage of the fact that nearly three-quarters of the leases in the Seagram Building will expire in the next five years. With rents in the building at about half the average in Midtown today, the new owners expect to raise rents quickly.
"If the market continues at this rate, it's an absolute home run," said one person involved in the negotiations. "If it doesn't, there's tremendous risk."

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO SCRAP BELGRADE EMBARGO ON OIL AND TRAVEL

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton is to announce on Thursday that he is lifting many of the trade and economic sanctions against Yugoslavia that were intended to speed the fall of Slobodan Milosevic, immediately ending the ban on American flights and an embargo on oil to the country, senior administration officials said.
Mr. Clinton will make a commitment to join with the European Union in sweeping away a variety of additional sanctions over the next several weeks, except for those specifically intended to keep Mr. Milosevic, his family and their political allies from sending millions of dollars in assets overseas. 
 But administration officials said they would retain, at least for the time being, the so-called "outer wall" of sanctions that prevent Yugoslavia from receiving aid from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
That last sanction -- a critical one, because foreign investors are unlikely to return to the country without guarantees from those international institutions -- will remain in place until the United States has discussed Mr. Milosevic's legal fate with the new government of President Vojislav Kostunica. Page A10.
"What we needed to do immediately is open the psychological and the economic spigots, get the oil flowing, get the airplanes in," a senior Clinton aide said this evening. Some of the lifting of the sanctions will be more symbolic than substantive -- the embargo on oil was notably toothless. However, the ability to trade with the United States is widely considered a prerequisite for economic recovery.
The official said that delivering Mr. Milosevic to the international criminal tribunal at The Hague, where he has been indicted on charges of war crimes, may not be a prerequisite for the removal of the rest of the sanctions. He said that the Clinton administration may be satisfied if Mr. Milosevic stands trial in Yugoslavia.
"Obviously Milosevic is an issue," the official said. "But it may be an issue that takes care of itself, either because they change their minds, and turn him over, or they try him themselves."
So far Mr. Kostunica, who has challenged the legitimacy of the the Hague tribunal as a tool of American policy, has said he would not turn over his predecessor. And even if he decides that removing Mr. Milosevic from the scene will serve his interests, it is far from clear that his tenuous hold on the levers of state power, many of which are still in the hands of Milosevic allies, would give him the power to determine Mr. Milosevic's fate.
All these questions will be raised, officials say, as the first American diplomats arrive in Belgrade over the next day to begin discussions with Mr. Kostunica's new government, being formed after last week's popular revolution. Two senior officials are already on their way: William Montgomery, the coordinator of the office of Yugoslav affairs, which is based in Budapest, and James C. O'Brien, the special adviser to the president for democracy in the Balkans.
While the first sanctions will be lifted this week, the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control, which enforces embargoes, is working to track financial flows out of Yugoslavia.
Already, officials say, there is evidence that Mr. Milosevic's cronies are using the almost nonexistent controls over banks, resulting from the upheaval of recent weeks, to funnel millions of dollars out of the country.
One American official said the movement of funds was "reminiscent of Ferdinand Marcos's last days" in the Philippines. It took years to track the former Philippine president's holdings, and even then only a fraction were recovered.
Even before Mr. Kostunica has consolidated his power, there is considerable debate in Washington over the extent to which the economic sanctions contributed to Mr. Milosevic's downfall.
Not surprisingly, White House officials believe that they played a significant role. Even aides to Mr. Clinton who have previously expressed great skepticism about the usefulness of economic sanctions -- especially the sanctions on Cuba -- insist that because so many nations worked together in cutting off Yugoslavia's access to goods and financial markets, popular discontent with Mr. Milosevic rose to the surface rapidly.
"The reason that people finally rose up and said we are going to get rid of this guy is that their lives are hard," said one of Mr. Clinton's closest aides. "This was a case in which sanctions played a big, big role."
But Richard N. Haass, a Brookings Institution scholar who served on the National Security Council under President Bush and has published two lengthy studies of sanctions and their effectiveness, disagreed.
"Sanctions at most played a modest role, and those who are suggesting that they were critical in recent events are simply wrong," he said in an interview today. Referring to the peace talks in Ohio that ended the war in Bosnia in 1995, he said: "Sanctions didn't get Milosevic to Dayton; that was the NATO bombing and the Croatian Army. And sanctions couldn't stop the massacres in Kosovo. They had a contributing effect, but not a decisive one."
Mr. Haass agreed with the administration, however, that turning over Mr. Milosevic should not be a prerequisite for breaching the "outer wall" of financial aid. "The goal is to make Yugoslavia a normal European country," he said. "I would not make coughing up Milosevic the No. 1 priority. After all, he was largely killing his own people, and he can be tried in his own country."

HEADLINE: I.B.M.'s Revival in Hudson Valley Gets a Ho-Hum

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: EAST FISHKILL, N.Y., Oct. 11

 BODY:
When I.B.M. announced on Tuesday that it would spend $2.5 billion and hire 1,000 new employees to create "the world's most technologically advanced" chip factory here, the conventional wisdom, perhaps, was that the news would elate the residents of this Hudson Valley town.
After all, the announcement came seven years after the company had stunned and demoralized the community with a severe downsizing that disproved the assumption that a job at Big Blue was a job forever. 
 But instead, as news of the expansion settled today, people here said that they were pleased, but added some asterisks. Sure, the 1,000 jobs would be nice and would complement the bevy of large and small businesses that have opened here in recent years. But would this mean more overcrowding in the local schools? Would it mean even more new housing developments in a booming real estate market?
"I can see where people are very tentative," said Marlene Stager, a substance-abuse counselor, who was taking two of her sons to the local library, which is in the midst of an expansion project. "I.B.M. is just not the same anymore, because people know that maybe they'll cut people loose in another 5 or 10 years."
If East Fishkill, which is 67 miles from Manhattan, was once the epitome of a one-company town, it is now the epitome of how the good times and astounding growth associated with the new economy can make the most painful of memories recede a little more easily, even after what was supposed to be the most crippling of events.
It is hard to overstate how devastating people thought I.B.M.'s downsizing was back in 1993. Everyone here, it seemed, either worked for the company or had a relative or neighbor who did. So when the company announced the cutbacks, people could hardly believe the news, and resented the company bitterly for destroying the area's equivalent of a tenured job, a resentment that still lingers in some quarters.
But the Hudson Valley of 2000 is much different from the Hudson Valley of 1993. Now, new developments with half-million dollar homes are sprouting everywhere. Home-based businesses run by former I.B.M. employees abound. Rentals are snapped up in hours. The unemployment rate is among the lowest in the region.
So while I.B.M. is still a major force in the area, people now regard the company as just one of many businesses, and not the only game in town.
"It's not the real bread and butter in the community," said Rich Robbins, the senior public health sanitarian for the Dutchess County Department of Health, who was inspecting wells at a new housing development not far the I.B.M. site.
I.B.M. plans to build its new factory, which will produce some of the thinnest computer chips in the world, within a building where it had closed a major chip-production operation in 1993, at the coda of a series of moves paring its work force in the region to 14,000 from 30,700 in 1985.
So naturally, the people most excited by the news, other than the local and state officials who had avidly courted the company and granted it a generous package of tax breaks and incentives, were businesses located near the site. Across the street from the old factory, Rania Nsheiwat, whose brother, Omar, owns Robbie's Y2K Deli, said that her family's business would probably extend its hours to cater to the new I.B.M. employees.
But in areas beyond the immediate vicinity of the plant, the reaction, while supportive, was also much more guarded and muted.
In recent years, the town has attracted a wave of people from Westchester, Putnam and the Bronx. These new residents -- sometimes called the "city folk" by longtime residents -- typically work either in Manhattan or in Westchester, but have decided that the long time spent commuting is a fair price to pay for bigger and cheaper houses than they could find in their former communities.
Theresa Belluzzi is typical of the new crowd. She and her family moved from Yonkers eight years ago, buying a house from a family that had been downsized by I.B.M. Her husband is a union representative in Manhattan, and she runs a business out of her home teaching people how to organize and preserve their family photos.
The I.B.M.-ers, she said, were bitter then, making snide remarks about the company. But these days, hardly anyone talks about the company's fortunes or misfortunes. In fact, the job market is so tight these days, service at low-wage employers like Wal-Mart is paltry. So the addition of 1,000 jobs will most likely make the job market even tighter.
"I really think they're going to overcrowd the area," she said.
As for the former I.B.M.-ers, some said that they thought the new factory was great news, particularly as a psychological boost. But some said that the original layoffs from the mid-1990's, while devastating at first, had not been a permanent blow because many employees had started their own businesses or returned to do some consulting work, albeit at lower salaries, for I.B.M.
"Actually, with I.B.M. downsizing, in retrospect, it was a big nothing," said Chris McClernon, a senior loan officer at Warwick Savings Bank, whose husband received a severance package from I.B .M. in 1993. "It's always nice to have people come in, but it's like 'where are we going to put them?' "

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton, in Ad, Faults Lazio for Missed Votes

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
If it was good enough for Alfonse M. D'Amato when he ran for re-election to the Senate in 1998, then it is good enough for Hillary Rodham Clinton as she runs for the Senate in 2000.
Or so it would seem from a new advertisement released by Mrs. Clinton yesterday. The ad attacks Representative Rick A. Lazio for precisely the thing that Mr. D'Amato attacked Charles E. Schumer for when Mr. Schumer challenged Mr. D'Amato: sneaking out of Washington so he could campaign. 
 "Recently, Rick Lazio skipped 59 of 60 votes in Congress," the announcer declares at the start of the ad. Then, in the space of 15 brisk seconds, it lists, in stark white type against a black background, the votes Mr. Lazio, a Suffolk County Republican, missed in Congress this month. In much the same way, almost exactly two years ago this month, Mr. D'Amato ticked off votes that Mr. Schumer missed for almost three straight weeks during the 1998 campaign.
News of the new Clinton ad produced a topsy-turvy day in the New York Senate race. As it turns out, many of the players from 1998 are still on the scene today -- either as campaign advisers or commentators -- and both Democrats and Republicans, apparently unabashed, raced to the opposite side of the ideological field and marshaled the same arguments that had been used against them the last time.
Two years ago, for example, Howard Wolfson, then the press secretary for Mr. Schumer, characterized the attack on Mr. Schumer's missed votes as "fraudulent." Yesterday, that word was not used by Mr. Wolfson, who as communications director for Ms. Clinton, excoriated Mr. Lazio for his absences from Washington.
"Congressman Lazio is trying to tell New Yorkers that he is an effective legislator for New York, and he has stopped doing his job," Mr. Wolfson said. "He has put his own career and ambitions ahead of New York."
Asked how this differed from Mr. Schumer in 1998, he responded: "If you look at 1998, then-Congressman Schumer was trying to make his votes. The difference is that Congressman Lazio has essentially stopped doing his job completely."
Over at Republican headquarters, Mr. Lazio's aides sounded, well, the same way Mr. Wolfson sounded two years ago: they complained that Mrs. Clinton was referring to absences for ceremonial votes, or votes on which Mr. Lazio's presence would not have made a difference, for the sake of some political points. "Either Mrs. Clinton has no understanding of the legislative process, or she is blatantly trying to deceive New Yorkers," said Bill Dal Col, Mr. Lazio's campaign manager.
Among the votes that Mr. Lazio missed, and that were listed in Mrs. Clinton's ad, were financing for 100,000 new teachers and the Violence against Women Act. The ad said Mr. Lazio was present for a vote on a 3 percent congressional payroll increase, but the measure that was cited was in fact part of a larger Treasury bill that raised salaries for a wide range of federal employees, including members of Congress.
Even Kieran P. Mahoney, the D'Amato consultant who helped direct the attack against Mr. Schumer in 1998, said it was unfair of Mrs. Clinton to use the attack against Mr. Lazio. The difference, Mr. Mahoney said, was that Mr. Lazio had a nearly perfect voting record until Labor Day, when he accelerated his campaigning, whereas Mr. Schumer had missed votes for nearly a year before his election. Unlike Mr. Schumer, Mr. Lazio did not have to face a primary for his party's nomination; he entered the race in June.
All of which begs the question: Does this kind of political attack work? Mr. Schumer's aides long insisted that the attacks by Mr. D'Amato had no effect on Mr. Schumer, who went on to defeat Mr. D'Amato's bid for a third term. That said, the fact that Mrs. Clinton is now embracing the same line would appear to be a belated affirmation of the effectiveness of the tactic.
Mr. Schumer's chief strategist, Hank Morris, declined to comment yesterday. But Mr. Schumer allowed that he believed attacks on a legislator's attendance record could be very potent. "It is an effective line of attack," he said.
Mr. Schumer said that he believed it had taken a toll on his campaign, until it was revealed that Mr. D'Amato had missed dozens of votes on the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors when he first ran for Senate. "Then it just evaporated," Mr. Schumer said.
But there is one practical effect to attacking voting records, as Mr. Schumer learned: It is harder to skip votes in Washington when public attention is suddenly turned on your attendance.
Yesterday, Mr. Lazio cut short a day of campaigning in Buffalo to return to Washington for votes on appropriation bills, among them an agricultural bill that included provisions for upstate farmers and apple growers. Although Mrs. Clinton's aides seized on this as evidence that he was scurrying in response to the ads, Mr. Lazio's aides had, for several days, said he intended to go to Washington for the spending bills.
His advisers expressed incredulity at learning that Mrs. Clinton had borrowed a page from Mr. D'Amato's book. "This is pure Clinton-think: They will say and do anything to win," said Dan McLagan, Mr. Lazio's spokesman. "And do it with a straight face. It's amazing."
While he was upstate yesterday, Mr. Lazio weighed in on a dispute between the Seneca Indian tribe and New York State over 18,000 acres of land. Mr. Lazio argued that a solution to the land claims dispute did not require federal intervention, but should be resolved locally. Mr. Lazio also toured Niagara Falls High School, where every student has been given a laptop computer, and met for about half an hour with Bishop Henry J. Mansell of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Buffalo.
In a series of speeches over the past two days, Mr. Lazio has moved away from asserting that the upstate economy had "turned a corner," after critics, including some upstate Republicans, said he appeared insensitive to lingering economic distress. Mrs. Clinton has criticized Mr. Lazio for not having an economic plan to benefit the upstate region.
Meanwhile, the New York State United Teachers group disclosed that it had bought more than $500,000 worth of time on radio stations for advertisements that might be used, the group acknowledged, to help bolster Mrs. Clinton's candidacy. Such advertisements are barred under an agreement between Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton on campaign spending, though that deal has appeared increasingly shaky. The union said it would not place such ads if the deal remained in place, and would use the time for get-out-the-vote ads.

HEADLINE: Albright Says She Will Visit North Korea Soon

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said tonight that she planned to visit North Korea soon. She will be the highest-level American official to visit the Communist nation since the end of the Korean War nearly 50 years ago.
Dr. Albright revealed her plans in a brief comment during a speech at a dinner here in her honor given by one of North Korea's top military leaders, Gen. Jo Myong Rok. 
 She said she would have more to say about the visit on Thursday.
A South Korean newspaper reported that the visit will be in December.
Dr. Albright's planned trip is another sign of the slow thaw in relations between the United States and North Korea, which is one of the few remaining Communist dictatorships. On Tuesday, President Clinton met with General Jo, the first time that a president has met with a North Korean official.
In remarks at a dinner that she gave for General Jo on Tuesday evening, Dr. Albright said that what has been contested ground can, over time, become common ground.
"Hostility between our two nations is not inevitable, nor desired by our citizens, nor in the interests of our countries," she said. "This is why we must seize the opportunity to take the concrete steps required to open a new and more hopeful chapter in our relations."
American troops have been stationed in South Korea since the end of the war in 1953.
In addition to objections about North Korea's Stalinist ideology, successive administrations have been alarmed by the country's development of nuclear weapons. The Clinton administration has mixed a lifting of some economic sanctions with threats of military force to persuade North Korea to halt its nuclear weapons program. North Korea is on the State Department's list of states that support terrorism.
The last year has also seen a thaw in the relations between North and South Korea.
Families divided for nearly half a century have held reunions, and in June, the leaders of North and South Korea met.
In a bit of diplomacy, the International Olympic Committee persuaded the two countries to march together at the recent summer games in Sydney.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Democratic New Spending vs. Republican Tax Reductions

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
The Republican National Committee released two new commercials this week attacking Vice President Al Gore for proposing a budget that it asserted would turn projected surpluses into deficits and endanger the nation's prosperity.
The advertising is part of an effort by the Republicans to put Mr. Gore on the defensive over his proposals for new spending and to neutralize any advantage that the strong economy might give Mr. Gore. It also tries to blunt Mr. Gore's attacks on Mr. Bush's tax plan, which Democrats say disproportionately favors the wealthy. 
 One of the commercials focuses exclusively on the scale of Mr. Gore's spending plans. The other contrasts Mr. Bush's tax-cut plan with Mr. Gore's spending proposals.
The commercials are scheduled to run in 17 states, including Florida, Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
 
PRODUCER -- Cold Harbor Films
 
ON THE SCREEN -- Opens with a white screen and the words "Whose economic plan is best for you?" Then flashes to a screen with a chart labeled "Bush: Tax Cut Plan," showing how people at various income levels would do under Mr. Bush's proposal. Next comes a chart comparing the spending proposals made by President Clinton with those made by Mr. Gore. Concludes with text on a white screen saying that Mr. Gore's plan would undermine the economy.
 
THE SCRIPT -- Announcer: "Whose economic plan is best for you? Under George Bush's plan, a family earning under $35,000 a year pays no federal income taxes, a 100 percent tax cut. Earn $35-50,000? A 55 percent tax cut. And Al Gore's plan? Three times the new spending President Clinton proposed, so much it wipes out the entire surplus and creates a deficit again. Al Gore's deficit spending plan threatens America's prosperity."
 
ACCURACY -- The chart describing the effects of the Bush tax plan is somewhat misleading. Many families making less than $35,000 a year already pay no federal income taxes. Mr. Bush's plan would remove more of them from the income tax rolls, mainly by doubling the child credit. But the claims in the commercial are based on a family with two children; single people and families with fewer than two children would not fare as well.
The assertion that Mr. Gore is proposing three times the spending sought by Mr. Clinton is based on a comparison of the 1992 Clinton campaign's agenda with Mr. Gore's proposals this year. Mr. Clinton made his proposals at a time when the government was running a record budget deficit and was constrained from expanding or adding programs. Mr. Gore is proposing ways to allocate a large and growing surplus. The comparison is based on a study by the National Taxpayer's Union, a conservative research group, which says Mr. Gore's spending plans total $2.9 trillion over 10 years. Mr. Gore puts the number at between $870 billion and $1 trillion.
 
SCORE CARD -- Mr. Bush has sought to frame the debate as one about who would best take advantage of the nation's prosperity, rather than about who gets the credit for it. The new advertising is intended to suggest that Mr. Gore is an old-style tax-and-spend liberal who will squander the surplus, while emphasizing that Mr. Bush is giving a tax break to lower and middle income families. But the more that Mr. Bush pushes economic issues, the more he risks reminding voters that the country has rarely, if ever, had it this good. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: Lazio Tax Cut Is Better for State, Conservative Group Says

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
A new study asserts that Hillary Rodham Clinton's tax cut plan would be less beneficial for New Yorkers than the one proposed by Representative Rick A. Lazio, because hers relies more on giving reductions to people who make certain expenditures and have incomes below specific ceilings.
The study, by the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research group, notes that salaries and the cost of living are higher in New York than in most states. As a result, plans that provide tax cuts to anyone in the country making less than a threshold -- often referred to as "targeted tax cuts" -- would exclude more people in New York than in some other states. 
 The report notes that the median income for a family of four is $50,200 nationally, $56,100 in New York State, $56,200 in New York City, and $83,100 in Westchester County. So tax cuts that are supposedly directed at an average family by imposing an income ceiling of say, $52,000, might exclude many of those in New York.
That conclusion is also true for the tax cut plan proposed by Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic presidential candidate. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican candidate, has presented a more sweeping package that would benefit far more New Yorkers by reducing taxes for people with all levels of income.
Democrats have generally favored targeted tax cuts whose benefits go more toward the poor and middle class, arguing that some of the federal surplus should be used to pay down the national debt and shore up Social Security. The Republicans argue that those objectives can be achieved even with more broadly based tax cuts, and argue that the government should not reward people for making certain expenditures, and should give benefits to all taxpayers.
Middle-class families will "fare better under Lazio's plan than under Clinton's, although most will receive less tax relief than under Governor Bush's plan," writes the author of the report, Edmund J. McMahon Jr. "Lazio's plan is particularly beneficial to families earning the median income or above in New York City's suburbs."
Mrs. Clinton has proposed a tax cut package for items like college payments, child care and retirement savings. Mr. Lazio has called for easing the so-called marriage penalty, repealing some taxes on Social Security benefits and allowing the payroll tax to be deducted.
Neera Tanden, the deputy campaign manager for the Clinton campaign, questioned the thesis and methodology of the report. She said the Clinton plan would in fact have more benefits for New York, relative to its overall cost. "Hillary supports targeted tax cuts that meet the needs of working families," she said. "Rick Lazio's trillion-dollar tax cut plan is fiscally irresponsible and threatens our current economic prosperity."
Like Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Lazio has proposed initiatives that include income ceilings for their cuts, although Mr. Lazio's are more broadly based than Mrs. Clinton's. The Lazio plan's biggest reduction, allowing the payroll tax to be deductible, is limited to those in the 15 percent and 28 percent brackets (that is, up to $105,950 in taxable income for couples, the report says).
The report concludes that the Lazio plan would provide New Yorkers with $4.2 billion in tax cuts.
Dan McLagan, a spokesman for the Lazio campaign, said, "We are pleased that the Manhattan Institute has joined the nonpartisan National Taxpayers Union in clearly showing that Congressman Lazio's economic plan is far superior for New York's families."
The Clinton plan would cut taxes by $1.2 billion for New Yorkers, according to the report. But the Clinton campaign said the report left out a $1.8 billion cut for retirement plans. Mr. McMahon, the author, said that he had understood from campaign officials that the cut was intended to benefit businesses, not individuals, but that if there was a misunderstanding, the amount should be included and the total benefits should be $3 billion.
Both packages are dwarfed by the Bush proposal, which would give New Yorkers $11.1 billion in reductions. The Gore plan would save taxpayers in the state $3.5 billion, according to the report.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: FOREIGN POLICY;
A Delicate Dance of the Interventionist and the Reluctant Internationalist

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
For the better part of a year now, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have gingerly stepped around much detailed discussion of how America should exercise its unchallenged economic, diplomatic and military power around the world.
When they were finally forced to face off on that question in their presidential debate tonight, it seemed as if each had calculated that there was little electoral advantage in fighting over foreign policy. Indeed, rather than talk about how to exert American might -- the subtext of the famous Nixon-Kennedy debates in 1960 and so many of the cold-war-era debates that followed -- they spent much of the time politely warning of the foreign entanglements they might avoid. 
 And yet there were some significant distinctions -- often buried in quick asides meant to hint, but never exactly state, how each man might run the country differently from the other.
Mr. Gore portrayed himself as the interventionist Democrat, the man who would be driven largely by "a question of values" and who would consider an act of genocide enough of a challenge to American interests to consider sending troops abroad. He stopped short, however, of saying the Clinton administration should have done so to stop the genocide in Rwanda six years ago.
Mr. Bush was the reluctant internationalist, the man who allowed that "we've got to do a lot of work in Africa to promote democracy and trade" and then insisted that America should keeps its troops out of Africa and Haiti, or anyplace else where the mission sniffed of "nation-building." He never defined that phrase, but he made clear that he thought the purpose of the American military was to fight wars, not rebuild countries.
And in Mr. Bush's world view, America's traditional allies mattered far more than remote, poor or strategically inconsequential nations. "There's got to be priorities," he said, ticking off the Middle East, Europe, the Far East and "our own hemisphere," a list that conspicuously omitted Africa and many of the world's poorest nations.
"I'm not so sure the role of the United States is to go around the world and say, 'This is the way it's got to be,' " Mr. Bush said, sounding much like the Democrats sounded in the aftermath of the Vietnam War. Later he added, "I just don't think it's the role of the United States to walk into a country, say, ' We do it this way; so should you.' "
That left Mr. Gore free to sound more like the Republicans of two decades ago -- certain that America's role is to make others in the world exercise their long-suppressed desire to "be like us more." He described himself, as he did in an interview last week, as a nation-builder and proud of it.
Once again, he invoked President Harry S. Truman's use of the Marshall Plan to rebuild Europe, seeming to suggest that it was the kind of role Mr. Bush would have opposed.
"We were nation-building," Mr. Gore said. "And it was economic, but it was also military."
This all seemed like an academic argument, more suited for International Relations 101. But it got interesting as soon as it got specific.
Pressed by the moderator, Jim Lehrer, about when they would have committed troops and when they would have backed off, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush politely quibbled. But these were quibbles with a deeper message that suggested significantly different standards of when American intervention makes sense.
Lebanon, where American marines died in a huge car-bomb blast? "I thought that was a mistake," Mr. Gore said.
Grenada, where President Ronald Reagan, in the name of saving American medical students, made a clumsy but successful stand against a tiny government that seemed to be defying American wishes and influence? "I supported that," he said, along with the Bush administration's ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's dictator. But he had second thoughts about Somalia, a decision of "the Bush-Quayle administration," he said, unable to avoid reference to one of the Republican Party's less admired vice presidents.
Mr. Bush, treading carefully, had problems with Somalia, too, not the mission his father began but the one President Clinton finished.
"Started off as a humanitarian mission and then changed into a nation-building mission," he insisted, "and that's where the mission went wrong."
But he supported almost every other intervention -- "Some of them I've got a conflict of interest on," he said, to laughter, in a reference to his father's decisions -- raising the question of when he in fact would decide to keep his forces at home.
Later, pressed about where he might pull back American forces, which he said were overcommitted, Mr. Bush had a hard time. He would keep them in Korea, he said, and in Europe. But he also said he would hand off peacekeeping to other, regional players; he cited Australia's role last year in East Timor as a superb example of where someone else provided the troops while the Pentagon gave advice and a bit of logistical help. He said he would like to withdraw American troops from the Balkans, but not immediately. The only place he named from which he would withdraw troops at once was Haiti, where there are only a handful.
Governor Bush may have left viewers with the incorrect impression that the United States is alone in maintaining ground troops to keep the peace in Bosnia and Kosovo.
"I'd very much like to get our troops out of there," he said. "I recognize we can't do it now; nor do I advocate an immediate withdrawal. That would be an abrogation of our agreement with NATO. No one is suggesting that. But I think it ought to be one of our priorities to work with our European friends to convince them to put troops on the ground."
But many other nations -- and not just the NATO allies -- have ground troops currently committed to the Balkans. Of the 20,000 troops now assigned to the Bosnia peacekeeping mission, 4,600 are American. In Kosovo, the total mission of 40,000 troops has 6,000 Americans.
The dynamic of the interventionist Mr. Gore and the more reluctant Mr. Bush also played out beyond the military realm.
As on other foreign policy issues, the two men gingerly approached the question of when America should put up its own money, or the International Monetary Fund's, to stop financial crises. Here, Mr. Bush was more specific.
"I think the I.M.F. has got a role in the world," the governor said, "but I don't want to see the I.M.F. out there as a way to say to world bankers, 'If you make a bad loan, we'll bail you out.' "
Yet that is exactly what the I.M.F. and the United States Treasury did in Mexico, an intervention that was supported by Mr. Bush, whose home state, Texas, would have borne the brunt of a more severe Mexican economic collapse.
Without noting that Mr. Gore had been the architect of much of the Clinton administration's Russia policy, Mr. Bush charged that the administration had blindly lent to corrupt regimes. "We went into Russia," he said. "We said, 'Here's some I.M.F. money,' and it ended up in Viktor Chernomyrdin's pocket."
He referred to the former Russian prime minister, who was Mr. Gore's counterpart in long negotiations over Russian reforms.
Numerous studies of the I.M.F. bailouts of Russia have failed to prove that Mr. Chernomyrdin benefited directly, though the enterprises that he made a fortune running were certainly helped.
Mr. Gore was clearly on the defensive, and said he was uncomfortable with the I.M.F. "I've seen them make some calls that I thought were highly questionable," he said, without giving specifics.
And then he went on to decry corruption -- hardly a controversial position -- before insisting that providing aid was also a way of extending American influence.
"We have a fundamental choice to make," he said. "Are we going to step up to the plate as a nation the way we did after World War II?"
Mr. Bush chose not to answer, at least directly.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1952 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE OVERVIEW;
This Time, More Accord Than Discord

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore agreed more than they disagreed last night in an event that was often closer to a cordial conversation than a debate as they exchanged views on tense foreign conflicts and domestic matters like racial profiling, gun control and same-sex marriage.
The forum in Winston-Salem, N.C., was a striking departure from the first debate a week ago in Boston, when they energetically took deeply different stands on issues like taxes and prescription drugs that have been at the heart of the presidential race. 
 But last night, breaking with their campaigns' scathing commercials and their own oratory, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush were respectful, and at times even complimentary. The civility prompted Mr. Bush to volunteer at one point that it seemed "like we're having a great love-fest tonight." Transcript, Page A22.
The subdued tenor was largely deliberate. Advisers in both camps said their candidates were determined not to put off voters by coming across as strident. Yet many of the questions by the moderator, Jim Lehrer of PBS, were on issues over which the nominees had few differences.
Not until the last 15 minutes of the evening did the candidates grow slightly combative, with Mr. Gore questioning Mr. Bush's record as governor of Texas, and Mr. Bush asserting that the vice president's tendency to embellish raised questions about his credibility. That prompted the vice president to take the unusual step of apologizing for his previous misstatements.
Even when they did clash, the jabs were cloaked in decorous tones. At one point, Mr. Gore, who was hardly bashful at deriding his rival in the first debate, seemed to almost apologize when he turned to Mr. Bush and said of health care proposals in Texas: "I'm sorry to tell you, there is a record here."
The first half of the 90-minute forum at Wake Forest University was devoted to foreign policy, with the candidates' largely agreeing on the nation's policies in the Mideast and the Balkans. They both, for example, went farther than President Clinton in calling on Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to restrain the violence in Israel.
But their exchanges showed Mr. Gore to be more willing to use American force to intervene in regional conflicts.
The vice president said that a case of genocide almost automatically engaged American interests and that it was appropriate for troops to stay on to help ensure a democratic transition -- a use of American power that Mr. Bush derided as "nation-building." For example, Mr. Gore supported American intervention in Haiti, which Mr. Bush characterized as a mistake.
Mr. Bush sought to present himself as a statesman by repeatedly saying he agreed with many of the administration's decisions. He also tried to demonstrate that he was as conversant on such matters as Mr. Gore, who has been at the center of many of the nation's most crucial decisions about international affairs. Mr. Bush made clear that he was strongly against sending troops and resources into failed states.
In a nod to the nearly two weeks of bloodshed in Israel, Mr. Bush said, "I think during the campaign, particularly during this difficult period, we ought to be speaking with one voice. And I appreciate the way the administration has worked hard to calm the tensions."
Mr. Bush, like Mr. Gore, often spoke in generalities about his foreign policy philosophy. "If we're an arrogant nation, they'll resent us," Mr. Bush said of people outside this country. "If we're a humble nation, but strong, they'll welcome us."
Mr. Gore emphasized his involvement in foreign policy and described a much more activist and broader moral mission for the United States in the plight of other countries.
Explaining his approach to foreign affairs, he said: "We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values. It also means keep our economy strong."
Just as they did when they took the stage in Boston last week, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore confronted a frustrating and even tormenting reality when last night's debate began: while Mr. Bush has edged up slightly, he and the vice president are mired in a race that is a statistical dead heat. If for no other reason, the stakes in this debate were even greater than in last week's because Election Day is only 26 days away. The third and final debate is next Tuesday in St. Louis.
In many ways, the candidates sought to dispel the same critiques and stereotypes that have plagued them in the campaign. Mr. Bush sought to show that he was no bumbler and that he could comfortably navigate the ins and outs of policy, particularly foreign affairs.
Mr. Gore, who is well known as a policy maven, tried to demonstrate that he was a likable politician and not an unappealing brawler. He succeeded in halting the audible sighs that marked his performance last week; in a contrast to last week, he at times nodded affirmatively when Mr. Bush was speaking.
At times, there was a marked contrast between Mr. Gore's seeming efforts to restrain himself from appearing belligerent and Mr. Bush's relaxed, even expansive, demeanor near the end of the encounter.
Over all, the feel and the format of last night's debate seemed decidedly more casual than the first one. For one thing, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush had already endured the drill once before. But the setting was somewhat more intimate. Rather than stand at lecterns, the candidates sat at a table with Mr. Lehrer.
The Bush campaign had pressed for the format in the debate negotiations. Mr. Bush's aides said he was far more comfortable in a more conversational format. It was the first time participants in a presidential debate sat at a table in that format.
It was not until the waning moments, under questioning by Mr. Lehrer, that the sparring began in earnest.
Mr. Gore said Mr. Bush had blocked hate crimes legislation, and he asserted that the governor presided over a state that ranked last in health insurance for families.
"Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in children with health care," Mr. Gore said, "49th for women with health care and 50th for families with health care."
For his part, Mr. Bush said the vice president had fought for a government-run health care system in the first two years of the Clinton administration. "That was fortunately stopped in its tracks," Mr. Bush said.
Governor Bush said Mr. Gore was "absolutely wrong" if he was trying to suggest that Mr. Bush was a hard-hearted person who did not care about children.
Mr. Bush acknowledged that a health insurance program for children "got a late start" in Texas. But, he insisted, "we're reducing the number of uninsured as a percentage of our population" in Texas, while the comparable figure is increasing nationally.
Mr. Gore said he was not questioning the purity of Mr. Bush's heart, but challenging his priorities and values. In Texas, Mr. Gore said, Mr. Bush "opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the Legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered, and instead directed the money toward a tax cut, a significant part of which went to wealthy interests."
On the question of Mr. Gore's embellishments, Mr. Lehrer asked Mr. Bush if he thought the vice president did indeed "stretch the facts," and whether that was something the voters ought to consider.
"We all make mistakes," Mr. Bush responded. "I have been known to mangle a syl-ABBLE or two myself." The deliberate mispronunciation was, of course, an allusion to several word gaucheries Mr. Bush has committed of late, and it brought a flurry of laughter.
Turning suddenly serious, Mr. Bush said a president's credibility is important, both at home and abroad, and is something the voters should consider. "This isn't something new," he said of Mr. Gore, bringing up a memorandum from the latter's short 1988 presidential campaign in which a staff aide warned him to stick to the facts.
Looking back to their first debate, Mr. Gore admitted that he had tripped himself up on some facts. "I got some details wrong, and some examples," he said. "I'm sorry about that, and I'm going to try to do better."
In one area where both candidates seemed to agree, Mr. Gore said he would support legislation to ban racial profiling. And he repeated a pledge that his first act as president would be to issue an executive order banning the practice.
"It will be the first civil rights act of the 21st century," he said.
Mr. Bush agreed but added that he did not want to "federalize" the local police. "It's very important that we not overstep our bounds," he said.
But in a sharp moment reminding viewers of his firm enforcement of the death penalty, Mr. Bush pointed to the racially motivated murder of James Byrd, a black man dragged to his death in East Texas in June 1998.
"The three men who murdered James Byrd," he said, "guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death."
Mr. Gore then politely suggested that Mr. Bush was blurring his stance on hate-crimes legislation, saying that the governor had barred such legislation in Texas.
Both candidates said they opposed marriages for gays and lesbians. "I'm not for gay marriage," Mr. Bush said. "I think marriage is a sacred institution between a man ad a woman."
Mr. Gore agreed, but then added, "I think we should find a way to allow some kind of civic unions."
He invoked Mr. Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney, who in the vice-presidential debate last week joined Mr. Gore's running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, in sounding tolerant of such unions.
"I basically agree with Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman, and I think the three of us have one view and the governor has another view."
Mr. Bush said he was not sure what kind of view Mr. Gore was describing, and added, "I can just tell you, I'm a person who respects other people."
The vice president also expressed his support for legislation to prevent gays and lesbians from being fired from their jobs because of their sexual orientation and asked the governor to lend his support. Mr. Bush replied, "I don't know the particulars of this law."
On gun control, Mr. Gore said he would "not do anything that would affect the rights" of hunters or sportsmen or homeowners seeking to protect their families.
Still, he said, "there are too many guns getting into the hands of children and criminals."
Mr. Gore said assault weapons were a particular problem. He said he favored closing the gun show loophole, for which he cast a deciding vote in the Senate. The Congress has failed to complete action on the bill, he said.
Mr. Gore said the government should strengthen enforcement of gun laws, keep schools gun free and issue child safety trigger locks on mandatory basis.
Mr. Bush echoed the importance of enforcing gun laws, saying criminals must know with "certainty" that they will be punished for using a weapon illegally.
He said he supported instant background checks at gun shows. Texas has been an innovator, Mr. Bush said, in distributing free trigger locks.
On the environment, an issue that has fascinated Mr. Gore for years, the vice president was asked whether he stood by his earlier statements that environmental protection should be the central priority in the new century. He said he did, explaining, "I think that in this 21st century, we will soon see the consequences of what's called global warming. What's happening is the level of pollution is increasing, significantly."
He said that an accusation, often made by his Republicans critics, that environmental concerns were in conflict with economic growth was "really outdated."
