PUB-DATE: October 12, 2000

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 2120 words

HEADLINE: Dublin: Now Fair And Worldly

BYLINE: By FLORENCE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: DUBLIN

 BODY:
ALEX WILLIAMS put down his mop and apologized for the mess. "I had a raging party in here last night," he said. Even so, the apartment looked good. A sleek blue sofa and expensive stereo accented the living room. Oak shutters framed wide windows.
Mr. Williams, 30, an unmarried software designer, moved into Dublin's new Wooden Building two months ago. It is the latest -- and most expensive -- addition to an ambitious state-sponsored redevelopment of Temple Bar, a previously down-and-out neighborhood on the south bank of the River Liffey. The area was full of obsolete four- or five-story brick warehouses and empty lots. About half the warehouses have been completely renovated, half knocked down. 
 "I'm in the center of town, but it's quiet, I can walk to work," Mr. Williams said of his one-bedroom home that he rents for around $1,100 a month. "It's like no other building in Ireland, with all the wood and the big canopy at the top, and inside, it's really well finished."
Mr. Williams represents a vanguard demographic in a vanguard type of architecture. In Ireland, a country with Europe's highest rate of home ownership, he is in the first wave of successful young professionals to rent an apartment in the central city. Both the luxury building and Mr. Williams's capacity to live in it would have been unthinkable just a decade ago. Since then, Ireland has become Europe's hottest, fastest-growing economy, drawing a huge influx of high-tech and financial-services companies.
After a century of exporting its young professionals, the country is enticing them back in droves as well as attracting emigrants. Mr. Williams, who is Irish, lived in Japan, Belgium and the United States before returning to work for an Internet start-up, WorldofFruit.com.
In the mid-1990's, Ireland became the grateful recipient of substantial urban renewal and tourism grants from the European Union, including $25 million to transform Temple Bar into a new cultural quarter for the city. Still, the Irish, known for their fierce, sentimental love of tradition and for their stubborn independence, view the Europeanization of Dublin with a mixture of pride and alarm.
Planners were determined not to turn the neighborhood into a EuroDisney of faux-Georgian architecture, but to encourage innovative design. In 1991, Temple Bar Properties, a state-run agency, hired a young team of Dublin architects to draw up guidelines for the 36-square-block area, previously slated to become a city transportation depot. Now, Temple Bar has restaurants, bars, shops, 10 cultural centers and 1,000 new residential apartment units. Of the units, about half were developed privately and the others were commissioned from a variety of architectural firms. The Wooden Building, designed by the Dublin firm Blacam & Meagher, was part of the neighborhood's final development phase.
The nine-story building, named for its exterior and actually comprising two free-standing halves separated by a narrow air shaft, has 17 one- and two-bedroom units. Part of the building is fully wrapped in untreated iroko wood, part in stucco accented by large iroko-framed windows, and part in thick mortared brickwork. References abound to medieval and contemporary Northern European design. The architects insisted on hiring artisans for much of the custom features, like six-panel oak doors and copper window casements.
"Temple Bar Properties essentially said, 'Go for it,' " said Shane de Blacam, a principal architect at Blacam & Meagher and a Dubliner with sparse but unruly reddish-gray hair. "A lot of the buildings there had been pretty boring. We think our building lives with what the modern notion of a tower is." Mr. de Blacam, who worked with Louis I. Kahn in Philadelphia in the early 1970's, is known for his innovative use of timber in such buildings as the Beckett Theater at nearby Trinity College, and in another multistory Temple Bar building that received an award last year from the Royal Institute of Architects of Ireland.
Mr. de Blacam said of the Wooden: "It's appropriate to this climate and culture, and we want it to be about Dublin. I'm delighted people are making a fuss about it."
Last spring, its apartments were sold at auction -- a first for the city -- and fetched prices rivaling those in Paris and New York. Mr. Williams's landlord bought his one-bedroom for $287,000. Martin Keane, a bar and nightclub owner, says he bought his two-bedroom (with a small roof garden) for $641,000, not including the parking space. "The price was higher than I expected," Mr. Keane, a married empty nester, said, "but if you want something bad enough you go the extra mile." Some are already calling it Dublin's most beautiful apartment building.
"The city is being reinvented before our very eyes," said Frank McDonald, an architecture and environment reporter for The Irish Times who lives in a converted fifth-floor warehouse in Temple Bar. "In the mid-1980's, Dublin was a backwater, so incredibly bleak it looked like a different city. There were 150 acres of derelict land. Now, there's hardly any. To a large extent, the inner city has been saved."
Today, down the street from the Wooden Building, jazz musicians give free concerts in Meeting House Square under an aluminum awning by Santiago Calatrava, the Spanish architect and engineer. Internet cafes vie with bars for attention from Dublin's young digirati. Half of Dublin's population is under 30. "I feel like a vanishing breed," Mr. McDonald, well over 30, said. "There's a real sense that the city has been taken over by this changeling species with no memory of thrift, poverty, no folk memory of famine. They're interested in money and having a good time. It's not dissimilar to the U.S."
Unemployment is at a record low, 3.8 percent, and jobs have grown 39 percent since 1994. In that time, greater Dublin's population grew 10 percent. With such heady growth comes headaches, especially for planners, environmentalists and those hurt by staggering traffic congestion, currency inflation and escalating housing costs. Dublin, with 1.3 million people -- a much higher figure than planners anticipated a decade ago -- has no subway system. The city will need 200,000 more homes for its workers in the next 10 years, Mr. McDonald said. At the same time, working-class families -- "true Dubs," as they are known -- are being priced out of the city. In short, sprawl has begun.
"We're at a crossroads," Mr. McDonald added. "Our planning is already infected by an Anglo-American, car-dependent thesis. The question is, how much can you control the spread of the edge city? We haven't yet reconciled ourselves to real urban living and higher density housing. Do we want to be a European city or an American city built around motorways and detached housing?"
The Irish have always considered apartments as either the unfortunate fate of those on the dole (like Chicago and New York, Dublin is scarred by disastrous public-housing high-rises) or the temporary domain of students. There is still no attempt to institute rent control or fair-eviction laws. The sentiment against renting springs from the oppressive legacy of English landlords. But changing demographics, a dire shortage of affordable housing and longer commutes are making apartment life more desirable.
The Irish are also catching up to Americans and other Europeans in marrying later, having fewer children and, since it was legalized in 1997, being divorced. As recently as 1972, women were forced to leave civic jobs upon marrying. That has all changed. "We're a post-Catholic country now," Mr. McDonald said.
The number of single-person households increased 17 percent from 1992 to 1997, and the number of couples without children increased 22 percent in the same period, vividly changing housing needs. Though people are waiting longer to start families, as in other industrialized nations, the change here seems swift and striking. "Dublin has acres of mindless, cheap flats," Mr. de Blacam said. "Apartments weren't considered proper. Now, that idea is being completely transformed."
In the wake of Temple Bar, other quarters of the city are planned for high-density redevelopment, notably the Docklands, an industrial warehouse and shipping district. Throughout central downtown, planners would like to replace the existing low-rise skyline with a more European seven- or eight-story skyline. For the most part, Dubliners still thumb their noses at anything higher.
Like so many other cities before it, Dublin is struggling to retain its small-city identity, and the gentrification of Temple Bar has its critics. Artists, once a catalyst for preserving the area, can no longer compete with dot-comers for rents. The city's oldest Catholic Church, around the corner from the Wooden Building, was converted to what many consider a cheesy tourist operation called Dublin's Viking Adventure.
"I found it began to show the same trend as SoHo," Dr. Mary Corcoran, a sociologist at the National University of Ireland, said. "An area with a bohemian ambience and low rents for alternative-arts people very quickly became a developers' paradise, with swanky new apartment buildings. The bohemian element feels pushed out -- it's not really an indigenous vernacular community anymore." In the last four years, 2,000 to 3,000 luxury apartments have been built in central Dublin, changing the once comfortably dowdy feel of the streets.
Michael Smith, the National Heritage Trust president, bemoans the loss of the vernacular pub. Only one Temple Bar pub out of every two dozen has retained its character, he said, adding that a lot "have been plasticated." "It's a drinking mile rather than a cultural quarter," he said.
Like New Orleans's French Quarter and London's Covent Garden, Temple Bar became a magnet for college rowdies, young European weekenders and those attending stag parties. Two years ago, pub owners agreed to ban the latter. But what had once been intimate, etched-glass and oak establishments have been transformed into mega-theme bars, like the All Sports Cafe, Thunder Road Cafe and House of Rock. Initially wanting to attract tourists, the city provided tax incentives to encourage pubs to build or expand in the neighborhood. With the theme bars comes a further dent in Irish identity, even as, ironically, Irish pubs are being replicated elsewhere. Even the Guinness Brewing Company is now owned by a British food and beverage company.
"In the old pub," Mr. Smith said, "typically the barman would be a true Dub with lots of character and wisdom to share. Now, foreigners have those jobs. Conversation was a major facet of national character, typically veering between politics and quasi philosophy. Now, the standard topic is the price of property."
Mr. de Blacam also regrets the change. He said: "I feel it was wrong to persist with commercial development in Temple Bar, because apartments went for astronomical prices in the end. The wisdom was that shops on the ground floor maximize investment, but if we want children and families to live in the city, that has to change. It may be a long time before we build a city quarter that feels truly residential."
Deyan Sudjic, architecture critic of The London Observer and editor of Domus, the Italian design magazine, said that Ireland is not alone in its increasing urban sophistication. "Housing throughout Britain is finally emerging from the stone ages," when only large, crude houses dominated the outer city, he said. The difference is that tasteful single-family houses are affordable in cities like Glasgow and Edinburgh, but not in Dublin, he said, adding, "Dublin is on an entirely different planet economically."
For its part, the Wooden Building also sparked a contentious neighborhood debate over building heights. Originally designed to be four stories higher, the building was reduced when protests forced the architects to compromise. "We took a strong stance, because Dublin is under enormous, vicious pressure to produce high-rises," said Mr. Smith of the National Heritage Trust. "Now, I'm somewhat embarrassed after what has turned into one of the most exciting and highest quality new schemes, but we needed to stop a dangerous precedent."
Mr. Williams, preparing for the next party, doesn't think he'll live in Temple Bar forever. "I'll do it for a year and then see," he said. "I do think the old city is a really nice area, and I might think of buying here. If I have kids, though, I'd probably move back out to the suburbs."
Does he think apartment-dwelling will become a commonplace? "Well," he said, "renting has not been that popular. But we're an adaptive people."

PUB-DATE: October 13, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 44; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4746 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If only a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman). 

 * "ART AND THE EMPIRE CITY: NEW YORK, 1825-1861," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). The point is that during the antebellum years New York began to become, well, New York, America's megalopolis and an international crossroads. The great metaphor was the plan to grid Manhattan: unsentimental, open-ended, utilitarian and democratic, it created the blank sheet on which the city could draw its future. Amusing, gigantic, only marginally an art exhibition, the show is really an ostentatious illustrated history lesson via hundreds of pieces of old crockery, etchings, paintings, rosewood firescreens, daguerreotypes and mother-of-pearl folding fans. Custom-made for today's acquisitive age, the exhibition is probably the only occasion on which a 19th-century brown ceramic water cooler and a six-sided pitcher with pictures of the presidential candidate William Henry Harrison have been presented in the style of the treasures of the pharaoh's palace in "The Ten Commandments." Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 "A BRUSH WITH NATURE: THE GERE COLLECTION OF LANDSCAPE OIL SKETCHES," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Nov. 12). Most of the artists in this show -- English, French, Italian, German, Belgian and Scandinavian, from the 17th to the 19th centuries -- are barely known today. In their own age they did something quite offbeat: they left studios to paint outdoors, registering transient moments of light and atmosphere by sketching quickly in oil from nature. Until recently it was assumed that this plein air approach, used to train hand and eye for more ambitious compositions, began with the Impressionists. These canvases today are sought-after prizes. The 68 on view here were assembled by a pioneering scholar and collector in the field, John Gere (1921-1995), former keeper of prints and drawings at the British Museum, and his wife, Charlotte. Mostly painted in Rome and the surrounding countryside, they capture such painterly events as the seamed face of a rock, the rush of water through a valley, the play of sunlight on a ruin, the quirky architecture of a building or a wall. Tune your eye to small when you look at this show, and you'll find it a treasure. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $5 for students (over 10) and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
 * "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with hand-written words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an ice-breaking introduction to an art that can all too easily seem, to non-Chinese speakers, unapproachable. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).
 
 "HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE," Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Dec. 31). The complex cultural amalgam of music, poetry, break-dancing, art and fashion that is hip-hop poses a serious challenge to any art museum, but with the proper resources and curatorial expertise, it could have been done. Instead this show offers a partial outline of hip-hop history, conveyed by photographs, posters, magazine and album covers, memorabilia and monotonous expanses of clothes that make the show nearly indistinguishable from the gift shop. Garnished with graffiti art, it bypasses many other equally interesting connections to contemporary art. Because the show omits music videos, it manages to be virtually devoid of the sounds, words and moving bodies that are the essence of hip-hop. The results are a cross between a mall and a mausoleum. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).
 
 "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000," the year-and-a-half-long, millenium-marking rethinking of the Modern's permanent collection, is off and running, with the first of three staggered floor-through sections in place. The dates covered are 1960 to the present, so there's some sense of how a bastion of modernism is dealing with a postmodern world. Pretty well, judging from recent acquisitions of work by Pipilotti Rist, Matthew Barney and Cai Guo-Qiang. The real interest, though, is in smart theme shows that play with such contemporary fixations as childhood innocence and adult experience, and the blend of art, abjection and design. (The fourth-floor galleries will open on Thursday and the third-floor galleries on Nov. 5.) Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 "THE OPULENT EYE OF ALEXANDER GIRARD," Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through March 18). The first comprehensive look at the multifaceted work of the architect and designer. Girard's contribution to contemporary design was a free approach that incorporated all sorts of visual stimuli, from Italian stage sets to Mexican folk art to motifs from modern technology, making exuberant use of color, pattern, texture and ornament. In photographs, models and objects, the exhibition displays his fabrics, graphics, interiors, furniture, tableware, radio cabinets and much else. A whole room is devoted to the more than 300 fabric and wallpaper designs he created for the Herman Miller Furniture Company from the 1950's to the early 1970's with fresh patterns and colors that pushed the limits of middle-class taste. While Girard may not have been a heavyweight in American design, he was one of its liveliest figures. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays until 9 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $3 for students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
 "PIERRE ET GILLES," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 7). No history of postmodern photography, fashion photography, celebrity portraiture, record album covers or the highbrow beefcake tradition would be complete without the work of the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles, who have collaborated on over-the-top, tightly styled, hand-finished photographs since 1976 and become wildly famous in Europe in the process. In their first American museum retrospective, their work feels more than a little embalmed, existing behind a not-so-invisible shield of artistic conservatism. Certain images come to life as art objects -- most notably, one of a beautiful young sailor up to his chest in water with an iridescent night sky behind him -- but those are few. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but this beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 "RUSKIN'S ITALY, RUSKIN'S ENGLAND, "Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Jan. 7). This show commemorates the 100th anniversary of the death of John Ruskin (1819-1900), artist, art and architectural critic, social reformer, educator and the first official professor of art in England. From its own collections, the Morgan has mined a biographical medley of letters, manuscripts, photographs, drawings, paintings and artifacts relating to the life of this Victorian giant, whose published writings run to 39 volumes. Although not really an art show, it includes paintings and drawings by Ruskin and artists he admired, among them J. M. W. Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites John Everett Millais, William Holman Hunt, Edward Burne-Jones and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. It touches on his widely influential books of criticism, his beautifully finished sketches of architectural structures, his teaching and his monographs on proposed social reforms. Not omitted are his 1877 attack on James McNeill Whistler, his failed marriage and attraction to young girls and his sad end after a long siege of mental illness. But there is much to celebrate in his life, and this show doesn't stint. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and the elderly; free for children under 13 with an adult (Glueck).
 
 * EDWARD STEICHEN, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676, through Feb. 4. A big, thorough exhibition, maybe a little too big and glossy, of one of the great photographers in American history, a restless, benign, flawed genius. Steichen also painted, made films, designed textiles, organized aerial reconnaissance photography in two world wars and put together the most popular photography exhibition ever, "The Family of Man." We'll see how people respond to someone whose eclectic work can look, if anything, almost too elegant and self-regarding. Steichen ultimately seemed to reduce everything and everyone to props to demonstrate his own refined and stage-savvy sensibility. But what refinement. His best work has a finesse that borders on the erotic. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12.50; $10.50 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 "THE YEAR ONE: ART OF THE ANCIENT WORLD EAST AND WEST," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500, through Jan. 14. The Met puts the millennial-marking art exhibition in a new perspective with a show that only an institution of its stature and girth could pull off. Drawn from seven departments, it revisits the beginning of the "modern era" around the time of the birth of Jesus with 150 sometimes tiny artworks that sample the nearly two dozen cultures flourishing at the beginning of the first millennium. The array stretches from imperial Rome to Han dynasty China, with many stops in between. High points include bronzes from Thailand and Indonesia, a Chinese mortuary pillar and a stunning recreation of the frescoed bedroom of a Roman villa. The display is supposed to reflect the beginning of a new world consciousness brought on by expanding empires and trade, a thesis more complex than the actual objects can sustain. But, no matter, most of them are considered masterpieces, all are beautifully installed and the opportunities for cross-cultural visual comparisons are rich. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
"IN THE EYE OF THE BEHOLDER," Kaikodo, 164 East 64th Street, (212) 223-0121 (through Oct. 21). Kaikodo's sales exhibitions are always a treat, and the sheer number of Chinese and Japanese paintings in this one is a major lure. These days New Yorkers rarely get to see material in this quantity and variety outside museums. Highlights include an album painting of a flower attributed to the 13th-century artist Qian Xuan (it's very fragile, so you have to ask to see it); a 17th-century calligraphic scroll by the fractious Fu Shan; and a witty four-panel portrait of a family of gibbons, gold-medal acrobats all. Devotees of ceramics and textiles will also find much to admire (Cotter).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
MARK DI SUVERO, Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through Oct. 21). This small retrospective presents pedestal-scale sculptures from three decades by an artist best known for his monumental industrial-strength abstractions. Each rough, heavy metal piece has a Cubist assemblage balanced Calder-like on one point of another assemblage. There is a clunky sameness to most of the works; Mr. di Suvero has always been most inventive when he works big (Johnson).
 
 * RINEKE DIJKSTRA, Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160 (through Oct. 28). This Dutch artist's solo debut in the United States includes a video (much seen elsewhere) of dancing teenagers in European clubs and a series of photographs she has been taking since 1997 of children in parks. In the video the kids preen touchingly. The photographs, color pictures along the lines of Thomas Struth's but more casual and less chilly, are heroic portraits, acutely sympathetic (Kimmelman).
 
 GERHARD RICHTER, Barbara Mathes, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-5135 (through Oct. 21). This exhibition of small works by the enigmatic and hugely influential German painter features a group of canvases from the 80's and 90's bearing his familiar brand of beautifully scraped, dragged and squeegeed Abstract Expressionism and an intriguing six-part photographic self-portrait in which blurry shirtless men -- the artist himself multiply exposed -- do mysterious things in dim, empty rooms (Johnson).
 
 BRIDGET RILEY, "Paintings 1982-2000 and Early Works on Paper," PaceWildenstein, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 421-3292 (through Oct. 21). This show picks up where the small survey of Bridget Riley's paintings at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea leaves off, following her continued involvement with color through nine recent canvases, while a group of gouache studies from the 1960's documents the transition from black-and-white to color, through subtlely vivid tones of gray (Smith).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
 MONICA KULICKA, John Gibson, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-1192 (through Oct. 30). As a protest against modern civilization's mechanization of the world, this young Polish artist who now lives in New York has slathered real, mossy green chlorophyll over five pieces of old wood furniture in a quixotic attempt to restore the dead wood to life. The absurdity of the gesture is amusing and yet somehow a little sad (Johnson).
 
 "LIFE, AFTER THE SQUIRREL," Location One, 26 Greene Street, (212) 334-3347 (through Oct. 28). This nutty fun house of a show begins with Filipe Miguel's rustic shed, supposedly inhabited by post-apocalyptic squirrels. The main exhibition space has a squishy plastic floor and a ceiling of inflated pine trees. Works include Tony Tasset's stuffed "Dead Bluejay"; Aernout Mik's video of old men horsing around; a hypnotic video by Pipilotti Rist; John Neff's deadpan video recital of Hal the computer's last speech; and Vincent Pruden's provocative makeup table for applying blackface (Johnson).
 
 MANUEL NERI, Charles Cowles, 74 Grand Street, (212) 925-3500 (through Oct. 21). This veteran Bay Area Figurative School artist continues to produce his signature female figure sculptures in bronze or marble, in which the combination of smooth, finished parts and rough, unfinished parts (accented in the bronzes by expressionistic painting) produces tension between raw physicality and classical illusionism (Johnson).
 
 "PARADISE NOW: PICTURING THE GENETIC REVOLUTION," Exit Art, 548 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 966-7748 (through Oct. 28). "We are at a threshold," declares the text panel at the start of this show. And we are, you know. Never mind that most of the art isn't great, because with more and more artists tapping into science, something big is bound to happen soon. Think of this as a preliminary report. The works span a decade and run the gamut from paintings and sculptures to the collecting of sperm and the breeding of very tiny exotic frogs. The artists fret predictably about tampering with Mother Nature and stress identity politics, also predictably, but the spirit of the show, an intangible, tips the scales in a positive direction (Kimmelman).
 
 GENEVIEVE SEILLE, Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through Oct. 21). This English-educated French artist is not a real outsider, but she does a good imitation. Her large, distressed, patched-together pages supporting dense, crazy-quilt accumulations of patterns, numbers and illegible writing suggest a collaboration between Jean Dubuffet and Adolf Wolfli (Johnson).
 
 * NEIL WINOKUR, Janet Borden, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 431-0166 (through Oct. 28). For this delightful portrait of his hometown, Mr. Winokur has produced a series of 32 still-life photographs, each a crystal-clear, deadpan picture of an ordinary but richly iconic object against a bright colored backdrop. A Greek-style paper coffee cup, a Chinese food container, a Giants pennant, an old Broadway playbill, a Con Edison orange cone, a hot dog, a rat, a toy-size Empire State Building: these images produce a resonantly evocative cross-section of New York experience (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
 SUZANNE ANKER, Universal Concepts Unlimited, 507 West 24th Street, (212) 727-7575 (through Oct. 21). One of those Leonardo types who like to combine art and science, Ms. Anker presents silkscreened paintings and sculptures addressing the representation of genetics. Silkscreen panels display silvery, gridded fields of chromosome symbols with little human images mixed in. The 500 silver-painted, three-dimensional letters A, C, T and G piled on a glass panel refer to DNA. It is all rather more decorative than conceptually illuminating (Johnson).
 
 LOUISE FISHMAN, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 242-7727 (through Oct. 21). Ms. Fishman's Abstract Expressionist painting is still tough and gritty in its bluntly gestural, grid-based physicality, but now it has a lusciousness of color that verges on the hedonistic. "A Stranger," with its web of impulsively made, wide slate-gray lines over a salmon pink field, is a voluptuous yet still excitingly raw picture (Johnson).
 
 DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111 (through Dec. 16). Welcome to the Damien Hirst Universe. It's a big shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and many large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
 ALBERT RENGER-PATZSCH, Tatintsian, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 633-0110 (through Oct. 28). If the German photographer Renger-Patzsch (1897-1966) were working today, he would probably make his formally perfect, subtly poetic pictures of industrialized landscapes, medieval church interiors and close-up plant studies into glossy, sofa-size Cibachromes. These small black-and-white vintage prints from the 1920's and 30's offer a welcome, intimately evocative respite from today's overly-showy photoaesthetics (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
TORBEN GIEHLER, Leo Koenig, 359 Broadway, at Franklin Street, TriBeCa, (212) 334-9255 (through Oct. 21). In bright acrylic colors, this young painter produces eye-grabbing gridded fields extending into deep space. The images suggest microscopic visions of computer circuitry or aerial views of futuristic cities. Mr. Giehler is indebted to Al Held for his hard-edged abstract illusionism and sci-fi fantasy, but he has his own promising vision (Johnson).
 
 "PASTORAL POP!," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through Dec. 15). Nature-inspired kitsch is the theme of this delirious seven-artist show. It includes Rob de Mar's comical landscape in the form of a spindly tree, Lisa Ruyter's psychedelic update of Seurat's "Grande Jatte," Alyson Shotz's grove of weird plant machines, Peter Gould's transformation of the guard station into a bucolic cartoon, Jason Middlebrook's Styrofoam stonewall planter, Katrin Asbury's miniature diorama in a planter and Rachel Feinstein's suspended Rococo-style pitcher exploding flowers like a pinata (Johnson).
 
 "RE-DRAWING THE LINE," Art in General, 79 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-0473 (through Oct. 28). This unfocused show of works in which line figures, literally or conceptually, includes an invigorating giant doodle by Diana Cooper; whited out ledger pages by Peter Wegner; the image of a scribble cut from brown felt by Arturo Herrera; a dripped line from a performance by Francis Alys; a string sculpture by Pae White; and tangled plastic zip ties by Mungo Thomson. The importance of line in obliquely conceptual works by Alessandro Balteo and Sophie Tottie is harder to see (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
 WILL BARNET, "Works on Paper," Tibor de Nagy, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 262-5050 (through tomorrow). Mr. Barnet is known today for his illustrative, poetically classicizing figurative paintings. This survey of drawings over seven decades shows that the artist, who was born in 1911, has tried his always adept if rarely original hand at most of the major 20th-century styles, from Social Realism to Cubism to flattened and simplified 50's-style abstraction. Some drawings of children, penciled with exacting, curvy lines in the 1940's, are particularly affecting (Ken Johnson).
 
 STEPHANIE BROOKS, Ten in One, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 604-9660 (through tomorrow). In her funny and inventively designed works, this young Chicagoan conflates ordinarily unrelated systems of verbal or visual signification (Johnson).
 
 NICOLE EISENMAN, Jack Tilton, 49 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 941-1775 (through tomorrow). Since making her mark as a wickedly provocative, often hilarious cartoonist, Ms. Eisenman has mutated into a would-be fine painter. Her first New York exhibition in four years features carefully made, Renaissance-inspired paintings that depict extremes of lesbian sisterhood, including a neo-classical mural in which Amazon cannibals dine on stew made from butchered men. She is still at her best with her more spontaneous and darkly idiosyncratic drawings (Johnson).
 
 APRIL GORNIK, Edward Thorp, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 691-6565 (through tomorrow). Ms. Gornik continues to combine 19th-century Transcendentalism and 20th-century Modernism in the production of expansive dreamlike landscapes. At best, optical intensity goes hand in hand with divine immanence, as in "Mirror Forest," in which greenish sunlight pours meltingly through a grove of young trees (Johnson).
 
 ALICE NEEL, "The Last Years," Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 366-4774 (through tomorrow). Late portrait paintings and a fine small drawing retrospective complement the Whitney's recent Neel retrospective. Some of the most arresting paintings are of children. The ghoulish-looking Jonathan in the arms of his father, Don Perlis, radiates demonic energy. The 15 drawings on paper, from the smoothly penciled "Sam" to the densely hatched "Phil" to the almost Minimalist "Andy Warhol," argue persuasively for a more extensive show of drawings (Johnson).
 
 "SELECTIONS FALL 2000," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through tomorrow). The center's latest show of emerging artists focuses on schematic drawing. It includes Mary Lum's cutout and layered painted line images of buildings; Lucas Monaco's crystalline transparent street maps; Oona Stern's cartoon wood floor; a mural by Geraldine Lau that resembles an air-traffic map; architectural and topographical fragments finely inked and layered by Julie Mehretu; Miranda Maher's semitransparent stacks of utilitarian illustrations; Glenn Grafelman's smudgy fenestration drawings; and photographs of Grady Gerbracht that trace passing scenes on a bus window (Johnson).
 
 BETTINA VON ZWEHL, Lombard-Freid Gallery, 531 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 967-8040 (through tomorrow). Ms. von Zwehl, a young German artist living in London, is one of several young photographers who fit a strict Conceptual framework around traditional portraiture. For her first solo show she invited young children into her studio, dressed them in identical (black) clothes and let them take their own pictures. She then juxtaposed the images in pairs, matching or contrasting poses, expressions and appearances. The disarming results rely too completely on the emotional transparency of children while also resembling Gap ads (Smith).

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 514 words

HEADLINE: Credibility Is Job No. 1 at MG

BYLINE: By RICHARD FEAST 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England

 BODY:
IT takes perhaps 10 minutes to walk from the National Exhibition Center here to the headquarters of what is now known as the MG Rover Group. And yet, when a biennial motor show opens to the public at the center next Thursday, there will be no display of MG Rover's cars.
This startling absence by the region's biggest automaker -- akin to General Motors not participating in the Detroit auto show -- is a sign of the huge challenges that confront MG Rover, the former Rover Group. After suffering huge losses, BMW sold the Rover operations to British investors this year for a nominal $14. 
 MG Rover has limited cash that it must spend wisely -- not even on a display at the local auto show. It must also re-establish its credibility among car buyers. A central part of its new strategy, reflected in the name change, is to put greater emphasis on the long-moribund MG brand. But American car enthusiasts with recollections of all those MG B, A, TC, TF and TD roadsters of yesteryear should not reach for their checkbooks yet. None of the current MG Rover models have had the expensive crash and emissions tests that might allow them to be sold in the United States.
Despite the tumultuous history of MG Rover -- known over the decades as British Leyland, BL and BMC, among others -- there is still value in the MG name, said Steve Saxty of FutureBrand, a brand-consulting firm in London. "The real issue, though, is how much it appeals to today's customers," he said. "A lot of the value is tied up in America, but it has no delivery mechanism in the U.S." He said the company was selling MG F's to customers in Europe "in their 50's, not the twenty- and thirtysomethings it expected to."
The emphasis is different, and much friendlier to the American market, at the other marques that were once MG's stablemates. BMW, which sold Land Rover to Ford for a more impressive $2.7 billion, retained the Mini brand and will bring out an all-new model in Europe next fall, with American sales to follow.
MG Rover will do most of its business in Europe, and in Britain in particular. Over the coming months, it will introduce sporty versions of Rover's 25, 45 and 75 sedans that will wear MG badges. The company will also endow the MG F, a midengine roadster, with much higher performance. That was a move that BMW seemed reluctant to take, perhaps to keep the car from stealing thunder from its own Z3 roadster.
MG Rover's greatest challenge concerns economies of scale. It is committed to selling four lines of cars, which it makes in a single old factory in Birmingham, for a total of 200,000 cars a year. Global consolidation means big automakers now consider a million units as a starting point for mainstream models.
MG Rover says it will sign a technology transfer agreement with an unspecified high-volume carmaker that will allow it to make its own cars using chassis, suspension and steering components designed by another company. Real independence would then disappear, but a partner with a global perspective could provide the long-term security that MG lacks.

SECTION: Section W; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1135 words

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS;
An Oasis for Programmers in Bali

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: PACUNG, Indonesia

 BODY:
Every start-up company has its tales of sacrifice. But few can equal the sacrifices accompanying the birth of Indonesia's latest bid to join the new economy.
A pig, a goat and a duck were among the animals laid out beneath a bamboo altar as ritual offerings at the official opening on Oct. 7 of BaliCamp, a software development enterprise in the center of Indonesia's legendary island, Bali. While musicians hammered out a hypnotic cadence on chimes, gongs and cymbals, a local priest recited prayers to bless the undertaking. 
 It was not your typical business start, certainly. But this is Indonesia's deeply religious Hindu holiday playground, and the gods sit on the board of any venture.
"We're trying to integrate very tightly with the local community," said Otto Sugiri, chairman of BaliCamp's owner, Sigma Citra Harmoni, who was dressed for the occasion in a sarong and headdress.
Mystical, laid-back Bali may seem like an unlikely location for anything high-technology. But Mr. Sugiri thinks Bali's magic can gather Indonesia's creative talent and help the country grab a slice of what Balicamp executives say is a $32.6 billion market for farming out programming to other companies.
BaliCamp, he hopes, will serve as a programming colony, where computing talent from Indonesia and abroad can write software for companies worldwide.
The enterprise is part of a well-worn path in developing countries, one made increasingly cost-effective by the Internet. With bits and bytes now cheaper to transport than bodies, companies in the West are farming out more of the spadework of building networks and sending them to programmers in Asia.
India, Malaysia and the Philippines are known for offering well-educated, English-speaking computing talent at a fraction of what it costs to pay programmers at home.
"They're cheap, and they have the skills," said Dane Anderson, vice president for Internet research at the International Data Corporation, a market research firm. Indonesia's programmers may be less numerous and their English skills may be poorer, but BaliCamp is counting on the advantage of location. Set on a lush hillside garlanded with rice paddies, the compound is within a two-hour drive of Bali's most popular surfing beaches, golf courses and tourist districts.
From the outside, BaliCamp resembles some of the island's many luxury resorts. A string of bungalows surround an airy central office complex of hardwood and whitewash, complete with swimming pool and koi ponds. Inside, however, are banks of personal computers networked to a satellite link that gives BaliCamp superfast connections to the Internet via Hawaii.
Each bungalow is an office for a team of programmers working on their project. One team, for instance, is developing an online trading system for a Singapore securities firm, while another is writing software for a credit union in Utah.
BaliCamp has already won the support of Sigma's big-name suppliers: Microsoft, Oracle, Cisco and International Business Machines. The Microsoft Corporation, which lent software to the venture, has also hired BaliCamp to develop an Indonesian-language spell-checker for use in its operating system, said Richard Kartawijaya, general manager of Microsoft Indonesia.
Mr. Sugiri, 47, was born south of Jakarta in Bandung. He studied programming in Germany. He returned to Indonesia in 1983 to work for an oil company and then worked for a bank.
In 1989, he left the buttoned-down banking world behind and joined the founders of a hardware distribution start-up company called Sigma. Today, Sigma is a $21-million-a-year holding company with seven subsidiaries involved in areas that include World Wide Web sites, corporate networks and software design.
Mr. Sugiri came up with the idea for BaliCamp in 1998, during the Asian financial crisis. Many programmers were taking jobs abroad to avoid the rioting and religious strife, he said. But Bali has remained an oasis of calm, offering refuge to both Jakarta-based expatriates and persecuted ethnic Chinese.
Years of tourist inroads have made Bali one of Indonesia's wealthiest and most-developed islands. It has an international airport with direct links to much of Asia and Australia. Bali is also home to a thriving arts scene that Mr. Sugiri says complements the kind of creative Web programming in demand today.
All these things, together with BaliCamp's communal atmosphere, Sigma executives say, will lure not only Indonesian programmers but also foreign software developers eager for the chance to visit. BaliCamp also plans to hire several foreigners to work as project managers and marketing executives, said Marina Budiman, the company's president director.
Foreigners seem to take to Bali's lifestyle. Jason Swanson, 30, a Canadian working in Singapore for DataOn, a software start-up company, spent two weeks at BaliCamp while it was under construction. "It was great," he recalled. "Here's a commute where you're driving through these terraced rice fields." After a week of 10-hour days, he said, he was able to unwind by playing volleyball on the beach.
BaliCamp executives say the new company is already on track to pull in up to $10 million in sales in 2001.
"I think $10 million is quite low for them, to be frank," said Mr. Kartawijaya of Microsoft.
BaliCamp, however, may have some difficulty expanding without sacrificing quality. It already has more than 80 full-time programmers and plans to more than double that number this year. With an average annual programmer salary of $8,000, roughly eight times the national average, there is no shortage of applicants. But of the 150 programmers who have taken the company's entrance exam in the last three months, only 10 have passed, said BaliCamp's general manager, Gunawan Tenggarahardja.
Most of Indonesia's programming talent comes from technical universities on neighboring Java. Mr. Sugiri foresees having to build BaliCamp branches near Java's college towns to be closer to his source.
Life at BaliCamp already resembles a campus more than the colony Mr. Sugiri envisions. Many programmers, like Yusuf Riza, 24, who is from eastern Java, walk to work each day from nearby villages. Others take a bus from Bali's main city, Denpasar. But many nights are spent sleeping in the bungalows in front of their terminals. "My home sweet home," Mr. Riza said, laughing. And there are no 24-hour pizza or coffee joints in Pacung, only a staff cafeteria and restaurant, in BaliCamp.
Mr. Sugiri and other Sigma executives say the isolation is intentional. They settled on Pacung not only for its beauty, but also for its distance from the heat and the distractions of the coast.
"You can't work at the beach," said a Sigma executive, Djarot Suiantoro. "You'll be tempted to go surfing."

HEADLINE: Import Prices Other Than Oil Fell Sharply in September

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Prices of imports other than oil showed the largest decline in one and a half years last month, government figures showed today, suggesting the nation's appetite for foreign-made goods is helping contain inflation.
The import price index minus oil fell 0.3 percent in September as costs fell for food, business equipment, autos and consumer goods, Labor Department figures showed. The index minus petroleum rose 0.2 percent in August. Including petroleum, overall import prices rose 1.5 percent last month -- the fifth consecutive monthly increase -- after rising 0.2 percent in August. 
 Offsetting the rise in oil prices has been the strength of the dollar, which makes other imports cheaper. That is good news for Federal Reserve policy makers, who are intent on keeping the economy's record expansion intact by preventing a pickup in inflation.
"Excluding petroleum, it doesn't look like we're seeing any acceleration" in price increases, said Scott Brown, senior economist at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. "There's very little feed-through to prices of consumer goods" from rising energy costs.
The September drop in import prices excluding petroleum was the first since May and the largest since a 0.5 percent drop in March 1999. Nonoil import prices have increased just 1.1 percent over the last 12 months, well below the 3.5 percent annualized inflation rate measured by the Consumer Price Index for the first eight months of the year. Import prices excluding oil declined 0.4 percent for the 12 months ended in September 1999.
A separate report today showed that the number of Americans filing the first time for state unemployment benefits rose 5,000 last week, to 306,000. The less-volatile four-week average for new claims fell to 301,500 -- the lowest since mid-August -- from 306,500 a week earlier, suggesting that the demand for workers is showing not signs of weakening. Job creation and near-record consumer confidence are underpinning spending.

HEADLINE: Washington Bets That a Bear Market Will Never Come

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
IT was supposed to be the day that Wall Street stabilized. Overnight the professionals who trade stock index futures bid up the prices. They were confident that the stock market would rally yesterday morning.
But it did not. Instead, the Dow Jones industrial average, which had been relatively calm as Nasdaq slumped, had its worst day since the spring meltdown. It ended just above 10,000 after losing 379 points, or 3.6 percent. Less than a quarter of that came from the latest disaster story, at Home Depot. There was selling almost everywhere, although some money went into companies like Procter & Gamble, whose business is less sensitive to the economy. 
 Home Depot's woes may be instructive. The big disappointments heretofore have been in technology stocks, whose high valuations left them vulnerable to slower growth. Home Depot is not a technology company, however, and its weaker growth reflects widespread problems: competition has intensified as the economy's growth has slowed while higher energy costs cut profit margins.
Those higher energy costs are not limited to retailers, of course. As winter heating bills soar this year, Americans will face choices. Do they pay for heat by cutting back on Christmas gifts or by cutting back on investments? Neither option looks very attractive for stock prices.
Perhaps the slide will end soon. Maybe the mutual funds have almost finished their year-end tax selling, before they close their books at the end of October. Maybe stocks will rebound today, on Friday the 13th. (This great bull market began on Friday, Aug. 13, 1982, so that day does not have to be unlucky.) Maybe, as so often before, investors will see the decline as a buying opportunity. The belief that stocks always rise, at least in the long run, is still widely held. And anyway, the Dow has gone down for six consecutive sessions, and it has been more than a decade since it had a string of seven straight losses.
But just as investors are unprepared for the notion that stocks can go down and stay down, so are the folks in Washington. The great budget debate being conducted by Al Gore and George W. Bush assumes there will be trillions in surpluses over the next decade that they can divvy up in tax cuts and spending. There is no discussion of just how closely those surpluses have been tied to the bull market.
Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, points out in a report entitled "The Bubble Budgets" that what took budget forecasters by surprise was the surge in individual income tax payments, reflecting capital gains and taxes on profits from stock options.
The official budget forecasts assume that those high tax payments will keep on coming. Which is to say, they assume that bear markets have been repealed. If that assumption proves wrong, the budget surpluses will shrink drastically, even if the economy keeps growing.
As Congress rushes to end this session, there is one sidelight that investors should watch. Some big accounting firms are seeking to push through legislation that would bar the Securities and Exchange Commission from taking steps to assure that auditors are really independent from the companies whose books they certify. It could pass.
Congressional muzzling of the S.E.C. would send a clear message to investors: You're on your own.
That may not be the ideal message for a nervous market. But Washington takes rising share prices for granted.
Wall Street agrees. Stock index futures rose as last night's trading began, just as they did Wednesday night.

HEADLINE: Chinese Official Reassures U.S. Envoy on Firm Plans to Open Trade

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Prime Minister Zhu Rongji has given "absolutely emphatic" assurances that China will not back away from the market-opening commitments that it made to gain entry into the World Trade Organization, the American trade negotiator said here today.
After more than five hours of discussions with Mr. Zhu and senior trade officials, the American negotiator, Charlene Barshefsky, sought to dispel reports that the application to join the trade body might be unraveling or that China was having second thoughts about the sweeping concessions that it had made in talks with the United States and Europe. 
 "The issue of China's accession is no longer whether" it joins the trade group, Ms. Barshefsky told reporters. "It's when."
She said American and European officials still believed that it might be possible for China to achieve membership by the end of the year, but only if it hastens to complete the complex final negotiations under way in Geneva to set the detailed conditions of membership.
Ms. Barshefsky flew here in a hastily arranged trip, hoping to give a jolt to stalled final negotiations at the W.T.O. headquarters in Geneva over the precise terms of China's membership. Those talks have to mesh together the previous agreements that China has signed with scores of countries on thousands of trade and investment issues and translate principles into precise rules and schedules.
China has agreed, in talks with the United States, the European Community and others, to cut tariffs significantly on agricultural and industrial products and to open major industries like banking and telecommunications to foreign investment.
Some Western officials contended that China was backsliding on some issues in Geneva, including the timetables to reduce tariffs. Some experts have speculated that China's desire to enter the group has flagged because of fears that a rapid opening of markets would cause a surge in unemployment and social turmoil.
Although there is great apprehension in China about the social effects of lower tariffs and investment barriers, top leaders have repeatedly stated their firm desire to join the trade group. Mr. Zhu and many economists here say they believe that China has to endure the painful shock of global competition to speed its transformation to an efficient market economy.
In the meeting this morning just before he left for a visit to Japan, Mr. Zhu provided the Americans with just the assurances that they sought, Ms. Barshefsky reported.
"I stressed the absolute importance of full compliance," she said. "Mr. Zhu was emphatic, absolutely emphatic, that China will not back away from the bilateral commitments it made to the United States and other trading partners."
Ms. Barshefsky said the main problems in Geneva arose from the incredible complexity and variety of issues on the table, as well as China's need to deal with an oversight group of 40 countries. Conflict and confusion in the final stages of joining the W.T.O., she said, are normal, adding, "We see this all the time, and I'm not overly concerned."
But, hinting at more substantive disagreements, she also said: "Every country that accedes would like to get in doing less rather than more, and the less specific the better. China is no exception."
She said the talks had become mired over a host of "dry, not sexy issues" like agricultural quotas and product standards, which differ for imported and domestic goods.

HEADLINE: Colombian Rebels Said to Seize 10 Foreign Oil Workers

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Members of the largest guerrilla group in Colombia kidnapped five American and five other foreign oil workers today in the Amazon region of Ecuador and hijacked a helicopter to take them across the Colombian border into territory they control, the Ecuadorean government said.
The group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, has increasingly operated across Colombia's borders in recent months. The kidnapping today was the most brazen effort in what appears to be a campaign to instill fear in Colombia's neighbors that a planned offensive in southern Colombia in the coming months, backed by the United States, will spread the conflict. 
 The kidnapping occurred hours before President Andres Pastrana of Colombia arrived in Argentina as part of a South American tour intended to increase regional support for his efforts to use greater military power to force two guerrilla groups to make concessions in peace talks. The seizure also seemed to bolster rebel assertions that United States military officials who arrive to train Colombian troops could be expected to be targets.
"The FARC has claimed responsibility for the hostage taking in retaliation for Plan Colombia," Vice President Pedro Pinto of Ecuador told reporters, referring to a $7.5 billion Colombian anti-drug plan that includes 60 United States military helicopters and American training for a new Colombian army brigade to help eradicate coca fields in two southern Colombian provinces that the FARC occupies. The plan is also financed by European governments and international agencies.
"The FARC dress like civilians and cross the border and do things like this," Mr. Pinto said.
He told a radio station that the guerrillas captured the 11 hostages -- including two French workers, an Argentine, a Chilean, a New Zealander and one Ecuadorean -- at 4 a.m. local time at an oil workers' camp near Pompeya and whisked them away in a Super Puma helicopter owned by an Ecuadorean service company. The hostages work for two service companies contracted by Repsol-YPF, a Spanish-Argentine oil company, to perform geological surveys.
A State Department official said the Ecuadorean had been kidnapped but quickly released. "We don't know much," the official said. "They were put in a helicopter -- one of the captives is a pilot -- and flown away. And we don't know where. But it is likely they took them to Colombia. We have to find out where they took them before we can do anything."
The official declined to identify the hostages.
A senior Clinton administration official said: "There have been incidents like this in northern Ecuador before where people have been kidnapped. It does bring up the issue of security for workers down there. It is a real concern."
The kidnapping occurred 47 miles south of the border, suggesting that the rebels have the capacity to operate deep inside Ecuador.
Spokesmen at Repsol-YPF in Buenos Aires said they were trying to confirm the reports.
United States military officials recently warned that the FARC has made contact with and has influenced an Indian movement in Ecuador that helped overthrow a democratically elected president in Quito this year.
The attack on foreign oil operations was carried out at a time the oil-based Ecuadorean economy is stumbling despite high oil prices. Recently the government asked Washington for increased aid to help feed and shelter an increasing number of Colombian refugees who are crossing the border to escape the fighting.
Ecuador borders areas of Colombia with some of the highest concentrations of coca fields anywhere in South America, including the Putumayo Province, where American and Colombian military officials plan to focus an extensive eradication effort. The officials hope that eradicating the coca in Putumayo and adjacent Caqueta Province will deny the FARC valuable resources to finance their war.
The FARC, the strongest, oldest and richest guerrilla group in Latin America, also makes a habit of kidnapping foreigners as well as Colombians to extract exorbitant payoffs. It has stepped up its activities, attacking one police station after another in the countryside since the United States Congress passed a $1.3 billion aid package four months ago.
The FARC does not hold other American hostages, although three American missionaries seized three years ago are missing and widely believed to be dead.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
As Prices Climb, Terminology Is Also Stretched

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
In what might be called terminology inflation, penthouses are descending and town houses are levitating as architects, developers and marketers of new luxury buildings stretch definitions in seeking to sell their seven-figure wares.
In a similar stretch, a building on Broadway that combines a residential component atop a commercial base is being billed as 70 stories high when there are actually only 49 floors, while the controversial Trump World Tower near the United Nations is advertised as 90 stories when it really bears only 72 floors. 
 And, as variable as the vocabulary, reaction to the practice ranges from outright criticism to mild bemusement.
"The issue is appropriation of quasi-architectural terms," said Reinhold Martin, a professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation. "Each reinvention reveals something. If somebody wants to buy an apartment and it's on the sixth floor of a 12-story building and it's advertised as a penthouse, what's being sold is the fantasy of the penthouse. If the person buys into it, that's their fantasy. I'm all for it."
But Andrew Alpern, an architectural historian, was not so sanguine. "Talk about twisting language and reality," Mr. Alpern said. "I write for a living, and I'm very aware of the need for precision in language. Words have customary meanings understood by ordinary people. Any unexpected use is deceptive unless completely explained."
The focus of the professionals' comments is the Beekman Regent, a 20-story condominium under construction at First Avenue and 51st Street. The first four floors incorporate the hollowed-out 1893 Romanesque Revival facades of what was once Public School 35.
The terraced apartments on the fifth floor, just above the old school's facade, are being marketed as town houses -- a term commonly applied to row houses at street level. The top nine floors, each with wedding-cake style setbacks, are being called penthouses.
Across town, at Broadway and 56th Street, a 630-foot-high building is rising -- its 26-story base to be headquarters for Random House, the publishing company, topped by a 23-story residential component called the Park Imperial.
But the building is being marketed as 70 stories -- with the first residential floor labeled the 48th -- based on what the developer, the Related Companies, calculates as the number of floors it would have if it were entirely residential. (Generally, new office spaces have floor-to-floor heights of about 12 feet, while residential space is about 9 feet.)
"They claim 'equivalent stories' is what counts," Mr. Alpern said. "By that logic, the high-ceiling buildings along Fifth and Park would be several floors taller than they actually are. Paraphrasing Gertrude Stein: a floor is a floor is a floor."
The original meaning of penthouse was a structure on the roof, set back from the parapet. "Thus, in the old days, when proper people wouldn't dream of living on a roof, penthouses were elevator superstructures, maid's rooms," Mr. Alpern said. Later, with Hollywood glamorizing the concept, the definition expanded to an apartment on the roof, "but still always a one-story structure."
In 1929, new building regulations allowed higher structures if they were behind the building line. "Those setbacks created terraced apartments, not penthouses," Mr. Alpern insisted. "So eight stories of so-called penthouses atop the former P.S. 35 are not penthouses but terraced apartments."
The Beekman Regent is being marketed by the Marketing Directors, whose president, Adrienne Albert, said, "They are unique homes with outdoor space enjoying the topmost levels of the building, as opposed to most high-rise buildings, which have a middle section with homes stacked one after another."
As to a town house being restricted to the ground floor, Ms. Albert said: "That's a narrow interpretation. An important component of a town house is outdoor space. Our homes are configured similar to Upper East Side conventional town houses. They have outdoor space larger than most backyards. So, instead of accessing them from an exterior street, you are accessing them from an interior street -- the corridor."
Mr. Alpern, the strict constructionist, conceded some wiggle room, "Whereas, the Beekman Regent is an apartment house effectively sitting on top of another building, it's not entirely unreasonable that that top serves like a street."
Other marketers took varying positions on variable definitions.
Saying she preferred precision, Joyce West, vice president of the Charles H. Greenthal Group, pointed out: "In the end, everyone sees the property they are going to buy. So, whether it's labeled town house or penthouse, loftlike or loft size, they're either going to like the space or not."
Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Associates, particularly citing building-elevation reinterpretation, said: "The notion 'big' is incredibly dear to the developer's heart. It's absolutely done for marketing. But not only to the community, it's also marketing to the industry -- impressing them with the size of your ambition and ability to deliver the goods."
By far the biggest stretch, Mr. Alpern said, is the word luxury, "which developers use for anything beyond a public housing project and a 19th-century tenement that has not yet been gentrified."
Professor Martin at Columbia concurred: "It's not only about square footage, nuts and bolts. This terminology game is, on one hand, a sort of ruse, on the other, an expression of something like the psychopathology of real estate."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Yugoslavia Will Move to Renew Diplomatic Ties

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The United States and Yugoslavia signaled today that they would move quickly toward the re-establishment of diplomatic relations, which were severed as NATO began its 11-week bombing campaign here last year.
A first meeting between James O'Brien, the special adviser to President Clinton for the Balkans, and Vojislav Kostunica, the newly elected Yugoslav president, produced no precise timetable for restoring diplomatic ties but demonstrated that a willingness to resolve the matter existed on both sides. 
 Mr. Kostunica, who has criticized American "meddling" in Serbia before and since taking office, said there had been "a gap in communication" between Belgrade and Washington -- a tactful way of describing often bitter hostility. But he added, "We hope we will bridge that gap and our relations normalize."
The meeting came as Mr. Clinton lifted the oil embargo and the ban on American flights to Yugoslavia that had been imposed in 1998 after President Slobodan Milosevic cracked down on Kosovo Albanians. Mr. Clinton said more significant sanctions, like the denial of much-needed lending from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, would be reviewed as the democratic transition that began last week with a popular uprising against Mr. Milosevic proceeds.
In a statement in Washington, Mr. Clinton said: "We have a strong interest in supporting Yugoslavia's newly elected leaders as they work to build a truly democratic society. The removal of these sanctions is a first step to ending Serbia's isolation." Yugoslavia is made up of the republics of Serbia and Montenegro.
The United States is particularly eager to consolidate the fragile democratic change in Serbia because it is crucial to bolstering the chances of an enduring peace in the Balkans, where four wars in the last eight years have involved a sizable commitment of American resources to an unstable corner of Europe.
Mr. Kostunica said today that he respected the 1995 Dayton agreement that brought peace to Bosnia, in effect committing himself to respecting Yugoslavia's border with Bosnia and the arrangement that grants Bosnian Serbs considerable self-rule in 49 percent of a Bosnia with a weak central government.
He also committed himself to United Nations resolutions that provide for wide Albanian self-government in Kosovo.
Speaking after a 90-minute meeting, Mr. O'Brien said Mr. Kostunica had agreed to "work through some technical issues, with an aim to establishing diplomatic relations." Those issues include a need for him to consult with the Yugoslav Parliament over a decision that is delicate in the light of widespread anti-American feeling here.
Any over-eager embrace of the United States would tend to undermine Mr. Kostunica's political standing at this stage because a majority of Serbs might see it as a form of moral surrender. Although the new president has enormous good will on his side after the uprising that forced Mr. Milosevic to finally concede defeat in last month's election, his hold on the levers of power is as yet partial.
In the light of the delicate political situation and the enduring hostility over the NATO bombing, Mr. O'Brien said Mr. Kostunica did not want to appear to be "picking favorites" and favored a restoration of diplomatic ties with Washington that would be simultaneous with "normalizing" relations with Western European nations. This seems likely to occur within the next several weeks, officials said.
The remaining sanctions provide Washington with some leverage in discussions over whether Mr. Milosevic, who has been indicated by the International Tribunal in The Hague, should stand trial for war crimes. But it was clear that the United States, whose first priority is the consolidation of long-elusive democracy in Yugoslavia, would not push Mr. Kostunica to try the ousted leader or deliver him to The Hague in the near term.
The Serbian uprising ended not with the violent removal of Mr. Milosevic but with a handshake between him and Mr. Kostunica that sealed an accord on the passage of power. What guarantees, if any, were given to Mr. Milosevic, who remains under guard in Serbia, are unclear.
The former leader's domestic position appeared to weaken today as his Serbian Socialist Party said their hard-line secretary general, Gorica Gajevic, a woman intensely loyal to Mr. Milosevic, had been replaced by Zoran Andjelkovic, an official from Kosovo.
The party called a special congress for Nov. 25, and one of its deputies in the Serbian Parliament, Miloje Mihajlovic, said Mr. Milosevic should quit on that occasion because he had lost the support of the members.
It also appeared that a political rift had opened up between the Socialists and the Yugoslav Left Party of Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic. The parties, allied in the election they lost to Mr. Kostunica, said they would run separately in Serbian parliamentary elections scheduled for later this year.
Mr. Kostunica appears quietly certain that his tempered political stance is steadily eroding Mr. Milosevic's support.
While insisting that Yugoslavia must become more democratic and open to the West, the new president has been sharply critical of the NATO bombing campaign and of the war crimes tribunal, which he has described as a pawn of American political interests.
Today, Mr. Kostunica renewed his criticism of the United States, but in far more muted terms, saying it had shown scant "understanding" of the political process in Serbia.
