SECTION: Section 6; Page 92; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 779 words

HEADLINE: The Great Hand-Me-Down Heap

BYLINE: By Helen Thorpe; Helen Thorpe is a freelance writer who lives in Austin, Tex.

 BODY:
Johnson's Ropa Usada, a concrete-and-cinder-block warehouse in the Texas border town McAllen, is the final resting place for some of the detritus of American consumer culture. The massive building is cooled by a giant, cacophonous fan. White light pours down from skylights. And strewn across the floor in huge, heaping mounds, like a brilliantly striated mountain range, are piles upon piles of used clothes. On Saturdays, the clothes go on sale for 30 cents a pound.
As America's primary economy has boomed, so has its secondhand economy; in 1997, Americans spent about $12 billion on used goods, 30 percent more than they did in 1992. And it's estimated that Americans give away as much as 2.5 billion pounds of clothes each year, much of which eventually arrives in a place like this. Increasingly, used goods from the United States are also sold in vast quantities to the third world. "We now export between $500 million and $1 billion worth of used clothing per year," says Daniel Rothenberg, an anthropologist at the University of Michigan. Johnson's represents the frontier in this expanding secondhand economy -- the last point at which used clothes are sold to Americans, and the first point at which they are sold to foreigners. 
 Inside Johnson's, customers scale and pick their way across the fabric heights. Francisco Villarreal chugs around on a forklift, moving bales throughout the warehouse. When I ask him where the clothes come from, he says: "New Jersey. Todas para New Jersey." A company there buys leftover clothing from Goodwill and the Salvation Army, then sells the used goods to Johnson's.
Small kids play tag on a mountain of clothes, and a bigger boy does back flips onto them. He stops when he finds a pair of black snow pants that he seems to love. From the bottom of a crater, Minerva Villegas picks up an item, glances at it and tosses it over her shoulder. "If you have problems," she says as she digs in deeper, "well, this helps. It opens your mind, like church." Her husband is a roofer in McAllen who works for minimum wage. "All my clothes are from here," she says. "My bras, my panties -- everything."
A few piles away, a dapper old man works furiously. Salvador Acuna Aparicios bends to pick up an item, tosses it away, picks up another, tosses it away, picks up a T-shirt and slings it over his shoulder. He lives in Nuevo Laredo, on the Mexican side of the border. "I've had my local crossing card since 1957," he tells me. "I'm 72 years old, but I exercise a lot. I box. I take good care of myself. And I don't like to be idle. I am a widower, and I don't like to spend my time sitting down, because I get nostalgic." As he speaks, Aparicios keeps sorting the clothing at a furious pace, salvaging T-shirts. "I take them to a lady in Nuevo Laredo, for resale," he explains. "I don't charge her anything for them."
Nearby, Rebecca Vasquez is looking for school clothes for her children. "If you can't afford new things, this is where you go," she says. She works for $150 a week putting stickers that say Off and On onto television remote controls. "All my clothes are from here," she says. "I don't buy new clothes. For my kids, I do, once in a while, but everything else comes from here." Vasquez pulls out a pink skirt with a gray felt cat on it. "My daughters will wear this," she announces. "Fix it up, little shoes -- the 50's!" Her 9-year-old son, the same kid who was doing back flips, parades by in an army jumpsuit. "Come here," she orders. "Turn around. No holes? O.K., good." Then she spots what he's hiding -- the snow pants. "No!" she tells him. "I told you! It never gets cold here!"
In another part of the warehouse, shy Mexican women pick through clothing as a transistor radio plays. They work for a man who sells American castoffs in Mexico. What they find will be shipped south by truck to Guanajuato to be sold at an outdoor market. Most of the people who shop here don't give much thought to those who are forever buying ropa nueva. If they think of them at all, it is with a kind of puzzled curiosity. "I don't know why they get rid of these things," says Aparicios. "Maybe it is related to the fact that there was a sickness in the family."
Minerva Villegas adds: "If they want to waste their money that way, it's their business. It's none of my business, what people do with their money." From her pillowcase, now lumpy with clothes, Villegas pulls out a plaid work shirt for her husband. "If he doesn't like it, I'll give it to my brother," she says. "And if nobody in my family wants it, then I'll put it in the back of Kmart, for those guys who sleep in the middle of the highway."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 39; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1390 words

HEADLINE: Bookend;
The Gentle Realist

BYLINE: By Daniel Menaker; Daniel Menaker is senior literary editor at Random House and the author of "The Treatment," a novel.

 BODY:
In his novel "So Long, See You Tomorrow," based on a true story about passion and murder on a farm in the Midwest, William Maxwell invented -- for the purpose of witnessing some crucial events -- a thinking dog. As in: "The dog took note of the fact that he didn't do any of these things." And: "The dog couldn't imagine what had gotten into them." This thinking dog caused a stir in the fiction department at The New Yorker when the novel was about to be serialized there in 1979. Maxwell's editor, Roger Angell, and others of us in the department thought that the dog was a mistake. On several occasions Roger urged Maxwell to put the thinking dog to sleep. Maxwell is reported to have responded, in Bartlebyesque fashion, "I'd like to keep it." Roger Angell is not and never has been an easy editor to face down, but this was no contest. If you look back at The New Yorker issues of Oct. 1 and Oct. 8, 1979, you will find the thinking dog there thinking away, to say nothing of taking note and imagining. He probably suspects that some time ago someone wanted to rub him out, and he may even pause to wonder why you're there checking on him.
Maxwell, who died last month at the age of 91, was widely regarded as a sweet and gentle man. And he was -- sometimes, in his writing and editorial sensibility and in his personal and social lives, almost to the point of preciousness. If you told him that you had just taken your son to camp or that your wife had burned a roast the night before, his eyes might fill with tears. A few wiseacres at The New Yorker sometimes referred to him as "Waterworks." The atmosphere at the dinner table in his apartment on East 86th Street could be so literary and artistic that it seemed to depart the hardscrabble world entirely. (Maxwell's wife, Emily, who died the week before he did, was a painter.) A lot about Tolstoy and two Elizabeths -- Bowen and Bishop. The voices so quiet and modest that they could hardly be heard. And his taste in literature could be very special. For example, he loved the elf stories of Sylvia Townsend Warner and insisted that one after another be published in The New Yorker. They were antic and -- to the mind of many of us -- limited creations, and they ceased their New Yorker materializations the minute Maxwell retired from the magazine's staff in 1976. But he stuck by them until the end. In a letter in November 1999, responding to my teasing him about those pieces, he wrote, "Your inability to get any pleasure in Sylvia's Elfin stories has driven me back to the book. I read the first story last night and was beside myself with pleasure." 
 So within Maxwell's delicacy there lurked a terse kind of assurance. In his writing, some of his sweet sentences and many of his neutral ones pull up short -- end abruptly, even curtly, as if he were requiring his language and his own voice to return to plain speech and unsweetened reality. From "Over by the River": "A child got into an orange minibus and started on the long devious ride to nursery school and social adjustment." "He smiled pleasantly at George and watched Puppy out of the corner of his eyes, so as to be ready when she leapt at his throat."
More often than one might at first realize, the gentility of his style falls away altogether, and when it does, it reveals the frank and sometimes grim man who was always standing behind it and was perhaps using civility of expression in part to make more emphatic the awful shocks that -- since his own mother's death when he was a child -- he knew lie in wait for almost all of us. From "So Long, See You Tomorrow": "Boys are, from time to time, found hanging from a rafter or killed by a shotgun believed to have gone off accidentally. The wonder is it happens so seldom." From "Over by the River": "If people knew how little he cared whether they lived or died, they wouldn't want to have anything to do with him."
In his conversation and his actions, Maxwell embodied this tension between civilization and its discontents, between the longing for a rational and cultured life and the bad luck and regrets and emotional anarchy that sabotage it. During those high-toned dinner discussions, when something difficult or bitter came up, as it sometimes did, you could feel both Maxwell and his wife not only accepting its arrival but almost welcoming it. In a letter to me he wrote: "Bad behavior one never really regrets in any serious way."
In 1975, when I was training to be a fiction editor -- working in Maxwell's office every day -- I handed him some poems of mine, hoping that he would see the genius that resided in them but that others had always been blind to. Maxwell handed the poems back to me the next day and said, "Stick to prose." As an editor, Maxwell was similarly concise and efficient. In the later part of his career he was in the office only three days a week but got six days' worth of work done. (And he took an hour's nap every day.) He read, edited and responded to stories with remarkable promptness and unfailing courtesy and professionalism. Despite his sometimes rarefied literary inclinations, he was always open to strange and tough writing. And his editorial hand was the subtlest, least cavalier I've ever seen. "Don't touch a hair on its head," he would say when I began to scout around for ways to show off at the expense of perfectly good writing. Unlike many editors today, he felt that his first responsibility was to the text, not to himself or to the company that paid him. In that way, in the way of the artist, he was subversive. And although he enjoyed praise and gratitude, they never seemed to go to his head; he never usurped the primary role of the author or congratulated himself or became puffed up about his sharp eye for talent or his eminent position. If he wanted an editorial change and the writer refused to go along, Maxwell never got angry. He would give way but seldom change his mind. Once, when I was frustrated about an author's resistance to fixing an obvious problem, Maxwell said to me, "It's all right -- apparently, it's a mistake she needs to make." Often, when the writer saw that Maxwell would give way, with grace, he himself would give way. It was an editorial version of kung fu -- of winning by seeming to yield. But of course it was not combat; it was help.
I went to see Maxwell a few days before his death. He was lying in a hospital bed in his apartment. His family and friends were hovering in the living room and dining room, signing remembrance books, discussing the calligraphy and the exquisite paper. There was some discussion about whom Maxwell wanted to see and whom he didn't. He was impossibly thin and frail-looking, but he smiled and his eyes were warm. I went to sit in a chair, but he motioned me over to sit on the side of his bed. "It's so lovely to see you," he said. "I've decided there's not much reason to stick around, now that Emmy's gone, and I'm doing my best never to take another bite of food." I said, "I hope you'll change your mind about that," and then I couldn't say any more. Maxwell gripped my arm with surprising firmness, as if to say, hold on. "When my mother died and I was 10," he said, "a man came to the door ostensibly to pay his respects to my father. But my father suspected that the man came in triumph or glee about my mother's death. It may have had something to do with a sexual secret. In any case, my father opened the door, saw who it was, and slammed the door in the man's face so hard that the house shook. I had never seen him do anything like that before, and I never knew until that moment that anyone could be so direct and angry in polite circles. And I haven't forgotten it since."
As Maxwell told me this story, all I understood about it was that it seemed at once disturbing and obliquely flattering. And that the elegant economy of its telling somehow kept me from falling apart altogether. The more I've thought about it since, the stronger it has grown in my mind as a distillation of Maxwell's character, at least as I saw it: the perduring influence of his parents; his spare, sure sense of narrative; his concern about decorum and its chronic destruction by love and hate; his capacity for blunt honesty; and the openness and trust of his friendship, which lasted through his final days.

HEADLINE: Chances Are, You're a Barbarian

BYLINE: By Alexander Star; Alexander Star is the editor of Lingua Franca.

 BODY:

 The Twilight of American Culture
 By Morris Berman.
 205 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $23.95. 
 Morris Berman is best known as the author of a trilogy on human consciousness. He has now devoted a book to a society -- our own -- that he believes is lacking in both humanity and consciousness. Indeed, "The Twilight of American Culture" is an impassioned indictment of contemporary life: the "toxicity" of corporate capitalism, the "nakedly sick" enterprise of deconstruction, the poor spelling of public signs and the "incomprehensible" conversation overheard on a Greyhound bus. If you'd like to combine the anti-multinational rage of a black-clad Seattle protester with the mordant cultural despair of a Hilton Kramer or Jacques Barzun, here is your man.
Relying on the writings of the great pessimist Oswald Spengler as well as on a drawerful of articles from Harper's and other magazines, Berman compares the predicament of contemporary America with that of the Roman Empire in its final days. Just like Rome, the United States suffers from an increasing gap between rich and poor, a teeming bazaar of eccentric faiths and a general dumbing-down of the collective intelligence. Today, democracy means "the right to shop, or to choose between Wendy's and Burger King," while the "corporate takeover of intellectual property" has resulted in "the replacement of intelligent citizens by mindless consumers." Despite all of America's entrepreneurial "dynamism," a new dark age is falling. "For those seduced by noise, toys and technology, the current transformation to a global economy is nothing less than cultural efflorescence. For those who place their values elsewhere . . . the very transformation . . . is ultimately every bit as dark as the early Middle Ages." Since he believes that during the Dark Ages "most people forgot how to read or think," this is bad news indeed.
While Berman asserts that it is futile to battle the corporate oligarchy, he does recommend an alternative way of life that he labels "the monastic option." Like the medieval monks who preserved brittle classical manuscripts on their wind-swept Atlantic retreats, certain new monastic individuals (N.M.I.'s for short) are preparing civilization's eventual revival. In the most interesting portions of his book, Berman cites a number of men and women who "resist" the "global corporate world order" by boycotting Starbucks and recognizing the difference between "hype" and "reality." He admires the Vancouver-based Adbusters magazine and the filmmaker Michael Moore for "exposing the emptiness of the corporate/commercial way of life"; he admires Earl Shorris's Clemente course for teaching the Great Books to the poor, and The Concord Review for encouraging high school students to produce rigorously researched history papers.
But does Berman really wish these endeavors success? After all, he champions new monastic individuals for knowing that they "need to stay out of the public eye," and that they are "likely to be more significant for being marginal." Therefore, he questions Shorris's decision to accept federal funding for the Clemente course, and worries that Moore may become merely "a commodity of an 'alternative' sort." Then again, Berman's advocacy of renunciation only goes so far. He sees nothing wrong with his favorite (federally funded) National Public Radio program or with Moore's expose of Nike's C.E.O., Phil Knight: "From a 'monastic' point of view, it is important for American audiences to see such people close up." Visibility is to be avoided, except when it isn't.
In general, Berman's broad-brush approach to social criticism makes Spengler look like Seurat. Writing about the Dark Ages, he tells us that "the intellectual disciplines of distinction, definition and dialectic" were lost. Perhaps Berman should try to find them. It's hard to credit a complaint about the decline of literacy from a writer who speaks of "a parade of mental theme parks," or whose idea of qualifying an argument is to maintain that "a descent into real barbarism" is "certainly possible, and may even occur to some degree toward the end of the 21st century, perhaps for a short period of time." With tongue partly in cheek, Berman likes to pronounce impressive-sounding numbers: "In terms of what's made available via the world of commercial publishing, 96 percent of it is pretty much the same stuff"; "millions of Americans already don't know the difference between fiction and nonfiction." Apparently, the author is among those Americans who see little reason to provide any evidence for their most sweeping statements of fact. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
All the Basics Of a Mexico Trip

BYLINE: By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON; MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON lives in San Diego.

 BODY:
AS temperatures drop in much of the United States, travelers' daydreams may turn to Mexico. Its warm climate, relaxed pace, miles of beaches and value continue to attract visitors from the north; the Mexico-United States border is one of the busiest in the world.
Yet despite friendly relations and ease of access, travelers to Mexico need to remember that they are entering a foreign country. Visitors require proof of citizenship: a valid passport or birth certificate (or certified copy) is best, although pedestrian day-trippers crossing at the San Ysidro border near San Diego can get by with a California driver's license. 
 When in Mexico, you should carry a copy of your birth certificate or passport identification page. Naturalized United States citizens should carry their naturalization certificate numbers. Minors (under 18) traveling without their parents must show proof of citizenship and a notarized, signed letter of consent from both parents; a minor accompanied by one parent must have a notarized, signed letter of consent from the other parent, or divorce, death certificate or guardianship papers.
Since July 1, 1999, Mexico has required an entry fee (about $18, at 9.45 pesos to the dollar) for those who wish to travel farther than 16 miles from the border (in Baja, as far as Ensenada or San Felipe, and in Sonora, as far as Puerto Penasco), or stay more than three days. This fee is included in the air fare of flights into Mexico.
For those driving or walking into Mexico, a tourist card must be obtained at a Mexican immigration office at the border. The entry fee (for the card) must be paid at a bank, usually nearby, where the card is stamped "paid." The card must then be taken back to the immigration office for validation. If no nearby bank is open, the immigration office can stamp it pending payment and final validation, which must be within a day or two. It allows travelers to stay up to 180 days; it's useful to make a copy of the permit.
 
Auto Insurance
Anyone wishing to take a car across the border must have a valid driver's license from his country as well as insurance with a Mexican company. Many insurance offices along the United States side of the border sell this. AAA members can buy Mexican auto insurance in border states. You can also shop online, where a range of agencies provide quotes and rates and will fax or mail a policy to you. One company, Bajabound (www.bajabound.com), lets you print out the policy.
Besides simple liability coverage (usually about $10 a day, with a deductible of $500 to $1,000), you can buy additional coverage for legal and/or medical services, theft and personal liability. A useful Web site, www.mexonline.com, lets you search for online insurance companies and law firms.
Some car rental companies (Hertz, Dollar and Avis among them) allow their cars into Mexico, though you must buy Mexican insurance at the counter. There may be limits on which models you can rent and how far you can go. Within Mexico, the same companies have offices in larger cities and at major airports, and fewer restrictions.
Using travelocity.com, I found these prices to be surprisingly competitive. For instance, at the Tijuana or Acapulco airports, an economy two-door manual model from Avis, without air-conditioning but with unlimited mileage, and including the mandatory Mexican liability insurance, was quoted at $149 a week plus 10 percent tax. Some companies require collision-damage-waiver insurance as well, covering the rental car, although this is included when you use many major credit cards.
To take your own vehicle into Mexico and go outside the 16-mile border area or beyond the Baja peninsula or Sonora free trade zone, you must go to Mexican customs at the border and present an original, plus one copy, of the following: proof of citizenship, your tourist permit, a valid vehicle registration or title in the driver's name (or a leasing contract in the name of the person driving the car), a valid driver's license and an international credit card in the driver's name. (An effort last year to require a hefty deposit, of up to $800, for vehicles driven into Mexico was suspended in January.)
Your credit card will be charged the equivalent of $10 and you'll be issued a temporary (180 days) importation permit. (Those without a credit card must post a sizable bond.) Do not leave the permit in the glove compartment, and on leaving Mexico have it canceled at customs. A separate permit and ownership is necessary for each vehicle; for instance, in the case of an RV carrying a motorcycle, each vehicle must be registered to a different owner, and each must be present and provide documentation.
 
The Tangle of Accidents
Try to avoid, at all costs, having a road accident in Mexico. As in the United States, they can be treated as criminal cases if there is injury, death, significant property damage, or evidence of drugs or alcohol. The drivers involved are likely to be detained until the charges and damages have been sorted out. Charges that may be applied include imprudence, a kind of criminal negligence.
A representative of the public prosecutor's office will come to the scene and ask the drivers for statements. Although not required, it is considered useful to do so; you have the right to have a person you trust -- a friend, relative, lawyer, or even someone from the American Consulate, should you request it -- present while you are questioned. If there is only property damage, the police may ask the parties to negotiate a settlement, in which case they all sign an agreement (be sure to contact your insurance company first; the larger agencies have 24-hour hot lines with adjusters who speak English) and the vehicles are released.
Even if no agreement is reached, arrests are rare in property damage cases unless it appears that alcohol, drugs or reckless driving are involved. The penal code provides that a valid Mexican insurance policy will guarantee bail in cases where the charge is negligence or imprudence; however, additional charges of excessive speeding or driving under the influence may not allow for release. Bail is paid to a court official, never to a police officer.
If no agreement is reached, or if there are injuries, your vehicle may be impounded for as long as the investigation lasts, even if you feel the accident was not your fault. But sometimes you can post a bond, which may be covered by your Mexican insurance. In any case, you must report any accident to your insurance company's claims office before leaving Mexico.
To avoid these problems, drive defensively, at or below the speed limit, in daytime, sober and where possible, on Mexico's expensive but high-quality toll roads and away from city traffic. Watch for extreme speed bumps, called topes, at the entry to towns, and keep an eye out for potholes. At stop signs, be generous with the right of way. To make a left turn on a busy two-lane highway with no left-turn lane, pull onto the right shoulder and wait for an opening.
If you're lost in a larger town or city, the AAA advises hiring a taxi driver to lead you to your destination, settling the cost in advance. A red circle with a diagonal line across a large "E" means no parking. The word cuota designates a toll road.
If the police issue you a ticket that you think you did not deserve, take the officer's name and number and ask to speak to the police chief or supervisor at the nearest police station. If this doesn't work, pay the ticket, on the spot if necessary, but if possible at a bank, getting a receipt; then register a complaint with the Secretariat of Tourism at (01-800) 903-9200 toll free, or, within Mexico City, (5) 250-0123 or (5) 250-0151. The secretariat also has a Web site, www.safeMexico.com, that provides safety tips and advice for specific cities and regions.
Motorists in Mexico are fortunate to have the Green Angels, road patrols that help stranded vehicles. Their free services include emergency fuel, towing to a nearby garage, primary first aid, protection, mechanical repairs and tire changes; motorists pay for parts, gas and oil (tips are accepted). They can be enlisted by calling a toll-free number, (01-800) 903-9200; in case of a breakdown on a major highway, park completely on a shoulder, lift the hood and await a patrol; they cruise the highways frequently in marked green-and white trucks and in green uniforms.
Those who would like to forgo responsibility for a vehicle might consider the Mexican bus system, which can be quite pleasant, though smoking is permitted. First- or deluxe-class buses usually have air-conditioning, reclining seats and footrests, restrooms, free snacks and beverages. Travelers going to out-of-the-way places may require second- or third-class buses, but there are very few villages not on some bus route.
Ferries ply the Gulf of California between Baja and the mainland: from Santa Rosalia to Guaymas, and from La Paz to Topolobampo, and Mazatlan. Schedules and rates change frequently; call (01-800) 696-9600 within Mexico for information.
The Secretariat of Tourism has travel hot lines: (800) 446-3942 for the United States; (800) 482-9832 to the Mexico City office from the United States; and within Mexico, (01-800) 903-9200.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00;
Investing Is the New Spending

BYLINE: By Jeff Turrentine; Jeff Turrentine, a senior editor at Architectural Digest, has written about finance for Forbes FYI, Spin and The Los Angeles Times Book Review.

 BODY:
In May, as he bickered with Gov. George W. Bush over the wisdom of allowing individuals to invest portions of their Social Security withholding taxes, Vice President Al Gore made a startling admission: he hadn't made a single dollar from the bull market. In fact, Gore explained, to avoid any conflicts of interest or the appearance thereof, he didn't even own stock, and hadn't since 1976, when he first joined Congress. The man fighting for ultimate stewardship of American fiscal policy had taken a pass on the greatest investment opportunity of our time in favor of an interest-bearing checking account.
The vice president clearly expected that the news would inspire confidence; instead, it inspired Fortune magazine to suggest he could be "a financial dolt." In this era of skyrocketing returns, what inspires confidence is the knowledge that an enormous chunk of your personal wealth derives from securities, especially those in the risky but potentially lucrative technology sector. Stock-market savvy has saturated every corner of society. (Liberty Financial now markets a special mutual fund to clients as young as 11.) By opting out, Gore lost serious street cred -- or at least Wall Street cred. 
 In a telling update of the mores established during the 80's, conspicuous equity seems to have supplanted conspicuous consumption as the most effective means of broadcasting your wealth and status. Back in the day when greed was good and barbarians were at the gate, visible symbols of wealth like Rolexes and BMW's were the rage -- but it was still considered slightly gauche to ask someone about his private investments. Almost a decade into the current bull market, for a small but significant group of young and successful individuals, investing has become the new spending. They are deferring the purchase of cars, houses, trips, home furnishings and the like, deciding instead to keep their dollars in the market, where they can generate even more purchasing power in the future. Call it the front-loading of the American dream. Expensive gadgets that help facilitate their investments are legitimate purchases, even status symbols. But mere luxury items, like Marc Jacobs suits and Land Rovers, seem more and more like indulgences, better saved for later. Much later, when you are ready to retire. You know, like at 40.
But why? I ask Bruce Gibney, a 24-year-old law student who majored in engineering at Stanford. "The chance that you'll make money now is so good, so obvious, that people just seem profligate if they're not putting it in the market," he explains. As a result, the pressure among his peers to announce their latest market triumphs can be huge. "Your investment in the market reflects your status. One, it reflects your intelligence, and two, it reflects how connected you are. It's not about being invited to one of Mr. and Mrs. Astor's parties anymore; it's how many people you know in really good start-ups. Or you mention 'Series A' -- that's a great way to get somebody's attention: 'I was in Series A, I was in the seed round, I got in for pennies a share.' "
Erich Fritz, a 31-year-old manager at an international consulting firm, moved to Seattle last spring and rented a loft. The cavernous space cries out for high-end, high-modern accouterments, but Erich has furnished the place like a room at Motel 6. "Just last Friday I got a sofa, a coffee table and a desk," he says. "Before Friday I had a bed, and that was it. I was actually sleeping in a sleeping bag on the floor for the first two weeks. If you're single and really focusing on your career and investing in your future, it's really not so hard at the end of the day to come home and just shrug and say, 'What the hell, I'll sleep on the floor.' "
And when you get right down to it, does any rich adult really need his own apartment? Earlier this year, Dan Lurie, 34, left Los Angeles and moved in with his sister, brother-in-law and their new baby in a small town near Charlotte, N.C. He barters for his room and board, helping out with household chores and assisting them in their business. He drives a Mazda he bought used. But Dan is hardly a slacker. He is an investor. In January he set a goal of making a certain amount (he's shy about the number, but it's in the low six figures) by the end of the year. Through his success in buying and trading "leaps," or options that are realizable nine months or more in the future, he reached his goal in July. He has now set a new goal for December, nearly twice as high as the first. For now he's allowing himself only one consumer fantasy. "I've talked to some friends about investing in a farm. We could get a hundred acres for $200,000 and put three houses on it. We could have a big organic vegetable garden and trade stocks all day." And as for the long term? "I've always wanted to be semiretired by 40," he tells me. "I want to travel around the world."
That's the dream: stocks now, the world at 40. Retirement at 40. Dinner parties and families and novels at 40. I heard it again and again as I talked to these prudent 20- and 30-somethings. But I worry for them about how possible it will be to achieve.
Not just because there is no telling where the market will land. (Though when everything you've got can fit in an Ameritrade account, the difference between guessing right and losing the farm can come down to perilously little.) The market is risky, but these guys know that. They've all lost money at one point or another. And if they think they can stay one step ahead of the Dow -- well, they might very well be right.
The more relevant question is not where the market will land, but where these eager workaholics will land. It's one thing to work hard during the week to make sure your weekend is free; these guys are signing over at least two solid decades of their lives -- to the willful exclusion of a comfortable home life, time to spend with friends, small indulgences and who knows what else. They think that if they hold on just a little longer, let things ride through one more uptick, they'll reach a plateau at which they can trade in their 80-hour-a-week grind for an eternity of leisurely, unstructured fun. But what are the odds that, having spent their entire lives in the glow of a computer screen, they will be able to reinvent themselves in middle age as carefree bons vivants? Of all the speculations they've made, the most sanguine by far is the gamble that they'll be able to enjoy the life they've worked so hard to buy.

Chart: "My Happy Birthday Portfolio"
"I am 10 years old and already own several stocks. When I was in the fourth grade, my classmates and I entered our local newspaper's stock contest. We chose five stocks. . . . After one year of recording, the best was Home Depot.
After my 10th birthday, my dad suggested that instead of using my birthday money to buy toys, I should buy stock. . . . What was it that led me to Home Depot? To tell you the truth, I hated the trips to Home Depot with my parents. They bought so much and spent hours in that store. But the aisles are fully stocked, the checkout lines packed and the parking lot filled with cars.
I also chose Home Depot for a second reason: HGTV (Home and Garden Television), one of several home-improvement shows on television. To do those projects, you need supplies. Where do you go? Home Depot.
Here's the third reason: customer service. . . . Since I have purchased Home Depot stock, it has split and its value has increased." -- Bethany Murphy, quoted in The Stein Roe Young Investor Fund Quarterly Newsletter.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00: Economics Of An Underdog Campaign;
The Price of Admission

BYLINE: By Kerry Lauerman

 BODY:

The First Half-Million Is the Hardest
In the summer of 1999, David Johnson -- an Indianapolis attorney active in Indiana's Democratic Party -- decided to challenge Senator Richard Lugar, a four-term senator and onetime Republican presidential nominee. He immediately retained the services of Fred Yang, a pollster, and Frank Greer, a media consultant, who offered this advice: raise money. It makes you look like a serious candidate, he explained, thereby allowing you to raise still more money. Johnson, a political insider, knew whom to call. He took a leave of absence from his law firm and hit the phones; by the end of the year, he had amassed close to $500,000.
 
Hire a Penny Pincher
In February, Johnson hired a campaign manager: Tim Shock, a Democratic political consultant with a reputation for upsets. Because he'd have to commute from Kentucky, his salary was relatively high -- about $10,000 a month. But he kept a close eye on incidental spending. "Nobody can authorize an expense, any expense, except me," Shock said. He guided Johnson to hire a press secretary and two field managers, who joined a finance manager and three fund-raisers already on staff. Total monthly salaries: about $20,000. He ordered "Johnson for Senate" signs and bumper stickers that were low gloss, chose adhesive lapel stickers (25,000 for $400) rather than pins (as much as 70 cents apiece) and had Johnson driven around, rather than flown, even on 10-hour round trips. Meanwhile Johnson kept raising money, and by late June he was up to $1.3 million, far more than Lugar's previous opponent raised but less than half of what Lugar had. 

Make the First Ads Free
In April, The Indianapolis Star gave Lugar a 45-point lead over Johnson. Shock initiated "work days," on which Johnson performed blue-collar jobs around the state in order to meet voters and generate footage for the nightly news. On a typical trip, Johnson and his press secretary traveled an hour and a half to Lafayette (population: 115,624) to give a civics lesson at an after-school class for "at risk" children. Total cost: just over $20, including gasoline ($6.40), sandwiches to eat in the car ($5) and M&M's for the kids ($9.63). It paid off with full media coverage, including a front-page story with photos, in The Lafayette Journal & Courier and a segment on Lafayette's TV station, WLFI.
 
Get Lucky
Then, in July, Lugar's son was arrested for possessing marijuana. The possible upside was not lost on the Johnson campaign. Pinned to the wall of Shock's cubicle are newspaper clippings of the event, along with what looks like a fake joint and a note that reads "Vote for Dick Lugar." But Shock insisted that any attempt to make an issue of it would backfire. "That all stays in here," he said. "Both sides here are playing clean."
 
Make Your Pitch
In August, at the Democratic National Convention, Johnson learned that the party would spend $250,000 on a TV "issue ad" that would "raise questions about Lugar's record," Johnson said, adding, "this is the big time." As party spending goes, it's not much, but it would set off a key series of events. First, the campaign would commission a poll by Yang (from $15,000 to $30,000) to show where voters stood after the ad ran. The campaign would then follow up with a pro-Johnson ad by Greer (between $10,000 to $12,000) -- one that's purely positive, with no mention of Lugar at all," Shock said -- and buy air time (an additional $250,000). The week after the convention, Johnson's campaign had vetted the ad, and air time had been purchased on eight TV stations.
 
The Loneliest Number
But then two weeks after the ad was shown, the terrain shifted dramatically. Lugar, along with former Senator Sam Nunn, was nominated to receive the Nobel Peace Prize. "There's nothing you can do about that," Shock says. Now Johnson is on his own. The Democratic Party has not promised to spend any more money on the race, and the campaign is dipping into its cash reserves. In mid-September (after an Indiana University poll showed Lugar leading Johnson by 43 points), his campaign launched its first ad, for roughly $400,000. In August, Shock had said that if the campaign didn't get a major ad blitz going by the end of that month, the campaign would be facing "major problems." Now he says, "We're doing what we can."

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
In St. Louis, Accord Despite a Fiscal Sour Note

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE B. JOHNSON; Lawrence B. Johnson is the music critic of The Detroit News.

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
THE St. Louis Symphony Orchestra arrives at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday and Thursday evenings bearing not only double basses and French horns packed with pride but also other baggage: the same burden of harsh fiscal reality that even in these flush economic times chafes many other American orchestras.
On its tally sheet, the orchestra counts substantial artistic dividends from the music directorship of Hans Vonk, the 58-year-old Dutch conductor now in his fifth season at the helm. There is a palpable spirit of camaraderie inside Powell Symphony Hall, the orchestra's elegantly appointed home. Also in the credit column is a reinvigorated community outreach program, which sends orchestra players into the city and suburbs alike to put a friendly, personal face on classical music. Partnerships with 30 black churches have helped the orchestra become a better citizen of its neighborhood, and the churches have responded by helping put listeners in the audience. The theme of the new classical subscription season is, pointedly, "music for everyone." 
 But all these good things, like a 1998 European tour, which brought glowing reviews, and annual visits to Carnegie Hall, seem to come at a price that isn't quite being met. Over the last 17 or 18 years, the orchestra has accumulated a potentially crippling deficit of $7 million. (Its annual budget is now $26 million for the orchestra itself with an additional $3 million for its music school.)
"The biggest problem will come if we don't look the beast in the eye," said Don Roth, the orchestra's president. The issue is not so much overspending as underfinancing, and Mr. Roth is determined to see the orchestra's endowment increased to $100 million from the current $30 million, and to make sure that all future touring is fully sponsored.
"This orchestra has been built to greatness without the financial underpinning of a great orchestra," Mr. Roth said. "There has been a series of interim, short fixes. But this is where the Band-Aids fall off and you get the cure. Probably for the first time in the history of this organization, we have laid it out plainly to the community and said it's going to take a hundred million to get it done. People haven't backed away from that.
"We're not New York or London. St. Louis doesn't automatically have the best of everything. This is a great city with significant social and economic challenges, and the St. Louis Symphony has the opportunity to provide some of the glue that holds the city together."
To spend a couple of days at Powell Symphony Hall is to see a certain poetic aptness in Mr. Roth's choice of the word "glue." Within its own organization, the St. Louis Symphony is nothing if not cohesive, in a singular spiritual sense. In conversations with the president, the concertmaster and the music director, a visitor could only be impressed by the aura of accord.
Mr. Roth, who has worked as an administrator at five other orchestras, said that since coming here three years ago, he has been surprised by "the tremendous caring and the willingness of the musicians to work with other members of the organization."
"It's even O.K. to be friendly," he said, "and you don't find that in a lot of orchestras."
But at least one cooperative venture between musicians and management has not panned out. Frustrated like many other orchestras by the recording industry's lack of interest in classical projects, the St. Louis Symphony created its own label, Arch Media, last year. The company was run by a board made up of musicians and members of the orchestra's board and staff. The first release, a Beethoven disc, sold 4,200 copies: strong sales for a classical release. But then came the bad news that not even such healthy sales were enough to break even.
Although Arch Media's long-term plans called for complete cycles of the Beethoven, Mahler and Bruckner symphonies conducted by Mr. Vonk, just four CD's were released before costs overwhelmed revenues. Now, only some chamber-music recordings remain in the works. But Mr. Vonk refuses to grouse about the lost opportunity to record Bruckner end to end, parrying a reminder of the abortive venture with a philosophical shrug. It's a dark age for orchestral recording, he allows, and for now there is nothing to be done.
Mr. Roth, less resigned, said the orchestra would continue to record all of its concerts digitally and wait for technology to catch up. He sees a near future when record collectors will be able to log on to the orchestra's Web site, select the works they want to buy and download them on recordable CD's.
AFTER the adventurous and artistically prosperous 17-year stewardship of Leonard Slatkin, who left in 1996 and now directs the National Symphony in Washington and the BBC Symphony in London, the St. Louis Symphony has apparently found a satisfying successor in the old-school Mr. Vonk, despite his radically different approach to music-making. Subscriptions are said to have held steady, neither breaking records nor slumping.
"Leonard Slatkin and Hans Vonk are extremely dissimilar personalities," said David Halen, the orchestra's concertmaster. "The orchestra didn't want a Leonard Slatkin imitator. That would have been an exercise in failure. Leonard made this a virtuoso orchestra. He wanted a certain brilliance in the sound, and he liked to give us extremely difficult music. He always had us on the edge. We would always be sweating bullets at the first concert. But that also made the orchestra really good readers.
"Hans wants a mellower sound, not quite as flashy, with softer edges. But just as important is the change of emphasis in repertoire. Hans comes from the great Dutch tradition of Van Beinum and Mengelberg, and his focus is on the core repertoire: Beethoven, Brahms, Bruckner, Mahler. But he's also wonderful with Stravinsky and French music, and his Tchaikovsky has a Mozartean purity." (The Carnegie programs this week are all Stravinsky.)
Significant changes have also occurred in the makeup of the orchestra itself. Since Mr. Vonk's arrival, the group has experienced a turnover of 20 players, including the principal flutist, the principal trombonist, the principal second violinist, the second trumpeter and the associate principal cellist. The new hires represent another way in which Mr. Vonk is making the orchestra his own.
The music at hand on a recent weekend was Brahms's Second Symphony and Berg's Violin Concerto, with Cho-Liang Lin as soloist. The sound that resonated through Powell Symphony Hall, a restored vaudeville theater and movie house, which has served as the orchestra's home since 1968, offered a veritable checklist of the qualities Van Beinum and Mengelberg shared: precision, clarity, subtlety. Mr. Vonk, who prefers good style and expressive playing to virtuoso display, elicited a Brahms Second that was as much chamber music as grand symphony. His tempos were expansive, his musical gestures elegant. Even in the finale's last rousing burst of trumpets, his restraining hand was evident.
In time, he hopes, the Dutch tradition will also carry Mahler to the hearts of St. Louis audiences. "I really don't understand it, but our subscribers have no real enthusiasm for Mahler," he said. "I grew up at the Concertgebouw in Amsterdam, where Bruckner and Mahler were revered like Beethoven."
Mr. Vonk seems to harbor no doubt that he can bring authentic Mahler to the Midwest. He dismisses any notion that European orchestras come to the core masterworks with an inherent cultural advantage. "It's nonsense," he said. "The standard of American orchestras, even in the second and third category, is incredibly high."
Mr. Vonk offers that assessment in the light of a long, far-ranging and sometimes tumultuous career. His first directorship was at the Netherlands Ballet, where in 1962 he met his wife, Jessie, then a teenage prima ballerina. He later directed the Netherlands Opera, the Hague Residentie Orchestra, the Dresden Staatskapelle and Dresden State Opera and, most recently, the Cologne Radio Symphony. His Dresden sojourn, from 1985 to 1990, in the twilight of the East German Communist regime, proved a trial by fire. He describes a constant run of political bickering, inadequate staff support and forbidden socializing between conductor and musicians, all capped by a bureaucratic cabal to oust him.
By comparison, Mr. Vonk's only real difficulty in St. Louis is that albatross of a deficit, not cause enough for him to rethink his commitment. He recently signed a contract extension that will keep him in St. Louis through the 2004-05 season. Indeed, in the easygoing atmosphere of Powell Symphony Hall, surrounded by musicians and administrators who value his Dutch heritage, Mr. Vonk appears to be settled in for the long haul. He has shown that he is not a quitter, and he knows that cultivating a tradition takes time.
"You have your ups and downs in life," he said, recalling old hopes of becoming music director of the great Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra, a post that instead went for the first time to a non-Dutchman, the Italian Riccardo Chailly, in 1988. "For a long time I was in the picture to succeed Bernard Haitink. That didn't work out for me. Now I am here, and I truly believe I'm in the best position I could possibly be in."
Or he will be, if Mr. Roth and the St. Louis Symphony can shed those fiscal Band-Aids and find their $100 million cure.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 7; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1672 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
It's Great to Be a Playwright, but Oh, the Pain

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN; Mervyn Rothstein, an editor in the Real Estate section of The New York Times, frequently writes about theater.

 BODY:
THEATER is stressful," says Neil Simon. The winner of the Pulitzer Prize and four Tony Awards is back in New York for his 31st play, "The Dinner Party." But getting to the city wasn't easy. He had planned to arrive from his home on the West Coast on Sept. 15 for the start of rehearsals, but found himself laid up with a stomach ailment that refused to go away.
"So many times when I do a play I wind up having a physical problem," said Mr. Simon, 73, sitting in the living room of his Park Avenue apartment recently and looking somewhat thin. "I made a list the other day, and I thought of 11 of them -- all over my body, in so many different places. But I know there are others I haven't remembered." 
 When he was doing "Broadway Bound" in Washington in 1986, he said, he thought he was having a heart attack on opening night -- "I wasn't, but it felt like it" -- and he had to be taken to a hospital. "When 'Jake's Women' was first done in San Diego," he said, "I bent down and my back went out and I had to go the hospital. When 'The Dinner Party' was in Los Angeles, I had a 10-day headache. The mind does this for you."
His friends ask him why he still feels such stress, since he has written so many hit plays and the success or failure of the latest one is not going to change his life. "But it has nothing to do with that," he said. "It has to do with the work, and wanting the work to be good, wanting to make it the best I can make it."
The symptoms of physical distress don't occur during the actual writing and rewriting, he said, they happen before or after. And they don't show up when he is working on a movie. "The difference," he noted, "is that a movie isn't opening in one city, in one theater, with a handful of critics, and it's not being judged the night the critics come."
"The Dinner Party" opens on Thursday at the Music Box Theater, after an earlier run in Los Angeles and a critically praised sold-out month in Washington. Its subject is marriage and divorce. The cast -- Len Cariou, Veanne Cox, Penny Fuller, Jan Maxwell, John Ritter and Henry Winkler -- is directed by John Rando.
Set in an exclusive Paris restaurant, the play is little more than an hour and a half long and is performed without an intermission. Three French men, recipients of a mysterious invitation, arrive at the restaurant, not knowing for sure why they are there. Gradually, the three other guests -- their former wives -- also arrive, and what has started out as a seemingly classic French farce is transformed into an often serious look, with a leavening of humor, at the sadnesses and despairs of marital bliss turned cold. It is Mr. Simon's take on why couples break up, on why even loving and caring mates can sometimes be heartlessly cruel to each other.
Speaking of the audiences that saw the play in Los Angeles and Washington, Mr. Simon said: "There's a vicarious thing that happens to them. They're viewing something that may have gone on in their own lives and are very happy to let other people be the spokesmen for what their feelings are."
The three couples have been divorced four times -- one couple married twice and divorced twice. Mr. Simon himself has been married five times to four women. His first wife, Joan Baim, died of cancer in 1973. He subsequently wed three actresses: Marsha Mason, then Diane Lander (twice), and ultimately Elaine Joyce, his current wife.
But Mr. Simon takes great pains to distance himself personally from his play. "It's very important for me to delineate that the play is not about me," he said, "nor are there references to any of the marriages."
"The Dinner Party," he explained, was conceived two years ago, at a house he had rented in East Hampton on Long Island: "I was out there alone, and the theme of divorce came to me, because it has been so prevalent in my own life, and in the lives of my friends. But I truthfully never thought about any of my own marriages, or my own feelings about them. I tried to deal with these characters purely as characters I was writing about."
That was one reason he set the play in Paris -- "to make it far away from the problems we have here."
"Maybe I was also influenced by French films," he added, "because the French are very much more open about personal things than we are. But what I tried to do was to make it universal."
In attempting to create a "bonfire, a clash between these people, of why they got divorced, and how they feel about each other," he was also trying to write a play very different from anything he had done before.
"There's something for me that's a little abstract about the play," he said, "certainly compared to my other plays. I had the concept of creating a farce up to a certain point, and then instead of continuing the farce, to make a turn to where it becomes quite serious. I wanted to break the concept that farces can never get real, even for a minute."
The play is also unusual for Mr. Simon because of its short length and lack of intermission. "I couldn't find a place to break it," he said. "And I didn't see it as a long play. I also think that today's audiences are not as patient as they used to be. Most of my plays have run two and a half hours or so. But when we did the revival of 'The Sunshine Boys' with Jack Klugman and Tony Randall, we cut about 20 or 25 minutes, and it was much better. So I found that one can be more concise with things, rather than go on and on."
Does the bleakness in the play reflect his feelings about marriage? "In any marriage that breaks up, there's bleakness," Mr. Simon said. Even in the best of marriages, people can be cruel to each other. "But you can't leave out the other half, the wonderful things people say to each other. I try to cover both.
"At times all of us who are married say, 'Why am I in this thing? Why did I do this?' Who's to say that because you get married, every day is a wonderful day? It's not."
Not many people are lucky enough to get the partners they would like to have, he said, "and so they settle."
"If you marry the right person, a person you can work things out with, who's loving and giving and sharing, you're very lucky," he said. "I only expected to be married once in my life. Joan died, and I was thrust into a whole other life."
Even his first marriage wasn't perfect, he said, though he may have idealized it in his autobiographies, "Rewrites" and "The Play Goes On." "We had our ups and downs," he recalled. "But it was a true marriage in that we married for the right reasons. We fell in love. I was not Neil Simon then; just a kid scraping to make a few dollars. We married because we loved each other. That's not to say that that didn't happen in the other marriages."
But, he said, he does not want to talk about the other marriages -- it's too personal. "I'm married now," he said. "I'm very happy. I don't like the idea of being married four or five times. But that's what happened. I guess I could have gone the other way and said, after the last divorce, 'That's it, I'm not going to do it any more.' But I'm kind of an optimist."
It would seem the case in his professional life as well. Mr. Simon has been writing for the Broadway theater for almost 40 years now, since "Come Blow Your Horn" in 1961, and so far, despite the stress, he has shown no signs of letting up. "It's what I do," he said.
Over the last four decades, Mr. Simon has had many successes, among them "Barefoot in the Park" and "The Odd Couple" in the 60's, "The Sunshine Boys" and "Chapter Two" in the 70's, and "Brighton Beach Memoirs," "Biloxi Blues" and "Broadway Bound" in the 80's. In 1991, he won the Pulitzer Prize for "Lost in Yonkers."
But he has also had his share of flops. And he has not had a major hit in the last nine years. In 1995, after the failures on Broadway of the musical "The Goodbye Girl" and "Laughter on the 23rd Floor" -- that play wound up losing about $800,000 -- Mr. Simon and Emanuel Azenberg, his producer, announced with some fanfare that the next play, "London Suite," would be presented Off Broadway. Because of the high costs, it was not economically viable to go to Broadway anymore, the two men said, pointing out at the time that the play would cost $1.6 million to produce on Broadway compared with $660,000 Off Broadway.
BUT "London Suite" failed -- Mr. Simon said that in retrospect the reason they didn't take it to Broadway was that deep inside they knew it wasn't good enough -- and Mr. Azenberg and Mr. Simon were Broadway bound again in 1997 with Mr. Simon's 30th play, "Proposals," even though they said the economics had in fact become worse. But "Proposals" was also a flop. And now, three years later, they are back again.
"We were very careful with 'The Dinner Party,' " said Mr. Azenberg, who has been producing Mr. Simon's plays since 1972. "When it opened at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, we didn't think it was right for Broadway. But we've got to give the Mark Taper people credit. They brought it into the Kennedy Center in Washington. There were cast changes that suddenly caused a change in the play and a change in the reviews." The economics are "still crazy," he said, "but this is where Neil is comfortable. And there was a time when Neil Simon and Broadway were synonymous."
Because the set already existed, the play is capitalized at $1.2 million instead of the expected $1.7 million or $1.8 million, Mr. Azenberg said. Part of it, he said -- "not a minor amount" -- is Mr. Simon's own money. "He always backs his own stuff, win or lose," Mr. Azenberg said.
Mr. Simon said the recent spate of failures does not concern him. "I love the sitting down and the writing," he said. "I read this in a book about Edward Albee, and it amazed me because it's so much the way I think. He said, 'Oh, I've got an idea for a play -- I'm set for the year.' I have those feelings, too."
And besides, he said: "I've had more hits than I ever thought I would have. I don't expect to win five Pulitzer Prizes. One is enough."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 7; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1901 words

HEADLINE: Answering a Calling To Make You Believe

 BODY:
LAST Sunday in these pages, two Americans, the actress Mary-Louise Parker and the director and former actor Joe Mantello, who went to theater school together, talked about the proper education of actors and audiences.
In the dialogue below, Eileen Atkins and Alan Bates, two British actors of an earlier generation (they are both 66), discuss how actors develop from the moment they realize there is no other suitable profession. 
 Mr. Bates and Ms. Atkins are starring in "The Unexpected Man" by Yasmina Reza, the author of "Art." Now in previews at the Promenade Theater, the play opens on Oct. 24 and, like "Art," has been translated from the French by Christopher Hampton and directed by Matthew Warchus.
Ms. Atkins won an Olivier Award for her performance in the original 1998 London production of "The Unexpected Man," opposite Michael Gambon. Mr. Bates has not appeared on a New York stage since Simon Gray's "Butley" in 1973, for which he won a Tony Award.
Unlike "Art," "The Unexpected Man," which is set on a train, does not allow its two characters to speak directly to each other until the final moments. With that in mind, The New York Times invited the two stars to talk, over lunch in London late last month, about their lives as actors. They were joined by Matt Wolf, the London theater critic for Variety. Following are excerpts from the taped conversation:
ALAN BATES -- We've never worked together, although we've always wanted to, from the days when it was just remotely possible for us to play Romeo and Juliet. We talked about it for years, and then we began to laugh because we realized we weren't going to get the offer. Now we're actually doing it.
EILEEN ATKINS -- And we don't have to worry about Mercutio.
BATES -- Laughs No.
MATT WOLF -- But why be an actor? And what is it about Britain that breeds so many?
BATES -- It has nothing to do with being in this country. You want to be an actor because you want to be an actor. You suddenly realize that's what you want to do. In my case, when I was 11.
ATKINS -- You have to be an actor -- in my case, when I was 12 -- there's no choice.
BATES -- People say, "What made you want to be an actor?" and you don't know, there isn't an answer. But you can guess at a few things. I never expressed myself. I was quite shy, though I was also quite happy; I wasn't miserable. I think through acting you find you can say things through other people's words and other characters.
ATKINS -- As for actually choosing to be an actor -- we both get this now -- we get young people wanting advice. But if anybody comes to me and says, "Should I become an actor?" I say: "Well, no. If you've got to ask me, no."
WOLF -- Because?
ATKINS -- It's very, very rigorous.
BATES -- You can't just say, "It's something to do because I can't think of anything else." There used to be people at RADA the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London like that who would say, "I couldn't think of what to do, so I'm here."
ATKINS Half my year at drama school was like that; they didn't last very long.
BATES -- They're out in a term. They either can't do it or perhaps they realize they don't want to, which is fair dues. But the profession, too, has changed. When we started, once you were lucky with something, or hit a nerve in audiences, more or less from then on you were in demand. People wanted us the minute we had made a mark. Now, for the most part, there isn't the same hunger. You can do something and then have six months out of work, whereas we got offers and got work and kept going and got used to the fact that we were always working. This generation can't rely on that at all -- with very few exceptions.
I've always felt a huge need to do the theater, and it's never left me. People say "Well, it's where your heart is." And it is there: it is in the doing of it at the same time with the audience present and being in charge of it, unless you've been thrown off course by a director, which can happen, and then you have a miserable time because you can't get back to your own instinct. With television and film, there are other things that are intriguing: acting in the actual location somewhere, acting sometimes very intimately and sometimes with the camera miles away. But there's nothing as big or as complete or as satisfying as the theater.
ATKINS -- I would hate to give the impression, and it's not true, that you don't have to be a very very good actor on screen as well. It is just that there is more freedom for you as an actor in the theater. But you have to be careful not to give in to the theater audience too much. It's very easy to do because you're seducing them, basically. I think there are actors who go out there just determined to seduce.
BATES -- I remember someone coming backstage to me one night after "Butley" in London and saying to me, "You have to be careful that you're leading the audience and that the audience isn't leading you, which of course was what was happening to you tonight." I didn't know how to interpret this, so I just said, "Good night and thank you very much." I realize that what he was saying might have even been true. You have to stay in charge; you've got to keep the lead.
WOLF -- Do American audiences differ from British ones?
ATKINS -- I much prefer Americans.
BATES -- This is rather awful about the rest of the audiences, but the first audiences you get in New York -- and it can last for the better part of six months -- are the best you ever get. They have an enthusiasm, an observation, a concentration. It has been a long time since I've been on the stage there, but I'm told this hasn't changed: you feel the audience participation. They don't feel they're at all above it. They're letting it be what it is, and they like it or they don't.
ATKINS -- It's that enthusiasm, which is that thing about America. They are naturally on the whole -- because we're only speaking in generalizations -- a more enthusiastic race and they show it. They also show it when they don't like it. I quite like the definiteness of that.
BATES -- I don't mind being sent back on the boat. You know where you are, and you can get on with the next job. You don't go dribbling on.
WOLF -- What about different kinds of acting? In films, audiences frequently pay to see a star play versions of himself or herself; it's performance as personality.
BATES -- If you believe what you see, then it's good acting.
ATKINS -- Believability is the whole thing.
BATES -- If the acting is true, if an understanding of character is within you, whether you have to go outside your own shape or vocal range to achieve what you want, it doesn't matter, as long as you understand it and believe it yourself.
ATKINS -- I don't think there are any rules, Alan, do you? It's like Beryl Beryl Reid, Ms. Atkins's co-star in "The Killing of Sister George" 34 years ago used to say, "I've got the shoes; now I've got the part."
BATES -- I love those stories. I don't disbelieve them at all. When I did the film "An Englishman Abroad," I watched a run of it with a friend, and he said, "Where did you get that funny little walk?" -- a kind of drunken shuffle, really. And I didn't know I was doing it. You don't think, "I'll do a funny walk," or whatever.
ATKINS -- They're the best things: when you don't know you're doing them. I had a tiny part in the film of "The Dresser," and an American said, "The way you marched across the bridge at the railway station -- it was so funny: go on, do that walk," and I said, like you, Alan, "I was just walking." But the point is that it is coming from how you're feeling, so I had found this terribly sort of bustly-brisk walk with a much bigger length of stride. And this man said I had busy legs.
WOLF -- Have you changed over time as performers?
BATES -- You're bound to have, but you don't always know how. Life just happens to you, and it's bound to influence you. You probably have more insight as you grow older, though that's not to say that you always see that you're any different. You just hope you're a bit more economical.
I think you change because you must. You must develop -- become more philosophical, more wise, more witty, less witty, more showoffy, whatever. But you can't really talk about it because as an actor you're not supposed to be watching yourself. You're supposed to have a sense of yourself, but not actually stand outside and analyze yourself. I think you would lose an awful lot of your mystery or your spontaneity or your natural instincts if you did. In some ways, you don't change a lot and the reason is because acting is instinctive, and your instincts, hopefully, were always there. You understand more. Maybe that's what changes.
ATKINS -- If you think of yourself as an instrument that you use, the instrument is the same but maybe -- you hope -- it has all got a bit more finely tuned. But if you began thinking about it, you'd be a dead duck. The famous one is when you think, "I really do know how to time things now."
BATES -- Laughs That's hell. And that's when you go out and fall flat on your face because you meet a different audience; you don't meet the audience that you have planned to meet.
ATKINS -- Laughs I love that, Alan. That should be the title of your autobiography: "I didn't meet the audience I planned to meet."
WOLF -- Do you get braver?
BATES -- Yes. You think, "I can do it."
ATKINS -- The older you get, I find, the more you think, "I can't do it at all" and that everybody else is much cleverer. I got into a habit about 20 years ago of suggesting another actress for every part. I remember once, before I did John Schlesinger's production of "Heartbreak House," with Colin Blakely and Kate Nelligan, telling John I couldn't do it. And then I heard he had asked another actress who was even more neurotic and thin and nonmaternal for Hesione Hushabye than I am, so I played it. But mostly, I do tend to think, "Now I wonder if I can play it." It's got worse as I've got older, although I won't say the nerves have got worse because I've always had horrifying nerves.
BATES -- In mock alarm Oh, thank you very much.
ATKINS -- But it is always frightening, isn't it?
BATES -- It's always frightening, yes. And the thing is, the opposite to what you've described also happens. Sometimes you think: "I could do that role. Why have they asked him?" And then you think to yourself, "Oh, perhaps I am 20 years older or too old for the part." You always stay about 40.
ATKINS -- Laughs What do you mean, 40? Twenty-three! You certainly say you're at least 20 years younger than you actually are.
BATES -- The point is, acting is mysterious in the sense that you can't really talk about it. You end up down a blind alley: a dead-end script.
ATKINS -- And you can't learn it. You can learn to be better and improve your technique, but you can't learn the basic talent.
BATES -- No, I don't think you can. Sometimes, when you see a film with nonactors, they can do it once but they don't know what they're doing and they couldn't do it twice; they couldn't do the run of a play. It's there once because they happen to be right for it. It is a craft, but it's a craft that's no good if you're not absolutely born to it in the first place. It can't stand alone as a craft. If you haven't got an actor's own instincts, you've got nothing.
