SECTION: Section 11; Page 12; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1456 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Mixed-Use Development Plan for a Bleak Waterfront

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: PERTH AMBOY, N.J.

 BODY:
IT is not much to look at:a 50-acre slice of Perth Amboy's waterfront dotted with empty factories and polluted, rubble-strewn lots. They are the remnants of industry's exodus in the 1970's from this once-bustling port city across the Raritan Bay and Arthur Kill from Staten Island.
But that is about to change. Last month local officials completed an agreement with a developer to transform this piece of the city's past into a $600 million development, called the Landings at Harborside. It is to mix 2,000 condominium apartments and town houses with a 300-room hotel and some 170,000 square feet of retail space, including restaurants, stores and a movie theater. There will also be parks, a cultural center, a public waterfront promenade and parking for 4,200 cars. 
 The development is the first of several projects expected to get under way in the next 12 to 18 months as part of this city's redevelopment plan to reclaim large swaths of its former industrial land. It is also consistent with the plan's focus on a mix of uses, from housing to retailing and entertainment.
Harborside is to take shape in four phases on the property, parts of which must be cleaned of contaminants, with construction to start next summer. Some 42 families and 15 businesses must be relocated from the site, which is bordered mainly by High Street, Smith Street and Buckingham Avenue. The entire project will take up to eight years to complete, according to the developer, Westminster Communities, an affiliate of the Kushner Companies of Florham Park, N.J.
"We're basically building a new city at the water's edge," said Jeffrey Freireich, a principal at both Kushner and Westminster, "and believe the rewards outweigh the risks."
This month local officials also designated an operator to run a high-speed ferry service to Manhattan as well as to build a landing barge and terminal, which along with parking, will rise on nine acres adjacent to Harborside. The operator, Lighthouse Fast Ferry of West Caldwell, N.J., runs two such ferries between the Highlands in Monmouth County and Manhattan and expects to have the Perth Amboy ferry running by next summer.
While many residents feel the redevelopment plan in general and the Harborside project in particular could rejuvenate the city, they are worried about coping with increased traffic and blending the old city with the new. Some people who must relocate are also concerned about moving and finding comparable housing elsewhere in the city.
AMONG them is Bernie Parkhurst, who with her husband, Mark, both in their 30's, lives in the house she grew up in on Commerce Street, near the water. "Yes, the area needs to be improved," Ms. Parkhurst said. "But in the meantime what do we do?" Not everyone can afford the new housing, she said. And one commercial property owner is suing the city, contending its redevelopment plan is improper.
Mayor Joseph Vas said the project's benefits outnumbered the perceived negatives, which will be addressed. He said the development would not only increase the stock of middle-income housing in Perth Amboy, a city of 55,000, and bring in tax revenue and jobs but would also serve "as the engine that will drive investment in the rest of the city."
Besides the waterfront, the other areas in the city's Focus 2000 redevelopment plan are in the northeastern and southwestern sectors of Perth Amboy. In all, the plan calls for reusing 700 former industrial acres, and in the last month the city has selected developers to rebuild parcels in the other areas as well.
By early next year, for instance, Matrix Development Group of Cranbury, N.J., known for building big box warehouses, plans to begin to transform 26 acres in the city's northeast quadrant into up to a half million square feet of light industrial and manufacturing space in one to two buildings. The site, formerly occupied by Chevron, has sat dormant for many years.
Plans also call for about 68 more acres in that section to be used for an arena with 9,000 to 12,000 seats and a minor league baseball stadium with 5,000. The site, occupied by an industrial complex once used by a smelting and refinery operation, is to be redeveloped by a partnership of R.B.I. of Newark and OENJ Cherokee of Bayonne. Construction is expected to start in the next 18 to 24 months.
The mix of uses "will assure the economic vitality of the city," Mayor Vas said, adding that the projects announced so far are expected to produce 7,000 permanent jobs and more than $24 million a year in tax revenue, starting within five years. That revenue compares with about $18 million a year lost in 1970 to 1990, when industry moved out and shifted the tax burden to homeowners, he said, adding that developers are not being given tax abatements.
Perth Amboy's redevelopment effort follows those of Hudson River cities like Jersey City and Hoboken. Such efforts are bolstered by the economy, renewed interest in urban living and the state's development and redevelopment plan. The plan encourages growth in areas where highways, sewers and mass transit are available and discourages it where they are lacking.
Though the city adopted its redevelopment plan in 1997, it has been setting the stage for it over the last decade. In that time it attracted public money to revive its faltering downtown and begin to rebuild its waterfront. The latter included building a new marina and restoring a historic ferry slip.
HARBORSIDE "is the natural next step for the waterfront," Mayor Vas said.
Mr. Freireich said Westminster is involved with the project because "we believe the future trend is in urban living." Along with the state's efforts to push growth to cities, he said, Perth Amboy's pursuit of redevelopment was another factor.
Westminster will finance construction of the project privately and has already "pumped over $2 million into it," Mr. Freireich said. But his company, he added, will seek state and federal assistance to clean contaminated areas, a process he called "doable." It is also under contract to buy some parcels and is negotiating to buy others.
The Tri-State Ship Repair and Dry Dock Company, which owns 12 acres that have been used for a dry dock operation for more than a century, has contested the city's redevelopment plan. William D. Grand, the lawyer for Tri-State, said the company is one of only a few such operations in the Port of New York and therefore is an "important business to the port and region."
The company, he said, challenged the city's right to include the site in a redevelopment plan meant to improve blighted, unproductive properties.
Mr. Grand said the city had recently filed "essentially the same petition to dismiss the complaint" as one denied in March by the Superior Court of Middlesex County. He said pending the outcome of the recent petition, which is to be decided soon, his client would continue to fight.
Mayor Vas would not comment about the litigation. Mr. Freireich said he was confident a resolution can be reached because "the site is important to the redevelopment." Meanwhile, he said, his company will, if necessary, initially build around the 12 acres, even though they are part of the first phase.
Depending on whether the 12-acre parcel is out or in, that phase is to have 400 residences and 25,000 square feet of stores or 600 residences and 70,000 square feet of stores. In either case, there will also be two restaurants. Though prices for the units have not been set, Mr. Freireich said they were expected to start at $225,000 for the condominiums, averaging 1,100 square feet, and $400,000 for the town houses, averaging 2,000 square feet. He said the housing would be marketed to young professional couples and empty nesters.
To address concerns about traffic, city officials say they are pursuing plans for an extension from High Street to Route 440, which connects to the Outerbridge Crossing to Staten Island, and they are seeking $4.5 million in public money. The hope is that much of the traffic from Harborside and future projects will be directed to the new road and not clog city streets.
And to put together a relocation plan, the city has hired Abeles Phillips Preiss & Shapiro, a planning and real estate consulting firm in Manhattan. State law requires the property owners be paid a fair market price for their property as well as relocation expenses and dislocation benefits. No specific timetable has been set for the plan.
"Perth Amboy should utilize its waterfront as other waterside communities have done," said Donald E. Zupko, 53, who lives in a 100-year-old Victorian near the waterfront on Lewis Street. "It could be better for this city. Things must go on; things change."

HEADLINE: Grumman Site Getting High-Tech Incubator

BYLINE: By JOY ALTER HUBEL

DATELINE: CALVERTON

 BODY:
SINCE 1994, when the Northrop-Grumman plant assembled its last F-14 and E-2 aircraft here, the 2,900-acre naval weapons facility has been in a holding pattern. Amid a host of development proposals, ranging from a golf course to a cargo airport, Riverhead's political and business leaders have been unable to decide on a course that would best replace the jobs and tax revenue that took flight when Northrop-Grumman abandoned its aircraft facility.
But last week's announcement of a new technology incubator, along with the near-final sale of 493 acres to Burman Properties for $17 million, signals that Calverton is moving toward a new economic frontier. 
 An incubator is designed to promote business growth by offering services to new businesses that ordinarily would not be able to afford them. The Calverton project would offer below-market rent for the three to five years that companies would stay there. The businesses would have access to laboratories, conference rooms and classrooms. The State University of New York at Stony Brook would operate the incubator, and its Small Business Development Center would consult. Companies could also get academic and research support.
The 50-acre business incubator is scheduled to open by the end of next year. A town hearing will take place Nov. 8 before Stony Brook receives the final go-ahead from the town planning board to proceed with a subdivision plan. Sources, including the senator who has lobbied for the project and the executive director of a local development agency, believe the hearing is largely a formality because of wide support for the project across business, political and environmental lines.
Tentatively, the incubator is to be placed along Route 25, just east of the 25A intersection. Yet several members of the town board, who feel that a site along Route 25 is too commercially valuable to give to Stony Brook, are still lobbying for an alternative location on the property. This last-minute tussle is one example of why it has taken six years for the town of Riverhead to develop any economic momentum with the site, the largest single lot of commercial property now being sold in New York State. It had been declared surplus by the United States Navy and was turned over to the town of Riverhead in 1998 for commercial development.
"The word out there in the business community has been that there have been too many false starts," Senator Ken LaValle said. "I think now the Riverhead government and community are recognizing that the state is making an enormous investment that will jump-start development in Riverhead. It will be the first project that will come to fruition rather than 'talk talk talk.' "
The business incubator will center around aquaculture, agriculture and environmental technologies. Since 1994, Mr. LaValle, who helped secure $3 million for the incubator from New York State's Science, Technology and Academic Research program, has been lobbying for its creation as a more environmentally friendly alternative to a cargo airport that had once been proposed.
"We wanted to have industries that were compatible with the East End of Long Island, and that would add to our economy and to the resolution of some of the problems that we are facing," Mr. LaValle said.
Beach preservation technologies, fish farming, underwater development of drugs and cosmetics, crop production and distribution, and renewable energy are some industries the incubator would promote.
The $3 million in state financing would be spent on the construction of a 17,000-square-foot building for 12 to 15 tenants, according to Monique Gablenz, the executive director of the Riverhead Industrial Development Agency. Companies are qualified if they are concluding their research and development phase, and are trying to move into commercialization of their product in any of the three areas of focus.
"Very often these research companies are in an expansive phase and are trying so hard to activate research and development that they don't have the time and staffing to concentrate on business aspects," Ms. Gablenz said.
For example, a company that has been developing alternative pesticides would seek a place at the incubator once it was ready to adapt its findings for commercial use.
The incubator, Ms. Gablenz said, would provide companies with the business and research support they need to graduate into economically viable companies -- companies that would take root in Riverhead.
"The odds are they will not want to move away from support services they've developed," said Ms. Gablenz.
"These companies will also be better able to identify funding sources for the continuation of the work," Ms. Gablenz said.
There are many small business incubators on Long Island, but not all are successful. The ones that thrive have the ability to create lasting relationships among academic, financial and governmental lines of support, said Michelle Stark, a business consultant at the SUNY Stony Brook Small Business Development Center and co-author of the incubator feasibility study.
"The biggest problem that emerging technology companies face on Long Island," Ms. Stark said, "is where to go after they graduate from the incubators. After spending so much effort creating relationships in the research community, they don't want to cut the umbilical cord completely. They will want to continue to use graduate students and other support programs offered throughout the university to commercialize technology.
"And from a logistical point of view, the supplier networks and telecommunications infrastructure that has been already been built up in that geographic core should continue to be accessible," Ms. Stark said.
Government and business officials in Riverhead believe the incubator is a harbinger of great economic promise. It is hoped that successful graduates will find a home next door in the industrial park planned by Jay Burman. There, they can provide manufacturing and executive jobs that the town's retail sector cannot offer.
Ms. Gablenz is also confident that the incubator will benefit from the expertise that Stony Brook has developed in the management of its biotechnology incubator.
"The university has been extremely successful, and has enjoyed full occupancy since its doors have opened. It continues to graduate companies that have stayed in the area," Ms. Gablenz said.
SUNY Stony Brook will market the Calverton project, which will begin construction this spring, in the hope that it will be fully occupied by the time its doors open in late 2001.
By November, Mr. Burman's subdivision plan for the industrial park should be approved, according to Bob Kozakiewicz, the town supervisor of Riverhead.
The industrial park includes an 850,000-square-foot-facility, two-thirds of which can be filled immediately, given the level of interest expressed by prospective companies, said Jack O'Connor, the executive managing director for Grubb & Ellis, the commercial broker for Riverhead and the 2,900-acre parcel. The park will also include two million square feet of industrial space to be developed mostly for use by manufacturing firms, as specified in Riverhead's 1996 Land Reuse Plan.
The fate of the remaining 2,400 acres, including two airstrips, is still undecided, although most of the parcel has been rezoned for family recreation uses. Offers are pending for a golf course, a motorcycle racing venue, and a hotel conference and golf center with a private residential community attached. Nothing has been decided, Mr. O'Connor said.
"Many years ago industries thought Riverhead was the end of the world, but now that western land is saturated, Riverhead is looking like a place to be," he said.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK;
Where the Elite Meet and Really Mean Business

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
ONE evening last month, Jim McCann, chairman of 1-800-Flowers, stood near the cold seafood appetizers in a private room in Hofstra University's library, reachable only by private elevator. He greeted about 100 invited guests who nibbled on shrimp and two types of caviar before heading into the adjacent dining room.
Mr. McCann, it turns out, is more of a bon vivant than is evident from his many television appearances as spokesman for his Westbury-based company. At once oracular and avuncular, he visibly enjoyed his role as host of what he described more than once as an intimate gathering. Without notes, he chatted about the digitalization of commerce, part of a trend he called the Next Economy. He theorized about its still unknown effects on retailing. Then he introduced a series of academics from Hofstra, where he serves on the Board of Trustees, before welcoming several partners from Ernst & Young, his longtime advisers. 
 As guests prepared to tuck into dinner, Mr. McCann sang the praises of a young wine merchant from Manhattan, before introducing the young retailer to the podium. Mr. McCann beamed as the young man, Josh Weston, delivered a slightly edgy tribute to wine and the good life.
The occasion was a rehearsal for four similar gatherings to be held at locations throughout the country; the first will be in Carlsbad, Calif., next week. Another will be held on Long Island next fall. While the topics remain undetermined, the format -- genial gatherings of people Mr. McCann describes as "thought leaders and marketing geniuses" -- will be retained.
However, the programs will be limited to about 20 people, and will be restricted to executives, he said.
"The list is confidential, but I can tell you they include the chairmen and C.E.O.'s and presidents of major companies," Mr. McCann said.
To get confirmation from such a high-powered list, he said, required assuring them that the meetings would be intellectually productive.
"These are all people who have serious constraints on their time," he said. "To get them all together, you have to be able to give them access to truly innovative thinking from across the business spectrum."
In recent years, such gatherings of so-called "thought leaders" have become a feature of the business landscape, often expanded to include A-list politicians. Perhaps the granddaddy of them is the Renaissance Weekend event held every year in Hilton Head, S.C. In addition to attracting business leaders and academic innovators, the gathering also brought in an ambitious young governor, Bill Clinton, who expanded his contacts enormously -- and used those contacts as he prepared to run for President.
Held in upscale hotels, resorts, and fine restaurants temporarily closed to the public, such elite gatherings characteristically address ambitious topics in luxurious settings. For business leaders the meetings offer the opportunity to learn first-hand how their peers are handling similar problems not only in their own industry, but in others.
Long Island has lagged behind this trend. While there is no shortage of business gatherings here, few attract participants from outside the region. Few of them attract even the senior executives of local companies. Executives beg off most conferences with complaints that they are variations of Pay to Play: if you're willing to pay the lunch tab, the group will be happy to listen to you as the expert on your choice of topics. Many meetings are little more than marketing opportunities, with little discussion of trends or new technology, or anything not involved in selling a product or service.
There are signs that's changing.
This summer, an invitation-only series of business dinners was launched by the Garden City Hotel in partnership with the Long Island Business News, the Ronkonkoma-based weekly. Called the Executive Roundtable, the forum meets monthly in the masculine confines of the hotel's Grill Room, where the publisher and editor, John L. Kominicki, keeps discussion candid and focused. Each month the Roundtable takes on a new industry, and with it a new guest list.
Part of the appeal of these invitation-only forums is that they bring together people who know each other by reputation, but have never met face to face.
"These are all senior people, each a leader in their industry, yet remarkably in many cases they have never met," said the Garden City Hotel's executive vice president and general manager, Patrick Smalley, who helps plan the meetings and also participates. Mr. Smalley said the meetings attract executives who are turned off by what he called the "insular" nature of many Long Island business functions -- the same people offering familiar ideas.
"One of our purposes is to allow people to be more candid," he said. "We make it a point to let them know the meetings are confidential."
Mr. Kominicki has found that the forums allow him to meet influential executives and establish relationships with them. "I'm still a relative newcomer here," said the publisher, who arrived from a similar post in Oklahoma City in June 1998. "The meetings are a great opportunity for me to meet the players and the issues facing the Long Island market."
Executives make time for the programs, he said, in part because it's "a big treat to be there as our guests and explore the trends and issues in depth, detail and historical perspective. The debates have been very lively, especially about the future of high tech and commercial development. I find myself scribbling notes on cocktail napkins until the wee hours."
While reporters are not allowed to listen in, they do have access to the guest list, and may follow up afterward, Mr. Kominicki said. "It has been a decided plus for our editorial coverage, and we may have sold an ad or two, although that's not really what it's about."
The dinners are scheduled to end at 9 p.m. Usually about half the group stays on and continues chatting, he said. Although a bar is open, "everyone drinks tea," Mr. Smalley explained with a smile.
David Levitan, senior director for Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial real estate company with a regional office in Jericho, attended last month's real estate program expecting little in the way of intellectual stimulation, and found himself pleasantly surprised.
"I usually don't get involved in such forums, because I find very little is accomplished," he said. "But I'll come if I feel ideas will be raised and discussed."
Mr. Kominicki kept the discussion spirited and informative, Mr. Levitan said. "I was impressed. It was a wonderful evening. It was like a group of people who got together for dinner at someone's house and just started talking about the issues they care about."

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Art at Silvermine
Antonio Frasconi, an artist, printmaker and art educator, was the juror for the 23rd Annual National Print Biennial Exhibition and Competition, opening today at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan. A public reception is scheduled from 2 to 4 p.m. when admirers of the graphic arts may peruse the 112 works chosen from a field of 800 entries. The show will run through Nov. 12 and admission is free. 
 Fethi Meghelli of New Haven won the top award of $1,000, Sophie Acheson of Greens Farms and Fran Henry-Meehan of Southport were the only other state residents to receive awards. Barbara Harder of New Haven received an honorable mention. Among the Connecticut artists represented in the exhibition are Richard Brynes, Mari Gyorgyey, Ann Chernow, Paul Harvey and Mary Jo Lombardo.
Artists from New Jersey to Texas have works on view, and from nearby Westchester County Tony Woolner, Michael Arike and Louise Stern are exhibitors.
In conjunction with the show, a walk and talk through the galleries will be conducted by Anne McKeown and James Reed next Sunday at 11:30 a.m. Admission will be $5. Ms. McKeown has a Master of Fine Arts degree from Yale and teaches at UConn in Stamford. Mr. Reed, a master printer whose work has been exhibited widely, is a recipient of grants from the Rockefeller and Ford Foundations.
The center at 1037 Silvermine Road is open Tuesday through Saturday from 11 to 5 and Sunday from 1 to 5. Call (203) 966-5617 for more information.
 
World Affairs Forum
Shunji Yanai, Ambassador of Japan to the United States, will head a forum of the World Affairs Council at 6 p.m. Tuesday at Konica Business Technologies, 500 Day Road in Windsor. Before assuming his duties as Ambassador last year, Mr. Yanai was vice minister in the Japanese Foreign Ministry as a senior career diplomat.
His appearance on Tuesday is expected to include a discussion of Japan's trade relations with Korea and those between his country and the United States, as well as a general overview of the Japanese economy. A reception ending at 8 p.m. will follow his talk. For tickets at $50 call (860) 594-4100.
 
Dance Festival
The Connecticut Dance Alliance, a newly formed group of distinguished dancers, teachers, choreographers and theater directors from around the state will stage its first statewide dance festival on Friday and Saturday in New London. Brett Raphael, director of the Connecticut Ballet and Zig Zag Ballet in Stamford and president of the alliance's board of directors, noted that "the entire dance community in Connecticut is celebrating our strength and our statewide talent."
New London has played a significant role in the history of dance in the state through Connecticut College, the birthplace of the American Dance Festival. As one of the hosts of this event it will house master classes on Saturday at 9 a.m. in ballet, jazz, ethnic, hip-hop and injury prevention. Showcase performances will be presented at the college from 2 to 5 p.m.
A gala performance at the Garde Arts Center on Saturday at 7:30 p.m. will feature more than 20 Connecticut dance companies including Momix, Pilobolus, Judy Dworin Performance Ensemble, Works/Laura Glenn, Brass City Ballet, HarttSchooll/School of Dance Connecticut, Sankofa Kuumba Cultural Arts Consortium, Sonia Plumb Dance Company, and the New Haven Ballet among others. For tickets, directions or more information call (860) 439-5054.
 
British Art
The Yale Center for British Art, said to contain the the most extensive collection of British art outside the United Kingdom, will hold an open house on Saturday from 10 to 7 honoring Yale's tercentenary.
Visitors will be squired from galleries to conservation labs to the archives and authoritatively informed about the paintings, sculpture and prints, rare books, education programs, Louis Kahn -- the museum architect, and Paul Mellon, the museum's founder and benefactor. At each stop they will meet with the appropriate resident curator, conservator or archivist, and by the museum's director himself, Patrick McCaughey. A British film will be screened at 2 p.m., a scavenger hunt will be in progress and a jazz reception will end the day from 5 to 7 p.m. Call (203) 432-2800 for information.
 
Saxophone Quartet
An answer to the call of the saxophile will be heard today at 5 p.m. in Chester, when the Amherst Saxophone Quartet opens the Robbie Collomore Music Series at the Meeting House.
Together since 1978 this Buffalo-based ensemble has done yeoman service in the cause of not only popularizing an already established jazz instrument, but broadening its appeal as an exemplar of traditional and contemporary chamber music. In 1993 the group won first prize for Adventuresome Programming from Chamber Music America of Ascap.
The Meeting House, with just under 200 seats, is at the junction of Goose Hill Road and Liberty Street. Tickets are $16 for adults, $5 for students. Call (860) 526-4029 for reservations or more information.
 
Lectures About Democracy
"A Democratic Critique of the American Constitution" is the title of a a series of four lectures to be delivered by Yale's Professor Emeritus of Political Science Robert Dahl on the university campus in New Haven. Professor Dahl is the author of 21 books and over 100 articles on politics, economics, welfare, democratic theory, polygarchy and other related issues.
His talks answer questions conveyed in the titles. The first, scheduled tomorrow, asks "Why Does the American Constitution Fail to Meet Democratic Standards?" It will take place in Room 102 of the Linsly-Chittenden Building, 302 High Street. The second lecture on Thursday in Room 119 of the William L. Harkness Building on High Street is titled "Why Haven't Other Advanced Democratic Countries Adopted a Constitution Like Ours?"
The remaining two lectures will be presented in the Linsley-Chittenden Building and all four lectures will be held from 4 to 5:30 p.m.
The third, on Oct. 24, poses the question, "How Well Has the Constitution Performed?" and the final query on Oct. 26 is "Isn't Democracy More Important Than a Constitution?" The series is open to the public free of charge. Call (203) 436-4075 for more information.
 
French Artists
More than 600 works of art by 75 emerging French artists will be for sale in Westport from Friday through Monday, Oct. 23, at Ligne Roset, a French home furnishings shop at 180 Post Road East.
Varied as the subjects and techniques of the pictures may be, they are all 8 inches by 8 inches, unframed and priced at $250. A portion of the proceeds will aid in finding a cure for breast cancer. Show hours are from 10 to 6.
Call (203) 912-8595 for more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Kew Gardens, Queens;
Small-Town Feeling at a Busy Crossroads

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN

 BODY:
KEW GARDENS, Queens, is the kind of place where many pedestrians will not cross the street until the sign says "Walk" and will not feel sheepish about waiting to cross, even when there is no traffic.
Maybe this behavior reflects the fact that many of the people who live in the neighborhood do so because they want to live in a place that is decidedly not cut from the same frenetic cloth as much of the city, or maybe it is just because many of the streets are curved and hilly and a pedestrian can never seem to see far enough down the road to find out if cars are coming. 
 The neighborhood started out as a genteel garden suburb, and despite intense development pressure because of its location at the confluence of a number of highways and subway lines, a number of vigorous community associations have worked hard to keep it as close to that ideal as possible.
The area, which had been a recreation area for the residents of Richmond Hill, was first developed at the turn of the century by Albon Man, a lawyer who turned his attention to real estate development, and his son Alrick. "They believed, like the builders of Central Park did -- Olmsted and Vaux -- that if you were surrounded by green, you would be renewed," said Barry Lewis, a 30-year resident of Kew Gardens, an architectural historian and author of "Kew Gardens: Urban Village in the Big City." "Your mind, psychologically, could relax; it could kind of heal up from all the assaults of the modern day commercial existence."
The neighborhood is served by the E and the F subway lines, the Long Island Rail Road and the Grand Central, Van Wyck and Jackie Robinson (formerly the Interborough) Parkways. It is roughly halfway between John F. Kennedy and LaGuardia Airports -- and is sometimes called "Crew Gardens" because it is host to many pilots and flight attendants, who can often be found at night at the neighborhood's bars.
With such an accessible location, development pressures on the area have been high ever since the railroad came through in 1910. The Kew Gardens Civic Association, which includes owners of single-family and two-family homes, was formed in 1914. "We try to maintain the quality of life in Kew Gardens that brought us here," said Murray H. Berger, the chairman of the board of the civic association. "The private homes and a sprinkling of larger buildings have provided a good mix."
The early single-family homes, often Tudor or colonial style, still predominate in many of the neighborhood's residential lanes, where the cicadas and leaf blowers drown out the sounds of distant traffic on Metropolitan Avenue. On some of the most desirable streets, which are a short walk to the Kew Gardens L.I.R.R. station, like Grosvenor Lane, Audley Street, Abingdon Road and Park Lane South, single-family homes usually cost between $425,000 and $975,000.
In the more developed parts of the neighborhood, generally areas closer to Queens Boulevard and along Lefferts Boulevard and Metropolitan Avenue, there are a number of midrise apartment buildings. Among the most prestigious are the Shellball, Hampton Court, the Beverly House, the Curzon House and the Georgian House -- all built before World War II. The vast majority of the apartments in Kew Gardens are co-ops, real estate agents said; most rental apartment buildings in the neighborhood converted in the early 1980's to co-ops.
WITH their arched entrances between rooms, large windows, eat-in kitchens and inviting foyers, apartments in these older buildings, which contain about 70 percent of the apartments in the area, are typically about 25 percent taller than the area's postwar apartment towers.
"The problem with the postwar buildings is that they're boxier and their ceilings are lower," said Varnua Singh, the owner of Crossings Realty on Lefferts Boulevard. "Space became a premium after the 50's."
One-bedroom apartments in the Shellball, a 10-story co-op on Talbot Street, just off Lefferts Boulevard, sell for $70,000 to $79,000, Mr. Singh said, while two-bedroom apartments sell for $130,000 to $160,000.
By contrast, one-bedroom apartments in the Texas, a seven-story co-op on Austin Street built in 1956 by Sam LeFrak, have recently sold for $65,000 to $68,500, said Ken Oppenheimer of Delkap Management, the building's managing agent.
One frequent favorable comment from people looking to buy homes in the area is the neighborhood's feeling of community, said Mr. Singh, who remembers coming to the neighborhood for the first time in 1969, when Kew Gardens Road was unpaved. "Even though you're in the city, it feels like a small town," he said.
Helping to create the small-town feeling in the neighborhood around the train station is the Bliss Gourmet Cafe on Austin Street just steps from the New York-bound platform, where the owner, Wendy Brendel, serves coffee and McBliss egg sandwiches to customers, many of whom she knows by name. Her shop is busiest in the morning rush as commuters bound for Pennsylvania Station line up for coffee and doughnuts, but in the afternoon it quiets down, and Ms. Brendel manages the place by herself.
Ms. Brendel said people often ask her, why not avoid the work and sell the shop to Starbucks. "I would never do that, just on principle," she said. "I can't really imagine a Starbucks here."
Indeed, there seem to be remarkably few national chains in the neighborhood, in part reflecting its great diversity. Kew Gardens has long served as a place where new groups of immigrants come to get a foothold in the United States.
. After the Iranian revolution of 1979, there was an influx of Iranian Jews into the neighborhood. Their numbers have declined as many have moved to Nassau County and other suburban areas, realtors said.
After the 1990 collapse of the Soviet Union, people from former Soviet republics, particularly Uzbekistan and Tajikistan, arrived, and there are many people from India and Pakistan and Middle Eastern countries, including Yemen and Egypt, and from Central and South America.
On a strip of Lefferts Boulevard, which is the heart of the neighborhood, one can find Regents Row, which is a new Irish restaurant and bar; the Romashka Russian grocery store, which has Russian newspapers, Russian caviar and Russian yogurt; the Uzbekistan Cultural Center; and Coconuts, a Caribbean nightclub under construction.
Balancing these cosmopolitan influences at its center, the neighborhood also retains its rustic qualities with the help of Forest Park, which borders Kew Gardens on the southwest. "There are no cars allowed -- it's just continuous green," said Dennis Pahl, a professor of English at Long Island University, who has lived in Kew Gardens for six years and said he walks or rides his bicycle through the park to relax. "It's nice to know you can find this incredible tranquility by walking to the park or just walking down the side streets."
The biggest problem facing Kew Gardens, according to the chairwoman of the local community board, Sylvia Hack, is the construction of what she termed "architecturally insignificant houses." She mentioned a new cluster of townhouses being built on Talbot Street that are set back from the street far enough to give each townhouse a parking spot in front of the buildings. "We're getting the kind of development that turns a someplace into a no place," she said.
The neighborhood has one public elementary school, P.S. 99, a magnet school for students interested in law. It is undergoing a $4.2 million exterior renovation that should be completed in the spring of 2001, said the principal, Judith Ibrahimi. A few years ago the school, which now holds 615 children in kindergarten through sixth grade, was so crowded that kindergarteners had to be bused to P.S. 144 in Forest Hills. But after the 1993-94 school year, the Kew Gardens Improvement Association, the board of education, the school and parents worked together to build the P.S. 99 Annex just down the street from the main building. The annex now houses slightly more than 400 students in the kindergarten, first grade and second grade.
Sixty-five percent of the children at the school read at or above grade level, well above the citywide average. "We don't want anybody to be anonymous," Ms. Ibrahimi said. "We're working very hard, and we're doing that with an immigrant population."
MOST public school students from Kew Gardens go on Russell Sage Junior High School, in Forest Hills, which has an enrollment of about 1,425 students in the seventh, eighth and ninth grades. The school is one of the few in the city to offer Latin, and it is usually among the top performing 25 percent of junior high or middle schools in the city.
The designated high school for Kew Gardens is Hillcrest High School in Jamaica.
There are also four Jewish schools in Kew Gardens. Yeshiva Shaar Hatorah-Grodno, founded in 1977 and named for a yeshiva in Poland that was destroyed in World War II, serves young men of high school and college age from around the world. Yeshivat Ohr Haiim serves boys and girls from kindergarten to eighth grade. The Bais Yaakov Academy, which has an enrollment of about 800, serves girls in kindergarten to eighth grade. Tifereth Moshe, an Orthodox school on Abingdon Road, is for boys in kindergarten to eighth grade.
Though there are no Catholic schools in Kew Gardens, residents send their children to two nearby schools: Our Lady of the Cenacle School in Richmond Hill and Our Lady Queen of Martyrs School in Forest Hills. The schools serve students in prekindergarten to eighth grade and have about 325 students each.
The future of Kew Gardens depends on different things for different people. Mr. Pahl said he hoped that the New York economy would continue to thrive, encouraging more Manhattanites to move to the area, and that the Kew Gardens Cinema would flourish, encouraging more community and small business development. "I think it's a 50-50 shot that this place is going to continue to reinvigorate," he said, noting that it had already come a long way from six years ago, when many now-successful storefronts were vacant.
Though he may worry about too much development, Mr. Berger, who spent 20 years as president of the Kew Gardens Civic Association, said the neighborhood is still special to him. "It's always been a tree-blessed area -- it looks like an oasis in an otherwise tenementlike city," he said. "We're a mixed community in religion and in ethnicity, and pretty much everybody's free to do his own thing without peer pressure in the background."

"I just couldn't believe that that was really going to happen," he said. HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
A Charity Becomes a Real Estate Giant in Maine

BYLINE: By SCOTT SUTHERLAND

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me.

 BODY:
THE big question bouncing around Portland real estate circles these days is, "What building will Owen buy next?"
Owen is Owen Wells, president of the Libra Foundation, a Maine-based philanthropic organization with assets estimated between $300 million and $400 million. In the last two years, Libra has purchased four prominent buildings in downtown Portland, all of them Class A office space -- the kind found in the newest, most modern buildings. 
 Libra's latest purchase, completed on Sept. 11, is 1 Canal Plaza, a 10-story, 130,000-square-foot office building it bought from KeyCorp for $16.5 million. The deal completes Libra's acquisition of the three-building Canal Plaza complex and means the foundation now controls roughly a third of the available Class A office space in downtown Portland.
The deal is another reminder of the depths of Libra's pockets and the scope of its buying power, the likes of which Maine has never seen. "I was born here and have lived here most of my life, and I don't remember anything of this magnitude," said Jim Harnden, president of Ram Harnden Commercial Real Estate in Portland. "We've had people come through and be players in smaller ways, but something like Libra is brand new for Portland and for Maine."
Libra concentrates its considerable resources solely on Maine, which means it can have a sizable impact on the state and its 1.2 million inhabitants. In Portland, a city of 65,000 that is showing new signs of economic vigor after a long dry spell starting in the early 1990's, the foundation has already left a lasting mark. Libra has given millions of dollars to cultural institutions and social organizations in the city, and in 1998 it built a $9 million public market in a marginal neighborhood on the edge of downtown in an effort to jump-start Portland's sputtering economy.
Despite the good will created by its far-flung generosity, Libra's real estate deals have generated criticism from Portlanders who view the foundation as a financial King Kong, capable of dominating the market and reshaping the landscape of what remains essentially a small New England port town.
Even though many of Libra's projects have received heavy publicity around the state, most of it favorable, the real estate transactions in Portland have prompted some to question both its motives and long-term strategy. "Because Libra was set up for economic philanthropy, people expect it to be a little more public about what it's doing," said Mr. Harnden, who has represented other parties in deals with Libra. "At the same time, they don't owe anybody an explanation about what they're doing. It's their own money, and Portland has benefited enormously from their investment."
Libra's strategy, according to Mr. Wells, is simple. "The plan is to have sufficient income from real estate to generate about a third of the revenues we want to give away each year," he said. "We need to give away at least 5 percent of our gross assets each year, or about $15 million. Our income from real estate is about $5 million, so we're where we want to be. We don't plan on buying any more real estate in downtown Portland." Libra was founded in 1989 by the Elizabeth Noyce, former wife of Robert N. Noyce, a co-inventor of the computer chip and a founder of the Intel Corporation. After the couple's divorce in the 1970's, Mrs. Noyce relocated -- with the fortune she received in the divorce settlement, including about two million shares of Intel stock -- to the 50-acre estate in Bremen, Me., where she and her husband had summered.
She began giving away money, mostly to Maine charities, almost as soon as she settled into the house on Muscongus Bay. Mr. Wells became her lawyer, and together they brainstormed worthy causes around the state. "He is the engine," Mrs. Noyce once said of Mr. Wells. "I'm just the fuel."
Mrs. Noyce purchased four downtown buildings of her own -- which Libra inherited when she died in 1996 -- including the building that now houses Maine Bank and Trust, a bank she started in 1991. By the time of her death, at age 65, she had given away roughly $75 million.
Since its inception, Libra has given more than $19 million to a vast array of charitable and nonprofit organizations throughout Maine. Last year Libra awarded 113 grants totaling more than $6 million, with beneficiaries including a program to provide summer camp scholarships for Maine children; the local chapter of the Nature Conservancy, for the acquisition of land along the upper St. John River; and the Maine Winter Sports Center, for the creation of world-class cross country skiing and biathlon facilities in two northern Maine towns.
This summer, Libra began its most ambitious project to date: the transformation of the Pineland Center, a derelict former state mental hospital 30 minutes north of Portland, into a gleaming multi-use campus that would include office space, a conference center, social service programs, working farms, a therapeutic riding facility, networks of fitness trails and more.
REHABBING the site -- which includes renovating 22 aging buildings, constructing new buildings, installing new systems and generally sprucing up the property's overgrown grounds -- will cost at least $40 million. The list of prospective tenants is growing, said Mr. Wells, who hopes to begin leasing the site's commercial space next summer.
Mr. Wells is not afraid to use terms like "social engineering" to describe his plans for Pineland or his vision for what Libra can accomplish in Maine. Sometimes, though, that vision meets resistance. Last year, a Libra proposal to buy land and provide money toward building a new civic center in Portland backfired, in part because some local residents thought Libra was trying to impose its agenda on a neighborhood that had not asked for its help.
In other instances, the foundation's vision can be difficult to put into practice. Such is the case with the award-winning 37,000-square-foot public market, which has been criticized by city advocates as being more of an upscale destination for suburbanites than a neighborhood market and by former tenants for its steep rents and inflexibility in meeting the needs of struggling businesses.
The market, which opened two years ago, recently cut its rents, however, and it is currently at full occupancy, with tenants that include an assortment of vendors selling produce, meat, seafood, flowers, wine and baked goods. Despite these developments, Mr. Wells said Libra continued to provide heavy subsidies for the market, which is probably years from supporting itself.
Discussing the foundation's real estate investments, Mr. Wells said income from the office buildings provides a revenue cushion during dips in the value of Intel stock, Libra's primary asset. The foundation periodically sells Intel stock but tries to avoid being forced to sell during market downturns, such as occurred in September, when the stock fell from above $70 a share to about $40. "We're not going to sell the stock, because we know it's going to perform over the long term," he said. But, acknowledging the recent sharp decline, he added, "It's not for the faint of heart."
Mr. Wells stressed that Libra maintains and improves its properties and that rents are at or below market rate, about $19 per square foot a year for Class A space. Additionally, he said, Libra pays taxes on all of its properties, which will amount to nearly $1 million in 2001.
Some of the grumbling over Libra's purchases is doubtless the result of a strong local market and low vacancy rates -- 3 percent currently for Class A and 6 percent over all, down from 23 percent in the early 1990's -- which mean few buildings come up for sale. Some of it also stems from Libra's dominance in the market; Libra owns close to 500,000 square feet out of a total of roughly 1.4 million square feet of downtown's Class A commercial space.
Mr. Wells says he is sometimes mystified by Libra's critics. "The Libra Foundation represents an unprecedented opportunity for Maine," Mr. Wells said. "The fact that we can send 5,000 kids to summer camp is phenomenal. We can try new things, experiment, see if they work. I think we actually do a very good job of getting our mission out there.
"Other foundations might not get criticized the way we do, but they're just giving money away. We're activists, after all."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 8; Column 2; Westchester Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS;
A SHORTAGE OF WORKERS

BYLINE: By PETER BELLER

 BODY:
RECORD low unemployment and the booming high-tech industry are causing a labor shortage in Westchester, posing problems for employers and spurring growth in reverse-commuting from New York City.
The unemployment rate for the county was 3 percent for August, the lowest it has been since 1990, and down from 3.6 percent in August of last year. 
 In contrast, the seasonally adjusted national rate was 4.1 percent in August, while New York State's was 4.5 percent and New York City's was 5.8 percent.
"The data suggest that employers are hard pressed to attract and retain workers," said John L. Wieting, the regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "You've had a pretty good economy in Westchester, and employment expansion has been pretty steady."
Rae Rosen, a regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank in Manhattan, agreed, saying, "It's certainly tight right now."
In 1998, she said, the county had an average per capita income of $47,000, the eighth highest in the nation, adding, "Obviously, this is a highly skilled labor market." The unemployment rate, while "not an exact measurement, is indicative of a very tight labor market," she said.
Harold E. Vogt, president of the county's Chamber of Commerce, said the labor shortage "goes across the board," from highly technical jobs to entry-level and blue-collar positions. He attributed the shortage of high-tech workers to the rapid expansion of that industry and the shortage of low-wage workers on a historical lack of affordable housing in the county.
Most companies have responded to the shortage by trying to lure workers from farther afield.
Westchester employers have been recruiting from northern New Jersey, Dutchess, Orange and Rockland Counties and from Connecticut.
"The ring is expanding," Mr. Vogt said. "All you have to do is look at the Tappan Zee bridge in the morning."
Between 1980 and 1998 the number of people commuting into Westchester every day rose to 134,246 from 85,110, according to a study by the County Planning Department in March. During the same period the median price of a house rose to $363,900 from $83,700, making it harder for blue-collar workers to afford to live in the county.
Commuters currently represent one-third of the county's work force, and the study predicted an increase to 40 percent over the next two decades.
The only area from which commuting decreased was Manhattan. The most striking increase was from Queens and Brooklyn, which went from around 6,000 to just over 15,000 commuters.
Ms. Rosen of the Federal Reserve said that recent immigrants were picking up the slack in some blue-collar fields like masonry.
It has been getting harder, however, to find minimum-wage workers in the county because of the costs of housing and commuting.
"If you have a car you can make it from Queens," Ms. Rosen said. "But it's hard to make it from the inner city."
The increase in reverse commuting has been a boon for the Metro-North Railroad, which has seen the number of riders going to Westchester during the morning rush increase by 240 percent, to more than 8,000, between 1986 and 1999. While that number pales in comparison with the 72,500 who commute into the city, it represents a surge in reverse commuting, said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for the railroad.
"All over our system our ridership has been growing tremendously," Mr. Brucker said. "But the growth rate of reverse and intermediate customers has outstripped all the other growth segments."
Lawrence C. Salley, the county's transportation commissioner, said that in the Bronx, Co-Op city, in particular, was sending more people to places like Yonkers.
Like other county officials and business leaders, he said that companies were not leaving the county because of the labor shortage, and in fact many were moving in.
"The businesses are here," he said. "More businesses are coming in, and the housing is being developed as we speak."
Schools are having trouble finding staff members as well. While math and science teachers are in short supply, said Ernest J. Piermarini, an assistant superintendent for the Lakeland Central School District, "We even have a hard time getting classroom monitors, teacher aide applicants, even basic clerical workers."
He said that, while the school system has increased pay in many areas, it could not compete with the private sector. "You'll get people who come out here, and then after a couple of months they'll go to Wal-Mart and Home Depot."
The scarcity of high-tech workers is being felt across the country as companies scramble to expand.
"It's really a national issue," said Russ Izzo, president of Nextech Training Solutions, which trains computer programmers, systems engineers, and the like. "The demand in Westchester is pretty much in line" with the rest of the country.
His company recently opened an office in White Plains. He said that graduates were being grabbed by companies and entry-level salaries were more than $30,000, compared with $20,000 a year ago.
Many big retailers said they were having similar problems finding workers.
"It's been tougher this year than it's ever been," said the manager of the Wal-Mart in Mohegan Lake, who asked that his name not be used.
He said that while the store, which employs 300 people, wasn't understaffed, he would hire an extra 20 workers if he had qualified applicants.
While the K-mart in Mahopac reported having similar problems finding enough workers, McDonald's says it has not had a problem.
"We have a lot of long-term people," said Peter Samaha, who owns and operates 12 McDonald's, 10 of them in Westchester. He cited a flexible work schedule and fair pay "so when a labor crunch comes, we're usually ahead of the curve."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Juliet Litterer, Ketan Majmudar

 BODY:
Juliet Maria Litterer, the daughter of Janet Dinius Litterer and Joseph W. Litterer of Fairfield, Conn., was married Friday to Ketan Dinesh Majmudar, a son of Kala and Dinesh Majmudar of Germantown, Md. Pandit Chaitanya B. Agnihotri, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Yesterday, the Rev. Dr. David J. Rowe performed a Congregational ceremony at Greenfield Hill Church in Fairfield.

 Mrs. Majmudar, 27, works in the Latin America and Caribbean department at the World Bank in Washington, assisting in public education and videoconferencing programs. She received a master's degree in international development from American University. Her father owns ComSim Inc., a company in Fairfield that conducts customer-satisfaction surveys for high-tech companies. Her mother is ComSim's director of marketing.
Mr. Majmudar, 26, works in the Gaithersburg, Md., office of GE Capital, a finance arm of General Electric, where he is an operations manager for international consumer financial services. His mother is an assistant manager and his father is the manager at a 7-Eleven store in Germantown.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING;
When Bribery Is Lost in Translation

BYLINE: By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Good, the Bad, and Your Business" (John Wiley & Sons). His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BRIBES are tricky. Well, not the bribes themselves. Deciding what constitutes a bribe and then whether you should pay one to do business in a foreign country -- knowing full well that if you don't, a less ethical competitor might -- can be the real quandary.
Washington hasn't made it any easier. Congress passed the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in 1977, making it illegal for American companies to pay bribes to secure contracts in foreign countries. But the law leaves just enough ambiguity to allow for continued payments to grease the skids. In permitting "facilitating payments," the law recognizes that a small amount of cash might sometimes be needed to expedite what it calls "routine governmental action." 
 So, according to advice that the Justice and Commerce Departments offer on the Internet, the American government is as likely as not to look the other way if a foreign government official is slipped a few dollars to process visas or work orders; provide police protection; ensure smooth mail, phone or power service; protect perishable products; or schedule inspections.
On the other hand, the government says "routine governmental action does not include any decision by a foreign official to award new business or to continue business with a particular party." (The full text of the government's advisory on the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act can be found at http://www.usdoj.gov/ criminal/fraud/fcpa/dojdocb.htm.)
To some experts, that guidance seems perfectly clear. "You don't need a law to know when you step over the mark between a facilitating payment and a real bribe," said Frank Vogl, vice chairman of Transparency International, an organization that publishes an annual index that ranks countries from least to most corrupt, with the goal of increasing accountability.
But to others, the law merely disguises a bribe by calling it something else. "What's silent here is that facilitating payments are still illegal in that country because they're bribes," said Patrick J. Gnazzo, vice president for business practices at United Technologies in Hartford. "And there isn't a country in the world that doesn't have a law on its books that says 'you may not bribe my government officials.' "
So if the law does not provide clear guidance, how can anyone decide how to behave? In particular, what do you do if you're an executive from a country that is regularly ranked among the least corrupt (say, Finland) and you want to do business in a country that is regularly near the bottom of the list (say, Nigeria)?
The argument could be made that in notoriously corrupt countries, the best thing to do is to adopt the local cultural norms. After all, don't you owe it to your shareholders to do what needs doing and pay what needs paying to land a lucrative contract? And if you reject that idea, what victory is won for ethics if the host country simply decides instead to do business with your more evil competitor?
"I've seen successful businesses who follow the policy 'if in Rome do as the Romans do' 100 percent, and I've seen businesses who strictly adhere to their home country policies everywhere they operate," said Walter Kuemmerle, an associate professor at Harvard Business School. "Both of these types of businesses have been successful."
But Professor Kuemmerle warned that "it's generally better to stay out of corruption processes for good than to go into them just tentatively."
"If the business decides to give in once" -- assuming that it can rise above the morass later -- "that strategy is definitely not going to work," he added. "It's like a drug addiction. Once you signal that you're willing to play the game according to the local rules, it's very hard to reverse that policy."
Mr. Gnazzo counsels taking a realistic view of doing business in a corrupt nation. "Decide you're going to be patient," he said. "That means that your stuff may stay on the dock for a period of time. And you might not be able to get the product out as fast as you would like to."
Even in the countries perceived to be the most corrupt, "not everybody in that environment is corrupt," Mr. Gnazzo added. "That's a starting point."
In the 1990's, United Technologies itself came under Justice Department investigation, though the department ultimately found no violation of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and dropped the matter. The action was spurred by a civil suit in which a former employee accused a United Technologies subsidiary of dismissing him for publicizing what he said were bribes to two Saudi princes to secure a contract; that case was settled out of court in 1993.
Then, as now, the company had a strict rule against making illegal payments to obtain business.
THE author of an article in The Economist earlier this year described with satisfaction that while in the early 1990's it took bags of cash to get through customs in Nigeria, on his most recent trip he only needed to hand over a ballpoint pen.
But in the realm of corruption, such deflationary forces are rarely seen. The ante to play the bribery game is always rising. "It goes up the next time and the next time and the next time," Mr. Gnazzo said.
Or, as Professor Kuemmerle put it, "Corruption is a never-ending story."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ST. GEORGE;
Fund-Raising for a Museum Is Too Slow for Comfort

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY

 BODY:
Once a cause for celebration on Staten Island, the National Lighthouse Center and Museum may now be a cause for concern.
Since 1998, when a national steering committee selected a 10-acre former Coast Guard base next to the Staten Island Ferry terminal as the project site, the museum's board has had trouble raising money. As a result, the museum's opening has been postponed from 2001 to 2003. 
 The museum's board has raised $500,000 for operating expenses and to hire a design firm. But it has only about $100,000 toward the $5 million needed to meet the new opening date.
The site was chosen two years ago because of the "visitor potential" of the 1.5 million tourists who arrive at the nearby terminal each year and because of $5 million the city and state pledged to the project.
The city's Economic Development Corporation has been spending that money to shore up, replace two roofs and remove asbestos from several of the site's seven brick and limestone buildings. But the board is still far from the matching $5 million.
"They have until July 2002 to raise the money," said Janel Patterson of the Economic Development Corporation, "and we're confident that they'll reach their goal." Ms. Patterson did not say what might happen if the goal were not reached.
Henry Stephenson, the museum's executive director, said the corporation met with the board last spring and told it to pick up the fund-raising pace. Since then, the museum has dismissed a fund-raiser and a director of development and replaced them with new people.
Lack of money has also hampered the museum's plans to add attractions. For example, the owners of a lightship -- a vessel that carries an electric beacon as a kind of portable lighthouse -- have wanted to sell it to the museum for some time. Mr. Stephenson said he had hoped to open the lightship to the public at the site's pier during Operation Sail on this July 4. But the museum has raised only $35,000 of the $100,000 needed to acquire the ship.
Liz Aubert, a spokeswoman for Seaeye, the Massachusetts company that owns the ship, said that if there was not "significant progress" toward meeting that goal by next July, the company might offer the ship to another organization.
But there may be financial hope. Mr. Stephenson, who recently announced he would soon step down as director, said he had learned "our property seems to qualify for federal historic preservation tax credits." He said those credits might be parlayed into several million dollars, through a process that entailed setting up a partnership with private investors. "I'm very optimistic," he said. "Maybe I don't have good reason to be." JIM O'GRADY

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
A New Fight for a Rich Slice of the Insurance Pie

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
LONG ago, the Chubb Corporation figured out that wealthy people would pay a little more to insure their mansions and yachts if, when it came time to collect on a claim, they were treated royally.
So instead of following the usual practice of paying as little as possible on claims, Chubb habitually erred on the side of the customer. It did not quibble over costs for the finest workmanship when paying repair claims. Often, it paid borderline claims that it might legally have rejected. 
 Neighbors talked to neighbors, and Chubb, which is based in Warren, N.J., came to dominate coverage in this rarefied world where a family might own three or four multimillion-dollar homes, a stable of expensive cars, a yacht and maybe a helicopter or small jet, and pay annual premiums of $50,000 or more to insure it all.
The niche has proved so lucrative that it has attracted an aggressive new entrant, the American International Group, which is best known for providing high-level commercial coverage worldwide. The company, based in New York, has taken particular aim at customers with holdings of more than $5 million and has hired away more than a dozen Chubb executives. It seems bent on out-Chubbing Chubb.
However, analysts say that won't be easy. "I think A.I.G. has got a shot," said Weston Hicks of J. P. Morgan, "but Chubb has set the bar very high." Several companies have challenged Chubb, he said, and failed.
While Chubb previously offered a maximum of $10 million in liability coverage, for example, A.I.G. has upped the ante to $100 million. And while Chubb sometimes shied away from covering more exotic car models or all of a wealthy client's homes, especially those in hurricane or earthquake zones, A.I.G. plunges in. It wants all of a customer's business -- for homes, yachts, Lamborghinis, fine art and aircraft, and even coverage against kidnapping.
"We're trying to provide comprehensive insurance for wealthy families," said Ross J. Buchmueller, who left Chubb to start A.I.G.'s private-client group in July.
Chubb has responded with a number of service upgrades. It will now write liability coverage up to $50 million. And though, like most insurers, it may not want to add clients in parts of Florida and California, it is gritting its teeth and doing so rather than watch those customers take their business to A.I.G. Chubb has also begun offering aircraft and kidnapping insurance linked to homeowners' policies.
"We don't want to let the camel's head under our tent," said Richard Ort, who is in charge of Chubb's coverage on homes and other personal belongings.
Yet Mr. Ort said Chubb modified its coverage not because of new competition, but because of the growing number of personal megafortunes made during the economic boom. "All of a sudden, lots of people have homes in the Caribbean," he said.
Some brokers say Chubb was becoming a bit arrogant, rejecting some kinds of coverage on homes and cars and insisting on preventive measures that customers occasionally saw as unnecessary.
Now Chubb appears to be softening up. "Chubb seems much more responsive to our needs since A.I.G. has announced its plans," said Jim Brooks, the vice president in charge of marketing at the Amaden Gay Agencies, an insurance broker in the wealthy Hamptons area of Long Island.
CHUBB has managed to profit on its high-end coverage; the company, which is also doing well with its commercial business, is expected to earn $1.02 a share in the third quarter, versus 43 cents in the period a year earlier. It charges roughly 15 percent more than most other insurers for the same dollar amounts of home insurance -- and the difference may be even bigger on less expensive properties. It has comparatively few claims because the wealthy often take special precautions to protect belongings. Chubb also appraises property to ensure appropriate coverage.
But more important, Mr. Ort said, "when you're insuring a $5 million or $10 million property, a whole lot more money comes in the front door than if you're insuring a half-a-million-dollar property."
A.I.G. plans to capitalize on that idea, too. While Chubb insures $400,000 homes as the low end of its market, A.I.G. has aimed to start its coverage at $1 million. One incentive for A.I.G. to offer very wide coverage is that profits on insuring art collections, jewelry and liability run considerably higher than for coverage on homes alone.
So far, A.I.G. has received regulatory approval to sell coverage on homes in 17 states, including New York, but not New Jersey or Connecticut. It expects to be licensed in all states by early next year.
One of its first challenges is to persuade independent brokers -- the go-betweens with homeowners -- to take on a new company. Some brokers say they like the idea of having an alternative insurer in cases where -- for whatever reason -- Chubb may not want to provide coverage. But others say they are content with their relationship with Chubb and are not seeking a new one. And some say they are not sure how A.I.G., as a newcomer, will perform in this niche.
"I sleep well when I know my customers are going to be treated right," said Philip B. Weymouth Jr., the principal owner of Weymouth & Smith Insurance, in Wilmington, Del., which has been selling Chubb coverage for many years.
But to reach its target market of cream-of-the-crop clients, Mr. Buchmueller said, A.I.G. needs to sign up only about 250 of the thousands of independent agents.
Many brokers can provide examples of how Chubb has gone the extra mile on claims. One told of a Mercedes-Benz that was insured for $13,000; when it was totaled in an accident, Chubb adjustors calculated its value at $25,000 and paid the higher amount. Another broker recalled a client whose grounds were damaged after a heating oil tank was punctured. The insurance applied only to the house, but Chubb still paid $20,000 for the cleanup.
In Coral Gables, Fla., driving rains last year caused $75,000 in damage to a large condominium owned by Clayre and Jay Haft. "I just submitted the bills and they paid," said Mrs. Haft, a former stockbroker. "They were as cooperative as anyone could possibly hope."
But A.I.G. has a reputation in the industry as being tough on claims. "They're very good at defending liability suits," Mr. Weymouth said, meaning that the company fights hard to pay as little as possible in lawsuits against its customers.
A.I.G. contends that it pays precisely what it should on its claims. Robert M. Sandler, the senior claims executive who also oversees its homeowners coverage, said the company "is not tough on claims in the sense that we avoid paying claims we should pay."
But brokers said that following the letter of the law would not cut it if A.I.G. wanted to take business away from Chubb.
"A.I.G. is going to have to take on the same attitude in adjusting claims as exists at Chubb," said David Rubin, the owner of the Rubin Group in Manhattan, which provides commercial and personal coverage to clients across the country.
A.I.G. plans to do just that -- and more. "Our claims handling," Mr. Buchmueller said, "is going to make us stand out above and beyond anything that's been done to date."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Big Banks May Not Be Better Online

BYLINE: By PAUL SWEENEY

 BODY:
FRUSTRATED by the meager checking account deals offered by their local banks, consumers may turn to the Internet, thinking that they can do better. After all, that is where they have found competitive deals on cars, books and even, until lately, groceries.
But attractive offers are harder to find in the online banking world, especially when it comes to checking accounts offered by major banks. Many of those institutions offer customers the same rates and fees on their Web sites as they do at their neighborhood branches. Moreover, the most attractive rates and fees are sometimes determined by the customer's ZIP code, both for technical and competitive reasons. That was what Bankrate.com found in its semiannual survey of the 10 largest financial institutions in the country's 35 major markets. (The checking account pricing survey is at www.bankrate.com.) 
 "We noticed that accounts obtained on the Internet are the same ones you'd get walking into a brick-and-mortar bank," said Greg McBride, a financial analyst at Bankrate.com, a company in West Palm Beach, Fla., that tracks the financial services industry.
Bankrate.com also said that many big banks with operations spread across several regions practiced "geographic discrimination," in which deals vary greatly by state. (Consumers who visit the banks' Web sites are often asked to disclose their ZIP codes before any information is dispensed.)
Mr. McBride said Wells Fargo's Stagecoach Interest Checking Account charges customers in Seattle, online or off line, a $13 monthly service fee, unless they keep a minimum balance of $100; the bounced-check fee is $28. In San Francisco, he said, the service fee is $10, the minimum balance is $2,000, and the bounced-check fee is $15.
Bank of America customers in California get a better deal on its interest-bearing checking account than those in Florida. In California, accounts below the minimum balance carry a $12 monthly fee and pay 0.4 percent interest; in Florida, Mr. McBride said, there is a $14 monthly fee and 0.25 percent rate.
STEPHEN BROBECK, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, a consumer group based in Washington, said banks should give customers better, more consistent deals.
"There is no question that Internet banking should be less costly for consumers," he said. "Internet banking should also be systemwide, not local, and therefore benefit from economies of scale and lower costs."
For their part, major banks acknowledge the disparities in their practices. Some bank officials blame the continuing mergers and acquisitions within the industry, which often result in fragmented operations.
Thomas A. Kelly, a spokesman for Bank One, which is based in Chicago and whose branches span Texas, Louisiana, Arizona and the Midwest, said the bank's regional computer systems were largely incompatible with one another. He said he expected to see the problem rectified -- and fee and rate schedules integrated -- over the next three years. Eloise Q. Hale, a Bank of America spokeswoman, said her bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., was doing the same. "Everything is being unified to increase consistency," she said.
Even so, that will not necessarily translate into lower costs. "The banks' fixed costs aren't going away," said Theodore J. Iacobuzio, a senior analyst at the TowerGroup, a research firm based in Needham, Mass.
Bankrate.com recommends that consumers looking for the best deals consider "pure" Internet banks. Many of those banks, including nBank, First Internet Bank of Indiana, and directbanking.com, offer free, interest-bearing checking accounts, electronic bill payment, and rebates of other banks' A.T.M. fees, according to Gomez Advisors, an Internet consulting firm that rates Web-based consumer services.
Christopher E. Musto, a vice president for research at Gomez, said consumers had another option. Many major banks waive fees for consumers willing to do business electronically, using the telephone, A.T.M. or Internet.
Of course, Internet banking is still not for everyone; some people prefer talking to real tellers, or they are reluctant to break old habits. "You may prefer to walk into a Wells Fargo branch because it's in the lobby of your office building," Mr. Musto said.
